para.tab:
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa)
took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, will be absent from Question Time today. Senator Tate is delivering the keynote address to the Attorney-General's Department conference in Perth on counter-terrorism. Questions relating to the Attorney-General's portfolio should be directed to Senator Bolkus; questions on immigration should be addressed to Senator Ray; and questions on health and veterans' affairs should be addressed to Senator Cook.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

para.tab: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate or to provide for the consideration of any other matter.

speech.para: Mr President, we are forced to take this action today to try to avoid the debacle of last week when Question Time was so abused that, in fact, it ceased to be Question Time at all. It was so abused because the Government was not prepared to face up to its responsibility—

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I indicate that we would rather get on to debating the motion than debate whether we ought to debate it. If Senator Hill wants to move that the Standing Orders be suspended to allow him to move the other motion, we will support the suspension and then we will debate the motion itself.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.
That a motion to provide for a time limit on questions and answers during Question Time this week may be moved forthwith and have precedence over all other business until determined.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I seek some clarification. We will also accept that motion because we want to get to the substance of the debate. However, I notice that it is a rather open ended motion; is there some indication of intent with regard to the time we are going to spend debating this motion and the time each individual is going to take in speaking to it?

—in reply—We do not want to spend time debating the motion; we want it carried so that the Government can be disciplined in the answering of questions. Last week questions were not answered; Question Time was simply turned into a one-sided debate and we are not prepared to tolerate that.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That during Question Time this week:

speech.para: (a) the asking of each question not exceed one minute and the answering of each question not exceed two minutes;—

talk.start.para: —What!
—Two minutes. It will be a real test for Senator Collins, I would think. The motion continues:

speech.para: (b) the asking of each supplementary question not exceed one minute and the answering of each supplementary question not exceed two minutes; and
(c) the time taken to determine the suspension of standing orders and this motion not be regarded as part of the time for questions today.

talk.start.para: —Does it start tomorrow?

—No, it starts today, It will be good discipline for the Minister to start today. As is provided in the Standing Orders, Question Time is the time when Ministers answer questions as to the administration of their departments. That has been so abused in recent times that it has ceased to have that effect at all. As you know, Mr President, on one day last week the Opposition in an hour of Question Time received three questions; and on the following day, four questions. That is not at all how the process was designed to operate. It was suggested for a while that perhaps interjections were at least part of the cause of that slow progress.

para.tab: As you recall, Mr President, we managed to restrain colleagues, despite the provocation last Thursday, from making interjections, and the problem still continued. It is therefore obvious that Question Time, as it was intended to operate, is not going to be permitted to operate because these Ministers are going to abuse their responsibility. In particular, the worst culprit last week was Senator Button, who sought to turn each Question Time into a one-sided debate on the car industry and then had the nerve to say to us across the chamber, `We are happy to debate this at any time'.

That was not so at all. He simply sought to put down his case without the Opposition having any opportunity, because of the structure of Question Time, to answer. That is not the time for debate; the time for debate is after Question Time, and we are happy to take Senator Button on in that debate any time he likes. But in Question Time, which is our right to be able to question Ministers on their administration, we want that right.

Question Time is part of the Westminster system. It is respected in most chambers of this kind. Everybody knows it is not respected in the House of Representatives. It is totally abused in the House of Representatives. It becomes a farce in the House of Representatives and, sadly, in recent times this Government in this place has sought to do the same thing in the Senate. It was once never the case.

There was a time, even in the years that I have been here, when questions were asked in this place and Ministers sought to answer them rather than lecture the Senate or give speeches on their policies or, as in recent times, generally abuse those on the other side of the chamber. As I said, it need not operate that way. A motion such as this need not be carried if Ministers were prepared to meet their responsibility. They are not prepared to meet that responsibility and, therefore, it is time that the Senate took control of the matter.

talk.start.para: —That would make the Senate more irrelevant than it currently is.

—It is time that the Senate took control of the matter, particularly for people such as Senator Collins, in order to get answers to questions rather than the tirade of abuse that we have to put up with each day. I have therefore moved this motion which, if it is carried, will be a reform to this Senate that will result in a better Senate and a better accountability of Ministers for their administration.

—We will support this motion, recognising that it is being imposed for only one week. It would be a very chastening experience indeed for many of the Government Ministers to strip their answers down to two minutes. I am quite sure that most answers could be given in that time.

para.tab: However, I also have a word for the Opposition. We have seen many points of order being taken, perhaps not in the latter part of the week, as Senator Hill pointed out, but certainly in the early part of the week. We would therefore move an amendment that the time taken to make and determine points of order not be regarded as part of the time for questions or answers. So, in the giving of a two-minute answer, the relevant Minister would have at least a full two minutes to give that answer. We look to both the Government and the Opposition to support that amendment. That will allow three minutes for each question and three minutes for supplementary questions and, with six minutes, we might be able to get through 10 questions in the hour, which surely is enough. Without extending this debate any further, we simply indicate that we support the motion but with an amendment relating to points of order. I move:
At the end of motion add: "; (d) the time taken to make and determine points of order not be regarded as part of the time for questions or answers.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —This motion comes as something of a surprise to us. We were not extended the usual courtesies in respect of a motion of this kind, but that is nothing unusual. I must make the point that if those opposite relapse into their habit of asking each other questions, they will have grave difficulty.

para.tab: Senator Hill took five minutes to make a very simple point. Question Time is about eliciting information, and if those opposite seriously want information in this place rather than this sort of stunt, which will reduce Question Time to a set of staccato exchanges, then I think they should stick with what they have got. As has already been pointed out, it will be very interesting to see whether some of the questions are comprehensible if they have to be confined to one minute.

Over the last week or so, Question Time has been punctuated by points of order and noisy interjections—the same old stuff because the Opposition cannot stand the heat in the kitchen. That is what it has been all about. Indeed, on one occasion we recognised that questions had been long and that answers were long, so we extended Question Time for 25 minutes. That was the Government's initiative, not the initiative of anyone in the Opposition.
I think the Government should support the Democrat amendment to this motion because I will be interested to see how the Clerks or the President are able to administer it.

Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Here we have an Opposition saying that time is wasted at Question Time; yet there have been six or eight interjections in the course of my brief remarks on this matter.

para.tab: We will oppose this motion. We think it is silly. Question Time should be about seeking and obtaining information. If those in the Opposition were interested in genuine information rather than running away from a bit of heat, they would not be moving this motion.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion and I compliment the Opposition on the phrasing of the motion. I informed the Opposition that I was about to put that motion during the time allotted for notices of motion, so I can scarcely disagree with it. However, I regret that it needed to be introduced by a contingency motion rather than being debated at the proper time.

para.tab: I also agree with and support the Democrats' amendment because I feel that the kind of grandstanding that takes place in Question Time is part of the deterioration of the process. Many people here need to take responsibility for that, apart from the President, and it particularly marginalises me and the people in this part of the chamber.

I support the motion because I believe that a trial period would be a very sensible way to pursue this procedural change. It may appear to be too great a restraint on individual questioners and answerers, particularly in the light of their form; however, the optimum number of 20 questions to be asked and answered in each Question Time would be achieved by this motion and the timing that has been stated.

The purpose of the motion I was planning to propose is to endeavour to discipline ourselves so that we can return to the true function of Question Time, which is to question Government decisions on urgent issues and not to grandstand.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

question.block.title: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the leak of eight confidential DFAT cables from Jakarta on or about 4 June 1991. We understand that the source of the leaks was soon discovered. Who leaked the documents; was the Minister briefed on the matter and, if so, when; and what disciplinary action was taken?

—My answer to this question was always going to be short, Mr President; so I do not do it in deference to Senator Hill's recent motion. So far as we can ascertain, there was no leak from any Australian source of those documents. I was briefed to that effect at the time. I am not in a position to say anything more on the public record about this subject, but I am prepared to give a confidential briefing to Senator Hill, as Leader of the Opposition and shadow spokesman in this area, and also to the chairman of the relevant Senate committee where this matter was first raised.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, and it is only in part about Geelong. In view of public debate on the future of the car industry, can the Minister outline the basis on which the Government decided policy on the passenger motor vehicle industry?

—I can say that the Government decided its policy for the industry on the basis of an Industry Commission report which recommended a 15 per cent tariff at the year 2000 and the continuation of export facilitation. The Government accepted that report. The Opposition does not accept that report, and the cynical use of organisations such as the Industry Commission seems to be reflected in the Opposition's view of the electorate and concerned groups in the community about this issue.
—So you agree with them on the sugar industry, too?

—I agree with what Mr Sinclair said at the weekend, not only about the sugar industry but about the automotive industry and the sugar industry. As he put it, maybe the defect in Fightback was not that it was wrong but that it just had not been sold and could not be sold. That is a problem.

para.tab: Of course, there is a reluctance in the Opposition to listen to the views of any industries or concerned groups about these matters. Bertol Brecht once said in the time of the Weimar Republic that the Government has lost confidence in the people and will dismiss the people. The Opposition's attitude on this is quite clear: the Government has lost confidence in the people and will dismiss the people in so far as their views are concerned, under this policy enunciated by Dr Hewson.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister explain the links between car industry policy and the Government's general approach to industry policy and tariffs? In particular, can the Minister explain why the Government has rejected an industry policy based solely on the reduction of tariffs?

—This supplementary question is, of course, very important. The Government has had a phased approach to the reduction of tariffs across industry. In all sorts of industries, in order for the adjustment process to be made, we have put in place funds for the restructuring of industry and a range of measures of general application, such as tax incentives for R&D, improved depreciation allowances, the provision of the National Industry Extension Service, the national product development program and things of this kind, which have all been beneficial to industry in making the adjustment process.

para.tab: These things are dismissed by the Opposition by references to `so-called' industry policy. Of course, industry is driven more and more by technology and innovation. It is not driven exclusively by price related factors. It is not driven exclusively by cost factors. These things are of fundamental importance, but—

talk.start.para: —I would have thought so.

—They are of fundamental importance, but the thing which drives contemporary manufacturing industry is its capacity to innovate and develop new ideas and so on, which is not price related. Senator Aulich is right: there is a whole range of issues relating to innovation in manufacturing and service industries which are not price related factors, but which are very important in the development of viable industries for the future.

question.block.title: United States Policy in the Pacific

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What did the Prime Minister mean in saying that US policy in the Pacific was `largely the policy of the US Navy'? Is this correct? Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister's narrow accusation? Why is the Prime Minister so intent on attacking our friends and allies?

—I have heard about pots and kettles, but it is not matter of shooting yourself in the foot, as Senator Teague's question suggests; it is a matter of taking aim first. The story that Prime Minister Keating has attacked the United States in relation to any matter of security policy is a total misreading of the Prime Minister's remarks which, as I recall, were made some time ago in the context of a general discussion about security developments in the region. It has been the case—
—Last Friday.

—He said it last Friday when I was away. He has also said it on earlier occasions, because I have heard him publicly. The Prime Minister has made the point that, in the past, United States policy in the Pacific has been in the context of the Cold War and the approach taken to combating the military presence of the Soviet Union—an approach which emphasised naval power and bilateral alliance relationships, and an approach which has not given particular weight to multilateral defence arrangements or cooperative strategies.

para.tab:
It is the case that, as a rethinking of positions takes place in the aftermath of the Cold War and as a dramatic change occurs in the character of the security environment in the region, quite a lot of thinking is going on, not least in the United States itself, as demonstrated, among other things, by former Secretary of State Baker's long piece in the journal
Foreign Affairs
recently, which addressed the whole question of multilateralism in the context of Asia-Pacific defence and security arrangements. Anything the Prime Minister said along the lines that Senator Teague has pointed out is, no doubt, entirely accurate as an historical characterisation. To that extent, it is something which the United States is now addressing.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has not answered the question. He has given various excuses for the Prime Minister's foolish statement last Friday. I again ask the Minister what I asked at the beginning: is it correct that, as the Prime Minister said, the US policy in the Pacific was `largely the policy of the US Navy'?
—I have nothing further to add to my previous answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Government verify reports that a unit of the PNG Defence Force conducted a raid on a Solomon Islands village close to the border, killing two people? What is the Australian Government's reaction? Was any equipment that was provided by Australia utilised by the PNG Defence Force in the raid?

—I am asking our High Commissions in Honiara and Port Moresby to seek further details of this unhappy affair. At the moment, they have not been able to elicit more details than have been contained in the public reports of this; so let me give a reaction at this stage simply on the basis of those public reports, which do seem, at least in essence, to be well founded.

para.tab: Certainly, the Australian Government is very concerned by the reports of the killing and wounding of Solomon Islands citizens during a raid by a PNGDF unit on a trades store at Kamalea in the western Solomon Islands, which appears to have taken place on 12 September. The Papua New Guinea Prime Minister, Mr Wingti—who, since his elevation, has been very concerned to improve Papua New Guinea's relations with the Solomon Islands—has been reported by news services to have been shocked by accounts of the raid and to have called for a full report from military commanders. I understand that the Papua New Guinea Government's statement is expected later today.

Assuming that the raid took place without any endorsement by the Papua New Guinea Government, this does, of course, underline the crucial importance of effective civilian control of security forces. This is a point that I made to Papua New Guinea Ministers during my recent visit. It has been made by Senator Ray and other Australian Ministers. It is one that we hope will be taken seriously.

If the reports are correct, the killing of innocent civilians during a cross-border incursion is a very grave development. There have been recent improvements in relations between the two countries. We certainly hope that this reported very tragic incident will encourage the PNG Government to accept the Solomon Islands' request for early border talks.

We are naturally concerned from a regional security perspective about any worsening of relations between two such significant regional neighbours. The border is a particularly sensitive issue between them; it has been for some time. It is crucial that each nation makes a deliberate effort to take account of each other's concern.
Finally, Mr President—if I have time—we do not yet have confirmed details of equipment used on the raid.

talk.start.para: —Order!
—My time is up; I will sit down.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to recent suggestions that Australia should join NAFTA, to the Minister's own suggestion that APEC should be developed into a free trade community with Australia's participation, and to the Government's and Opposition's single-minded preoccupation with tariff cutting. Does the Minister agree that some nations which compete with Australia do not possess adequate wage levels, work safety standards and environmental safeguards? Secondly, how does the Minister propose to protect these standards, which are part of Australia's quality of life, unless Australian industries and workers are protected by tariffs or quotas to ensure that we are not dragged down to the lowest common denominator?

—The first point I would make, I guess, is that any economist worth his salt, whether wet, dry or damp, would accept the point that standard of living and workers' conditions are not best guaranteed over time by trying to erect high tariff barriers around domestic industry but rather by a nation trading competitively on the basis of its comparative advantage and ensuring that, as a result, nations do get the benefit of that open trading environment and that that flows through into the cost of purchasing particular consumer goods. That is, of course, why it is that this Government has generally favoured a significant reduction over time in tariffs and a freeing up of the Australian trade environment, including in our own region but extending beyond that to the rest of the world. The difference between us and the Opposition, of course, is the manic zeal with which the Opposition is pursuing its position to absurd and intolerable limits so far as at least two major industries are concerned.

para.tab: The second point I would make is that, in the specific context of the Asian-Pacific regional area, I think Senator Spindler understated in his question the extent to which there is already occurring a significant convergence of wage and other standards in the major trading economies in this region. That is a phenomenon that seems likely to continue at a fairly rapid pace in the years ahead. It is a phenomenon that can be expected to be encouraged by the operation of APEC and Australia's general commitment to open trading arrangements within the region.

I have just returned from a conference of the APEC countries at ministerial level in Bangkok last week at which very significant steps forward were taken in the areas of human resource development, harmonisation of standards and a whole variety of other areas which again, Mr President, are obviously too long to list for Senator Spindler here.

talk.start.para: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. We would agree that over time it would be desirable to reduce tariffs and quotas. But in view of his concern that these standards should be preserved, does he agree that in the process of reducing tariffs we should adjust our time scale for reductions so that we are not in danger of reducing those standards or, for that matter, getting rid of the industries concerned?
—That is not a position the Government has taken.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister any plans to introduce legislation forcing all employees out of the award system, along the lines of the Victorian Opposition's industrial relations policy?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —No, we do not have any plans to deceive Australian workers, as the Opposition in Victoria is proposing to do. Its policy is a low wage policy, a policy to drive down wages in Victoria and drive down working conditions in that State. The fact that it is lauded by Mr Howard and Dr Hewson only serves to indicate that it is a prototype for Federal industrial relations policy—a policy espoused by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, in an infamous address in Auckland this year as a big bang which will blow the winds of change through industrial relations in Australia. What a joke! Ever since the big bang policy has been proclaimed, Australian business has come out and said with one voice that this policy of the big bang would be counterproductive; it would destroy the very positive gains made at workplace bargaining level in Australia, and would create a counterproductive backlash that would set this economy back quite a long way.

para.tab: To go to the heart of the Victorian Opposition's industrial relations policy, one only needs to quote the foot-in-the-mouth Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, Jeff Kennett. Speaking in a Melbourne radio interview recently on 3AW, he told the interviewer, Neil Mitchell:

answer.para: Ultimately with the minimum wage, with any wage, you could walk in here today and Mr Bell (3AW station manager) would offer you a contract and you'll say, `Mr Bell, I'm sorry, I'm not prepared to take that' and he'll say, `That's fine, Mr Mitchell, off you go, I'll get another broadcaster.

The advertisements being run in Victoria by the ALP depict accurately the sort of exploitation that the Opposition's industrial relations policy would introduce into that State if it were allowed to function without access to the Industrial Relations Commission as an umpire.

talk.start.para: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister advise what effect such a proposal would have on workers?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —There are two key features of the Victorian Opposition's industrial relations policy which need to be identified. The first key feature is that all workers and employers in Victoria are put outside of the industrial relations system immediately—that is the immediate effect—and, while their awards continue, they have no recourse to the industrial relations system or the arbitrator unless one or the other of them agrees. So, if we have a dominant union able to screw an employer, it is unlikely to agree; if we have a dominant employer able to screw a worker, as is the case given the level of unemployment in Victoria, there is no access to the umpire for fair play at all. In other words, the screwee has access to the umpire only if the screwer agrees to it. That is the first principle of the Victorian Opposition's so-called industrial relations policy. The second element—

para.tab:
Opposition senators
—Ha, ha!

talk.start.para: —I know it is a laugh; it is a joke and it is the law of the jungle—and we will have no part of it. The second part of it relates to the role of the civil courts. We go back one century in industrial relations in Australia to take industrial relations through the civil courts—courts that are already clogged by litigants so we do not get a place in the queue; courts not equipped to deal with industrial relations; courts that provide justice for those who can afford it. Therefore, where court actions are beyond the capacity of individual workers litigating against a company, then those workers do not even have the rudimentary access to justice that would be applied even through the civil courts. This is a recipe for a big payout to lawyers. It is not a recipe for doing anything about improving industrial relations and, as I said, it is a return to the last century when, in the fight for the laws of combination, unions and I think Australia won a significant victory.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the Minister's latest musings that APEC should become a new European Community, an idea which Japan regards as somewhat quaint, as do we, and I refer also to his reported belief that this is possible because there is a cultural convergence in Asia. Would the Minister explain how he sustains this argument, given that almost everyone else has seen that the lack of cultural convergence together with the great diversity in the economies and political systems constitute obstacles to closer regional links; and is the notion that APEC should evolve into a regional trading bloc along the lines of the European Community the Minister's or is it in fact Government policy?

—I spoke last week of a convergence of commercial culture in the Asia-Pacific region in the way that business was done. I cannot be blamed for what some particular reporter says—if indeed there has been reporting of that kind and it is not just Senator Bishop putting her usual ignorant or malicious spin on the report that she has seen. What I spoke of was a convergence of commercial culture, and that is an analysis that I stand behind. Business is being done in a remarkably similar way all around the region, by a whole heap of countries, including, for example, the People's Republic of China with which one never previously associated any such concept. That is making for a trading environment in the Asia-Pacific region which lends itself increasingly to the kind of cooperation, harmonisation and eventually free trade arrangements that have been the case in Europe.

para.tab: Nobody pretends for a moment that there is any similar convergence of the political cultures of the region or that it is remotely likely in any kind of timeframe that we will get the attempts being made, and partially succeeding as they have in Europe to date, to develop a degree of political coherence and common outlook, although even those attempts are being demonstrably shown by the Maastricht process to be possibly premature. The point is that, in a purely economic context, already the degree of cooperation, harmonisation and liberalisation within the Asia-Pacific region is significantly ahead of that which existed, as I understand it, in the European Community in the early 1950s when the concept of a European Economic Community first took hold.

The context of these particular remarks was in response to a question about what it is that an eminent persons group set up in order to think about the longer term future of the APEC region might come up with. I indicated that one of the things that might reasonably be on their inquiry agenda was some concept of the evolution of the APEC region in a way that has been the case in Europe.

talk.start.para: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Leaving aside the Minister's gratuitous schoolboy insults, I wonder whether he would address himself to the other part of the question, which is: is the notion that APEC should evolve into a regional trading bloc the Minister's own, or is it official Government policy? We are all interested to know.

—It has never been the concept of anyone—me, the Government or any of the other participating nations—that APEC evolve into a trading bloc, if the word `bloc' is being used in the sense in which it is usually used; that is, to describe a group of countries building walls around themselves, both defensive and offensive, in relation to other similar economic groupings elsewhere. It is perfectly reasonable to think in terms of APEC evolving over time as a single large free trade area as a result of the development over time—quite a long time one would imagine—of subregional free trade groupings which are gradually extended with the benefits of liberalisation extending as a result. That is exactly the point that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, made last week in responding as he did to the thoughts expressed in very general terms on this subject by President Bush.

para.tab: In that sense, we are all, right around the Pacific, thinking essentially the same thoughts. It is the Opposition that is having difficulty in coming to grips with the sorts of notions that are involved here. It is the Opposition that cannot begin to see the competing realities of these different kinds of concepts. It is the Opposition that cannot understand, in particular, how it is that Australia would have very great difficulty indeed in benefiting from any specific free trade arrangement with the United States or the NAFTA countries, given the extent to which we already have free access for a whole range of goods, subject to some important exceptions in agricultural areas where there is a degree of managed trade which is highly unlikely ever to be alleviated by the particular domestic lobbies concerned, as Canada has found to its cost in the course of its negotiation of NAFTA. But these issues are obviously too complex for Senator Bishop to deal with. I understand that, and I will cut my answer off at that point.

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories aware that a minority of drivers in the Kellogg's Variety Club Bash 1992 breached entry conditions to Uluru National Park at the weekend which had been agreed between the bash organisers, the Aboriginal traditional owners of Uluru National Park and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service? Can the Minister advise whether any action is to be taken as a result?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I note reports that Prince Sihanouk, at the request of China, has withdrawn support for the proposal to proceed to Cambodian elections excluding the Khmer Rouge. How is this consistent with the Minister's statements that China's withdrawal of support from the Khmer Rouge is the most positive achievement towards peace? Where does the peace process go from here?

—That is not my understanding of Prince Sihanouk's position, as conveyed to me personally as recently as 10 days ago in Jakarta and as reported from Phnom Penh as recently as this morning. Reports do have to be looked at very carefully before being taken at face value. I would be surprised if at this stage Prince Sihanouk were to be reversing what has been a strongly expressed view of his—repeated to my knowledge as recently as two or three days ago to a meeting of the Supreme National Council in Phnom Penh—that the elections organised by the United Nations should proceed without the Khmer Rouge if the Khmer Rouge maintains its policy of non-cooperation. He made the point at the same time—I think it is a point certainly worth making—that the door should always be kept open to those not cooperating because it is only probably or possibly in that way that a viable long term settlement can really be put together.

para.tab: If China has played any role in this, I would need to seek confirmation of that. The point I have constantly made about China is not any political contribution it might be making to reduce the differences between the different parties; rather, the crucial thing about China's position is that it has withdrawn military support from the Khmer Rouge. I have absolutely no reason whatsoever to believe that that withdrawal of military support has been in any way changed in recent times or at any time since the settlement plan has been put into place. That is based on conversations that I have had as recently as a couple of days ago with the Chinese Foreign Minister as well as with confirmatory reporting from many other sources. The settlement process is a long and difficult one, but there is no reason to believe that at the moment it has broken down as to any of its fundamentals.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Is the Government planning to fund its proposed housing affordability benchmark for renters with taxes on the family home?
—The short answer to that question is no. For a longer answer, I will have to go to the Minister for Social Security and provide further information for Senator Crowley.

—My question is addressed to Senator Button in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minster's investment in a piggery company which is a joint venture with a Danish company, Danpork Australia. I ask the Minister whether he still stands by his answer given on 19 June 1992 that there were no prime ministerial or ministerial discussions on the issue of the importation of live pigs from Denmark.

—My recollection of the matter is that, as I have told the Senate on a previous occasion, the Prime Minister at one stage did have discussions with the head of the Danish Pig Corporation, or whatever it is called. I think that was mentioned on a previous occasion. I do not know what was discussed, but I do not see any reason to change the answer I gave on the last occasion.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Minister aware of correspondence from AQIS dated 3 June which states that live pig imports `re-emerged as an issue at Prime Ministerial level in the context of proposals for a joint venture' and refers to recent Minister to Minister discussions? Is he aware of a letter from AQIS dated 21 July 1992, after my question to the Minister and after a freedom of information application had been made, which seeks to correct the letter of 3 June and states that there were no prime ministerial discussions according to AQIS records, but does not refute the reference to Minister to Minister discussions? Can the Minister explain that letter? I ask the Minister whether it was the case that there were recent Minister to Minister discussions as referred to in the letter and, if so, who the Ministers involved were. I also ask the Minister when these discussions took place. I seek leave to table the documents.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I have said on a previous occasion that there were no Minister to Minister discussions involving the Prime Minister. If I might say so, Senator Boswell is a little confused, because that was the substance of the document. At the time the first AQIS memorandum from which the honourable senator quoted was written, there had been questions in the Senate about the issue, but that does not alter the facts. I will look at the documents that the honourable senator has referred to me and try to provide him with a more detailed answer which I guess will very much repeat the last one.

—My question is also to Senator Button, representing the Treasurer, and it concerns job creation at the local government level. I have been told by councillors from two different councils in Queensland that local government grants for job creation announced in the Budget have been made with no guidelines attached. I ask the Minister whether that is true. I have also been told that some councils intend to use the money for existing programs and some intend to use it for the typical pork-barrelling exercise. I ask the Minister: is the Government concerned that few real jobs will be created if this is the attitude of local government to this important and welcome grant?

—I am quite unfamiliar with the allegations in relation to two local councils in Queensland, but I will certainly make some inquiries about that and see whether we can find out whether grants were made without appropriate guidelines. On the more general question, at the national level, I think the local government organisations were fully cooperative and very diligent about the approach that their organisations should take to these programs, which were both to improve the infrastructure of local government and also job creating. The local government authorities at that level were, I think, very concerned that there should be appropriate guidelines which should be appropriately administered. I will seek information on the two particular matters.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I simply ask the Minister for a general clarification of whether there were guidelines. In giving that clarification, could he please advise me as to how the Government intends to monitor what this money is spent on.
—I do not have much to add except to say that there are guidelines.

question.speaker: O'Chee Sen W.G.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Cook. I refer the Minister to a letter written by AQIS to the Pig Improvement Co. on 13 February 1991 which stated:

question.para: Importation of pigs from Denmark has been given a high priority because of Denmark's excellent disease status and strong interest from industry and the States.

However, given that the United Kingdom refuses to accept live pigs from Denmark because of the disease risk, and given that the Pig Improvement Co., the Australian Pig Producers Federation, the New South Wales Farmers Federation, the West Australian Pig Producers Association and others all oppose these live pig imports, I ask where the strong industry support for this proposal was. Is it correct that just about all of the industry support came from Brown and Hatton, a company that not only had strong links to the Danes, but also was closely linked to Mr Keating?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —I will put that question on notice.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question.
—How can you have a supplementary when it is put on notice?

—In that case, I seek, as a supplementary question, that the Minister find out when this became a priority issue for AQIS and who directed AQIS to write the letter. I seek leave to table the letters in question.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I must point out that supplementary questions are usually used to elucidate further information from the Minister's answer.

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —While I will put most of the supplementary question on notice, under the new rules, I will say that I resent and reject the criticism of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service which is inherent in that supplementary question. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is a body independent of government, made up of veterinary scientists qualified to make proper judgments. It is not a non-tariff barrier; it is a transparent, scientific organisation in a position to make proper adjustments. I do not know why we feel a lack of patriotism towards our own institutions and attack them because some foreign institution has a different point of view.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. The answer to question on notice No. 708 revealed that $800,000 had been, or will be, paid jointly to the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Worldwide Fund for Nature for the ecologically sustainable development process. Now that the ACF has pulled out of that process, what steps will be taken to recover some or all of the money apparently obtained by false pretences?
—I have no information on that subject and I will refer the question to the Minister.

question.speaker: Vanstone Sen A.E.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to his Government's confident assertion in relation to savings, made through Senator Evans in August last year when replying to a question of mine when he said:

question.para: We would expect the savings situation to improve as the economy consolidates the recovery that is now manifestly under way.

How does the Minister therefore explain the massive slump in both private sector and household savings in the June quarter? Is it true that the run-down in savings for the last five quarters means the stock of national savings is now being whittled away faster than at any time in the last 18 years? Do not these figures show that Senator Evans's recovery vision was nothing more than either his usual wishful thinking or his economic incompetence?

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I have to answer these questions more succinctly than we used to do, perhaps. Senator Evans is a most competent and agreeable chap—a very competent and agreeable chap.
—And perspicacious.

—Senator Evans interjected that he was perspicacious into the bargain, and I agree with that. On the other hand, Senator Vanstone is not perspicacious. This question was asked in the Senate last week and I answered it, but if Senator Vanstone is going to pick up the same press comment and recycle it, I guess that is what she is likely to do.

para.tab: The answer I gave last week is one which I simply give again. Private sector savings, reflected in retained earnings and so on, are down because of the recession. Private sector savings are down in many countries at the moment because of the recession which is taking place in various countries. Public sector savings are down because this Government ran large Budget surpluses during the 1980s and in a period of—

talk.start.para: —Two years.

—It is four years—four years out of the last 30, of which those opposite were in government for 27. Do they recall that? Because of those public sector savings which were made during the late 1980s, the Government was in a position to expand the deficit in the last Budget to a level of about one per cent of GDP, which is about half the level of fiscal expansion in Japan, for example, of 2.1 or 2.3 per cent because of its recession. We expanded by half that level. Public sector savings are down for the same reason. Corporate savings are improving.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am sorry, I did not understand from the Minister's answer whether he was trying to tell us that in August last year the confident assertion made by his Government that savings would consolidate and the recovery was manifestly under way was in fact an incorrect assertion. What does the Minister now say as to whether savings will start to consolidate and a recovery is under way? Does the Minister say now the same as he said 12 months ago when he was wrong?

—The proposition that the savings ratio will improve in both the private and the public sector as the economy comes out of the recession is impeccable. I think Senator Vanstone, in her question, characterised Senator Evans as a person not economically literate. His view of that is impeccable. That will happen. In so far as the recession is concerned, we have had two quarters of growth in the Australian economy—not the level of growth we would have liked—and that is a sign that the recession is over.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the air services talks held between Australia and Argentina. What was the outcome of the talks, specifically in regard to airline flights between Australia and South America? Was any agreement reached which would give effect in part to the recommendations regarding aviation links of the report
Australia and Latin America
of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade?

—To his credit, Senator Maguire has in fact been pursuing this issue for some time. I am pleased to advise the Senate that, in response to recent air services discussions that were held in Buenos Aires, agreements were concluded successfully on 3 August with the signing of new arrangements for air links with the region. This was in accordance with recommendations from the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which, in its inquiry into Australia's relations with Latin America, called on the Government to give sympathetic consideration to any request from Aerolineas Argentinas for a second service to Australia.

para.tab: The airlines of both Argentina and Australia are now able to offer two B747 services per week. Previously, the arrangements allowed for only one service. The new arrangements also allow the airlines to operate additional supplementary services during periods of peak demand. Aerolineas currently operates one B747 service per week in the winter months and two services a week in the summer, from November to March. Qantas currently leases seats on these services. It is a now a matter for the commercial judgment of the airlines whether a year-round second service is viable and when it might be instigated.

The opportunity also exists under the Government's initiatives announced in the One Nation statement for another Australian airline to be designated on the Argentina route and to seek allocation of available capacity from the International Air Services Commission.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. Did the former Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, give the owner of the Southern Tasmanian Bender's limestone quarry an official and conclusive assurance in a letter dated 18 August 1988 that the Government had no objection to the continued operation of the quarry? On the basis that such an assurance was given, has the decision to close the quarry been nothing more than further evidence that the Government simply cannot be trusted in any consultation or negotiation and that even a written agreement with this Government, such as the Cook-Groom agreement of November 1988, is not worth the paper it is written on? If the Minister is prepared to defend his Government's record, will he give an assurance that the quarry owner, Mr Ray Bender, will receive compensation as specified in clause 16 of the 1988 Cook-Groom agreement? Finally, why did the Government conduct meaningless discussions with the Tasmanian State Government on the so-called future of the quarry with the knowledge that it had already arranged for the proclamation closing the quarry to be signed secretly—
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—I am sorry; the question was incomplete so it is very difficult to answer. I will refer that part of the question which I heard and the additional part of the question, which I am sure Senator Calvert would be happy to provide me with after Question Time, to the Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to proposals outlined by the Australian Democrats to cut the defence budget by some $1.25 billion? Is the Government planning to entertain or adopt such proposals? What are the ramifications for the defence forces and for defence planning inherent in such budget slashing?

—On 9 July, Senator Coulter became the defence spokesman for the Democrats and he proposed the following: to cancel the new submarine project; to cancel the ANZAC frigate program; and to cancel a range of smaller programs. He went on to advocate the scrapping of the F111s, a mothballing of an F-18 squadron and reduction of overseas deployments. He further added, as some additional matters, that he wanted to retire immediately one submarine and that he wanted to retire immediately one destroyer. He wanted to turn the Army into a Mickey Mouse outfit by mothballing artillery, reconnaissance and the APC regiments. He went on to say that he wanted to suspend military aid to the South Pacific, terminate military aid to all other countries, close North West Cape, close Pine Gap and convert Nurrungar.

para.tab: This was all in the hope of creating jobs in this country. I have to say that the Government's adoption of such a policy would cost tens of thousands of jobs, mostly at the high-technology end. The cancellation of all those projects would involve enormous compensation; so there would be a double-edged sword—the Government paying all the money out in one particular direction and sacking tens of thousands of people around this country in the other particular direction.

In short, the Government has absolutely no intention of adopting any of this mishmash of Democrat policy. I find it interesting that the Democrats want to close the bases in July and then in September want to put them on the negotiating table with the US. If we do that and the US says, `Okay, we will get rid of EEP for wheat', does that mean the Democrats are in favour of retaining the bases? Of course not. Their policy is a total sell-out of defence policy in Australia.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to turn his mind to the ramifications for defence planning for Australia.

—This would take Australia back into the 1930s when, it has to be admitted, segments of Australian society did not approve defence expenditure and left this country defenceless at the start of the Second World War.
—Your mob basically.

—Not just my mob. Senator Alston should go back and have a look through the debates in Parliament and see how many of his mob were involved in that as well, so do not just say it was our mob that had that particular attitude. We had to take over in 1941 when the Liberal Government failed.

para.tab:
If we adopted the Democrat policy, this country would basically be defenceless. Mickey Mouse solutions do not do at all. This document came out at the same time as Senator Coulter described himself as the Captain Kirk of the Starship
Enterprise
, leading a team of Democrats out into the universe not knowing where they were going to go. I have to tell Captain Kirk that one of the crew has already deserted. Secondly, he is leaving the
Enterprise
totally defenceless. All I can say is: Do not beam me up, Scotty.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the Minister's claims last week about a changed culture on the waterfront and I draw the Minister's attention to the threat by Tasmanian transport and maritime unions to isolate the State as a reaction to the State's industrial relations reform. As this could lead to the stoppage of all cargo entering or leaving Tasmania and thus affecting Australia's vital export capacity, will the Minister inform the Senate whether he condones or condemns these threats?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —I thought Senator Newman was a Liberal Senator and yet she asks me a question which is reminiscent of what one of my own backbenchers might ask me as a dorothy dixer. The industrial relations policies of the Tasmanian Government are socially divisive, are disruptive, set Tasmanians against Tasmanians, create disputes, engender confrontation and bring the economy of Tasmania down.

para.tab: I have said that is true of the Hewson-Howard industrial relations big bang theory. It is true of that. I have said it is true of the Kennett-Gude industrial relations policies in Victoria. It is true of that. It was true for a time in New South Wales before the then Minister and now Premier, Mr Fahey, started to water down his so-called big bang. It is interesting to notice that he preaches a softly, softly, easy goes sort of industrial relations policy now that he is the Premier and is not being ridden by Mr Greiner.

What Senator Newman has indicated to me in her question is that there is industrial turmoil threatened in Tasmania. Who is surprised about that? When a government does not seek to bring harmony to the Australian workplace but, rather, on an ideologically driven agenda, seeks to make war in a doctrinaire way on that section of the community which happens to be in trade unions, of course there are industrial disputes.

That is the reason why, under our period of government, industrial disputes in Australia have been 61 per cent less than they were during the period of the Fraser Government. That is why, on all of the polls taken in this country as to who handles industrial relations best, the community says ringingly, `Labor does'. That is one of the reasons why, when governments start on this type of process, there is disputation and disruption. If the Opposition wants to improve industrial relations, it must bring the organisations and people into its confidence and build a framework for cooperation like we have.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Am I to take from the Minister's answer an understanding that he is, in fact, condoning the threats to isolate Tasmania by the maritime and transport unions?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —Senator Newman should take from my answer that, as a keen observer of industrial relations, I am now being asked in my capacity as a Federal Minister to comment directly on the industrial relations of a State government, which I understand on one occasion Senator Hill rose in here on a point of order and tried to prevent me from doing. Now that the honourable senator has asked, as a keen observer, I am saying that these are the consequences and likely outcomes of the sort of confrontationist policy being embarked upon, unfortunately and wrongheadedly, by the Tasmanian Government.

para.tab: I do not condone industrial disputation. I am one who has stood on a record of bringing industrial harmony to this country, and if those opposite look at the latest figures on industrial disputation in Australia, they will see that they are off the bottom of the graph. I shake my head in wonderment and surprise that the Tasmanian Government has not yet woken up to the fact that, rather than make war on a section of its populace, what it ought to do is set up a framework for cooperation and harmony in the industrial workplace. That is the best advice I can give.

talk.start.para: —Do you condone the threats?

—I do not condone disputation at all. Senator Newman should not put words into my mouth or pretend I am saying anything else. I am not. As an observer of the scene, I am saying that the actions being embarked upon by this Government are likely to create exactly the responses that apparently they are creating. It is reminiscent of what happened at Burnie with APPM. You attack your own workers and they stand up as Australians and try to defend themselves. It is little wonder. Australians are a proud group and we tend to try to defend ourselves if we are attacked. I do not condemn that. That is old industrial relations, that is Liberal Party industrial relations; it is not Labor Party industrial relations.
—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What were the main achievements of last week's Bangkok APEC ministerial meeting?
—Last week's APEC meeting—the fourth since it was initiated here in Canberra in 1989—really did represent a major step forward and a consolidation of the APEC process.
—Oh, Gareth!

—Much to the disappointment of Senator Hill, who is sitting there giggling away, hoping for yet another disaster, or what he thinks is a disaster, so that he can derive some political capital from it. He has not succeeded in this instance, because APEC has been a resounding success. Agreement was reached on the early establishment of a secretariat which will provide the very important vehicle for the early implementation of a whole series of practical regional projects, ensuring a much greater degree of effective coordination, including with the private sector, than has been possible so far.

para.tab: In particular, the meeting endorsed a series of regional trade liberalisation projects that will be of direct and immediate benefit in the short term to Australian and regional business. There will be immediate action on a range of non-tariff measures, including the harmonisation of customs procedures, the administrative aspects of market access, the sharing of information on investment regulations and the provision of up-to-date data on tariff rates.

As I said in answer to an earlier question, in the longer term the meeting agreed to an Australian proposal for an eminent persons group to provide and generate a longer term vision on regional trade policy issues. That group will look at the broad issues that we will have to wrestle with over the next decade or so about the opportunity for greater trade policy harmonisation and integration.

I believe that the meeting also demonstrated APEC's very unique value as a forum for wide ranging discussion of current trade policy issues, including the formation of NAFTA and AFTA—it did inject a sense of momentum and urgency, again overdue, into the Uruguay Round negotiations—about which I came away feeling much more confident about the prospect of early realisation at last, at least given the United States' attitude. In short, the meeting did show that APEC is the key regional body in which the major economies of the region can work to sustain their mutual interest in ensuring regional growth.

talk.start.para: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In the introduction to the basketball match in Perth on Saturday, 5 September between the Perth Wildcats and the Canberra Cannons, which was televised by Channel 9, special thanks were given to Senator Cook and his Department and to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs for facilitating the entry into Australia of an American citizen who was connected with one of the players but who was without a passport. Thanks were also given to Qantas for carrying that passenger without a passport.
—We won.

—Senator Cook should not start squealing. I presume that there were good and compassionate reasons for the above action. My question to the Minister is: how many other persons connected with basketball who initially had difficulty gaining entry into Australia have had their entry facilitated at the request of the Minister? If there are any, who are they?
—In line with the new policy on this side, all questions asked of Ministers representing other Ministers will be put on notice. This one will be treated in the same way.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and relates to the provision of inspection services by AQIS. Fees charged by AQIS are now based on a 1990 Budget decision to achieve full cost recovery. Can the Minister explain why fees for services provided by Federal inspectors in the non-prescribed grains areas are considerably higher than those provided by State departments and over four times the cost of services charged by authorities in New Zealand? I point out that New Zealand also has full cost recovery from industry. Is it a question of efficiency within AQIS? Does the Minister plan a review of the staffing arrangements within that body?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —In line with the new approach in Question Time, I will put that question on notice.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of a recent report by the International Labour Organisation which shows that Australia has one of the best records on achieving pay equity for women—second only to Iceland, I believe? How will the Government ensure that this record is maintained and improved?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —One mark of how fair and just a society is is how it treats people who are not equal. It has been a long time sad history in Australia that women have not received equal pay and, now that they have the equal pay entitlement, have not always received fair treatment in the work force. Therefore, I was pleased to see the ILO's findings, which appeared in its world labour report for 1992, that Australia is ranked second in the group of 14 OECD countries in terms of achieving pay equity for women. The report finds that, in Australia, female non-managerial employees working full time earn 87.9 per cent of men's earnings. In comparison, women in Iceland earn 90.6 per cent of men's earnings. Women in West Germany receive less than Australia—73.6 per cent—and in Japan they earn much less, 50.7 per cent. On that table, Australia must rank as a very good performer in terms of social justice and pay equity.

para.tab: One of the most outstanding features of the report was that in Australia, unlike most other OECD countries, women's earnings improved during the 1980s. I might say by way of a side comment that they fell back under the Fraser Government. The pay-equity gap widened under Fraser but it closed more closely under the Hawke years of the Labor Government.

In 1980 non-managerial women earned 86 per cent of women's earnings and by 1988, the last year included in the report—I refer to the Hawke years because this was the period surveyed by the report—this figure had improved to 87.9 per cent. Since then the position of non-managerial women workers has improved even further and was 90.1 per cent in May 1991.

talk.start.para:
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the
Notice Paper
.
—Mr President, I seek leave to move a motion to take note of the answer that Senate Cook gave to a question I asked last Wednesday.
—How long?
—For three minutes—four minutes.
—No. We only get two. Why should you get five? You are joking. You hypocrite.
—Order! Is leave granted?
—Can I make it clear that if Senator Walters undertakes to speak for no more than two minutes, leave will be given. Otherwise it will not.
—Mr President, I seek leave to speak for three minutes.

para.tab: Leave not granted.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I move to suspend Standing Orders. In doing so, I believe that it is extremely serious when a Minister deliberately misleads the Senate in this place.
—What are you moving? You cannot just move suspension.
—I move to suspend Standing Orders on the seriousness of the answer that Senator Cook gave to me in that he misled the Senate.
—Mr President, I take a point of order.
—Order! Senator Walters has to move to suspend so much of Standing Orders as would allow her to take note of the answer.

—Mr President, I have a point of order. My point of order is that the leave to take note is obviously directed at me. That has been made clear. Senator Walters has spoken about a Minister deliberately misleading the Senate. That remark is directed at me. I think she should withdraw because what she has said is unparliamentary. I have not at any time deliberately misled the Senate. Mr President, I think you have ruled on previous occasions that such allegations are unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.
—Order! The use of the expression `deliberately misleading the Senate' has been ruled unparliamentary. I ask Senator Walters to withdraw and then to move her suspension of Standing Orders.

speech.speaker: Walters Sen M.S.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I will say, `Has misled the Senate'. I withdraw the word `deliberately'. Mr President, in accordance with the appropriate contingency motion, I move:

para.tab: That so much of Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion to take note of an answer to a question without notice.

talk.start.para: —Order! There are too many interjections. Senator Walters can now speak to the motion which she has just moved.

—Mr President, you will remember that on Wednesday I asked Senator Cook a question regarding the waterfront in Tasmania and how the waterside workers there, through their particular actions, had done away with a $20m fishing venture and a $50m associated dock in Tasmania. In answer to that question, Senator Cook misled the Senate. He said that the fishing venture had financial difficulties. Further, he said:

speech.para: The advice I have before me is advice that the company had decided to abandon this enterprise—

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I raise a point of order, and it is this: Senator Walters is not arguing urgency, she is arguing the substance of the issue. I ask you to call her to order, ask her to argue the case for urgency or sit her down.

—Order! This is one of the reasons that we changed the Standing Orders. Senator Walters has three minutes to make an argument as to why they should be suspended—and I think she should refer to that every now and then.
—Thank you, Mr President. He said that the company had decided to abandon the enterprise because it had not negotiated terms at all.

para.tab: I have had a briefing from the company, Trident Seafoods, and it has assured me that negotiations were started in December and, indeed, that an agreement was reached where it would have three waterside workers per hatch on the wharf and none on the ship. This was a firm agreement. It was confirmed in March and, indeed, when two ships came to Hobart for the unloading, that agreement was again confirmed. The waterside workers worked for two days under that agreement when John Coombs came over from Melbourne and said that he would not tolerate that agreement.

That agreement had been reached, the company is not in financial difficulties—and Senator Cook misled the Senate in saying negotiations had not only not been completed but had not even started. It was because the negotiations fell through and Mr Coombs would not negotiate with the company at all that that venture has been taken away from Tasmania. Senator Cook must understand the history of it before he makes any comment in this Senate.

talk.start.para: —Order! Time has expired.

—It has not normally been Government policy to oppose the very new and increasing practice of noting questions after Question Time. However, this is not to note a question given at this Question Time but a previous one. Therefore, it is very difficult to argue urgency because, if it had been urgent Wednesday last week, we could have commented on it then. It has suddenly become urgent between Wednesday and Monday. The other reason why the Government has sought at this stage to oppose the motion is quite clearly on the matter of time. It is a matter that should be addressed. It could be addressed sensibly, if we agree that this is a new and innovative process to debate questions after Question Time, if we actually set a time limit.

para.tab: I think it was quite fair for us at least today to say, `Well, if we are limited to two minutes, why does not the other side try two minutes themselves?'. Can they condense their argument into two minutes? If Senator Walters was incapable today of putting her case in two minutes and required three minutes, I suppose the same could have been said for some Ministers for some answers today. But those opposite did not worry about that—`Just roll right over the top; don't worry about that, Ministers will only have two minutes'. Well, why should those opposite not have two minutes in their response? We sat here with two questions coming to frontbenchers—I think Senator Short and Senator Alston—who went seven or eight minutes each in their answers to their own back bench.

This is just part of the hypocrisy of this chamber. I do not want to anticipate a later motion on the
Notice Paper
. It is no wonder that people get disillusioned about this chamber when they see the degree of double standards that exist in this chamber. But if we want to sensibly approach this matter, take it out of this particular debate today, and if we want to sensibly say as part of the Senate process—something that virtually did not exist a year ago—that, after Question Time, we want to note three or four questions and have a debate, for heaven's sake let us get sensible about it and let us set time limits. It does not have to be the same time limit as we have on Question Time but a sensible time limit, instead of someone getting up by way of ambush and where we have to shout over, `Well, how long?'.

I was responsible in this chamber the other day for making arrangements that were breached. We said five minutes a speaker. The next three speakers—one on this side and two on the other side—went for seven or eight minutes. So if honourable senators opposite want to institutionalise the noting of answers to questions and have, if you like, a replacement of MPIs and urgency motions, let us structure it. Let us not have the anarchy of it going on for two mindless hours of boring repetition. In a lot of cases these things are worse than MPIs because the speeches are not even properly structured or prepared and people ramble on to waste time, one after the other with no structure whatsoever.

I repeat: this matter is certainly not urgent. Senator Walters can get up on the adjournment tonight and put her views. The second thing is that the reason we oppose the suspension of Standing Orders today whereas we may not on other days is the monumental hypocrisy of the Opposition in saying that a Minister of the Government can spend two minutes on an answer but a backbencher should have three minutes to do the same thing. Maybe there is a difference in terms of the Opposition's motion in that the intellectual powers of certain Opposition backbenchers are such that they cannot condense their contributions into two minutes. What we have seen today is monumental hypocrisy. But we should sort it out for the longer term, instead of meandering into a new process in the Senate with no discipline whatsoever.

talk.start.para: —I want to respond very briefly to the extraordinary contribution of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). Firstly, he seems to forget very conveniently that Senator Walters's statement was in response to something like 10 minutes of non-stop garbage from Senator Cook, and it is absolute nonsense to pretend that it is in response to a two-minute statement. I would have expected better of the Minister than to use that kind of nonsense about timing.
—You came in after the debate today.

—I say to the Minister that he clearly gave the inference that it was somehow wrong for the Opposition to take three minutes when his side was taking two. The fact is that she is seeking to respond to a 10-minute diatribe of nonsense from Senator Cook. That is the reality, and the Minister does not like it. The other bit of reality that he does not like concerns our having the temerity to raise the question of the Minister's generosity last week when he allowed a debate to proceed when—
—We had an agreement.

—We did have an agreement. I am glad the Minister underlined that. We had an agreement and the Minister's side broke it, because the Minister sought to talk first before allowing Senator Aulich to talk. That is the reality. If the Minister would only stick to the truth in his florid statements he would do a lot better. As it was today, he has fallen on his rather large front, and it is absolute nonsense to try to stand over our senator from Tasmania in his aggressive nonsensical way. I support strongly her right to reply for three minutes to some nonsense from Senator Cook that went on for something like 10.

—I will take but a minute under the new rules to make one observation in respect of this motion, and particularly in respect of Senator Robert Ray's response. The time limit has been imposed upon the answering of questions, not because of need, but because of a deliberate tactic by the Government to take as much time as it wishes for political advantage. When we arrive at a point where the majority of the Senate says that enough is enough and imposes a guillotine upon the time taken for Ministers to answer questions, we have a fundamental problem. It is either a tactic on the Government's part or incompetence that it cannot in some precise way answer a precise question.
—You ask the wrong questions.

—With respect, Mr President, it is interesting that Ministers take twice as long to answer questions from their own side as they do to answer questions from our side. I can only take it that the Government has members on its side who are twice as incompetent. There are occasions when a question requires a considered and quite lengthy answer, but the Government has abused the opportunity to allow that judgment—

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Even though Senator Crichton-Browne has extended the time from the one minute promised, it seems to me that you ought to ask him to address the issue before the Chair. He is addressing neither the urgency nor the substance of the motion.

—Order! As I said earlier, because of the change to Standing Orders I have been very lenient in allowing the debate, but I remind Senator Crichton-Browne that we are talking about the suspension of Standing Orders.

—Mr President, I am arguing for the suspension of Standing Orders. The motion was moved on the basis that leave to speak for an extra three minutes was not granted by Senator Robert Ray to allow Senator Walters to make her comments. I would have stuck to my one minute except for the stupid interjections from the other side. I am seduced into temptation from time to time to respond to them.

para.tab: Question resolved in the negative.

speech.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Loosely on 14 September 1992 relating to the defence budget.

speech.para: I will be brief. In his reply to Senator Loosley, Senator Ray sought to castigate the policy announced by the Democrats on 9 July in relation to a cut in defence spending of as little as 12 1/2 per cent—$1 1/4 billion, admittedly. This was money which was to go into an area in which Australia is in desperate need—namely, the restructuring of industry and providing jobs for Australians.

para.tab: Senator Ray seems not to have realised that we have got to the end of the Cold War and that our needs now are different from our needs of 10 or 15 years ago. The ordering of the frigates, submarines and so on related to an earlier period in Australia's defence needs and does not relate to where Australia's threat is coming from now. Australia is not threatened now from an external military force. Australia is threatened internally from a decline in its economic circumstances; the large number of unemployed people; the large number of people who are becoming alienated; the young people who are committing suicide; and the sort of people whom Senator Baume himself has talked about quite often.

We simply want to redirect some of that defence money into areas from which Australia needs to be defended, namely, those internal threats which are coming from the decayed and rotted economy which has been brought onto this country by this Government.
