It is a beating of submarines and frigates into ploughshares because that is the real need for this country.

The amount of money concerned, $1 1/4 billion, was not to be taken out of the defence Budget and simply frittered away but was to be redirected—and that was specifically included in my statement of 9 July—in ways which would restructure industry and provide the sort of employment which was necessary. Specifically, $450m of that $1 1/4 billion would go towards providing jobs in the industries which could take up the unemployment generated by the loss of those submarine and frigate contracts. Very careful attention was given to the redirection of that money so that those people engaged in those activities at present, those people with particular skills in the electronics industry and other industries, would not be disadvantaged or thrown on the scrap heap but would, indeed, find other employment in a civilly directed defence posture.

It is fair to say that all reports in recent times have indicated that Australia will not suffer any immediate threat from external military intervention in the next 10 to 15 years. It is also true that since the end of the Cold War the alliances which we built up during that time—although we had doubts about those alliances—are no longer necessary. Much of the defence expenditure, specifically in the area of submarines and frigates, was related more to those alliances than to the defence of this country.

It is difficult to see how the half a dozen submarines that we would build would be related to an effective defence of this country outside that alliance. There are other areas where that money would be much better spent. I believe the reply given by Senator Ray was a total misrepresentation of the Democrats' stance, a denial of the threats which this country clearly faces—from inside the country, not outside—an emphasis on threats which are now long past and an emphasis on alliances which are no longer relevant to Australia's defence needs. I believe that this chamber—indeed all people in Australia—should give a great deal of attention to the proposals that were contained in our `Getting to Work' document launched on 9 July.

speech.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para:
—One of the interesting things that Senator Coulter said was that I misrepresented his position; nothing could be further from the truth. Senator Coulter should go back and check
Hansard
and then indicate to me where I have misrepresented his position. Senator Coulter's position is very clearly stated on page 2 of his press release. This is what the senator advocates:

speech.para: Cancel new submarines and ANZ Meko frigate programs . . .

If we cancelled the submarine project today it would cost 4,000 jobs, mostly in South Australia, but some in the other States as well. We would also need—what Senator Coulter does not acknowledge—enormous compensation to the Australian Submarine Corporation for the cancellation of the project.

para.tab: What Senator Coulter regards as the bottom line savings is $1,250m. I think that is massively conservative for the project. Why be so modest? Leaving aside compensation, the program would save a lot more than $1.25 billion. Senator Coulter would rip about $3 billion out of the Defence Force budget. He should not be modest about it. Of course, the difficulty will be that it will be at the expense of an enormous number of jobs, and at the same time, when the honourable senator wants to reinvest that money, these companies will need to be paid compensation. We will lose the jobs, and get no replacement jobs in the short term—I am talking of one to two years. As a scheme it is crackpot. The press release states further:

speech.para: Scrap the F-111's . . .

I know that would appeal to the honourable senator's ideological predilections. The F111 happens to be the best bomber in the world and there is no other on the drawing board. Every country, when it configures its defence forces, usually has about 85 per cent defensive and 15 per cent offensive. Senator Coulter wants to remove from the Australian Defence Force the whole offensive capability that is one of the great deterrents when one builds up a defence force.

para.tab: Suppose we scrap 22 of the most sophisticated bombers in the world, which are halfway through their avionics update. Does the honourable senator want to stop midstream or will he let them be updated and then scrap them so that we are another $500m down the drain? The press release continues further:

speech.para: Retire one submarine . . .

There is no justification for why it should be only one submarine and not two or none. The honourable senator then wants to retire one destroyer. There is no justification; why not two or three? But this is the corker: the press release continues:
Decentralise army into a more autonomous, lightly-armed, mobile-regionally based patrol units. Mothball artillery, reconnaissance and APC regiments.
We will have lightly armed groups running around the country with no reconnaissance, so they will be able to be ambushed at will.

talk.start.para: —Who is going to ambush them?

—I will come back to that in a moment, because this is where Senator Coulter's strategic genius really comes out. He wants to suspend aid to the South Pacific. I assume that means the South Pacific patrol boat program—one of the best programs ever instituted in the South Pacific—which has meant that those countries can patrol their own fishing grounds and become viable, or have a chance at becoming viable, for the first time in their lives. That program has meant that they can stop a variety of rapacious nations coming in and fishing out the area. They can now protect it, apprehend the vessels, auction them off and fish their own fishing grounds. That is the very sort of independence—rather than dependence—we should be promoting.

para.tab: The Democrats want to close North West Cape. That is not a particularly good idea because they would be scrapping only one submarine; how are we going to communicate with the rest of the submarines when they are under water? I know the Democrats are scrapping the new ones and taking one existing one out of service, but the other three or four are supposed to go blind around the Indian and Pacific oceans, are they? Because that is the only way we could contact them under water.

I would have thought that Senator Coulter would at least have known that on 1 October this year an Australian commander will take over North West Cape, and we have an agreement with the Americans for it to become a totally Australian facility over the next seven years. It is not an overseas base or anything else. I ask Senator Coulter: why not, at least in this one case, drop your ideological baggage?

The Democrats want to close Pine Gap and convert Nurrungar. I have referred to that and I will not repeat my comments about that, but it is just a touch hypocritical to want to close them on 9 July and then, in early September, want to put them up for negotiations on wheat. If we succeed, where does this policy stand? Where do the Democrats stand on this policy if we do put those two things on the negotiating table and the Americans say, `Oh, gee, right—you're back in the wheat business. Are you back in the bases business? No, you're not'. And on it goes.

I want to speak about one or two other aspects of this matter, but I do not want to take the same amount of time as Senator Coulter. Senator Coulter made the statement that there is no immediate threat to Australia for 10 to 15 years. On what basis does he make that calculation? He makes it on nothing we in Defence have put out and on nothing that Foreign Affairs, or any other intelligent defence observer in this country, has. We have, however, held to the seven-year warning time as espoused in the 1987 White Paper, and we think it is as true today as it was then.

The absolute fundamental point where Senator Coulter gets it wrong is where he says, `With the end of the Cold War, we can go away and do other things'. I can tell Senator Coulter that Australian defence policy was never configured to the Cold War. If he goes back and reads the Dibb report and the 1987 White Paper on defence, he will find that our defence policy has always been configured to regional needs—never to the Cold War.

We have been living in this country without an identifiable enemy for 20 years. It is the same fundamental point that Canada and many countries in Europe have to come to terms with. How does a country configure its defence forces without a readily identifiable enemy? What Senator Coulter would do is say, `We don't need defence. We'll just scrap it. We'll plough the money into a few greenie things'—all of which have some merit, but if a threat suddenly emerges in a shorter time frame than 10 or 15 years, this country is gone. As I indicated at Question Time, a range of people in this country in the 1930s argued exactly the same thing as Senator Coulter did in his press release. It meant that in 1939 we were not able to defend ourselves. It was not just, as some people interjected, Labor Party pacifists; it was basically across the board in the history of this country, as one would see from reading the
Hansard
debates.

What this country is about is defence in depth, defence self-reliance and a modest allocation to defence of 2.4 per cent of gross domestic product. We are not a big defence spender by regional comparisons in terms of percentage of GDP. There is no peace dividend in this country because we were never at Cold War levels. We were not like Great Britain and other countries, spending 5.5 or 6 per cent of GDP.

What we do is set up a basic platform on which to defend this country—a platform which can be expanded if there is a high level contingency threat. If we drop that structure in the way that Senator Coulter wants to, it can never be recovered and it can never be rebuilt. It is the minimal structure. What Senator Coulter is seeking to do, for whatever motive possible—appealing to other people in the electorate; I do not know—is to drop us below that critical mass. I can tell Senator Coulter that if we did that, we would never recover in defence terms.
I am speaking not as a rabid militarist, just as an Australian who wants this country to be able to defend itself and defend itself absolutely.

talk.start.para: —You have taken seven minutes!
—The ultimate weapon is talking over there; if I really get into trouble I will be sending Senator Walters north. No-one would want to invade us.
—You have taken seven minutes; you would not give me three!

—That is right, because those opposite were the ones imposing time limits, not me. Senator Walters's reprimand is right. I wanted to speak only for as long Senator Coulter did. I see there are a number of other Senators anxious to enter the debate, so I will retire.

—I would like to ask the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), seeing that he is still stuck in the strategies of the 1930s, which sort of enemies he is now identifying. Does he not realise that times have changed and that we are no longer in the 1930s? Could he identify the targets that he proposes to hit with the long range weapons on which he is spending money?
—You are in a time warp!
—I think he might certainly feel like it, but it is quite clear—

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would have thought, under our new Question Time arrangements, that there will be plenty of time for Senator Spindler to ask at least half of that question tomorrow and another half later in the week when it might be in order, but it certainly is not now.
—It is in order for Senator Spindler to speak to the motion which is before the Chair. He can ask questions; it does not necessarily mean that he gets answers.

—I was, indeed, suggesting that the Minister should give some thought to those strategic considerations, and should, in due course, when he is ready, report to the House. Perhaps he can refer us to the strategic assessments that he has commissioned, or that have been made, which identify the threats that we should be prepared for at a level that was planned, two, three, four, five years ago, because there is a long lead time in the equipment that the Minister is ordering, and which he expects taxpayers to pay for. Surely we should go ahead in our thinking and take account of a changing world picture. We should work towards a regional association of countries, where countries have ties other than militarist ties, and where countries have cultural and economic ties on which we can build a much more cooperative relationship, rather than a sabre rattling one. I look forward to the Minister's strategic assessment on which he is basing Budget expenditure which remains static in real terms.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop on 14 September, 1992 relating to APEC.

talk.start.para: —Does Senator Evans know?

—With the interest that Senator Evans has shown in the trade issues, I am not too sure whether he would wish to participate in the debate. No doubt he can be advised, because this debate might go for a little while as there will be others who will wish to participate.

para.tab: I refer to the incredible events of the last week or so, in particular, the attacks by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, upon Dr Hewson in relation to trade issues. There is also the aspect of the linkage between domestic policy and trade. We on this side of the chamber have sought to put down a policy for economic reform that has the potential to result in Australia being internationally competitive again. That is what Fightback is all about—taking taxes off business, reforming the industrial relations system and removing tariffs, because they become imposts on our capacity to export, so that we can be domestically and internationally efficient and competitive again within our region and in the world.

Beyond that, there is then the question: if we are competitive domestically and we can compete internationally, are there barriers and obstacles that will inhibit our business community from taking full advantage of that new competitiveness? That is what the trade debate is all about. It is a debate up until now in which this Government has not been prepared to engage. It has only engaged in the debate now because the Prime Minister has resorted to his usual tactic of personal abuse in attacks upon two matters that Dr Hewson raised a little over a week ago. I think that the debate ought to be put in a rational and sensible sense, which to date it has not.

The first criticism was that Dr Hewson had the nerve to criticise continuing barriers that exist in the case of Japan. He criticised the extent of tariff and other barriers in Japan that are obstacles to expanding Australian trade. That, according to the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, was beyond the pale: it should not be done by an opposition leader and could in some way result in the deterioration of our relationship with Japan.

The second matter Dr Hewson raised was that of restrictions and obstacles imposed upon our export opportunities by the United States. Coincidentally or otherwise, the comments by Dr Hewson came at the same time as we experienced an enormous rise in the EEP subsidies within the United States upon its wheat exports, which have, as I think everyone understands, the effect of pushing down the price of wheat on the international market and which detrimentally affect the well-being of our producers. They also have the effect, as I think Senator Boswell and others will say, of increasing the likelihood of the US putting such subsidised products into markets that we have seen in the past as traditional markets. The more wheat that is subsidised from the United States, the more the pressure will be on to sell that product within new markets and markets that we have taken advantage of in the past.

Dr Hewson raised both those areas of concern and said that they needed to be debated. In fact, in the case of Japan, he said that this Australian Government should be putting a greater effort into negotiating with and pressing Japan to reduce continuing barriers to our exports. Apparently, in the eyes of Mr Keating, that is a crime. I am quite happy to be associated with Dr Hewson in that claim, because it is my view—and I think the view of everyone on this side of the chamber—that the Australian Government ought to do more to persuade Japan to reduce its barriers.

In saying that, it does not mean that we in the Opposition do not recognise and appreciate the extent of our trade with Japan. Japan is our No. 1 trading partner and we have a significant surplus in our favour. From our perspective, that is good. But that does not justify the continuation of the existing barriers to other areas of export—exports from either Australia or other countries. But this Government does not seem to believe those barriers are important. That is what Dr Hewson was criticising, and he has every right and resposibility to do so.

When one looks at this Government's trade documents—particularly the document headed
Australia and North-East Asia in the 1990s: Accelerating Change
, referred to by some as the `Son of Garnaut' document, which was put out earlier this year and was supposed to be the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's major analysis of trade and trade opportunities within the east Asian region—and the extent to which they cover trade barriers imposed by Japan, those barriers are hardly mentioned at all.

As far as I can find, there is one weak sentence in the whole of this document of nearly 300 pages that mentions them at all. That demonstrates, starkly, the extent to which this Government regards those barriers as important. It obviously does not regard them as important at all.

In November last year the Government put out a draft document, which was to be its overall trade strategy document, headed
Australian Trade and Investment Development
. It looks at various markets, at Japan and the rest of this region in particular, but again obstacles imposed by Japan on our producers are hardly mentioned at all. On page 16 of the document, there is some mention of formal impediments to trade in relation to Japan. It says they are low, except for certain agricultural commodities such as beef, dairy products and rice. That is about the sum total of its mention of those obstacles.

This can be contrasted with the attitude that is taken by the United States and in GATT by countries generally when they address Japan's protective mechanisms. I hope this will be taken in context because, as I said a minute ago, Japan has been gradually reducing barriers, and that is something we want to encourage, but where it has not reduced those barriers the Australian Government, in concert with other governments, should be urging it to do so. That is what Dr Hewson said Mr Keating should be doing, and that is what Mr Keating then condemned Dr Hewson for raising.

talk.start.para: —Seven minutes! That's all you were supposed to have.

—I will not be much longer. When I look at the US 1990 annual review of trade impediments, under the heading, `Japan', I find a whole chapter of structural obstacles that exist within Japan, such as problems with its import policies and tariffs. There is particular mention of leather and leather footwear, wood and paper products, agricultural products, aluminium, seed grains, rice—on which we know there is a total prohibition—and fish products. It then goes into the standards, testing, labelling and certification difficulties that one has. It then looks at obstacles in the pharmaceutical industry and obstacles to food additives, fresh and preserved food. It looks at the Japanese Government procurement programs, its attitude to semi-conductors and to satellites. It looks at export subsidies in relation to shipbuilding, government procurement code implementation, and at questions relating to its lack of intellectual property protection. It looks at service barriers—construction, architectural and engineering services—at obstacles in relation to legal services, investment barriers, barriers against direct investment, other barriers such as semi-conductors, amorphous metals, optical fibres, aerospace, auto parts, soda ash, and the distribution system, which, of course, is critically important. One does not have to have it in the form of a transparent tariff barrier for it to be effective. It also looks at the law on large retail stores and at marketing practice restrictions.

para.tab: The US looks at all those obstacles, addresses them and argues, through negotiation, that it is important that Japan be persuaded to reduce those obstacles. Australia should be addressing them likewise. It is not just the United States that is putting these matters on the agenda. Look at the GATT itself.

I will finish by simply looking at the concluding remarks by the Chairman of the Council of GATT in August 1990. This was a council meeting which was a trade policy review of Japan. I look at this document very briefly and just touch on some of the Chairman's comments. He mentions that members of the Council expressed their concerns in a number of areas, including the apparent lack of transparency in the administration of Japan's trade policies; the anti-competitive practices of certain Japanese firms which were not adequately addressed; a continuing high level of support for agriculture; the low level of intra-industry trade; the high tariffs for leather, footwear, jute products, textiles and clothing; import quotas on coal and some other products; low import content of government policies; tariff escalation; and the grey area measures. I will not go into all of these because those on the other side apparently do not want to hear them.

We are simply saying that Australia, together with other like-minded nations, should be addressing these obstacles. Mr Keating and his junior trade Minister—certainly not Senator Evans, because he has had no interest in trade whatsoever; there has been a whole series of subsidiary Ministers: one minute it was Mr Dawkins, then it was Mr Duffy, then it was Dr Blewett, and now it is Mr Kerin—should be at least pressing upon Japan the need to reduce these obstacles in order that trade can expand and that we can all benefit from that expanding trade. That is all that Dr Hewson was saying. It is a very reasonable thing for him to say. Instead of Dr Hewson being abused by Mr Keating for saying it, Mr Keating should take a leaf out of his book and get out there and do a bit of this hard work himself.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I, too, want to say a few words about this motion to take note of Senator Evans's answer to Senator Bishop relating to APEC. Senator Hill very correctly drew the attention of the Senate to the link between trade policy, towards which he directed his remarks, and industry policy. I want to say something about the respective approaches of the Government, on the one hand, and the coalition, on the other, so far as that second aspect is concerned—industry policy—because it was sadly lacking in any of the comments made in the answer given to the question today.

para.tab: I want to make several specific points. The coalition believes that Australia needs an internationally competitive and vibrant manufacturing industry, including an internationally competitive and vibrant motor vehicle industry and, I would hope, a competitive and vibrant textile industry. It is clear from the last 10 years, during which time Australia's manufacturing base has been massively eroded as a result of the failures of the economic policies of which Paul Keating was the principal architect—the puller of the levers, of which he boasted; the organ grinder directing and dictating to Senator Button, the industry Minister monkey of the organ grinder and other Ministers—that this Government, of which, amazingly to me, Paul Keating is the leader—

talk.start.para: —Use proper titles please; `Mr Keating'.

—This Government, of which Mr Keating is the Leader, does not have any idea of how to correct the deep-seated malaise that it, itself, has created within industry. This Government and this Prime Minister are without precedent in their willingness to blow with the latest political wind; to abandon economic and political principles whenever they think it suits them; to bow to the dictates of the trade union movement when it comes to an inability or a failure to take necessary measures to reform and restructure industry; and, above all, to totally confuse and abuse Australian industry.

para.tab: Just look at some of the things that have been said by the Prime Minister in recent times. He has given the impression that this Government has a vastly different tariff policy to that of the coalition. He gave the impression—and it started at the by-election for Wills earlier this year—that this Government was a government that was going to maintain protection against the ravages of a tariff-reducing coalition. But how does that sit against the comments made over the last few years by the Prime Minister? Only last year, when talking to John Laws, the Prime Minister, before he was Prime Minister, said:

speech.para: At the end of (tariff) phasing, which is 1997 and 2000, we will have removed tariffs altogether.

It is the Prime Minister—again, before he became Prime Minister—who described tariffs as `poison'. He also declared just last year that if the textile, clothing and footwear industries needed tariffs to survive then `we are better off without them'.

para.tab:
Senator Button, the industry Minister, used to be a bit more honest than he has been in recent times. Only three months ago, in the
Australian
Financial Review
of 23 June, he was reported as saying:

speech.para: Tariffs are inward-looking mechanisms, not outward looking mechanisms.
He said at the same time:
. . . it would be a cruel delusion to pretend—
I think he said this in the chamber—
that, by making what I would regard as a backward step in relation to tariffs in these industries, you would be in fact arresting what is a difficult and unfortunate decline in employment.

So much for the comments of the Prime Minister, and Senator Button in more recent weeks, as they have made a desperate attempt to make political capital out of the tariff debate.
In stark contrast to that political expediency and cynicism, the coalition's industry policies which are outlined in its Fightback proposals are the most comprehensive, internally consistent and logical policies for industry that have ever been produced by a political party in this country.

para.tab:
One of the elements of the coalition's industry policy—only one—is a reduction of tariffs to negligible levels by the year 2000. By `negligible', we mean nought to 5 per cent. We have stated on many occasions that the level we are talking about for the car industry within that range is 5 per cent.
For all other industries, with the single exception of the TCF industries, the Keating Government's policy is to reduce tariffs to zero, and before this level would be reached by the coalition. Indeed, the Government, in its manufacturing industry statement of March last year, produced proposals to reduce the average tariff level to 2 per cent by 1996. That is an even speedier program of reduction than the coalition has been proposing. For all industries, setting aside the motor vehicle and TCF industries, the Keating Government's policy is to reduce tariffs to zero and before this level is proposed to be reached by the coalition.

In essence though—and I make this point very strongly—the tariff policy aspects of overall industry policy are very similar for the Government and the coalition. Even in the case of the car industry, any difference between the two is small. The Government says 15 per cent duty by the year 2000; we say 5 per cent. When one takes account of the time span involved—and we are talking about another eight years; when one takes account of the movements in exchange rates with a floating exchange rate regime; when one takes account of all of the other important economic variables that can change so dramatically from one year to another—interest rates, inflation, fiscal policy and the like; and when one takes into account the extent of natural protection that exists for Australian industries, that difference between 5 per cent and 15 per cent is quite meaningless.

The overriding difference between the coalition's overall industry policy and that of the Government—there is an overriding difference here, if you set aside tariffs—is that the coalition will take a range of actions in the first two years of a Hewson government that, essentially, will make tariff protection unnecessary.

Those actions are: stripping $20 billion of taxes from the cost of making goods and services; abolishing the wholesale sales tax; abolishing payroll tax, which the Prime Minister himself acknowledges will either save or create 200,000 jobs; abolishing fuel excise; reducing the burden of regulation on industry; improving the efficiency of such vital support industries as transport and communications; bringing greater efficiency and competition to many government enterprises by transferring their ownership and operation to the private sector; returning and reforming the industrial relations system to produce greater flexibility in labour arrangements and, therefore, greater productivity and, in due course, higher real wages; and reforming the outdated structure of relations between the Commonwealth, State and local governments to remove duplication of cost, regulation, inefficiency, all of which hit industry.

The fundamental difference between the Government and the coalition is that we are going to do all of those things in tandem, many of them before the reduction in tariffs. It is a very cohesive, comprehensive policy. That is the difference between the coalition's policy and the Government's policy. The Government's policy is to go down the tariff reduction route without taking any of those measures that improve the efficiency, productivity and international competitiveness of Australian industry. That is the way it has gone in the last decade and that is why we have had such a savage erosion of our industrial and general industry base here in Australia.

The one conclusion we can draw from all of that, Mr Acting Deputy President, is that the fundamental difference between the coalition on the one hand and the Government on the other is that in the case of the coalition one has a clear direction being given, with conviction and with some leadership being shown right from the top, from Dr Hewson. There is a massive difference between that and the cynical political expediency of a desperate government and a desperate Prime Minister Keating. If anyone wants to read—

talk.start.para: —Ten minutes!

—I am just finishing. If anyone wants to read a very clear example of the differences between the two parties, then I can recommend no better article than that by Richard Farmer in the
Canberra Times
last Friday. Mr Farmer has not been known as a supporter of the Liberal Party—indeed, the contrary. I think he has made no secret of the fact that he is very strongly allied to the Labor Party and has in fact helped the Labor Party on many occasions in preparing for elections. A small part of his article from last Friday ought to be prescribed reading for everyone. It says:

speech.para: Prime Minister Paul Keating, desperately trying to hang onto office, succumbed to the industry pressure—
he was talking about motor vehicles in this case—

and pretended he knew how vital the tariff was . . . Opposition Leader John Hewson proved that he is made of much sterner stuff than Mr Keating by not succumbing to the blackmail of manufacturers. Dr Hewson stuck to the conviction, which Mr Keating shared until recently, that the real task was to make the construction of cars in Australia efficient . . .

One can extend that argument way beyond the car industry, to the whole approach of industry policy in this country. I have no doubt at all that the people of Australia, including those who are employed in industry, will see through the absolute charade and hypocrisy of the Government's current approach towards industry policy. Once one sees through that and one sees what is required in this country for a vibrant, internationally competitive and productive manufacturing sector, one realises that the policies the coalition is putting forward in a very comprehensive, cohesive way are the only way that we are going to correct the dreadful malaise that the policies of this Government over the last 10 years have wrought on Australian industry and on the Australian economy generally.

speech.speaker: Bishop Sen B.K.

talk.start.para: —In speaking to the motion moved by Senator Hill that we take note of the answer of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to my question earlier in the day, I point out the inconsistencies of the statement that he makes in the area of trade. Senator Hill has already very adequately shown what little interest Senator Evans takes in the question of trade: Senator Evans vacates the field and leaves it to junior Ministers. He likes to strut and parade on the international stage and perhaps pursue his ultimate goal, which has now gone sour: he thought he might get the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts with Cambodia.

para.tab: Of course, at the time that Senator Evans was floating his ideas, members from this side of the House pointed out that enormous difficulties were to be encountered with the Khmer Rouge, but they were things that simply would have got in the way of Senator Evans's strutting the stage in the way that he has become used to and enjoys. But when we come to trade, he does not find it glamorous; he apparently does not find it interesting either. So when he was at the conference which he mentioned just recently and made his pronouncement, he said that he wished that in the future APEC could become another European Community. He said:

speech.para: We might be as integrated and harmonised and as coherent economically, if not politically, as the European Community currently is. That is a big thought at this stage.

One sees how out of kilter that thought was with the very positive action that those who attended the APEC conference in Bangkok came up with. They have initiated short term programs that are aimed at removing barriers to intra-APEC trade, and I will list four of them. First, they have set up an electronic database of tariff schedules. Secondly, there has been a harmonisation of customs procedures to get rid of red tape. Thirdly, there is a program aimed at the elimination of administrative constraints. Fourthly, there has been the preparation of a guide to members' investment regulations and procedures.

para.tab: They are all very sensible initiatives aimed at reducing the barriers to intra-Pacific trade. When I use the term `Pacific', I mean Pacific Rim. When I talk about the Pacific Basin, I mean all the countries that are either contained in or in fact border the Pacific. So it does include Latin America, where the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade recently said we must enhance those opportunities. But when we do an analysis of what occurs in the Pacific Basin, we see that there is indeed a need to reduce, very particularly, non-tariff barriers within the region.

The OECD reports will show that in OECD countries tariff barriers are now down to an average of 4.5 per cent, quite within the confines of the aim of our tariff policy of seeing tariffs reduced to between nought and 5 per cent. Senator Short very ably pointed out that there is a very close nexus between tariff policy and trade policy. The tariff policy is designed to ensure that all Australian businesses get an equal access to capital and human resources.

`The level playing field' is one of those phrases which is oft misquoted and misused; it is not understood. It is meant to apply to Australia in the sense that all Australian enterprises get a fair go at capital and resources—not the idea which is behind a high tariff policy of saying, `We are going to tax this group of people over here and we are going to pay it to that group of people over there because they are somehow special'. Why are they special? The way those policies operate is in fact to very often penalise those people who are at the lowest end of the socioeconomic scale; people who need not an impediment, but indeed help.

Let me give honourable senators an example. Tariff policies as they apply to TCF mean that the cost of importing goods such as children's clothes and shoes from countries that are in the Pacific Basin bear such a tariff that, when a single mother, bringing up her child on a pension and with great difficulty, goes to one of the stores such as Target or K Mart to buy inexpensive but pleasant looking clothes for her child, she is effectively slapped with a consumption tax of the equivalent of at least 25 per cent. It is neither logical nor equitable.

The strength of a tariff policy such as ours is that it does give all Australians fair access to investment capital and to human resources, and in turn that is linked to trade policy, which ensures that we then have markets for the goods that we make to export. Very clearly the Opposition is committed to an industry policy which will enable manufacturers to flourish, to prosper and to export sufficiently so that we can in turn stabilise our huge international debt and start to pay it off.

When we look at the policy of how we maintain access to trade, I return to the point I made a moment ago, and that is that there is a need within the Pacific Basin and the Pacific Rim—which account for 70 per cent of Australian trade and a quarter of our foreign investment and include six of our largest export markets—to reduce barriers to trade in our own region. We support APEC as being the vehicle for doing just that. For Senator Evans to so misunderstand the trade side of his portfolio as to say APEC can become a European Community is just to show how uninformed he is in this area.

When we look at the question of the trading patterns that Australia enjoys with countries in the Pacific Basin, we see that we require, as a medium sized but strategically placed nation, to be a global trader. Very simply, that means that not only do we need access to our traditional markets and need to increase those markets, which include Japan, ASEAN, Korea, the three Chinas, the NAFTA countries and the Latin American countries, but also we need to maintain our access to the European market.

At all stages, the Opposition's policy is to encompass the pursuit of multilateral trade but with bilateral negotiations which are compatible with that multilateral thrust. Our policy has been consistent. Our policy with regard to closer economic relations with New Zealand is a very good example of how that policy works.

Let me go back to the question of the linkage between tariff policy and trade policy. It requires a philosophical framework to make those policies work. The philosophical framework within which I will always work is that of free enterprise. It is a lofty goal. The countries which have escaped from behind the Iron Curtain now seek to restructure their economies so that they too can compete. It is a goal which they see as worth pursuing.

If we look at tariff policy, trade policy, industrial relations policy and tax reform within that philosophical framework of free enterprise, we see that if we work at reducing impediments to trade for ourselves—that is, for Australians to be successful manufacturers and exporters—we need to free up that labour market, introduce taxation reform, keep access to our traditional markets and increase access to other markets, which include seeing a reduction in the common agricultural policy in Europe. The Europeans are simply running a social welfare program whereby they are asking the rest of the world to make those payments. We want to see a dismantling of EEP in the United States so that there is free trade in agriculture. We want to see Japan get rid of its total ban on rice imports and pursue its policy of liberalising access by lowering non-tariff barriers.

As I said, if we can negotiate through APEC a philosophy of free enterprise, which in turn means that international trade grows, thereby enabling all people's standard of living to grow, that is the route to pursue. That route leads to peace and neighbours remaining on good terms and, finally, it allows the standard of living of all people within, firstly, our region and, secondly, the rest of the world, to continue to grow. In that way, we will not face the prospect of unrest, further outbreaks of war and a diminution in the amount of international trade.

Free enterprise encapsulates lofty ideals. The Opposition's policies in understanding the link between taxation reform, labour market reform, tariff reform and access to markets—that is, our trade policy—give a formula that allows Australians to prosper and show that they are the strong and resilient people that they have been historically. Once the impediments and structures that have been placed upon the backs of good Australian people by way of government red tape and, as Dr Hewson says, green tape and black tape are removed, we will again see a very strong and proud nation.

talk.start.para: —I speak in support of Senator Hill's motion. The Government is failing Australians by not standing up and speaking for Australia's national interest. It has failed us in not having an adequate approach to trade, yet this is a crucial area for getting Australia out of its present bankruptcy. We have a continuing current account deficit and a huge national debt. To get Australia employed again, it will be important that we move to international competitiveness in the goods that we produce and ensure that we are able to trade effectively in the world.

para.tab: Senator Evans, as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, has failed to give any confidence in the answers that he has given in the Senate in recent days. Since the President of the United States, President Bush, early this month in the election campaign in the US announced in the EEP a huge increase in wheat subsidies to the great disadvantage of this country, our farmers and our trade effectiveness, there has not been an adequate protest or an alternative response strategy put by the present Government. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has failed, as has Senator Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The only positive approach has been put by the Opposition and, in particular, most effectively by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson.

What has the Government done? In Question Time in the Senate, as in the House of Representatives, Ministers of this Government have taken cheap shots at the positive approach of the Opposition. What is that positive approach? I refer honourable senators and members of the public to two documents. The first is a three-page letter written by Dr John Hewson to President Bush direct. That three-page letter is a substantial and positive document that should be read carefully by anyone who wants to see the lead that the Opposition is giving to solving Australia's trade problems. The second document is an almost full-page article written by Dr Hewson and published in the
Australian
last Thursday. It directly puts into a fuller context the trade initiatives that the Liberal and National parties are calling for.

From the present Government, especially the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, we have seen failure, silence and inadequacy and cheap shots at distorting what the Opposition is saying about this matter. I will summarise our approach in response to the recent announcement by President Bush, like our approach to many other events involving Australian trade, in this way. The Opposition advocates a three-track approach in relation to other countries in the solutions of Australia's trade problems: firstly, internationally; secondly, regionally; and, thirdly, bilaterally with each individual nation.

In international terms, we wholeheartedly support initiatives for free trade in GATT in the Uruguay Round, if it is possible. We are stronger and more eloquent, and seeking more cooperation in the Uruguay Round for a positive outcome to GATT. Unlike the Government, that is not the only thing that we advocate. The present Government has put all its eggs into the GATT basket. We have to be realistic and see that there is not necessarily an optimistic outcome to the Uruguay Round, given the initiatives recently announced by the United States and the slowness with which the Europeans have only begun to define what might be a lowering of their subsidisation of agricultural products in other ways. To be effective, we must be ready in Australia to work together with like-minded nations, in particular with our major trading partners, to ensure that there is an effective solution for our trade, even if there is a delay in a positive outcome to the GATT.

So the second level of approach is a regional one with important associations such as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation process. Australia has rightly initiated the APEC—the 15-member organisation made up of nations of the Asia-Pacific region. I say to Government senators that we are even stronger, even more eloquent and even more specific about what we wish to see from APEC. Let me give an example. Senator Hill has rightly lamented the slowness with which APEC has put on the agenda clear discussion which leads to action in trade liberalisation. Trade liberalisation has not flowed from APEC discussion, even though there have been three years of discussion so far. Positive action did not flow from even the Bangkok meeting that was held last week.

Of course, I welcome the setting up of an APEC secretariat in Singapore. I welcome the fact that APEC has three new members from last November in terms of the three Chinas. Trade liberalisation should be on the agenda. This should lead to a decision being made and a greater free trade environment within this region.

I now turn to the third area. I am afraid that the present Government has omitted completely, at least from any of its public statements in the last two weeks, any kind of imagination to produce a worthwhile outcome to initiatives that we can take on a one-to-one basis—one Australia with one Japan, one Australia with one Korea, one Australia with each of the ASEAN countries, one Australia with one United States, one Australia with Mexico, one Australia with Chile or one Australia with any other of our individual trading links.

In concert with Senator Hill and Senator Bishop, I continue to advocate the necessity for the Government to put the third track on its agenda. The Government should not have all of its eggs in a GATT basket. It should not just make some warm noises about APEC. There needs to be action on and a solution to Australia's trading problems. One of the essential elements in the three-track approach of the Opposition, which I advocate most strongly, is the exploration and active finalisation of bilateral free trade agreements with our trading partners.

A year ago in August after my return from a visit to seven Latin American countries I included in a comprehensive statement advocacy of a free trade bilateral agreement between Australia and Mexico and another between Australia and Chile. I have long advocated that we keep up a precise dialogue with our major trading partners in north and east Asia—with Japan especially, China, Korea and Taiwan. This should be done with each one of them on a bilateral basis consistent with what we are saying and doing in APEC and consistent with our goals in the GATT.

Today I was able to meet with the Chilean Minister for Mining, Mr Hamilton, who is an experienced senior Minister of the Chilean Government. The Minister was accompanied by officials and representatives of the mining industry. I was delighted with his response when I asked, `Is the Government of Chile willing to negotiate a free trade agreement with Australia?'. He answered that question positively and clearly.

Last Thursday I met with the Ambassador of Mexico. For some time I have been putting to representatives of Mexico that we ought to be moving towards a direct free trade agreement with those countries on a bilateral basis. Of course, that also includes the North America Free Trade Agreement, NAFTA. Why has Senator Evans closed his mind to these bilateral initiatives? Why does he take cheap shots at the Opposition and, in particular, at Dr Hewson?

I will conclude with these final remarks. The Opposition does not have an `either or' policy but a `both' policy in regard to international regional or bilateral discussions on trade. We do not have an `either or' approach to NAFTA and ASEAN. We have a `both' approach. We do not have an `either or' approach to any of the potential trading partners with this country. We have a `both' approach. We have all of them.

With my colleagues in the Opposition, I continue to put a request to Senator Evans and to the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, that they stop their policy and behaviour of failure and being frozen into silence about anything other than GATT. They should start to act by standing up for Australia's national interests. They should be responsive to the wishes of the Australian people by acting along the lines that my colleagues and I have been urging.

talk.start.para:
—This is not a debate which requires a long response from the Government. The debate reminds me a little of a joke on the back page of the
Australian
which describes a politician in the following way: `He must be an environmentalist; he is using 100 per cent recycled rhetoric'. That is essentially what we have had in this debate.

para.tab: There has been a fairly desperate attempt to cobble together some sort of veneer of rationale for a policy that is in very serious trouble in the Australian electorate; a policy that has been under effective attack. There has been a concerted and sustained attempt—it has been going on for a very long time—to paper over the cracks in the policy and conceal the problems with its domestic and international rationale.

The Opposition has failed very comprehensively in this debate. Opposition senators have set out to do two things. One has been to create in inaccurate impression of the Government's policy—to try to paint it as being exclusively to do with the Uruguay Round. As Mr Kerin has made clear on a number of occasions—he did so again as recently as yesterday—that is clearly not the case. Senator Evans has also made that point.

Opposition senators have tried to paint untruths about our policies and disguise the truth about theirs. It is one of those circumstances in which one is tempted to say, `If you stop telling lies about our policy, we will stop telling the truth about yours'. We are not prepared to enter into such a deal. We are prepared to continue to tell the truth about our policy and to point out the problems with the Opposition's policy.

I understand the Opposition's concern. We are happy to facilitate a debate at some time. It is a pity that that time is not now. But I will say this about the debate: it has a little more to do with the problems Australia is facing than the so-called urgency motion that we are likely to confront in the near future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to move a motion to take note of an answer given by Senator Button during Question Time today.
—For how long?
—For about as long as the debate takes.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Prime Minister (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Boswell on 14 September 1992 relating to pig imports.

speech.para: I sent a message to Senator Button in which I said I would be moving to take note of the answer that he gave today. No doubt someone will be looking at the television in his office and will note what is happening in the chamber. I would welcome his appearance in this chamber to debate this very serious question.

para.tab: On 19 June I asked the Minister whether it was correct that the issue of imported embryos, live pigs and breeding material was raised at a prime ministerial level and not purely at a department level. I also asked whether it was raised at a ministerial level. The Minister stated:

speech.para: The answer to that question is no. I have to say that I told Senator Boswell privately after Question Time yesterday that, when I referred to discussions between the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the company Danpork and the representative of the Danish pig industry, those discussions were with the quarantine service—and they were. I also understand that officers of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy were there. There was no ministerial discussion on this issue at all.
Yet, as a result of an application I made for freedom of information, a letter emerged dated 3 June from AQIS which, amongst other things, said:

The Danes first raised the possibility of access for live pigs in the mid 1980s. This request was not formally followed up until 1990 when it re-emerged as an issue at Prime Ministerial level in the context of proposals. . .
In the third to last paragraph the letter goes on to say:

Having regard to Government to Government discussions over the years and in particular recent Minister to Minister discussions it will be necessary to give some priority to the longstanding Danish requests. With regard to new genetic material it would be useful to gain an appreciation of whether there is any demand from the pig industry in this area from any member country of the European Community as it may be that this aspect is better handled on a Community basis.
It is very clear from that letter that there has been or was some prime ministerial intervention or some Minister to Minister intervention.

para.tab: Today I asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister (Senator Button) whether he stood by his answer to me of Friday, 19 June. The answer was yes, he did stand by that. He said he would go back and investigate his answer, and he suspected that he would be right and I would be wrong. He has not come back into the Senate chamber to correct his answer, yet we have a letter from AQIS which clearly says that there was prime ministerial intervention and Minister to Minister discussions.

On 19 June or thereabouts, I made an application for information under freedom of information and those papers were given to me about two weeks ago. Incorporated in those papers was another letter from AQIS dated 21 July—after my application under freedom of information—saying:

speech.para: I must correct an error in my previous advice to you at page 2, paragraph 4 of my 3 June 1992 letter regarding the status of proposals for importation of live pigs from Denmark. This letter incorrectly advised that the issue of possible live pig imports from Denmark re-emerged at Prime Ministerial level in April 1990. That advice was certainly not factual. . .

So we have a disparity between the two letters dated 3 June and 21 July from AQIS. Between the writing of those two letters was my request for freedom of information. I want to know: was any pressure put on AQIS to write this second letter; if not, where is the disparity? This is a very serious matter. If there is any pressure to circumvent the protocols of AQIS and expose the whole of the Australian herd and flock to imported disease, we have to take this matter very seriously.

para.tab: A number of other issues have to be investigated. Where does the pressure come from? I have not found anyone in the industry who is lobbying to import breeding material or live breeding pigs from Denmark. I invite Senator Button to come in here and explain the situation, but I suspect the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) will not let him do so. The Prime Minister must now make this Government's position clear. It is a very serious matter and it deserves a full explanation from the Government.

speech.speaker: O'Chee Sen W.G.

talk.start.para: —Today Senator Button had the opportunity to correct what is quite clearly a glaring inconsistency between an answer that he gave this Senate on 18 June this year and information which is now contained in letters that Senator Boswell has obtained from AQIS under his freedom of information request. On 18 June, Senator Button told this Senate categorically that there was no ministerial involvement in these discussions. He told the Senate categorically that there was no prime ministerial involvement in these discussions. It is almost like Senator Button was standing there saying, `Read my lips'. We did not have to read his lips because we got the opportunity to read the documents. What do the documents say? The documents say something which is completely different. For example, the letter which AQIS wrote on 3 June 1992 says:

speech.para: The Danes first raised the possibility of access for live pigs in the mid 1980s. This request was not formally followed up until 1990 when it re-emerged as an issue at Prime Ministerial level in the context of proposals for a joint venture between Danish and Australian pig breeding and processing interests.
Further, on the third page that letter—and it is quite clear—goes on to say:

Having regard to Government to Government discussions over the years and in particular recent Minister to Minister discussions it will be necessary to give some priority to the longstanding Danish requests.

Why is it necessary to give priority to these requests? What Minister to Minister discussions was this letter referring to which Senator Button refused to acknowledge when he came into the Senate and answered Senator Boswell's earlier question on 18 June? What particular discussions? What Ministers were involved? These are the questions which must be answered.

para.tab: Senator Button is already on the record as telling this Senate—and we are bound to trust what he tells us—that there were no such discussions. Clearly, there is a glaring inconsistency. After the date on which Senator Boswell made his freedom of information request, when the Government must undoubtedly have realised that the jig was up, AQIS wrote another letter, on 21 July. What did that letter say? It said:

speech.para: I must correct an error in my previous advice to you at page 2, paragraph 4 of my 3 June 1992 letter regarding the status of proposals for importation of live pigs from Denmark. This letter incorrectly advised that the issue of possible live pig imports from Denmark re-emerged at Prime Ministerial level in April 1990.

What this letter did not do was retract the earlier advice that this had been the subject of government to government discussions over the years and most particularly had been the subject of recent Minister to Minister discussions. It is not what the second letter says. It is what the second letter does not say, what the second letter could never say; that is, that there had been recent Minister to Minister discussions regarding the importation of live pigs from Denmark and, as a result of those ministerial level discussions, this issue was now a priority.

para.tab: The people of Australia deserve to know which Minister over there or in the other place—I suspect it might be a Minister in the other place—has been pulling the strings; which Minister of the Government has been attempting to influence AQIS in making very important decisions about the safety and the sanctity of the Australian pig herd.

talk.start.para: —What about the cattle herd and the flock?

—These too are questions that should be answered. This Government has a track record of being soft on disease control. I remember perfectly well, when I asked Senator Cook about 18 months ago what this Government was going to do in terms of quarantine restrictions and whether it was the case that this Government had gone soft on quarantine restrictions, Senator Cook getting up and saying, as he attempted to do today, that the reason was that it was some sort of non-tariff barrier—and, sure as the sun rises in the east in the morning, within but months, ring spot got in and devastated the pawpaw industry in my home State of Queensland.

para.tab: What we are seeing now from this Government is the same lackadaisical attitude. But the question which we on this side of the chamber asked and which this Government has failed to answer is: what is behind this latest move and what is behind the pressure on AQIS to change the rules on the importation of live pigs? Is it because—and I asked this of Senator Cook today and he refused to answer—the pressure has come from Brown and Hatton, a company notorious for its links with the Danes and for its links with Mr Paul Keating, who is now Prime Minister of this country? There is undeniably a stench which hangs over this affair—

talk.start.para: —Porkergate.

—There is a stench which hangs over Porkergate which is not related solely to the natural products of breeding pigs but is related to the unnatural way in which this Government runs the affairs of this nation. There is a stench hanging over this Government because it refuses to come clean and tell the Australian people why it is that all of a sudden Danish requests that have been around since the 1980s leaped to the top of the pile in 1990. It refuses to tell the Australian public what the involvement of the Prime Minister is and what the involvement of other Ministers is. Honourable senators opposite say to this Senate that there has been no involvement; yet the letters that we have tabled show quite clearly that there has been.

para.tab: Moreover, we now find the absurd situation in which letters from AQIS have gone to the industry saying that it is doing this, firstly, because Denmark has an excellent disease record and, secondly, because there has been strong pressure from within the industry. We know quite clearly that Denmark has a terrible disease record in terms of pigs. But, more importantly, we know, from the letters I tabled in the Senate today, that there was no strong pressure from the industry. The Pig Improvement Company, which is one of the leading pig breeders in the nation, the Australian Pork Producers Federation, the Western Australian Pig Producers Association and the New South Wales Farmers Association all oppose the suggestion that we should import live pigs from Denmark and all wrote to AQIS saying that they opposed the suggestion that live pigs should be imported from Denmark. Yet the argument from AQIS was that there was strong pressure from the industry. I do not believe that there was strong widespread pressure from the industry, but I suspect there was strong pressure from one portion of the industry. What portion of the industry was that? Brown and Hatton, the same company which is notorious for its links with the Danes and for its links with the Prime Minister, Mr Paul Keating.

It is not good enough for the Government to try to sweep this under the carpet. It is not good enough for the Government to refuse to answer questions, as Minister Cook did today. It is time that we had the answers, it is time that we had the truth and it is time that this nation knew exactly what was going on in these hallowed halls of power.

talk.start.para: —The matters that Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee have raised are yet further examples of what is turning into an extraordinary situation where normal procedures clearly have not been followed. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service quite clearly and uncomplicatedly stated that the matter had been resurrected, having been around for quite some time, as a result of prime ministerial interest, and then suddenly, after a formal request was made after the matter was clearly shown to be of political significance in this chamber, the story was changed. This is a clear instance of where there is a requirement for the reasons for the change in the story to be presented; it is simply not good enough to say, `We made a slight error in saying `Prime Ministerial'; that is wrong', and then not say whether or not it was ministerial—but leaving the clear inference, because it chose to withdraw only the reference to Prime Ministerial intervention, that there must nonetheless have been some ministerial intervention.

para.tab: The procedures that have not been followed are very important, because there is clearly an attempt to gloss over some major concerns in respect of the animal health area. As Senator O'Chee said, there has been no pressure from the industry, apart from one company that seeks to benefit from the change, and that happens to be the company half owned by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). There is no pressure from the industry for this major change for the importation of genetic material or live pigs. As I understand it—perhaps Senator Boswell or Senator O'Chee could confirm this—the UK has expressed continuing concerns about Danish genetic material and the importation of Danish pigs. That is a matter that those National Party senators know more about than I do.

What I am concerned about is the continuing improper activity that seems to flow through this Porkergate proposition. In the first place, we have had an admission that full information was not provided to the Foreign Investment Review Board in dealing with this whole Danpork proposal. It has been admitted that Mr Keating's interest was hidden from the two applications made for Foreign Investment Review Board approval. There were no annual reports from the operating companies in the group for years. They were formed in 1988. The annual reports of those operating companies are only now dribbling out and they are full of the most extraordinary matters which, I let the Senate know, I intend to raise here in the very near future. These reports are dribbling out despite the fact that the Australian Securities Commission instructed companies in November last year that they should make early reports and that a failure to report in good time would lead to deregistration. I think we are entitled to know why these companies seem still to be able to get away without reporting without being rubbed out.

Talking about procedures not having been followed, we know that the Prime Minister's report to the House of Representatives disclosure of interest authorities was grossly inadequate in that it said simply that he had an investment instead of saying that he had a 50 per cent ownership, and in that it said that he was not a director when in fact he had a nominee as a director. We know all those things. But we only found out because we pursued the matter. We had to hunt and search to find the facts—facts which in many areas are still being withheld from us. Either the Prime Minister is simply obsessively secretive or he has something to hide in this matter. Whichever it is, it appears to be grossly unhealthy.

There was also a failure by the present Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to report, as required, immediately to the previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, when he took up his major stake—if I can use that word—in the pig company. This, of course, was done when he was Treasurer and the requirements of the Cabinet office are that any change in a Minister's assets must be reported immediately to the Prime Minister. I understand that Mr Hawke was not advised of Mr Keating's sudden and substantial interest in the pig companies, in a situation which is now known quite properly as Porkergate, and it obviously would not have been to Mr Keating's advantage to advise him as at that stage he was busy preparing to slaughter Mr Hawke rather than the pigs.

The situation now is that not only are there financial problems but also serious quarantine questions have been raised by Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee. These concerns underline the fact that there seems to be a specific inability for the Prime Minister's company to go about this thing properly and an incredible inability for this Government to handle this matter properly. It is getting to the situation where surely sooner or later there must be some serious questions about whether some kind of inquiry into Porkergate might not be appropriate.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support my colleagues Senator Boswell, Senator O'Chee and Senator Baume in relation to the question that was asked by Senator Boswell concerning the importation of Danish pigs. It is obvious to me that there has been some prime ministerial interference in the position of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. I want to emphasise that over the last two years at Estimates committee hearings I and a number of my colleagues have consistently asked questions of officers of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy relating to what appears to be a weakening in the stance that AQIS has had over a significant number of years—in fact, it goes back 30 or 40 years—to the point where we are putting at risk not only our pig industry but also a number of other livestock industries. It goes even further than that. It relates to seed that is being imported and to the blue-green aphid, which is currently devastating much of the pasture base in this country. When we as a nation have a country that is an island and thus has such a natural advantage, why would we want to take any risk whatsoever by importing product that carries a risk in whatever nature?

para.tab: We get told continually that we cannot use AQIS as a tariff barrier. Nobody is asking anybody to use it as a tariff barrier. What we are asking and what has been asked consistently by the industries involved in this country is that we protect and look after that natural advantage that we have. Why do we have to put it at risk? That is the question that has to be answered. Why would anybody in this nation, regardless of their political background or where they come from, want to put at risk the natural advantage we have by introducing disease and pests into this country?

We should learn from the mistakes that were made in the early days when the knowledge was not available. I am referring to what occurred by the introduction of rabbits and foxes into this nation. Why do we want to repeat the same mistakes over and over again? We can ask anybody in this nation at this time, particularly those living on the eastern side, what devastation the aphids are doing to the pasture lands. The position that has been adopted with regard to AQIS and the interference that is occurring is just criminal. It is too late to think about it afterwards. Why do we want to commit harakiri in this country instead of protecting our genetic base and what we have built up in Australia over the last 200 years?

I congratulate my colleagues on the research that they have carried out on this matter. I just wanted to add my own viewpoint. As far as I am aware, there is not one industry organisation or responsible leader of any of these organisations that supports the current position that is being adopted. One must ask: what is the political gain to the people involved? What is the financial gain to the people involved? Why do they want to go down a course of potential devastation to a whole host of industries in this nation by becoming lax in enforcing quarantine requirements for bringing these various things into this country, whether they be live pigs, embryo, seed or other forms of imports?

I want to stand here with the people who have raised this particular matter and others on this side of the House and say that it is about time we took control of our Quarantine and Inspection Service in a proper manner so that it is allowed to carry out its function without interference by politicians who have something to gain from it.

talk.start.para: —I will not take long. I know that some of the honourable senators who spoke to this motion genuinely care passionately about the issue of quarantine, although there is nothing in the history of the country to indicate that that is exclusive to people on that side. I accept that those who spoke about that matter do care about it. To the extent that they are raising legitimate concerns about quarantine, whether they are right or wrong, I accept the bona fides with which they did it. Over and above that, we had a bit of an attempt to drag a red herring across the political agenda to try to draw some attention away from some very serious problems, particularly those that the Queensland National Party has with regard to sugar. I understand that. It is a pity it took such great length.

para.tab: The only other comment I want to make is that we are getting to an absurd situation where Ministers are allowed two minutes to answer questions and people are taking upon themselves the right to debate for 10 minutes at least in response to those two minute answers, including complaining about the fact that the answer was not comprehensive enough when they have just limited the time. We have just spent one hour and 50 minutes on motions to take note of answers, which is significantly longer than Question Time itself took. I have nothing more to add in response to the motion that has been moved.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

petition.title: Constitutional Monarchy
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

para.tab: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies

provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

petition.title: Baltic Nations: Russian Disarmament
petition.para: To the Honourable The President and Members of The Senate in Parliament Assembled:

para.tab: We the undersigned, endorse the decision taken by the Baltic Council of the ACT on the 51st anniversary of the mass deportation of Baltic people on 13/14 June 1941 by the Soviet Union, to call for the prompt total withdrawal of Russian armed forces from the three independent Baltic Nations of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.
In calling for the removal of the forces we wish to bring to the attention of Senators and the Government the following situations in the Baltic States:
there are between 120,000 and 200,000 fully armed and equipped Russian military personnel with their dependants dispersed throughout the three nations;
they are there against the wishes of the local populations and their governments;
they act with total disregard of the laws and boundaries of these countries;

they are responsible for open threats to resort to military action to retain or enhance their presence, particularly if the present Russian Government is replaced by one in which the military is influential;
they occupy large areas of land on which military exercises are conducted and from which local authorities are excluded;
they are the only fully equipped and trained military forces in the three nations;
they are a serious destabilising force in the social, economic and political life of these nations and pose a visible and real threat to their newly acquired independence;
Russia has given no positive responses to any attempts to negotiate agreements for the withdrawal of its forces; and
Russia has indicated its unilateral intention to retain a military presence in the Baltic, for example the naval base at Paldiski in Estonia as well as bases in Latvia and Lithuania.

We request that Senators give bi-partisan support to directing the Australian Government, in the course of its bilateral relations with Russia and at the multilateral level, to actively support and promote the Baltic Nations' efforts to achieve a prompt and orderly withdrawal of Russian military forces and armaments from Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Withdrawal of Russian Armed Forces from Estonia
petition.para: Canberra Eestlaste Koondis P.O. Box 3,
Canberra Estonian Community Lyneham, ACT 2602
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

On behalf of the Estonian Community in the ACT, we the undersigned request the Australian Parliament and the Government to support international efforts to have the Russian Government implement a genuine program for withdrawing its armed forces totally from the independent nation of Estonia.
Honourable Members, in calling for the complete removal of Russian forces and their armaments we point out that:
.there are tens of thousands of fully armed and equipped Russian forces and their dependants in Estonia, only the Russian Government knows the exact number;
.the Russian Government is making no genuine effort to remove the forces, indicating that it could take from five to seven years;

.the commanders of the Russian forces frequently issue unveiled threats to use force to maintain their presence. This could be particularly dangerous if the current Russian Government is replaced by one in which the military is dominant;
.large areas of Estonian sovereign territory are occupied by these forces and local authorities are entirely excluded from these areas;
.Russia has indicated its intention to retain some military bases in Estonia;
.the destabilising presence of the forces seriously affects the morale of the indigenous population and undermines social, economic and political development;
.the Estonian people cannot feel their nation is independent while a very large and visible occupation force postures its might; and
.as long as Russian forces remain in Estonia many foreign companies have stated that they are reluctant to risk much needed investment in Estonia.

We request that Honourable Senators urge the Australian Government to give increased emphasis in its relations with Russia, and in the United Nations, to supporting all efforts to bring about a speedy and total withdrawal of Russian armed forces from Estonia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

speech.para: 1.HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION—Report on Review of Permanent Exemptions under the Sex Discrimination Act 1984—section 46 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)
—I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 14 September, from Senator Hill:

proctext.para: Dear Mr President
Pursuant to standing order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need to condemn comments by the Prime Minister that Australia `shouldn't have a Senate'.
