Is the proposal supported?

tab.emphasis: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

speech.para: The need to condemn comments by the Prime Minister that Australia `shouldn't have a Senate'.

The attack last week by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on this institution, on the Senate of Australia, cannot go unanswered. It typifies both Mr Keating's ignorance and his arrogance in taking the opportunity of a school visit to this city to attack the Senate in the following terms. First, he attacked the Senate by saying that it frustrated the House of Representatives through parties in which he did not have a majority. Secondly, he basically said that we should not have a Senate. In other words, he made an attack on the very existence of this chamber. Thirdly, he said that the Senate was an impediment to the smooth operation of the parliamentary system. What he means by that is that it is an impediment to his always getting his way in the terms that he requires.

para.tab: That is what this chamber is all about; it is a chamber of accountability. It requires accountability of government—both in its legislative program and in its finances—in running the financial affairs of government. Principally, this Senate is proud of its contribution in both those functions. It has a highly developed system. In some ways it has been an international leader in the systems that it has developed in an effort to require proper accountability of government.

If this Senate were not fulfilling that function, what other body within this democracy would be doing so? The answer, of course, is simply none, because the Prime Minister basically controls and rides roughshod over his parliamentary Party, over the Caucus. His view is paramount; it prevails at all times. He treats the House of Representatives in exactly the same way. He has the numbers in the House of Representatives; he therefore refuses to permit proper debate and proper scrutiny by that chamber, using those numbers to thwart such proper debate and functioning.

We see it at the end of each parliamentary session with the number of Bills that are forced through under the guillotine in the House of Representatives with literally almost no debate at all, no opportunity to scrutinise the legislation, no opportunity to require proper accountability of Ministers and no opportunity for any committee stage debate to look at the detail of the legislation. This happens in each of the two sessions—in the middle of the year and at the end of the year. The legislation is simply pushed through and the Prime Minister regards that as his definition of democracy. This chamber does not.

This chamber has a role, a function, to ensure that that does not occur, that within the democratic process in this country there is some attempt at scrutinising the role of government. If this chamber were not doing it, no-one would be doing it and Australian democracy would be the loser. It is interesting that the vast majority of Australians agree with that point of view. They recognise the importance of this chamber as a safeguard and they want this chamber to remain, whether or not the Prime Minister is of the same view.

From the statement that the Prime Minister made last week to schoolchildren, we know that his view is the traditional Labor view, the view that was stated in the platform of the Labor Party up until 1980—that is, that the Senate of Australia should be abolished. It should be abolished because, in the view of those in the Labor Party, it provides some constraint or restraint on their behaviour and Prime Minister Keating is not prepared to tolerate that restraint. Whenever the Prime Minister runs up against some form of accountability, some form of questioning, his answer is always to attack and abuse. He does it again: in this instance, it is the Senate, the institution of the Senate, that is the target. We are not concerned about individuals—he can attack individuals within this place—but he attacks the safeguard contained within the Constitution of Australia that gives the Australian people some security that a Prime Minister will not ride roughshod over their interests, as this Prime Minister would seek to do.

The Prime Minister divides his attack into three parts. He says that his program is frustrated. Mr Acting Deputy President, if you look at the functioning of this Senate, you will find that it does not frustrate the program of government; it accepts the program of government but, where possible, will improve the legislation. It will do so not only in this chamber but also within its committee system. It will do so within the standing committees that have been developed. It will do so through the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. In the case of subordinate legislation, it will do so through the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. This Senate does it well.

The Regulations and Ordinances Committee and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee ensure the protection of the civil liberties of individuals in this country. In that area, this Senate led the world and it is a precedent that has been taken up in so many other democracies. We are pleased about that; we are pleased that the people of Australia get that added protection that Mr Keating does not seem to think they should be entitled to. We will fight to preserve that and we have no shame in doing that because it is in the national interest.

The Prime Minister says we should not have the Senate at all. That is a prejudice from the old Labor position. It is not the first time he has said that or the first time he has spoken offensively about this chamber. Speaking offensively is probably what he does best. On another occasion the Prime Minister referred to the Senate as `the swill of Australian politics'.

talk.start.para: —He's into pigs.

—He is in the pig business. What a highly intellectual contribution to the Australian debate from our Prime Minister. How highly offensive but how typical it is of Mr Keating. He excels at personal abuse, at being personally offensive. He is not the only one on his side who has spoken in similar terms of this chamber. We can look at the role that was taken by the now Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans). He saw it as his personal responsibility—
—To undermine.

—He saw it as his personal responsibility to try to undermine the Senate from within. Senator Patterson will obviously remember that article which appeared in the
Canberra Times
back in 1978 which foreshadowed the contribution that Senator Evans would make within this chamber. He said: `The way to abolish the Senate or at least muzzle it is to white ant it from within'. That is a now Minister of the Crown speaking in that way. That was his attitude on coming into this chamber. He was prepared to take all the opportunities and advantages of this chamber to pursue his political objectives whilst having put down in writing that his real objective was to destroy the Senate. I guess that typifies Senator Evans. Senator Kemp has a pretty strong argument that Senator Evans in fact takes more benefits than most in the form of titles—`the honourable', `Senator' and `Queen's Counsel'. He will take the benefits side, but he will not take the deficit side. Senator Evans has also stated:

speech.para: If one believes, as I do, along with all good Labor men and women true, that the Senate ought to be abolished, or at the very least deprived, of its capacity to destroy properly elected governments, there is surely no better forum in which to promote these insidious heresies than the institution itself.

para.tab: The Senate has by all accounts always been a silly and pompous institution—

speech.para: this is Senator Evans talking about others being pompous—
but now it is obvious to most people that it has become a very dangerous one as well.

What arrant nonsense. Of course, I have to concede that Senator Evans did try to get out of this chamber. He did seek preselection to move to the other place, but his own side would not have him. I will not go on, because many of my colleagues wish to make a contribution to this debate in defence of this institution and its contribution to Australian political life, particularly to detail some of the ways in which it improves the political life of this country. I will end my contribution with a quote from one of the great men of all time, John Stuart Mill, when he was looking at the case for upper chambers. What he says fits particularly aptly alongside the attitude of Mr Keating. He states:

The consideration which tells most, in my judgment, in favour of two Chambers (and this I do regard as of some moment) is the evil effect produced upon the mind of any holder of power, whether an individual or an assembly, by the consciousness of having only themselves to consult.
Does that not fit the mould of Keating so well? He continues:

It is important that no set of persons should, in great affairs, be able, even temporarily, to make their sic volo prevail without asking any one else for his consent. A majority in a single assembly, when it has assumed a permanent character—when composed of the same persons habitually acting together, and always assured of victory in their own House—easily becomes despotic and overweening—
that sounds very much like Keating—

if released from the necessity of considering whether its acts will be concurred in by another constituted authority. The same reason which induced the Romans to have two consuls makes it desirable there should be two Chambers: that neither of them may be exposed to the corrupting influence of undivided power, even for the space of a single year.

My share of the time is up, but I leave the Senate with that comment because it is this Senate that places some constraint upon the potentially corrupting influence and undivided power of this Prime Minister.

talk.start.para: —It is a very sad commentary on the priorities of some people that we have today this so-called matter of urgency that we must talk about, and that we must get ourselves in a lather about ourselves and our own importance. If one walked out into the street and asked the people of Australia, `What is it that you think should be debated as a matter of urgency in the Parliament today?', one would not find any who said, `We should be talking about the preservation of the Senate'. One might find a few who said, `We should be talking about tariffs'. But we understand why those opposite do not want to talk about that. They would rather talk about the Senate. They would rather talk about trade. They waffled on, trying to paper over their problems about that rather ineffectively today; but, no, they would rather have an urgency motion about the Senate.
—South Australians would want to talk about the car industry.

—Those opposite would rather talk about the Senate than come in here and defend their States' interests, such as the car industry. We could talk about the goods and services tax, but they do not want to talk about that. They would rather talk about the Senate. The doctors of Australia are planning to go on strike, but those opposite say, `We don't think that is important. We would rather talk about ourselves'. The only way people want to talk about jobs here is in the passionate defence of their own. They are concerned about the Senate as a matter of urgency. What a trivial diversion from the great issues that this institution was set up to talk about—we have to come in here and talk about the Senate.

para.tab: We know the people in the street would not think this is a matter of priority but if, instead of asking them, we told them, that on this day, 14 September 1992, the Senate thought the matter it should discuss as a matter of urgency was itself and its defences against this slanderous and potentially fatal attack upon its future, they would only be strengthened in their view that perhaps the Prime Minister was right after all. Nobody of reasonable concern could consider that this is the most important issue in Australia today.

We know that this is a threat that is not going to eventuate. The Prime Minister in no way conveyed the slightest intention of doing away with the bicameral system. There has been rivalry between members of the respective chambers for as long as we have had two chambers, not only here but also in every parliament in Australia. Members of the House of Representatives talk about this chamber as the B-grade. Senators talk derogatively, as Senator Hill just did, about the role of the House of Representatives. It has been going on since Federation. It has been going on in the States since self-government—since we had a bicameral system—and it will go on. In a sense, that is a product of those people's pride in their respective chambers.

The Prime Minister is not proposing to take any initiative with regard to the abolition of the Senate but those opposite are horrified because he has a view they do not agree with. Let us bring out the thought police and say, `He has had a contrary view; he disagrees with Senator Walters'.

talk.start.para: —This is pathetic. You are pathetic.

—Senator Walters should take away the mirror. I thank her for her generous assistance. No-one is going to be threatening the precious virtue of those opposite. They may stay over there pristine for as long as they wish, and may it be a very long time. There is no serious proposal that anybody will be initiating moves to get rid of the Senate.
—You don't even have your eyes open.

—I have actually got my eyes open; I just cannot stand looking at those opposite. Nobody is seriously proposing to abolish the Senate. But I have to say that when I look around the world at democracies which operate quite effectively without two chambers of parliament, it reminds me of Kim Beazley Sr saying that Australians should be so concerned about their poor colleagues in New Zealand that we should mount an armada and go over there to defend them in their democracy because they only have one House of parliament, they do not have any States and they have one vote, one value. What a shocking condemnation of their democracy that they should have those three things.

para.tab: Of course, he said that in a State where these great defenders of the checking role of the upper House have, for 100 years, conspired to ensure that they always have the numbers in that upper House and that even when the Opposition—the Labor Party in that instance—gets 50 per cent at two elections in a row, it cannot win control of the upper House just in case it might be a constraint on the conservatives. It is all right for it to be a constraint on Labor governments, but not on conservatives, who have had control of that upper House for 100 years without a word of concern about the lack of check and balance upon conservative governments in Western Australia that have rorted the system for 100 years.

Let us get down off that high and mighty perch about the great significance the abolition of the Senate would have for the Australian democracy. Frankly, it would not matter very much at all. It would not make very much effective difference at all. When one studies the democratic processes of unicameral and bicameral democracies, one sees that the procedural significance and the democratic distinction is very hard to find. The Senate does play a useful role, but if it were abolished the House of Representatives would adapt, as it does in every other unicameral democracy.

Let us keep some sense of perspective about our lather of enthusiasm for ourselves and get a sense of perspective about the issues that we should really be dealing with in Australia today. This is certainly not it. There are very important questions of concern to a lot of people—not on the opposition benches, perhaps, and that is their right—

talk.start.para: —One million unemployed?

—That is right. Let us have a debate about that. It is a lot more useful than this. There is very real concern about the powers of the Senate. There are real concerns about the abuse of the power of the Senate. Have we not had a glorious example of it today? Have we not had a glorious example at 25 minutes to six? We had Question Time and then nearly two hours of self-righteous indignation about motions to take note of answers which were limited to two minutes. Then we had passionate speeches that the answers were not comprehensive enough. People chose to speak for 10 minutes on the motions to take note of those two-minute answers.

para.tab: Of course, as soon as I say that perhaps there is a bit of filibustering going on to waste time, there is shock, horror and indignation. What a terrible suggestion for anybody to make! If that is not what is happening, it is a monumental waste of time and a monumental abuse of the powers of the Senate and everybody knows that it regularly happens.

It is no wonder that people get frustrated with the Senate. It is no wonder that people get frustrated with the abuse of power of this chamber because it happens over and over again. We get people come in here with the filibuster. We get people come in here with needless and continuing duplication—for example, the duplication of what has happened in the House of Representatives where the same second reading speeches are given here that were given there—but nobody wants to smooth and streamline the procedures to do away with that duplication.

We have the Estimates committee farce of the leadership of the Opposition in the Senate agreeing that we should not have the duplication in this chamber that we have at the committees, but they cannot deliver. They get rolled by the loonies in their party room and we wind up having to have the duplication again, and do the whole thing twice. Is it any wonder that people are frustrated about this chamber and the way it performs when it insists upon doing things twice; when it insists upon, at enormous cost to the taxpayer, sitting to do nothing and then failing properly to do the things it is supposed to do?

What happens if somebody expresses a bit of disagreement? This is a democracy, but one is not allowed to disagree with the views of those opposite about the nature and role of our democracy. One is not allowed to say that we should only have one House of parliament. This is a scandal. Call out the thought police. Someone has a different view to those opposite. They say, `It is one of the great scandals and must be debated as a motion of urgency. Let's not get on to dealing with the sales tax Bills'. The businesses in Australia are saying to the Opposition, `Let's get on and do it. Let's get on to debating all the other legislation that is on the program'. No. At the end of it, those opposite will all be crying and saying, `Why are you trying to rush this legislation through at the end? We haven't sought to obstruct your program; we only sat around spending two hours talking about ourselves'.

talk.start.para: —What about the Prime Minister bagging the Senate?

—If Senator Teague thinks that this motion is the most important and urgent thing for us to waste our time on in here today, he should go out and tell the car workers in Elizabeth. If those opposite think that this is the most important issue, they should go out and tell the people in their various constituencies that their concerns are not as important as us having an urgency debate about this.

para.tab: I have not been in Parliament as long as some. I have not endured this place as long as my good colleagues Senator Walsh or Senator Walters, who have both been here a long time; I have only been here four and a half years. I have seen some great wastes of time in this place, but I have not seen anything to equal an urgency motion getting us in a lather about the fact that the Prime Minister has told a few people that he thinks it would be better if we did not have—

talk.start.para: —Not a few people—students.
—Students—so much the better. Let them think about some alternative viewpoints. If Senator Patterson does not like it, she should express the opposite view.
—I do. I go around to school after school after school preaching the importance of the Senate.

—That is fine. I do not mind if students have a different view from me and I do not mind if they hear views I disagree with. I am fairly happy to be involved in the debate; I just wish that we did not have to divert our serious time and attention away—
—Why don't you sit down? If you don't think it is important, why don't you sit down?

—Because Senator Vanstone will only get up and waste more time and bore everybody stupid. I went to Senator Hill at the start of this debate and said, `Why are we wasting two hours on this? Why don't we just agree to have one speaker on each side and after 15 minutes we'll all be finished?'. No, he would not agree. If those opposite think that I will allow them to have 25 people say the same things instead of the 10 who are already on their list, they have another think coming. There is not the slightest chance of that happening. If they would give the slightest intimation that my finishing seven minutes early would finish the debate and we could get on—
—It will save seven minutes.
—No, it will not. A lot of those opposite would get up. If we could have had a guarantee that the debate would be shortened, we would have agreed. I put that proposition and it was rejected.
—You sit down and we will not take that time.

—Why not have all Opposition senators not speak; we could then hear Senator Coulter and finish. What about that? We could all put up with that deal. One speaker on each side and then we will call it a day and get on with some business. How about that? No way. They all have to get up and speak for five minutes at a time—and some of those people who said they would not do so are actually on the list.
—He has now got to resort to reading the speakers list.

—I have not really had to do that. I will not learn anything from what is on it and, I regret to say, nor will the Australian people. What we have today is a desperate attempt from a number of people. One can imagine the debate that went on in the Opposition party room with everybody trying to be more indignant than the others by trying to prove they were more enthusiastic about the Senate than everybody else. What a wonderful debate that would have been! I am only glad I was not there.

para.tab: What I am concerned about is that it indicates to the people of Australia the priorities of this chamber. After we have had a whole range of opportunities for all Opposition senators to indicate what they think is the most important thing in Australia that we should be debating today—

talk.start.para: —Yes, getting rid of your Government.
—I would rather be talking about whether the Opposition thinks that is a better idea than this. In the course of this debate, those opposite have gone—
—Perhaps if I go out again, he might stop.
—It will certainly make the place more attractive. Today we at last have a clear indication of the priorities of the Opposition and what it thinks is the most important issue.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is against the Standing Orders of the Senate to be tediously repetitious. The speaker, Senator McMullan, is vacuous and repetitious. I do not believe that he is speaking relevantly on this matter and it would be of great service to the Senate if he sat down.
—With respect, I accept Senator Teague's expertise in that matter.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)
—I have not yet ruled on the point of order. This could be a very serious point of order, Senator McMullan. I ignore the point of order. I understand that Senator McMullan is about to finish his speech anyway, and I imagine he will be relevant again for the next five minutes.

talk.start.para: —I have actually been referring regularly to the terms of the motion; I keep coming back to them. I accept that, whatever Senator Teague might not know about this subject, he knows a lot about tedious repetition, so I accept his right to raise the point of order even if he is wrong.

para.tab: I return to what has caused this great concern. Mr Keating made informal observations about our parliamentary system to a group of students last Thursday. They were never at any stage intended to convey any plan to do away with our bicameral system. No such plan exists and everybody knows no such plan exists. That is why this motion is such a nonsense. This urgency motion is a supersensitive and self-indulgent response to what were no more than a few casual remarks. As I said earlier—and this is repetition, but it is not tedious—honourable senators who support the motion will be in danger of confirming some of Mr Keating's observation in the minds of many Australians.

talk.start.para: —So he did mean it.

—If Senator Kemp thinks that that is what those words mean, he is welcome to that misunderstanding; I am not surprised, because it happens often. For us to be concerned about the fact that members of the House of Representatives criticise this chamber or express views about it, is as stupid as the House of Representatives wasting its time because Senator Walters, in her response to Mr Keating's remarks, on radio on Friday said some very critical things about the House of Representatives. Why should she not? She is entitled to, and she made them fairly vigorously. I have not been listening to the House today, but I very much doubt that its members wasted their time by debating Senator Walters's comments. Why should they? Senator Walters is entitled to her point of view and they are entitled to disagree; it happens to be a democracy.

para.tab: I do not understand the shock and horror. If some proposal was being contemplated or brought forward that we should abolish the Senate, we would have a very big debate about it. But everybody knows that that is not seriously under contemplation. Everybody knows that there has never been any such proposal in contemplation this century, and nor will there be. Let us get away from pretending that we have some urgent motion about our own passionate defence of our self-interest. Let us get rid of this silly motion and get the debate, with its tedious repetition due to a lengthy speakers list, out of the way. Let us get back to the business for which we were elected and sent here and for which we get paid, which is dealing with the legislation that is before us and the issues that are causing concern to the people of Australia—trade and tariff policies, tax, jobs—

talk.start.para: —Unemployment.

—Yes, employment and unemployment and industrial relations. These are the issues that we would have the time to debate if only we did not waste it in this way. If we must have a debate about the Senate, let us have a serious debate about its proper powers and the abuse of its powers, such as the one that we are seeing here today. If this is an urgent matter which we should deal with, all I can say is that it condemns its advocates rather than those which it seeks to criticise.

speech.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I have heard Senator McMullan speak on many occasions, and I have to say that that was not one of his better contributions to debate. I thought that Senator Teague, in his point of order, was about to mispronounce the word `repetitious' and say `reptilian'. This urgency motion is rather carefully worded. It says:

speech.para: The need to condemn comments by the Prime Minister that Australia `shouldn't have a Senate'.

It seems to me that the issue is one of some importance, because these words, in relation to the Senate, were spoken by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to a group of schoolchildren from his former school and not in the context of a serious debate by adults before people who could make some critical assessment of his proposals.

para.tab: I think in that context it was dishonest of the Prime Minister to use that particular forum to float an idea before schoolchildren who were not capable of—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Coulter, you used the word `dishonest' in relation to the Prime Minister. That is unparliamentary and I ask you to withdraw it.
—I will withdraw the remark, Mr Acting Deputy President. However, I did not say that the Prime Minister was dishonest. I said I believed that that act of the Prime Minister was dishonest. But if you—
—I insist both ways.

—Okay. I withdraw the remark in both senses. It was inappropriate for the Prime Minister to choose that forum to raise what is really an important issue—whether we should have an upper chamber. It is particularly inappropriate to do so in front of schoolchildren who, as I say, are not in a position to examine critically what he was saying to them.

para.tab: Moreover, the Prime Minister went on to talk about the House of Representatives `putting on a better show'. I think the Prime Minister revealed himself as someone who does not fully understand or appreciate the gravity of what goes on in both Houses of this Parliament. After all, we are formulating laws in regard to the very things that Senator McMullan talked about. We are discussing issues to do with such things as unemployment, tariffs and the GST. We are discussing a whole lot of important things. Yet the Prime Minister says to schoolchildren, `We should not have a Senate because the House of Representatives puts on a better show'. Surely that is denigrating the whole function of parliament.

What he is really saying is that parliament is really all about a theatrical performance—and we all know what goes on down in the other place at Question Time—rather than the business of better government. I think his reference to a `better show', linked with his remark about smoothing the processes of government, indicates a megalomaniacal wish to have the processes of his Government smoothed without the intervention of this Senate casting a critical eye over those legislative processes.

Of course, the Senate should be an impediment to those smooth processes because, as we all know, so much of what passes for debate in the House of Representatives is simply decided as a result of number crunching. When the time is up, the numbers vote and the party with the majority simply gets the vote irrespective of how many good points are raised by whichever party happens to be in opposition at the time.

It is unfortunate that the very important role of the Senate in relation to legislation—namely, the close scrutiny of legislation by a chamber in which for some years no party has had sufficient numbers to get legislation through without the support of another party—is not noticed a lot more by people in the media. The media still has over-interest in what goes on in the House of Representatives to the exclusion of an awareness of the very important legislative changes and amendments which are made in the Senate.

For quite a number of years it has been the Senate in which important amendments and changes to legislation have been made. The Senate has upheld the appropriate processes of Parliament, which have been neglected in the House of Representatives simply because of the nature of the election process in that chamber. For instance, in the last 12 months we dealt with a very important package of fisheries legislation. The Senate considered a package of six Bills which was designed to restructure totally the management of fisheries which come under Federal government control.

The legislation went through the House of Representatives in 45 minutes with no amendment whatsoever. The legislation was then introduced into the Senate and was referred to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. The Committee sought evidence from the CSIRO, State fishery experts, tourism interests, conservation interests, and professional and recreational fishermen. As a result, over 80 amendments were proposed to that package of fisheries Bills. Those Bills were incomparably improved because of the presence of this Senate. Australia would not have been well served had the processes of government been smoothed, to use Mr Keating's terminology, and if the Senate had not existed.

A larger number of amendments were inserted into a package of social service legislation as a consequence of the Senate committee processes. We can look at recent debates in this chamber on superannuation. Irrespective of what one might think about the end result, very significant changes were made to superannuation legislation as a consequence of the fact that in this place serious debate must occur and serious amendments must be considered. Nobody has the power simply to push things through on the numbers without that proper consideration being given.

Industrial relations legislation is another example of very significant changes being made. When Senator Peter Baume—a senator who had been a member of this chamber for a very long time—gave his valedictory address he remarked how significant it was that the Senate was the place in recent years in which the major portion of changes and improvement to legislation occurred. He said that it was in the Senate that the proper government of this country was managed.

Let me say something about the role of the Senate, Independents, minor parties and, indeed, oppositions. It is important to recognise that there is a debate going on out there in the community. This debate is raised in today's
Canberra Times
. I refer to the issue of what in fact constitutes a mandate and whether the party that gains the largest number of seats in the lower House has a mandate to carry through its legislation without any intrusion by the Senate.

I would simply observe that because of the single member electorate system it is possible for a party to gain control of the House of Representatives with a very small proportion of the total vote. Indeed, if there were a three-party contest in each electorate—and often there are more parties than that—all that a party would need to gain to take control of the lower House is 25 per cent of the vote plus one vote in 50 per cent of the seats plus one seat and 25 per cent of the vote from the party that gets the second preferences. That amounts to just over 12 per cent of the vote. So, theoretically it would be possible for a party to gain control of the lower House with somewhere between 12 and 13 per cent of the vote.

However, because of the proportional representation system, to gain control of the Senate a party must gain the support of more than 50 per cent of the voters in more than 50 per cent of the electorates. This is, indeed, the democratic chamber. Consequently, it is appropriate that when legislation comes to this chamber the majority here should determine whether that legislation passes or whether that legislation passes with amendment. Let me be specific. The goods and services tax was raised in the editorial in today's
Canberra Times
. If the Democrats make it quite clear, as we have, that we are opposed to the goods and services tax and we gain a certain percentage of vote at the next election—

talk.start.para: —There is not much chance of that.
—we will have a mandate from those voters—irrespective, Senator Kemp, of how many—to carry forward that policy.

para.tab: If the Opposition were to form the Government and the present Government were to form the Opposition, and if the Labor Party went into the election with a policy of opposing the GST and got a mandate from its voters so that the present Opposition, which would be the Government, did not have a majority in this chamber, that would mean it would not have the support of the majority of Australians. The Labor Party and the Democrats combined would have a mandate from the majority of Australians to block or to modify the GST legislation, whatever that will be when we see it.

To argue otherwise, as people from the
Canberra Times
and a few others have attempted to do, would mean that the Independents and minor parties must go back on their word to the electorate. Indeed, if one follows the logic of it, the Opposition would also have to go back on its word to the electorate and vote for legislation to which it was philosophically opposed. Consequently, there would be no further use for the Independents, for the minor parties or for an opposition. One would finish up not just with a single chamber parliament, but with no opposition at all; and one would see the extinction of democracy.

Not only do I strongly defend the Senate, but also I defend the right of every honourable senator in this chamber to vote according to the policy which that senator put before the electorate at the time he or she was elected. If there is a majority of honourable senators in favour of or opposed to particular legislation, then that is the way that legislation will be dealt with.

If indeed we are going to get rid of one House of Parliament, then it should be the House of Representatives, not the Senate, because the Senate is indeed the democratically elected House. As I have already pointed out, it is in this chamber that most of the legislation is constructively modified and amended and dealt with according to the systems in this place and particularly the committee system.

Returning briefly to the motion before us, it is not that we are debating whether we should have a Senate or not—as Senator McMullan has said, that is not a matter of urgency; it is a matter which will be around for some time. What is of great concern is that the Prime Minister should have used the words he did to a group of schoolchildren. Those words indicate an inappropriate level of behaviour on the part of the Prime Minister with schoolchildren and an unwillingness to accept the gravity of the legislation which is dealt with in this place. Instead those words place emphasis on the theatrical performance in the House of Representatives, rather than on that important aspect of dealing with important legislation—legislation which does indeed deal with the issues of unemployment, tariff reductions, stimulating industry, trade and all those other things that Senator McMullan indicated. These are the important things. I think the Prime Minister's remarks do not indicate that he accepts these as the important issues which they really are.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —The statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that Australia does not need a Senate is really the statement of a man who has no regard whatsoever for the parliamentary checks and balances inherent in a democratic society, a man who believes that all power should reside in the Executive—that is, in the Government—and therefore that the Parliament should be subservient to the Executive, and a man who is so consumed by the lust for power that he will do anything to trample underfoot any curbs to that power. Coalition speakers today in this debate will deal with a host of concerns that all Australians should have about Mr Keating's desire to see the Senate abolished. In the five minutes available to me, I wish to devote my remarks to just one of these issues and that is the rights of the Australian States and Territories in our Federation or Commonwealth.

para.tab: The founding fathers quite deliberately and correctly decided in the 1890s, when the concept of federation was being debated, that the new federation, which was born on 1 January 1901, should have a bicameral parliamentary system. It did this for very good reasons. The Senate was to be two things: the House of review and the House which protected the rights of the States. I am sure that the role of the Senate as a House of review will be the main focus in this debate today. The gross incompetence of this Government over the last 10 years that it has been in office has only been curbed at all by the vigilance and diligence of the Senate, which has corrected time and time again dreadful legislation which abused people's civil liberties, which was sloppy legislation, which was regulatory legislation and which was just sheer bad legislation. I will not go any further on the House of review aspect; others will do that. It is in terms of the rights of the States that I want to address my remarks.

There would have been no federation, of course, without the agreement to establish the Senate, because the smaller States, in particular, would not have been prepared to join. They feared that the larger States of New South Wales and Victoria would have all the say, and that their rights would be neglected and, indeed, abused. That is why we have an equal number of senators from each State, regardless of the population of each individual State.

Although it is correct to say that, over recent decades at least, voting in the Senate has been along party lines rather than along State lines—I certainly acknowledge that—I think that equally there is no doubt at all that the existence of the Senate has acted as an important watchdog over the rights of the States.

talk.start.para: —How long since it has done that?

—I believe, contrary to honourable senators opposite, that that is an essential requirement of any true federal system. The Prime Minister does not want that because he does not want to protect the rights of the States. Mr Keating is and always has been a centralist through and through. He believes that all power, all knowledge, all wisdom, resides in a central government, a Federal government, in Canberra, and his whole political life has been built around that.

para.tab: He has not been on his own, because for decades it was the official policy of the Labor Party to abolish the Senate. That has only changed in recent years, but there are still members of this Senate on the Labor side who have fought long and hard within their own party over many years to have the Senate abolished. Senator Evans is perhaps the classic example; he is on the record time and time again for wanting to abolish the Senate. He first put it to the national Labor conference back in 1979. As recently as 31 May 1988, which is only four years or so ago, he said in this place that he believed:

speech.para: . . . along with all good Labor men and women true, that the Senate ought to be abolished . . .

So let there be no doubt that it is the underlying wish of many people in this chamber—Senator Walsh I know is another one—to abolish the Senate. Very importantly, that would have the effect of abolishing the rights of the States to be protected in a true federal system.

para.tab: That is an essential difference between this Government and the alternative coalition government. We on this side of the chamber happen to believe that in a true federation there is a proper and responsible role for each of the three spheres of government, and that all power and knowledge does not and should not reside in the Federal Government. We believe that the States do have a very real and important role to play and that the rights of the States, without any doubt at all, would be trampled on and trammelled if the proposal mooted yet again by the Prime Minister, that this nation of ours does not need a Senate, were to come into operation. One could not think of a more undemocratic action for any Prime Minister to propose. That is the reason the coalition has moved this amendment, and that is why the Prime Minister's statement needs to be roundly condemned by all Australians.

talk.start.para: —I take issue this evening with some remarks made by Senator McMullan. In my view, Senator McMullan on many occasions comes into this place under the pretence of being a reasonable man. He puts his view in a calm and, what seems to be, reasonable manner only to disguise the fact that there is not a lot of reason at all behind what he says. That is in contrast to someone like Senator Ray, who does not necessarily put his view in a way that comes over as being calm and reasoned but by and large usually is, even though one might not agree with the reasons in themselves.

para.tab: I would like to draw attention to some of the remarks made by Senator McMullan. The first remark he made is that we should have a sense of perspective and that sense of perspective, he says, should tell us that this is not an issue we should be talking about. We should, for example, be talking about what the Government should be doing for the one million people it has made unemployed. But, of course, that is his version, his sense of perspective. His sense of perspective clearly does not put at the base of all issues having a properly functioning parliamentary system. He says there is no plan to get rid of the Senate—and I will come to that in a minute.

I simply make the point first off that, by any sense of perspective, in order for people to enjoy the rights and freedoms that they now do enjoy, an absolute precondition for issues to be properly debated—sensible and important issues like unemployment, trade policy, tariff policy, all those sorts of things—is that we have a proper parliamentary system. So the question of whether we should have a bicameral system in fact comes before all of those issues and, from my sense of perspective, therefore, is more important in itself than any one of those issues on its own.

Secondly, Senator McMullan says that no such plan exists. Since when has this chamber been restricted to discussing things where there is a plan on behalf of the Executive to undertake a particular course of action? It is not my understanding that the Senate is so restricted, nor do I think is it the understanding of anyone else here. I am sorry that Senator McMullan in his 4 1/2 years has not learnt that this place is not restricted to discussing things that the Executive has a plan for. This place is not restricted by that at all. I do not know why he even raises that as a point of debate which he thinks has any merit. He then goes on with an overdramatisation of the case. He says that, because we want to discuss this issue, we are bringing in the thought police, and is it not shocking that because someone has a different view from ours we have to discuss it—quite missing the point altogether.

I do not have a problem with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) having a different view from mine on any issue. In fact, it only confirms in my mind that my views are right and his are wrong. Of course there is going to be debate on this issue and all others—and of course there should be—but I take offence at Senator McMullan suggesting that this is not an appropriate place to have such a debate. He suggests that we can have a debate on the important issues—for example, what type of parliamentary system we want—when we are talking to schoolchildren but that we should not have such a debate in this chamber. In my view, that clearly is not an acceptable proposition for him to be putting.

Let us get to the question of what are the important issues. He seems to have a false logic of saying, `This is not an important enough issue for us to be discussing here'. I have already dealt with why I think the parliamentary system is the prime issue that we should always keep in our minds, that we should always be promoting debate on and that we should always be trying to get the public more interested in. But it begs the question: if it is not important enough for us to be discussing it here, why is it important enough for the Prime Minister to be raising it with schoolchildren? If the most important issues of the day are unemployment, tariff policy, monetary policy and the incompetence of this Government, why does the Prime Minister not go and explain the one million unemployed to the schoolchildren and leave the distracting issue—which Senator McMullan sees it as being—of the Senate's survival or otherwise to others? So, quite frankly, I found Senator McMullan's calm and quiet exposition of his case totally flawed.

In the last minute or two, let me address myself to what I think is the best example around of why we obviously do need the Senate, why we need to constantly remind people of why we need it and the good work it does, and why we especially need to remind them when someone in the position of Prime Minister raises with impressionable schoolchildren the question of not needing the Senate. That is obviously the appropriate time to put an alternative case.

There is no better alternative case than the sales tax legislation currently before this place. Just on a procedural basis, I think it was something like 18 months ago that this Government said that it could reform the wholesale sales tax system in a way we say cannot be done. It spent all that time doing it. It brought the legislation in here; it tried to guillotine it through with the support of the Democrats and I think some of the independents; and those Bills were referred to a select committee. What did we find out after that was done? The Bills were drastically flawed: they either do not say or did not say in their original state what the Government wanted them to, or the Government finally realised what it had done and is now trying to undo that legislation by means of amendment.

That sort of review will not happen if we give unbridled power to one House. The legislation will just be shoved through on a guillotine. People will suffer because of the ineptitude not of draughtsmen here but of Government instructions, and they will then wait even longer to get the legislation repaired and put in the state it should have been in the first place. There is no better example than the sales tax package of how a lower House on its own is manifestly incapable of producing legislation to be inflicted on the community.

talk.start.para: —Senator McMullan opened the debate today by telling us that the matter before the Senate was trivial and no-one outside this place would believe that we would debate it. Let me make it quite clear that today we are debating democracy. The comment of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was not a throwaway line that he often uses, although his staff went to great pains to say, `Oh, it was just an off-the-cuff statement'. We know that from 1919 it has been Labor policy to abolish the Senate. It was not until 1980 that Senator Evans at a Labor Party conference said, `Well, look, we know that this is pretty unpopular with the Australian people and therefore we ought to take it out of our policy, but there is no reason for us not to white ant the Senate from within'. That is why when he came to the Senate he used those words. Senator Coates, as we all know, has made similar statements in this place on many occasions. As so many of the Government members opposite agree that there really is no need for the Senate, I wonder why they bothered to enter it.
—Because we could not win seats in the House of Representatives.

—Senator Walsh earlier made some odd interjection about the States' House and said, `When has it ever been a States' House?' Let me tell Senator Walsh that in 1976, when the Fraser Government, of which I was a member, tried to have a referendum on issues on the Senate, Fraser lost that referendum, even though the Labor Party was in agreement with him, because several of the States' members in this Senate, members of the Liberal and National parties in this Senate, voted against their Government and divided on Senate State lines alone. Indeed, many Western Australian, Tasmanian, Queensland and South Australian senators crossed the floor and were instrumental in arguing the case with the Australian people that the Senate and all its powers ought to be retained.

para.tab: However, let me come to perhaps an even more important issue. Mr Keating has been very concerned that the Senate interferes with his powers in the lower House. His main reason for wanting to get rid of the Senate is that he cannot continue to just push legislation through the lower House, guillotine it if there appears to be any substantive debate, and get it passed without debate.

Since this Government has been in power, 2,954 amendments have been passed in this place. That is, nearly 3,000 amendments to Government legislation have been passed in this place since this Government has been in power. There have been 1,922 amendments put and passed by the Government. The Government passed through the lower House such shoddy legislation—as I say, without debate, guillotined through—that it was not until the legislation was fully debated in the committee stage of this place that the 1,922 amendments were agreed to by the Government. The Government believed 1,922 amendments were needed, and they were debated and put up in the Senate.

In total, nearly 3,000 amendments were put up in this place to overcome deficiencies in the legislation that would otherwise have gone through, creating tremendous problems in the business community and for individuals in terms of interfering with their rights and benefits. There is no doubt at all that Mr Keating is, as was said in an interjection from our side a few minutes ago, flying a flag. I do not doubt for one minute that if he had his way we would have another referendum to try to abolish the Senate. But there is no way that he would ever get that through. We have him attempting to dump the Queen, the flag, the Senate and free speech. Anything at all that interferes with his power in the House of Representatives he opposes very strongly.

speech.speaker: Crane Sen W.

talk.start.para:
—I rise to support the urgency motion before us. In doing so I wish to comment briefly on what Senator McMullan said when trying to trivialise this motion. It is worth noting who put this matter on the public agenda. It was this country's Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the same man who put the republican debate on the agenda and the same man who chose, overseas, to put the flag debate on the agenda. In fact, Senator McMullan was criticising his own Prime Minister, because we are debating this matter in this place today because of what the Prime Minister did at a school in this country. It is worth noting what the
Canberra Times
said. One could quote from a number of things but I will quote from the
Canberra Times
because Senator Coulter referred to it. It said:

speech.para: Those who exercise executive power may resent having to deal with parliamentarians rather than rubber stamps; but they are having to learn to live with them.

That is what this debate is all about. It is about Mr Keating trying to get the same sort of position that he happens to enjoy in the Right of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party. That is what Mr Keating is about. This is not about good government for this country; it is not about good government for everyone in Australia; it is about his own little power base. That is why I rise to defend very strongly the Senate and what it stands for.

para.tab: I also want to make particular reference to what Australia is about, because Australia is a federation of States. Let me say quite clearly that, if ever the Senate were abolished, I would be leading the charge for Western Australia to secede. Not only would I lead that charge to secede, but also it would in fact secede, because there would be no point in being subject to a dictatorial parliament in this country. I suggest that we would probably see Senator McKiernan, who is sitting on the other side of the chamber, alongside us in that charge.

It is worth looking at the figures in order to understand the reasons why we would secede. We should look at what Western Australia contributes—and the Senate provides us some protection in that regard in terms of the policy making process. Western Australia produces 100 per cent of the liquefied natural gas—not to be confused with liquefied petroleum gas—produced in Australia. It produces 97 per cent of the iron ore and 84 per cent of the lupins. One can go down the list of natural resources. Western Australia is the leader in terms of this nation's exports. We are one of the smaller States in terms of population but the largest in terms of production, and it is this Senate that gives us protection.

Let us look at some of the legislation that has been before this Senate. Previous speakers have already mentioned some examples. The sales tax Bills are not yet through. The Government slammed that legislation through the House of Representatives but has been forced to deal with 48 amendments. We can look at one of the pieces of legislation that I dealt with when I first came to this place—the legislation in respect of the wool industry. The Government was forced from its position of 15 per cent to 12 per cent. In fact, we on this side of the chamber were right; it should have been 10 per cent as that was all that was required. Let us look at the contractors legislation. The Government was hell-bent on unionising contractors. Because of the activities of the Senate it was forced to remove that part from the Bill.

The Senate, through the Committee system, gives people the opportunity to put their point of view and have it dealt with. Senate standing committees and the Friday legislation committees review legislation, and that is a very important component of the legislative process in this country. We have very important issues to deal with in this country. In the last unemployment figures the unemployment rate in Western Australia went up another 0.7 per cent to 11.5 per cent. One would have thought that when Mr Keating went to this particular school he would have talked to the children about how he as Prime Minister was going to do something about getting them jobs. But he took off on a diversion; he stepped sideways. He does not have the ability, any more than the Government as a whole does, to address the key issues that bedevil the Government.

The Prime Minister is the man who brought this debate on today, and I, for one, will defend the position of the Senate, from a Western Australian point of view and from an Australian point of view, as long as I am around.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the remarks of my colleagues and to condemn the comments of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, that Australia should not have a senate. Mr Keating's extraordinary comments to a group of young students really show his nature. Mr Keating has recently put on the agenda the issue of hang-ups. Let us look at the hang-ups of the man who is the leader of our country. He wants to abolish the monarchy as it exists in Australia; he wants to abolish the flag; he now wants to abolish the Senate. Those of us who have witnessed Question Time in the House of Representatives know that he has effectively abolished the institution of Question Time there. It is my view that he is a very strange man indeed. Rather than glorying in Australia's great constitutional achievement in having had continuous democracy for 92 years, Mr Keating tries ceaselessly to denigrate the institutions of our constitutional democracy—institutions which have helped protect the liberties and rights of Australians.

para.tab: Senator McMullan mentioned a quotation by Kim Beazley Sr. I could not recall that quotation but for the benefit of Senator Bolkus I mention another quotation by Kim Beazley Sr that I do recall. I believe that in the early 1940s he said that when he joined the Labor Party it comprised the cream of the working class but that when he left the Labor Party it comprised the scum of the middle class. I do not know whether that was right or wrong, but it was an interesting comment and an interesting reflection on the quality of the people who now occupy the Labor benches.

interject.speaker: Senator Bolkus

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. If Senator Kemp is to assert that a particular quotation comes from a particular person, he should establish

interject.para: that it does, and he should not then go on to say that he is not so sure whether it is an accurate quotation or whether it comes from that person and then go on to bag that particular person. I think Senator Kemp is taking a lot of liberties that should not be allowed in debate.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)
—There is no point of order.

talk.start.para: —There was clearly no point of order—merely another attempt by the Labor Party to divert an attack. The problem with the Labor Party is that it plays the man all the time. We have a Prime Minister who, in an extraordinary fashion, has said that he will single out for personal attack the leader of the Liberal Party, Dr Hewson. Every time people respond to the Labor Party we get the type of reaction we had from Senator Bolkus. I say to honourable senators opposite that, if they can give it, they had better learn to take it as well. We on this side of the chamber have noted what a lot of glass jaws there are on the other side. Today we had an incident where the Senate exerted its authority and brought Ministers to order. For eight years now, or perhaps even longer, Ministers in the Hawke and Keating governments have been running roughshod over this chamber in Question Time.

—Prior to the meal break, the issue before the chamber was the comments by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that Australia should not have a Senate. I wish to condemn those remarks by the Prime Minister. It is extraordinary that the Prime Minister made these remarks in a period when representatives of at least three countries have come to Australia to closely examine the success of our Senate and to see how they could replicate the Senate structure in Australia. I refer of course to New Zealand; as was mentioned by Senator McMullan, it has a unicameral parliament. Many people on the Labor side of this Parliament are very worried about the powers of that single chamber in New Zealand, and New Zealand has turned its mind to whether it should not have a Senate upper house.

para.tab: It is interesting also that a few months ago some observers from Canada came out to examine closely the operations of our Senate. Senator Peter Walsh would probably know that one of the major reforms proposed to change the Constitution of the Canadian federation is to bring in a Senate which, in all key respects, is very similar to the Senate in this country.

Some weeks ago, I had the pleasure of going to South Africa to examine and discuss certain critical problems which are facing that country and the tragic circumstances in which some of their people are embroiled. One of the issues put to me in that country was that one of the ways out of the impasse in South Africa is to look very closely at the way Australia has developed a federation. It was suggested that maybe the future for South Africa lies in a federal structure, one of the checks of which are to have a Senate like we have in Australia.

In conclusion, I would like to raise another point to show what sort of man we have as a leader of the country. He has been trying to attach himself recently in his remarks to what he described as the `great Labor traditions'. I put this before Senator Faulkner and Senator Walsh: is it similar to Mr Keating's practice in relation to having a butler in his office? Did Ben Chifley need a butler; did John Curtin need a butler; did Gough Whitlam need a butler?

talk.start.para: —What about Malcolm Fraser?

—Malcolm Fraser did not have a butler in his office. But when we come to Mr Keating, the man who holds himself out as the inheritor of the Labor tradition, we see that we have a Prime Minister who cannot survive with 35 staff without having a butler in his office. So much for Mr Keating, so much for the Labor tradition.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —Senator Kemp has mentioned, and I think he is correct in saying, that some Canadian politicians are contemplating establishing in Canada a Senate with teeth, as distinct from the Senate Canada currently has, which is essentially a Senate without teeth. The United States has a Senate with teeth, but I think I would find it very difficult to argue that the United States is better governed than Canada.

para.tab:
However, just over 18 years ago, I was elected to the Senate and, as a matter of course, received by mail a copy of Odgers's
Australian Senate Practice
. Mr James Odgers was the Clerk of the Senate at the time and was sometimes referred to—I think more derogatorily than respectfully—as Senator Odgers. But being a simple country boy all those years ago, I thought `Well, I am now in the Senate. I had better read this book which someone has been kind enough to send to me'. I started reading it. I got up to about page 140 and my getting that far before I threw it away just shows how simple and how slow I was. I got up to the section which said that the Senate is a State's house.

Simple country boy though I was, I had read a bit of political history. One did not have to read very much to realise that as Deakin had correctly predicted—and I assume, Senator Kemp, that Deakin if not an idol of his own would be an idol of his father, both being Victorian protectionists—at the very beginning the Senate, no matter what various politicians' rhetoric asserted to the contrary, would become a party house just like the House of Representatives. Of course, Deakin was very quickly proved correct on that issue, if not on some others.

When I got to this assertion that the Senate was a State's house, I gave up reading
Australian Senate Practice
and I have not bothered to look at it since. However, from time to time I have said, especially when Mr—alias Senator—Odgers was the Clerk of the Senate, that, notwithstanding my fundamental disagreement with him about the nature of the Senate, whether it was a State's house or a party house, I believed the Senate was a very necessary institution. The reason for that was that it provided a consolation prize for people like me who could not win seats in the House of Representatives. Every time I said that, Mr Odgers used to look pained and displeased.

talk.start.para: —What would the Labor Party secretaries do?

—There is actually a purpose behind all this, and Senator Kemp should pay attention to realise what the purpose is. I think that anecdote was terribly important because I believe it displays or explains the extreme sensitivity of the Senate as a whole—or at least of many members of it—to the comments by the Prime Minister the other day that it would be better if we did not have a Senate, or whatever his exact words were.

para.tab: By that, I mean that there are many rejects from the House of Representatives in this Senate, that is, people who have lost their seats. They are not all here tonight, but when I look along the Opposition front bench, I see Senator Short who was kicked out of the House of Representatives; Senator Tambling who was kicked out of the House of Representatives and Senator Baume who was kicked out of the House of Representatives. Three of the Liberal Party front bench in the Senate are rejects, discards, from the House of Representatives.

Then, of course, on the Opposition back bench, we have Senator Chapman, and we used to have Senator Jessop. In response to what I think Senator Kemp was saying a while ago, there is one reject from the House of Representatives sitting on the Labor side in the Senate; that is Senator Coates. I asked him before and he does not mind me mentioning this. What is more, there are two people on the Labor side of the House who could not even get into the House of Representatives in the first place: myself, which I have already admitted, and Senator Evans, who could not even get preselection. These are only the people that I know about off the top of my head; there are probably many others. There are as well people like Senator Durack, who was sacked by the electors of Perth from the Legislative Assembly of Western Australia some 24 1/2 years ago, if I remember correctly; one-time Senator Olsen who—

talk.start.para: —He went back.

—Senator Schacht is absolutely right. He made one of the greatest miscalculations of all time. He thought he was going to become Leader of the Opposition in South Australia. He had been effectively kicked out of the Legislative Assembly of South Australia, came into the Senate, then decided he would go back because he thought he was going to be leader, and he miscalculated on that as well.

para.tab: They are only the ones that I can remember. Fred Daly was the long time member for Grayndler. Fred is a practising Catholic, as I understand it, and certainly a Christian who believes in a life hereafter and things such as that. Quite frankly, I do not, but I respect the views of those who do. Fred used to give what he thought was a decisive blow in favour of his view of the way the world and the heavens are when he said that anybody who did not believe that there was a life after death obviously had not seen the Senate. Then there are the myths and nonsense about the Senate being a States House. If it ever was, that idea certainly did not survive the first decade of Federation.

The present electoral system—that is, the proportional representation system—has been thrust on the Senate. I am being quite objective about this; it was a Labor Government in the late 1940s which gave the Senate its present electoral system. I do not believe it would have done so had it realised what the ultimate dangers of adopting such a system would be, but the system has been adopted and neither side of politics has since proposed that it should be removed.

Honourable senators should look at the weirdos who are elected. The Liberal Party need not worry about this, because there are two real parties in Australia: the Liberal Party and the Labor Party. The Country Party used to be the tail that wagged the Liberal Party dog; I think it is the other way around now—the Liberal Party dog wags the tail of the Country Party, or the National Party as it calls itself these days.

Honourable senators should contemplate some of the weird outcomes of Senate elections which have occurred because of proportional representation. At least half the time the last Senate position to be filled in any State is more a consequence of a lottery than a real election. Most people would remember that we had here, until about four years or 3 1/2 years ago, Senator Woods.

talk.start.para: —One per cent.
—That is right. He had 1.3 per cent of the primary vote.
—You are kind to him.

—No, I think 1.3 per cent is rounded off to the nearest decimal point. It did not happen but it is possible that the fate of government legislation—regardless of whether it is a Labor government or a non-Labor government—could be determined by the probably ill-informed, capricious, or possibly even worse, vote of somebody who got the support of 1.3 per cent of the electorate.

para.tab: I do not know the context in which the Prime Minister made his comments the other day. He may well have been a bit facetious. Some people think that that is a pretty good approach to the Senate—that one should treat it as a bit of a joke. That is a view that I do not entirely agree with but, given the way the Senate sometimes behaves, if that was the Prime Minister's intention, I think he could be excused for it. As Senator McMullan has already said, if the Senate thinks the most important thing—a matter of urgency, indeed—is whether it should debate whether the Prime Minister thinks it should exist, that really displays a culpable ignorance or disregard of the things that really matter in this country.

There are a couple of other issues that relate more to the behaviour of individual senators than to the Senate per se. I remember, I think five years ago, Senator Bishop delivered a tirade in the Senate, as she is wont to do, alleging that there were irregularities and electoral fraud in the electoral roll for the State by-election in Castlereagh, New South Wales. This was delivered two days before the by-election was to be held and we did not hear any more about it.

I have not got time to go into this in full. Senator Bishop has been conducting what she thinks is a blitzkrieg against the Taxation Office and especially the Taxation Commissioner on the grounds that the Tax Office—what she calls `Boucher's bloodhounds'—has been launching a Crimes Act prosecution as a `political act'. This is all set out in much greater detail in the
Australian Financial Review
of Thursday, 10 September in a letter from one Gordon Brysland, whom I do not know, but who is apparently a lawyer employed in the firm of Phillips Fox in Perth. I have not got time to go into it in great detail, but I recommend to those who are interested in Senator Bishop's competence—or, rather, incompetence—as both a lawyer and a politician that they should read this.

I have a chance to make a couple of observations. Senator Bishop had accused the Tax Office of having `Boucher's bloodhounds' set on one Mr Smiles, a former member of the New South Wales Parliament, a Liberal member, as a political act and prosecuting him for breaches of the Crimes Act. The letter goes on to make the point that Mr Smiles was charged with `keeping false records, making a false statement himself and encouraging someone else to do so'. The letter from Mr Brysland goes on to say:

speech.para: In fact, the DPP—
that is, the Director of Public Prosecutions—
Mr Michael Rozenes QC, had already pointed out in a letter to Senator Bishop that the Crimes Act charge was laid because—
this is the important thing, the punch line—
no equivalent offence exists under the Taxation Administration Act.

While it is true that the Taxation Administration Act provides penalties for late lodgment of returns, monetary penalties and so on, if somebody is going to make false declarations and encourage other people to make false declarations, that is a breach of the Crimes Act and is by definition a crime instead of being a breach of the Taxation Act.

para.tab: I will finish with another quotation from the letter written by Mr Brysland. He said:

speech.para: The case on which Senator Bishop relied does not have quite the same complexion once the full public record is revealed.
I can only add that that must be one of the understatements of the month, if not of the year.

para.tab: When we have in the Senate people such as Senator Bishop, behaving in the unprincipled, undisciplined—and I mean intellectually undisciplined—way that she does, then if the Prime Minister did really say or mean that we ought to get rid of the Senate, given the fact that Senator Bishop is a member of it and that Senator Woods used to be a member of it, we can understand the Prime Minister saying that.

speech.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —I believe in the Senate and I support the Senate. I believe it fulfils very responsible legislative and other political parliamentary roles within Australia. I reject the views of the two speakers from the Government, Senator McMullan, who was vacuous, and Senator Walsh, in making half-baked generalisations about a few instances that relate to a few senators, only some of which are, I believe, in any way relevant in a proper evaluation of the Senate.

para.tab: With regard to the Senate being a States House, I know that it has become a commonplace amongst Labor Party members to criticise the long held view of the constitutional fathers that one of the Senate's major responsibilities was to protect the States. I put the view that this Parliament would be very different if there were not an equality of representation of the various States. If the representation in this chamber went according to population as it does in the House of Representatives then it would be perfectly possible for new amalgamations or coalitions—internal to a party or across parties—to form on particular issues that would be unfair to the smaller States.

As a senator from South Australia, I not only subscribe to the traditional view that the Senate does protect the States, but I also assert that in practice it is the case because we have not tested the alternative. We have never moved from there being an equal number of representatives from the various States. I reject the statement made by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, five days ago when he said that we did not need the Senate. He made other derogatory remarks about the Senate.

It is also commonplace in Australia for many people to make fun of schools. They say that schools are boring, schools are not exciting or schools are a waste of time. Particularly those who are 15 years of age, who are not coping with a school and who feel they are not being well-served by a school, will make all sorts of derogatory remarks about schoolteachers and the place that they are constrained to attend. This sometimes carries over to half-baked criticisms of schools by those people, even into adult life. I do not believe that the Australian public takes that schoolboy half-baked logic in any way seriously. In the same way, I do not believe that any flippant and irresponsible remarks about the composition or existence of the Senate within this Parliament ought to be taken seriously by the public.

It has been common over many years for the Labor Party to choose to be highly critical of the Senate. In Question Time five days ago, on the same day that we heard the Prime Minister's remarks, my good friend Senator Tate, who is in the chamber, happened to say:

speech.para: The Minister for Justice from New Zealand is observing these proceedings and considering whether to institute a Senate in New Zealand. Do not do it!
he cried, half tongue in cheek. On the morning of the day before, Senator Schacht, who is also in the chamber, made a similar remark when he said:
If they need any proof why they would be absolutely bonkers to establish a Senate in New Zealand, they have just seen it in the last half hour—
here in the Senate. These half-baked tongue-in-cheek remarks, at the expense of our own valuable institution in this Parliament, ought not to be taken seriously in any event.

para.tab: In the minute or two remaining, I want to say that I believe the Senate is the only legislative chamber that takes seriously the task of debating potential laws in this Parliament. In the House of Representatives there is too much of an acceptance that the Government's proposals will be accepted. It is only in the Senate that we have a debate on Bills with regard to the laws of this country. It is only in the Senate that we have a fully developed committee system. I could go on about subordinate legislation in comparison with the United States, about the perspective of senators over House of Representatives members and so on. I fully support the Senate. I believe it will be here for all of my lifetime.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support this urgency motion because the comments that need to be answered were made by the Prime Minister of this country. Had they been made by the likes of Senator Walsh, Senator Schacht or any other nonentity, perhaps it would not have mattered a row of beans. But the fact is that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said that the Senate should be dispensed with. He went on to make remarks that the Senate frustrated his Government's legislation. Other people have passed the comment that to have a second chamber adds to the cost of government.
