I can see from the arrogance and the attitude of many in the Government, but more particularly of the Prime Minister, that he would enjoy being a dictator. Dictatorships are a very cheap form of government. Personally, I am right into democracy at whatever the cost.

para.tab: There are two things to say that are important about having a working parliamentary democracy. A bicameral system enables checks and balances to be put into place that a single chamber does not. Anyone who wants to take a very good and close look at what has transpired in the State of Queensland, which only has one House, could say that many of its troubles could have been spared had it had a second chamber. Very simply, a single chamber was introduced in that State by the Labor Party Government. I am sorry to say that that was not rectified subsequently.

The New Zealanders have been across here recently looking at introducing a Senate into New Zealand for the simple reason that it provides better government. Why does it provide better government? The manner in which legislation is guillotined, gagged, or whatever term one likes to use, through the lower House, has to be explained in terms of the way government works. There is a misconception abroad that those people who are members of the party which is elected with a majority of members are all part of the government. That is wrong. The only people who form part of the government are those people who are sworn in as members of the Executive Council. The other members of the political party who are of the same persuasion as those people so sworn in are merely there to give the numbers.

I heard somebody—perhaps it was Senator Walsh or somebody who spoke before him—say that legislation can be passed or not passed on the whim of someone who does not enjoy a very great majority, I think he said perhaps 1.3 per cent of the vote. There are members in the lower House who enable legislation to be gagged without debate who are sitting on a margin of less than one per cent. That is hardly what I would call an overwhelming majority.

talk.start.para: —They got over 50 per cent of the two-party preferred vote.

—Indeed, they did not get over 50 per cent. We have a government sitting there which got fewer primary votes than the Opposition did. On that argument, we should be in government today. But the point is that we do have a system whereby government is formed in the other place. The Government has the numbers to force through legislation without proper consideration or debate. Legislation comes here into this chamber where we have an adequate and sufficient committee system to ensure that many of the unintended consequences of the poor legislation that comes through—

para.tab:
Honourable senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! The cross-fire across the chamber is not at all helpful.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Poor legislation in a poorly drafted form comes before us so often, but through the various mechanisms that we have been able to put in place of scrutinising and seeking answers, we are able to rectify many of the errors that the other place send to us simply because they are guillotined or gagged without adequate debate. That is one aspect.

para.tab: The second aspect is that the Senate is able to give a voice to the ordinary people. I happened to overhear some rather paltry remarks made by Senator Walsh who, I think I can say kindly, is probably past his prime. I heard him talk about matters concerning the Public Accounts Committee inquiry. Because of the time constraints that we have agreed to on this side of the House, I am limited to five minutes. The ramblings of Senator Walsh were not so limited as the other side did not decide to limit itself. I will choose—and I give notice now—to deal with that by way of a personal explanation when we conclude the comments in this particular debate.

For the Prime Minister to say that we do not need a flag, and to denigrate our potent national symbol by getting stuck into it overseas, and to say that we should abandon bits of our Constitution—why not the Senate? He is clearly a man of great arrogance who believes that if his will is for a moment frustrated then the whole world must change to suit it. Wrong, Mr Keating. Our forefathers not only founded for us a House to represent the States—and that is satisfied by there being an equal number of senators from each State—but, more particularly, they combed the world for the best system to give constitutional democracy. Indeed, they modelled us on the United States Senate. That was meant to be a House of power, of influence and of vitality. That is what we have in this place and long may the Prime Minister remember it.

speech.speaker: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

talk.start.para: —I congratulate Senator Bishop on the way she has made the point very clearly—
—Don't crawl to her; you only encourage her.

—I am not crawling to anyone. Senator Schacht should crawl back into his burrow and go to sleep for a while. The point that Senator Bishop has just made is very clear: the Senate has played a part and will continue to play a part. It was quite interesting to listen to Senator Walsh earlier here tonight. One wonders why he has actually stayed in this place for so long. He said that he was a failed candidate for the House of Representatives. He is somebody for whom I have had in the past a little bit of respect, but I did not agree with all the things he said here tonight. He lost a lot of my respect for the fact that he has lived in this place, worked in this place and used the offices of this place while he has been representing the people and now says basically that it is not such a good place and that he does not agree with a lot of the things it stands for.

para.tab:
Senator Walsh mentioned Odgers. One only has to read the foreword to the latest Odgers
Australian Senate Practice
to see why we have a Senate chamber. Senator Walsh mentioned the Rt Hon. Sir Edmund Barton, whom I now quote:
We cannot fail to remember that the Constitution designed the Senate to be a House of greater power than any ordinary second chamber.

speech.para: That is a very lucid point. The Rt Hon. Sir George Pearce said:

para.tab: The Senate was constituted as it is, after long fighting, prolonged discussions, many compromises, and many concessions on the part of the various shades of political thought throughout the Commonwealth, and it stands there in the Constitution in a position that has no equal in any Legislature throughout the world.

speech.para: Senator Bishop has just made some points about that. It is quite interesting to listen to Labor Party senators arguing the points and trying to support the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he cannot be supported for the remarks that he made. The ALP platform in 1984 mentioned review of the Constitution to ensure that the Senate did not have the power to reject, defer or otherwise block money Bills. It also wanted reform and eventual abolition of the upper Houses in the State parliaments but did not go so far as to suggest that the Senate ought to go at that time.

para.tab: In 1991, at the ALP conference, the platform seems to have done away with the objective of abolishing State upper Houses and refers only in the briefest way to the function of the Senate, suggesting that the lower House should be able to govern unobstructed by the House of review, as it refers to the Senate. God love us! What sort of country would we have if that had been allowed to happen?

Let us think of some of the things that this Senate has done in the recent past. The Australia Card legislation was flawed and it was discovered only through the work of the Senate. The superannuation legislation was flawed and was amended in the Senate. Sales tax amendments were pushed through the House of Representatives and while in the Senate committee the Government realised the flaws in that legislation. The Senate has blocked Labor Government legislation that would have affected the honey industry, the dairy industry, the prawn industry and the fishing industry, and it has been able to avoid the deeming of assets as income for country people. It has been able to quarantine the family home and the family farm from the capital gains tax.

Let us give a bit of credit to the committee system. The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and the Selection of Bills Committee do not exist in the House of Representatives. I have had the honour of being Deputy Chairman of the Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The number of times we have found flaws in the Bills and have referred the matter back to the Minister are innumerable. These committees have been consistently responsible for amending flawed legislation, that is, legislation that is legally incompetent, not just legislation that does not have the support of the Opposition parties. Without the Senate, flawed legislation would become law and would need to be redrafted and reintroduced.

Look what happened the other day when we had another shambles caused by the Government pushing something through in the other place. It is this chamber in which the Government departments are brought to account. I believe Senator Bishop does that very ably in scrutinising the expenditure of government departments. Without the Senate we would not be able to do that.

I suggest that Mr Keating's efforts would be better served by focusing on achieving the objective of fixing up the economy of this country, fixing things that need fixing, rather than trying to get a red herring across this landscape by trying to get rid of the Senate. The throw-away remarks which the Prime Minister made to school kids, or to any people in the community, does him little credit. One only has to watch him at Question Time and the way he handles that. He has no regard for the parliamentary process. I reiterate: if we abolished the Senate the country would be much the poorer for it, because we do scrutinise legislation and we do a job to make it better for all Australians.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support this motion, recognising the enormous contribution the Senate has made to good government. I listened to the whimsical remarks of Senator Walsh. His remarks are probably best seen in the context of his inability to appeal to any voters at any stage, either as a candidate for the House of Representatives or as a member of the Senate team. He certainly failed in any attempts he made to get into the House of Representatives. His lack of popularity amongst his own colleagues probably indicates that his views are not to be taken terribly seriously. I do not think he took them terribly seriously himself.
—He gave you a big serve.
—I understand he mentioned me in passing. I find it an

speech.para:
honour to be referred to by Senator Walsh. I seek leave to incorporate in
Hansard
a table from the Department of the Senate annual report detailing the legislation dealt with by the Senate. The table shows that, of the 204 Bills that were passed last year, there were 67 to which amendments or requests were agreed; in other words, one-third of all Bills that came before this chamber had to be amended. I have just received a message saying that my five minutes has expired, having spoken for two.

talk.start.para: —In that case, I ask whether leave is granted for the incorporation.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The table read as follows
—

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. It is evident that there has been a dramatic need to correct legislation that is gagged and rushed through the House of Representatives with no debate. If it were not for this chamber, those corrections to legislation would not have been made. As it is, enough legislation goes through, over our dead bodies, to cause the Australian people enough problems. Some of it is even so bad that it is thrown out by the High Court, despite our endeavours.

para.tab: If one wanted to get rid of any sort of restraints or constraints on the exercise of power—in other words, if one were Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, and one did not like the fact that one's whims, one's decisions, were not automatically rushed through the Parliament without debate, without proper scrutiny—then naturally one would want to get rid of the Senate; if one were that sort of person. So we have an attack on the Senate. We have had an attack on the Crown which provides a structure, which imposes some constraints on government. We get the continual attack on the States which are another power centre which are out of Mr Keating's hands.

Whenever we see people who are obsessed with power, we will see people who wish to destroy those instruments which separate them from the full exercise of that power. The Senate stands in the way of a man who wants to exercise power. That man is the present Prime Minister of Australia whose obsession with power is self-evident when we watch him, when we look at him, when we see what he has been doing. As a result, it is inevitable that the Senate should stand in his way. It is essential for democracy that it continue to stand in his way.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on this urgency motion—what can only be called a bizarre motion. In the past week, with the issues of trade and tariffs confronting Australia, what have been the attempts of the Opposition to raise the big issues in this place? Senator Boswell wants to drape the Senate chamber in Australian flags. As I said in that debate, he wants a bunting-led recovery; he wants flags draped all over the place.

para.tab: Despite all the debate in the community, again today we get a debate about tariffs and about trade. We get the best we can get from the people opposite—a motion moved by Senator Hill condemning the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) regarding the role of the Senate. As my colleague Senator Walsh said, the remarks of Mr Keating were informal and obviously facetious, but there is more than a grain of truth in them. He said, `In reality, it's a (political) Party House'.

This is not a States House. It has never been a States House. Ever since it was formed just after Federation, people have been voting in here according to their party tickets. It has always been thus and it always will be. Senator Bronwyn Bishop does not vote for what is best for New South Wales. She votes the way the Liberal Party caucus tells her in the party room to vote. That is her role; it is my role; it is the role of everybody here. That ought to be recognised.

Remarks have been made about Mr Keating's concern about power. What has Dr Hewson said on a number of occasions over the last 12 months about the Senate? He has said that if a coalition is elected at the next election and it does not have a majority in the Senate and the Senate thwarts the introduction of Fightback and the GST, he will call a double dissolution. He is already indicating that he is frustrated with the Senate as it is presently structured. He will go to a double dissolution if the coalition wins the next election. Six or twelve months later what will we have? London Bridge to two bob the coalition will be back in here with a minority party holding the balance of power because of the proportional representation system of voting.

What Dr Hewson wants is almost impossible even in a double dissolution. Under the present political support in this community about 10 per cent of the public will always vote for a third or fourth party. They will ensure that this Senate will stop the Liberal Party from introducing large sections of Fightback and GST. Then we will hear the screams from those on the other side. The bagging they already give the Democrats for not voting with them on every occasion will continue. They will be bagging and crying about the powers of the Senate thwarting the mandate they have from the House of Representatives if they win the next election. So do not come in here and spill crocodile tears about the powers of the Senate, the balance of power and reducing the power. When those opposite were in government, especially when they had a majority in this place between 1975 and 1977, they used their numbers consistently to vote the Opposition down because they could put anything through they liked.

We have had evidence in here before in debates about the guillotine; where the toecutter, Reg Withers, used to move that 20 Bills go through in an hour. That was when those opposite had the numbers. When they had the numbers outright they used it to make a mockery of the Senate as a house of review. Senator Walters, who was part of those gag motions, should not come in here and talk about the House of review representing the small State of Tasmania. You have never voted for Tasmania. You have always voted for the Liberal Party because its members select you into this place.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Schacht, it might help if you directed your remarks to the Chair.

—We have had remarks in here relating to other countries and their looking at introducing a Senate. Canada has been mentioned. Canada has an appointed upper House at the moment and it is looking at a way to overcome its problems and the difficulties between the French-speaking Quebec province and the rest of the English-speaking part of Canada by establishing some sort of elected upper House. I bet Canada does not allow that upper House to have the power to overturn Budgets and stop money Bills.

para.tab: We had representatives of the New Zealand Parliament in the chamber last week. What a great day it was to observe the Senate in full flight. I certainly know that the Labor members of that group went back saying, `We would really have to be stupid to take this on in New Zealand to move away from the unitary system'. The National Party in New Zealand is delighted to have a one-chamber parliament so that it can put through all the measures on industrial relations, to wipe out all the industrial relations regulations. The Opposition will not get that through the Senate because a compromise will be reached. Those opposite will be screaming and shouting about it.

We have had mention of South Africa as a possibility for an upper House. Of course, the South African Constitution will be negotiated with an upper House to protect certain political and human rights, but I bet the bottom line will be that the popular House, the lower House, will not allow the Senate in any constitution of South Africa to stop money supply and bring the government of the lower House down. In all of those cases there has been no suggestion that the Senate, the second House in most cases—

talk.start.para: —Order! Will the honourable senator standing please understand that he is between the Chair and the speaker.
—No-one is suggesting that that Senate should have the same powers as our Senate which can bring down the democratically elected Government of the popular will in our lower House.

para.tab:
I find the list of the Liberal party spokespeople remarkable. This year is the fiftieth anniversary of the movie
Casablanca
. One of the great lines in Casablanca involves the police commissioner, who is rather corrupt. To deflect attention from his activities, when some crime takes place he issues the immortal phrase, `Round up the usual suspects'. One can see what Senator Hill and the Liberal Party did for this debate. They rounded up the usual suspects who would scream and shout about Senate powers—the Senator Walterses, the Cranes, the Kemps, the Bishops, the Brownhills and the Baumes—the usual list of suspects who stand in this place and rant and rave about the powers of the Senate.

I do not believe at all in the Senate having the power to overthrow the popularly elected House of Representatives. I do believe that the only justification for a House of review is to review legislation, but if the lower House insists on that legislation being carried, it should be carried. Here we have had people defending the Senate as an end in itself. That is not democracy. I think a lot of people in this place justify the Senate and its associated paraphernalia as an end in itself.

People ought to remember that the Senate operates in the way it does because of a quirk of the counting system that was introduced in 1948. As Senator Walsh says, if Mr Calwell, the Minister who introduced it, had realised he would be inflicting on the two major parties, the Labor Party and the Liberal Party, a Senate voting system which ensured practically for all time that a minority, a third or a fourth party, would have the balance of power, he would not have done it. So the only reason the Senate has any standing in exercising power is a fluke of the proportional representation system.

If those opposite happen to be fortunate enough—I hope they are not—to win the next election or some subsequent election, they will be screaming in here about how a balance of power in the Senate has stopped the introduction of their Fightback and their GST. Then we will see what those opposite think of the Senate powers. Then they will be taking a different view. Certainly Dr Hewson has already indicated that he does not like the Senate having the power to thwart his GST or his Fightback policy. I am interested that people like Senator Bishop and Senator Walters, who are great devotees of the Fightback and the GST, do not recognise that at least Dr Hewson is honest in suggesting that he is going to take the Senate on and he disagrees with the Senate having the power to stop the implementation of his radical policy to introduce a Fightback and a GST.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—You have to put the vote.
—Would Senator Tate let the Deputy President look after the Senate?
—I call Senator Walters.

—Senator Schacht this evening said that I for one had never voted for Tasmania. Can I just tell him that in 1976 when we were in government, long before he came into this place, Mr Fraser went for a referendum that I believe would have disadvantaged my State considerably.
—Senator Walters, did you say that you had been misrepresented?
—I did. That is what I told you.
—I have not heard on what point you have been misrepresented.

—To do you justice, Mr Deputy President, I do not think you were listening from the beginning. Senator Schacht said that I had never voted for Tasmania. I am now about to tell him when I did. Would you like me to continue? That is how I opened, Mr Deputy President.
—I think I am probably being a little flexible. If you do not make it a major speech, you can go ahead.

—It is a personal explanation purely and simply. As I was saying, in 1976 I had only been here a short time. Indeed, I crossed the floor and voted against my Government on the question of a referendum. It is something that Senator Schacht cannot understand. If any of his crowd vote against their own Party, they are thrown out. That does not happen on our side of politics. Indeed, Senator Georges was thrown out because he voted against the Labor Party. On our side of politics we have the—
—I think he retired.

—No, he did not; do not tell fibs. On our side of politics, we are permitted to vote against our Party if we so desire. Indeed, I have on several occasions, not only on the referendum but on other Tasmanian issues. If Senator Schacht wants to take me on at any stage, he should do his homework first. On every occasion, as I have in the past, I will scupper him. He does not do his homework and he talks off the top of his head. He does not understand the situation and he has no idea what democracy is all about.
—Order! Senator Walters, you have made your point. Resume your seat.
—Under standing order 190, I wish to deal with the matters on which I foreshadowed as having been misrepresented.
—Mr President, I raise a point order. The two hours allotted for the urgency debate have expired. You should put the question and deal with that matter. Any—
—Let the Deputy President organise the Senate.
—I am taking a point of order.
—He is taking a point of order, if that's all right with you. You are not running the show.
—Order! Neither are you, Senator Faulkner.
—I took a very proper point of order, and I am entitled to as a senator.
—Order! Senator Tate has the floor. I do not expect him to be interrupted when he is making a point of order.

—I was making the point that I understood, the time limit for the urgency debate having expired, the proper procedure would be to have that matter resolved by the Senate. If there is a personal explanation to be made on a point of misrepresentation during debate, that is usually made after the Senate has determined the question. I am not trying to preclude Senator Bishop from making her personal explanation; I am just looking for a means to do it in accordance with the order that normally prevails.
—Senator Tate has a point. With the concurrence of the Senate, I will put the question. After that matter has been decided, I or the person in the chair will call Senator Bishop.

para.tab: Question put:
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Bishop Sen B.K.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy President, I continue my request to you under standing order 190. I claim to have been misrepresented and wish to make a personal explanation.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy President, I foreshadowed during the short intervention that I made in the urgency debate that I would deal with some of the remarks that were made by Senator Walsh, en passant as they seemed to me, concerning the behaviour of the Australian Taxation Office and the comments that were made by Mr Boucher in his opening statement on the first day of the hearing conducted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

para.tab: I would remind the Senate and place on the record, so that we are not confused by Senator Walsh's comments, that I was making the point that the Tax Office has enormous might and power. I have said that the Tax Office and the Taxation Commissioner have the power to make grown men cringe. If anyone takes a look at the correspondence that I have received since this matter was aired they would see that there are thousands of ordinary Australians who have felt that might upon their heads.

The Opposition has been arguing that the Senate is a place in which ordinary Australians can get their voices heard. I now cite the Tax Office inquiry as a relevant case. Senator Walsh misrepresented my position in that he did not explain the points that I thought I had made succinctly. I had made the point that when we are dealing with an office such as the Australian Taxation Office we may examine only what is on the public record. Section 16 of the taxation legislation precludes, at least at first blush, the Australian Taxation Office from giving details of any particular tax pay out. Therefore, I said that we may examine what is on the public record. We find on the public record a letter dated 3 November 1986 written by Mr Cortese, the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation, to the Hon. P.J. Keating at his home address, in a very friendly fashion—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I believe that Senator Bishop may be going into a realm of debate on this very sensitive issue, which is, of course, a matter of concern to many senators. She has championed a certain point of view. But I think she should be restrained at this time to making a personal explanation as to where she was misrepresented rather than going into a regurgitation of correspondence and a debate more appropriate to the substantial issue.
—Mr Deputy President, on the point of order: Senator Tate was not in the chamber when Senator Walsh was speaking.
—Yes, I was!

—Then the Minister did not listen very hard. Senator Walsh quoted at great length from a letter in the
Australian Financial Review
dated 10 December, which canvassed exactly the area with which I am dealing. It is necessary to be specific in order to point out the manner in which Senator Walsh misrepresented my position.
—I think Senator Bishop is aware of just how far she can go with a personal explanation. I would ask Senator Bishop to continue.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. As I have said, I dealt with what was on the public record. What was on the public record was a letter to Mr Keating from the Australian Taxation Office. It was a personal letter to Mr Keating because it was sent to his home address. The letter stated:

para.tab: Dear Mr Keating,

speech.para: The purpose of this letter is to draw your attention to the need for you to file your 1986 tax return which is now outstanding.

The letter pointed out that his 1985 tax return was also outstanding. I compared that with a question that I asked in Estimates committees as to how many ordinary Australians—that is, not the boss of the Tax Office—were in fact prosecuted for exactly the same thing. The Tax Office itself answered me. It told me that there were nearly 10,800 ordinary Australians who got no such kindly letter but simply a summons.

para.tab: As I said, I have received much correspondence from ordinary Australians who highlight the unfairness and injustice in the way they have been treated. I compared this to the way in which Mr Smiles had been treated. I drew attention to the fact that Mr Smiles' case involved an apportionment fight. During Estimates hearings I again asked the Tax Office how many matters had been pursued under the Crimes Act as distinct from the Taxation Administration Act on a matter of apportionment.

The reason that the prosecution has been brought under section 7A of the Crimes Act was outlined to me in a letter from the DPP, which I have tabled in this place before. I did that because the DPP, together with the ATO, has chosen to deal with certain negotiations between those people and Mr Smiles in a particular way. I am merely saying that, on the public record, they have chosen to deal with Mr Keating in a particularly favourite way. A favouritism has been given out to the man who was the boss of the Taxation Commission.

talk.start.para: —Who else got a personal letter?

—Nobody got a personal note. I have also raised the question of Ministers in the Greiner Government who very shortly after being sworn in received audit information requests. Earlier on I used the term `desk audits'. Mr Boucher very cleverly used a very technical definition to answer my questions.

para.tab: I say that Senator Walsh has misrepresented my position for the following reason: I have highlighted these questions because I say that the Australian people cannot and will not respect the Tax Office and the people who administer it unless justice is not only done but is seen to be done. The evidence that I have before me is legion to show that that is not the case.

If Senator Walsh wants to dismiss the rights of ordinary Australians to have their case put and if he thinks that the Senate should be abolished then I can only say that there are some people who have been elected to this place—

talk.start.para: —I ask Senator Bishop to take her seat please. I assume that Senator Bishop is approaching the end of her personal explanation under standing order 190. She will be aware that there is a clause that says `but such matters may not be debated'. That means that she cannot in fact debate the issue with Senator Walsh or anyone else in this chamber. Senator Bishop has clarified basically where she has claims to have been misrepresented. Does she have any more to add on this issue without debating the issue?

—Very simply, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will not debate the issue, as the standing order precludes that. But I will say that I was solidly misrepresented by Senator Walsh. I would recommend that anyone who is truly interested in the matter read the
Hansard
of all the circumstances surrounding the way in which I have raised this issue which, in my view, has been perfectly proper and in the interest of Australian electors and democracy.

speech.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in the name of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, I move:

speech.para: That standing order 64 be suspended to allow new business to be commenced after the question for the adjournment is first put.

para.tab: Question put:
That the motion be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para:
—I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the implementation of pharmaceutical restructuring measures. I seek leave to incorporate the document in
Hansard
and move a motion in relation to the document.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The document read as follows
—

speech.para: Senator A O Zakharov
Chairperson
Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Olive
I am writing in response to the final report on the implementation of pharmacy restructuring measures, handed down on 7 May 1992 by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs.
I note that the final report focused on the administrative aspects of pharmacy restructuring rather than broader policy issues that arose during the course of the inquiry.
Administrative and Legislative Framework
The Senate Standing Committee found the legislation for pharmacy restructuring unnecessarily complex and identified problems with the initial administrative processes to implement the restructuring.

The Committee recommends the consolidation of legislation and subordinate legislation for pharmacy restructuring and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. This idea is a positive one which would streamline the legislation. I will ensure the suggestions made by the Committee are taken into account in the context of the review of major portfolio legislation which was announced in this year's Budget.
As I advised in the Government's response to your interim report, administrative procedures to implement restructuring measures, considered by the Committee, have been addressed.

The Government recognises that some pharmacists may maximise their financial gain by using two interrelated guidelines under the Agreement. This practice is difficult to prevent as the two guidelines are pivotal to restructuring. A small number of pharmacists are able to take advantage of an unusual and fortuitous situation with pharmacy location, where they can claim a closure package on one pharmacy and subsequently relocate another pharmacy they already own which is within 500 metres of the closure site to that site.

Administrative measures to implement pharmacy restructuring were, in the first instance, undertaken on the basis of my press release. The Government acknowledges that there were problems with the introduction of these administrative reforms but, given the need to implement the decision with respect to the new approved criteria quickly to prevent speculation amongst pharmacists and entrepreneurs, the use of press releases to implement the changes were necessary in this instance. There was no intention to either advantage or disadvantage pharmacists through the implementation of the new arrangements.

However, I would note that, except in circumstances when a very rapid response makes it impossible, it remains a major objective of the Government to implement all national programs by means of an effective and appropriately organised strategy.
Implementation of Pharmacy Restructuring

In accordance with the sub-section 98BAA(1) of the Act, the Government acted appropriately by negotiating with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. With well over 90% of the owners of community pharmacy in Australia represented by the Pharmacy Guild, it is the most appropriate body to represent pharmacists in negotiations over restructuring of community pharmacy.

The more specialised pharmacists' organisations referred to in the Committee's report, such as the Extended Hours Pharmacy Association and the Isolated and Essential Pharmacy Association are generally members of the Guild. As such, they were aware of and are represented in the Government/Guild Agreement.

In the early stages of restructuring, there was a settling in period as the Health Insurance Commission and the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority's duties were defined and clarified. This may have resulted in some administrative duplication. However, the few cases in which duplication occurred have been addressed during the course of your review. Administrative procedures have been streamlined.

Nevertheless, both the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority and the Health Insurance Commission have roles in the administration of the arrangements. To avoid the potential for duplication in the future, the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services will continue to provide a secretariat service to assist the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority in its day-to-day functions and to undertake liaison with the Health Insurance Commission.
Following these initial administrative difficulties, the Government believes all officers involved in administering the legislation are adequately familiar with the legislation.
Evaluation of Pharmacy Restructuring Measures

In recognition of the importance of evaluation, the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority undertook a survey of industry in late 1991. Submissions on the effects of restructuring were invited, and those received from various pharmacy bodies showed a favourable attitude to the initial phase of restructuring. As a result of this favourable response, it was not considered necessary to undertake any major reforms at that time. Departmental evaluation of the processes of restructuring is ongoing with the continued assistance of pharmacy bodies. The Government is also about to undertake a computer analysis, using geodemographic modelling, on the impact of restructuring.
Lack of Appeals Mechanisms
When the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority was set up, no internal appeal mechanism was developed as it was envisaged that usual appeal mechanisms would operate including:

para.tab: —appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal;
—review of decisions by the Federal Court of Australia;
—complaints to the Commonwealth Ombudsman; and
—complaints to the Minister.

speech.para: These appeal mechanisms were found not to apply as a result of an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Administrative Appeals Tribunal ruled that, although it had jurisdiction under section 105 AB of the Act to review a decision of a Secretary of the Department, it had no greater power than the Secretary. Since the Secretary could not grant an approval in the absence of a favourable recommendation by the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal could not do so either.
The absence of these normal appeal mechanisms was not intended.

Following this decision, the Government moved immediately to amend the National Health Act 1953 to allow aggrieved applicants access to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The amended legislation was granted Royal Assent on 24 December 1991 and was made retrospective to the date the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority commenced operations.

By late January 1992 all aggrieved applicants were advised in writing of the changes. They were also advised of their right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and of the right to obtain a statement of reasons for the rejection of their application from the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority.

More than forty applicants notified of the amended legislation exercised their right to obtain a statement of reasons from the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority and a significant number sought an Administrative Appeals Tribunal review.
Remedy for misleading advice

Any pharmacist who can establish that he/she has been financially disadvantaged through being given wrong advice by Commonwealth Officers has remedies at common law which have been available since 1981 and has also had a possible remedy under the Audit Act 1901 since 1979.
These remedies are:

para.tab: 1.Following the High Court decision in L. Shaddock & Associates v. Council of the City of Parramatta (1981) 150 CLR 225, a Court can award damages if it finds that a public servant or other person acting on behalf of the Commonwealth has given advice negligently and the claimant has relied on that advice to their detriment.

2.Where it is apparent that a claimant is likely to succeed against the Commonwealth, in a claim for damages arising from misleading advice, the matter can be settled without being determined by a Court.

3.Section 34A of the Audit Act 1901 enables the Minister for Finance to authorise the payment of moneys to a claimant where the Commonwealth is under a moral, as distinct from a legal, obligation to do so.

speech.para: Duplication of remedies which have been available for many years and which are directly applicable to the situations envisaged by the Committee is unnecessary.
The Government also notes that complaints that certain pharmacists may have received incorrect advice have not been substantiated.

In conclusion, I would like to reiterate that pharmacy restructuring will achieve savings to the taxpayer and encourage a competitive, streamlined pharmaceutical industry. The initial administrative problems experienced with the introduction of pharmacy restructuring have been resolved and evaluation processes are in place to monitor the restructuring process. In addition, any significant policy issues which the committee identified in the inquiry have been promptly addressed.
Yours sincerely
Peter Staples

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —I read with some concern the Government's response to the final report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the implementation of the pharmaceutical restructuring measures. The response I am talking about is dated 11 September, which does differ somewhat from the document provided to the Committee on 10 August. There have been some changes in the Government's response over that month and, while these do show a more positive attitude than the first response, I believe that the Government has still not appreciated the extent of the problems caused by the pharmacy restructuring measures which it began to implement in 1990.

para.tab: My colleagues will remember that the objective of the pharmaceutical restructuring program was to rationalise the number and distribution of retail pharmacies throughout Australia. In its early stages the program was characterised by a lack of proper legislative basis, poor communications between the parties involved and confusion among public servants and the pharmacies alike.

Evidence before the Committee indicated clearly that the program had a number of loopholes. On the one hand, these led to rorts by some pharmacists who either obtained new approvals to dispense pharmaceutical drugs through questionable eligibility, or obtained closures or amalgamation payments in excess of those that they should have received. On the other hand, misleading and incomplete information left some pharmacists in a disadvantaged position. Although the Government addressed some of these problems prior to the Committee's final report to the Senate, its response to the final report falls short of expectations.

I note that one of the changes that the Government now appears willing to accept is the Committee's recommendation that legislation be consolidated. I also note that there is now a greater willingness to accept that there were indeed problems inherent in using press releases as the basis for extensive action without the provision of standard guidelines. I welcome these changes. However, I note the explanation given by the Minister that there was a need for a press release in order to prevent speculation amongst pharmacists and entrepreneurs, which I consider to be simply an evasion of the issue. Discussions were being held for a considerable period before the press release of 24 July and 8 August 1990, so many pharmacists and others were well aware that changes were coming.

It remains my belief that the failure to provide a sound administrative framework for the changes led to chaos, and certainly did not result in there being no speculation. The variable meaning of the word `commitment' in the Minister's press release resulted in some extraordinary decisions being taken, which is hardly conducive to establishing a solid basis for a major restructuring. The Minister suggests that the continued respective roles of the Health Insurance Commission and the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority will be safeguarded from duplication by the provision of a secretarial service by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. This is no guarantee at all. In fact, since the status quo is being preserved in all aspects of the restructuring program, we must expect to see a continuing absence of clear definitions, continuing blurring of the areas of responsibility and a growing number of disadvantaged and confused pharmacists.

The Minister goes on to say that the Government believes all officers involved in administering the legislation are adequately familiar with it. I would like to believe that, but I have yet to be convinced. With regard to evaluation, one of the major concerns of the Committee was that there was a limited relationship between the supposed objectives of restructuring and the means of achieving them.

In the Minister's response of 11 September, we were advised that departmental evaluation of the process of restructuring is ongoing with the continued assistance of pharmacy bodies and that a major reform of the process was not considered necessary in late 1991. I am afraid I find this response totally unsatisfactory, as I do the promise that there will be some future computer analysis using geodemographic modelling. Surely it should have been the Department's responsibility to establish this before restructuring got under way. Is it that the Department and the PRA simply do not know what the current situation is? Why has no clear statement been issued on what has been achieved so far? Is not this response the place to state clearly that restructuring is working because there has been an appropriate and expected shift in the distribution of pharmacies, that the process has been cost effective and that the community can look forward to much more efficient and economical provision of this valued service? As this has not been said, as we have no real evaluation, I believe we still have some serious problems with the achievement of the objectives of restructuring.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

speech.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para:
—I present the Government's response to the reports of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare on: animal welfare in the racing industry; equine welfare in competitive events other than racing; and transport of livestock within Australia. I seek leave to incorporate the document in
Hansard
and move a motion in relation to the document.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The document read as follows
—

para.emphasis: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORTS OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON ANIMAL WELFARE ON TRANSPORTATION OF LIVESTOCK WITHIN AUSTRALIA, ASPECTS OF ANIMAL WELFARE IN THE RACING INDUSTRY, AND EQUINE WELFARE IN COMPETITIVE EVENTS OTHER THAN RACING

speech.para:
1.
The final three reports of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare were tabled on 3 September 1991. The reports were entitled Transport of Livestock Within Australia, Aspects of Animal Welfare in the Racing Industry and Equine Welfare in Competitive Events Other Than Racing. The Government is now in a position to respond to the reports.

2.
The reports on racing and other equine events are directed primarily towards State and Territory Governments and the controlling bodies of the sports concerned. With the exception of the Equestrian Federation of Australia, these bodies are not funded by the Commonwealth Government. The Government's role in the response to those two reports will therefore be primarily a coordinating and monitoring one, through the Sport and Recreation Ministers' Council. The National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare (NCCAW) will also be providing advice to the Government through the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, on the implementation of measures proposed by the Senate Select Committee and on any outstanding issues of animal welfare concern. The Government has brought to the attention of the Equestrian Federation of Australia those aspects of the Committee's conclusions which are within the Federation's influence. The Government will continue to contribute to equine welfare through funding sources conducted by the Australian Coaching Council, which address issues such as equine conditioning, nutrition, injury prevention, work stress and recovery. Consideration is also being given to the establishment of an Australian Horse Industry Council in order to facilitate research and development in the horse industry.

3.
The report on livestock transport contains twenty recommendations, several of which are directed specifically to Commonwealth Ministers, their Departments or Councils which play a significant coordinating role between Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments. These recommendations will be addressed in detail in this response.

4.
Legislative control of animal welfare and transport within Australia is primarily the responsibility of State and Territory Governments; the Commonwealth's involvement is limited to a coordinating role. Animal welfare legislation and codes of practice are administered by the Government of the States or Territories through which the stock travel and may vary considerably from one part of Australia to another. Model codes of practice for animal welfare are developed by the Sub-Committee on Animal Welfare (SCAW) of the Standing Committee on Agriculture. Once endorsed by the Australian Agricultural Council (AAC), these codes serve as the basis for the States and Territories to develop their own codes. The Model Codes are revised every few years to take account of advances in scientific knowledge.

5.
There is a need for uniformity in the States and Territories with regard to the transportation of livestock. The regulation and control of livestock transport is complex and, even within one State, involve at least two Government departments and several other interested parties. Furthermore, one truckload of animals can fall within several State or Territory jurisdictions during the course of one journey. This has two consequences. Livestock transporters can be fined in one State for what is quite legal in another—for example, volumetric loading is legal only in Queensland, and carriage of horses in double deck vehicles is illegal only in New South Wales. Secondly, it becomes more difficult to undertake a successful prosecution for cruelty to animals during an interstate journey unless it can be proven that the cruelty occurred in the State or Territory under the legislation of which the action is being taken.

6.
There has been an overall increase in the distances stock are being transported for slaughter, resulting from economic rationalisation of the slaughter industry, and this increases the need to address livestock transport from a national perspective so as to minimise welfare problems.

7.
The Commonwealth Department of Transport and Communications plays an important coordinating role in promoting a national perspective on road transport policies through the adoption of uniform practices. The Department's objective is to improve the operating environment of the road transport industry and reduce regulatory impediments to interstate trade. The National Road Transport Commission (NRTC) will play an important role in developing a national perspective on road transport, including the transport of livestock. The NRTC is an independent statutory authority established under Commonwealth legislation. Its role is to develop national technical and operating standards for heavy vehicle registration, regulations and charging arrangements. The regulations will include design and construction requirements, vehicle road worthiness and inspection standards, traffic codes, driver licensing standards and procedures, special codes of practice, enforcement levels and penalties for breaches. Regulations will apply nationally unless the NRTC considers there are compelling reasons to allow regional variation. The NRTC will also oversee the implementation and enforcement of those technical and operating standards by State and Territory administrations. The proposed establishment of a consultative committee on transport will ensure that the needs of both industry and government bodies are taken into consideration.

8.
The AAC, known from February 1992 as the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand (ACANZ), will also play a major role in national coordination of livestock transport policy. The Sub-Committee on Animal Welfare (SCAW) has expertise in this area from an animal production perspective and is presently revising the model codes of practice for road and rail transport of livestock into a National Model Code of Practice for Land Transport of Livestock. The AAC considered the Senate Select Committee's recommendations at its February 1992 meeting and has referred them to SCAW for detailed consideration with a view to implementation by the States and Territories. The National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare (NCCAW) has also made recommendations to the Government on how the welfare of animals during transport can be improved and its recommendations have been referred to State and Territory Ministers for consideration.

9.
I am now in a position to respond to the recommendations made in the Senate Select Committee Report on the Transportation of Livestock.

Recommendation 1: That the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Transport and Communications assess current mechanisms for national co-ordination of animal welfare and transport matters.
Supported.

The Government agrees that a national perspective is required on road transport policies, with the adoption, as far as possible, of uniform practices in the States and Territories. The Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand (ACANZ) (formerly the Australian Agricultural Council) and the National Road Transport Commission (NRTC) will play a major role in the national co-ordination of animal welfare and transport matters. Establishment of a common national livestock transport advisory committee will facilitate coordination between the two portfolios.
Recommendation 2: that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Transport and Communications establish a national livestock transport consultative committee.
Supported.

At its February 1992 meeting, the Australian Agricultural Council considered this recommendation and agreed that the Sub-Committee on Animal Welfare (SCAW) should form the core of a Consultative Committee on Land Transport of Livestock. Council considered that in addition to State and Territory Departments of Agriculture, already represented on SCAW, the Consultative Committee should include representatives of the Australian Livestock Transporters' Association, the Australian Veterinary Association, RSPCA, the National Farmers Federation, the National Road Transport Commission (NRTC) and the State and Territory Departments responsible for transport. The establishment of this Consultative Committee will be implemented by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and Minister for Transport and Communications.

Recommendation 3: that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy ensure that the Model Codes of Practice on Animal Welfare and, in particular, the Code on the Road Transport of Livestock are published in a more compact, durable and professional format.

Recommendation 4: that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in conjunction with other members of the Australian Agricultural Council ensure that these Codes are distributed to all relevant parties.
Supported in principle.

The Government agrees that the national Model Codes of Practice should be published in a compact, durable and professional format, and should be available to all relevant parties but considers that industry organisations must share the responsibility for making their members aware of, and encouraging them to comply with, the Codes. Several Model Codes of Practice have already been published by CSIRO as part of the SCA Technical Report Series and are available from CSIRO at $10 per copy. It is intended that the new Codes and those currently under revision, including the transport codes, will be published in the same format. The Government acknowledges that the cost may be a disincentive and the Sub-Committee on Animal Welfare is currently addressing the need to achieve wider dissemination and greater awareness of the codes in conjunction with State and Territory Governments, statutory authorities and industry organisations.

Recommendation 5: that all State and Territory Governments adopt the Model Codes of Practice and, in particular, the Code on Road Transport of Livestock and give them recognition by regulation under relevant legislation relating to the prevention of cruelty to animals. The Committee further recommends that the codes be disallowable instruments and that breaches of the codes, although not actionable as such, may be used as evidence in support of prosecutions under provision of the principal legislation.
Supported in principle.

The availability and status of the Model Codes of Practice is an issue which was addressed by the Senate Select Committee both in this report and the report on the Culling of Large Feral Animals in the Northern Territory and which is being given continuing consideration by Governments. There is a diversity of views among State and Territory Governments, industry bodies and animal welfare organisations regarding the status of Codes of Practice, some considering they should have legislative backing while others believe their value is greatest if they are regarded simply as guidelines as is the case in most instances. There is also a divergence of view as to whether the codes should reflect average farming practice or the leading edge of good animal welfare practice.

The Government considers that this lack of agreement on the role of the codes is limiting their effectiveness and needs to be resolved, particularly in the case of Codes on transport. The Government's view is that the Model Codes endorsed by AAC should have the status of guidelines to industry on good animal welfare practice, based on the best available scientific information, and that measures which are necessary to prevent serious animal welfare problems should be incorporated into the State and Territory legislation rather than into Codes of Practice. The need to make Codes of Practice more readily available to, and accepted by, the relevant industries is recognised by both Governments and industry and is being addressed through SCAW.

Recommendation 6: that all State and Territory Governments ensure that authorities enforcing legislation relating to prevention of cruelty to animals being transported be given sufficient powers and resources to perform these tasks.
Supported in principle.

It is the responsibility of State and Territory Governments to ensure that legislation relating to cruelty to animals being transported is appropriate and can be enforced. This matter has been referred to the States and Territories through the Australian Agricultural Council.
Recommendation 7: that all State and Territory Governments prohibit the transport of horses in double decked vehicles.
Supported in principle.

The Government considers that measures need to be implemented to protect the welfare of horses and other animals during transport. However, it is not convinced that there is sufficient evidence of welfare problems arising from the use of double-deck vehicles per se to warrant their being banned at this time. The greatest opportunity for improving the welfare of horses during transport may lie in other measures such as selection of horses of suitable height for the crates to be used, and careful handling and driving. Research in Queensland has demonstrated that horses can be carried safely in double-decker transport, provided there is sufficient head clearance to allow them to stand comfortably and that they are drafted on height before transport; however, opinion is still divided on whether these criteria are likely to be met in practice. The Government concurs with the view of the Bureau of Rural Resources Report entitled "The Welfare of Horses Being Transported" which concludes that further research is needed into the welfare implications of horses travelling long distances with their heads close to wither height before a conclusive statement can be made on the humaneness of double-deck transport for horses. The Government urges the Northern Territory and those States from which horses are sourced for slaughter to undertake such research as a matter of priority and for all States and Territories to develop a consistent regulatory approach based on the outcome. The Consultative Committee on Land Transport of Livestock will be asked to consider this issue.

Recommendation 8: that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in consultation with other members of the Australian Agricultural Council amend the Model Code of Practice on the Road Transport of Livestock to include

.
specific limitations on the strength of the current in electric prods:

.
Clear instructions on appropriate use of electric prods; and

.
Clear guidance on inappropriate use of electric prods.

Recommendation 9: that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in consultation with other members of the Australian Agricultural council review the recommendations contained within the Model Codes of Practice relating to duration of journeys involving the transport of livestock.

Recommendation 10: that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in consultation with other members of the Australian Agricultural Council include guidelines similar to those set out in the New South Wales Government pamphlet "Livestock Traffic Accidents" into the Model Code of Practice on the Road Transport of Livestock.
Supported.

These recommendations are being considered by the Standing Committee on Agriculture Sub-Committee on Animal Welfare in its review of the Model Codes of Practice for Road and Rail Transport of Livestock.

Recommendation 11: that the Australian Agricultural Council and the Australian Transport Advisory Council co-operate in the drafting of a set of national design rules appropriate for the registration of vehicles to be licensed to carry livestock. Once drawn up, the rules could be administered in parallel with Australian Design Rules.
Supported in principle.

The Government agrees that a set of national design rules appropriate for the registration of vehicles licensed to carry livestock could be a positive step in a welfare sense and has referred this recommendation to the relevant Ministerial Councils. The Consultative Committee on Land Transport of Livestock would be a suitable body to carry out this task. Research into design of vehicles to be licensed to carry livestock has been carried out by the Victorian Department of Agriculture and the Queensland Department of Primary Industries and much of the information needed to draft national design requirements should already be available from this research.

This committee will be asked to co-ordinate the drafting of a set of national minimum standards for design of livestock transport vehicles, ramps and yards. The National Road Transport Commission should be involved in any design standards relating to heavy vehicles designed to carry livestock.
Recommendation 12: that research into optimum density loading and other aspects of the conditions associated with the transport of livestock should be extended.

The Government concurs with the view of the Committee that optimum density loading is beneficial for both animal welfare and meat quality. The adoption of this practice should be encouraged by the livestock industry by highlighting the nominal benefits resulting from reduced bruising and stress.
The question of exempting optimum loaded livestock vehicles from weight checks remains contentious (see Recommendation 14).

Recommendation 13: that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with other members of the Australian Agricultural Council review the loading densities recommended in the Model Code of Practice on Road Transport of Livestock. Upon completion of this review densities should be set out in the Code with stated margins for flexibility and applied nationally.
Supported.
This recommendation will be taken into account by the Sub-Committee on Animal Welfare in its revision of the Model Codes of Practice for Road and Rail Transport of Livestock.
Recommendation 14: that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Transport and Communications, through appropriate inter-governmental bodies:

(i)
seek uniform road transport regulations which would permit vehicles carrying livestock to be loaded to optimum density and exempt such vehicles from regular and random weight checks.

(ii)
propose that, if all governments cannot agree to the removal of weight limits for semi-trailers of standard length when carrying livestock, regulations specifying such maximum length and tare weight be introduced as would result in average or typical laden weights falling within the current weight limits.
Supported in principle.

A distinction needs to be made between "optimum density loading" and "volumetric loading" as the latter term is widely used to describe the system which operates in Queensland, under which trucks loaded to optimum density are exempt from compliance with weight limits.

Livestock producers and transporters strongly support volume loading on the grounds of both animal welfare and productivity considerations. The Australian Livestock Transporters Association is in favour of volume loading.

The overriding concern of the Department of Transport and Communications in the movement of livestock is that any initiatives are implemented on a national basis. Whether or not optimum density or volume loading is adopted on a uniform and reciprocal basis is a matter for the States and Territories to resolve. If a decision is made to introduce optimum density or volume loading, the Department would support the establishment of a consistent national regulatory framework to improve the operating environment of the livestock industry and minimise regulatory impediments to interstate trade.

Volume loading has not been adopted outside Queensland because of a lack of general agreement between the State and Territory Governments due to concerns about greater road damage and safety. The National Road Transport Commission is currently preparing a discussion paper on national arrangements for moving specific commodities which will encompass volume loading of livestock.
The Government considers that the establishment of a common national livestock transport advisory committee (see Recommendation 1) will facilitate resolution of this longstanding issue.

Recommendation 15: that Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments, rural and producer organisations and transport industry associations promote training programs to extend the knowledge and skills of those who handle livestock during transport. In addition to special driving techniques, these programs should include training in all aspects of the Model Code of Practice on the Road Transport of Livestock.
Supported.

The Government strongly supports the concept of industry accreditation and has provided funds to the Road Transport Forum, which represents the major industry associations including the Australian Livestock Transporters' Association, to develop national standards covering training, health and fitness and vehicle maintenance. It is also monitoring development of the proposed national accreditation scheme through the Australian Road Transport Advisory Committee and AUSTROADS, a national association of road traffic authorities.

Recommendation 16: that all drivers of vehicles carrying livestock as part of a commercial transport enterprise should be properly trained and possess a suitably endorsed vehicle driving licence. This will ensure that those offering services in the livestock transport industry have undertaken an accepted form of training or have demonstrated a specified level of competence in livestock handling.
Supported in principle.

The issue of driving licences is a State and Territory function but qualifications are a NRTC function. Any proposals to include additional information on the licence would require the agreement of all States and Territories. At the request of the Australian Transport Advisory Council, this recommendation has been referred to the National Road Transport Commission for consideration. The Government considers that in any training and licence endorsement system, appropriate distinctions are made between species of livestock and the Consultative Committee on Land Transport of Livestock could provide expert advice on this matter.
Recommendation 17: that Australian National Railways take positive measures to encourage owners of livestock or their agents to provide train drovers for consignments of stock on ANR services.
Supported.

The Australian National Railways Commission (AN) advises that the decision to provide a train drover when cattle are transported by rail rests with the owners of the cattle or their agents. Arrangements are still in place for a drover to be accommodated free of charge on trains conveying livestock, subject to prior application by the consignor. The AN also recently sought the views of the companies and associations with a major role in the transport of cattle on the Alice Springs line. Those responding saw no need for the accompaniment of cattle by a train drover, but appreciated that the facility was available if required.
Recommendation 18: that Australian National Railways review the operation of Train No. 7166 in order to ascertain whether transit times can be reduced.
Supported.

The AN advises that the timetable of Train No. 7166 is to be reviewed as part of an overall rationalisation of train services on the Alice Springs line, taking into account the requirements of loading other than livestock and the need to integrate all services. It may therefore be possible to schedule the arrival of Train No. 7166 at Dry Creek for 10am Sunday and the scheduled journey time would then be approximately thirty two hours compared to the existing thirty six and a half hours for this service. This change will be implemented at the beginning of the 1992 season for transporting livestock from the Northern Territory.

Recommendation 19: that the Department of Transport and Communications accord priority to the promulgation of amendments to Marine Orders Part 43, (Cargo and Cargo Handling—Livestock) pursuant to the Navigation (Orders) Regulations under the Navigation Act 1912.
Supported.
The amendments to the Marine Orders Part 43 referred to in this recommendation were implemented on 1 September 1991.

Recommendation 20: that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in consultation with other members of the Australian Agricultural Council ensure that properly trained personnel, experienced in stock handling, load and unload animals involved in transport by sea.
Supported in principle.

A number of such courses have already been held and have been attended by seagoing personnel, waterside workers and Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) surveyors. The courses, run by the Victorian Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs at the departmental farm near Werribee, are held under the supervision of veterinarians and provide practical experience in the handling of animals. The selection of personnel to load and unload stock is not under the direct control of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy or his State and Territory counterparts. However, the process is overseen by a Government veterinarian.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.speaker: Burns Sen B.R

talk.start.para: —As the Chairman of the Animal Welfare Committee, I welcome the Government's response to the reports on transport of livestock in Australia, aspects of welfare in the racing industry and equine welfare in competitive events other than racing.

para.tab: I wish to refer briefly today to three matters raised in the response to the Committee's report on transport of livestock. Firstly, the response recognises, as did the Committee's report, that legislative control of animal welfare and transport within Australia is primarily the responsibility of State and Territory governments and that the Commonwealth's involvement is limited to a coordinating role. As legislative controls and codes of practice may vary considerably from one part of Australia to another, the need for a consistent and coordinated approach becomes obvious. For example, during the course of one journey, a truckload of animals can come within the jurisdictions of several States or Territories and hence a livestock transporter can be fined in one State for what is legal in another.

Therefore, I welcome the Government's initiative, in response to the Committee's recommendation, to establish a National Livestock Transport Consultative Committee. This Committee will include representatives of the Australian Livestock Transporters Association, the RSPCA, the National Farmers Federation and the National Road Transport Commission—all organisations which are involved with these matters.

Secondly, I note the statement that the Government is not convinced that there is sufficient evidence to prohibit the transport of horses in double-decked vehicles. In this regard, I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that, in 1987, the New South Wales Parliament prohibited the transport of horses in these vehicles after a series of incidents involving several injuries to horses carried in double-deckers.
I bring to the attention of the Senate some of the remarks that were made in New South Wales at that time. The State Government argued in the following terms:

Horses on the lower deck [of a double-decked trailer] are unable to adopt a normal head carriage. Horses are forced to hold their heads at or below the level of their withers [shoulders]. This necessitates extension of the dorsal muscles (stretching of the top muscles of the neck) for prolonged periods in the case of long distance transport. An opinion on the effects of this type of head carriage was sought from Dr Rex Butterfield, former Professor of Veterinary Anatomy at Sydney University and President of the Australian Equine Research Foundation. Dr Butterfield said this position would cause great discomfort to horses forced to maintain it for extended periods. He added that it would also make it difficult for a horse to maintain equilibrium when the natural tendency when unbalanced is to elevate the head.

Severe head injuries, including skull fractures, eye injuries and deep lacerations, are frequently sustained by horses travelling on the top decks of trucks—due to the horses being hit by overhanging branches, etc.

speech.para: This was the basis for the outlawing of the carriage of those animals on double-decker trucks. I find it very difficult to understand the sort of advice that might have led the Minister to make the comments he did about not being convinced of the sufficiency of the evidence. For instance, paragraph 2.5 of the report states:

para.tab: The position adopted by the New South Wales Government is also supported by animal welfare organisations. RSPCA Australia's policy statement maintains that the Society "will only accept the transport of horses in single deck vehicles especially designed for the needs of the species carried". Similarly, ANZFAS opposes the use of double-decked vehicles for horses.

speech.para: Paragraph 2.6 states:

para.tab: Representatives of other organisations appearing before the Committee were opposed to the use of double deckers for horses. These included Mr Michael Clark, of the Australian Council of Livestock Agents and Dr Lex Carroll and Mrs Ruth Wade, speaking on behalf of the Cattlemen's Union.

speech.para: That is by no means an exhaustive list of the people who oppose this practice. During the Committee's investigations I did not talk, either privately or officially, to anyone who did not agree that such a practice should be outlawed. Therefore, I again suggest to the Government, through the Minister, that it take whatever action is possible, and not give succour to those State governments which appear to say, through pressure from whatever lobby, that this practice should not be outlawed.

talk.start.para: —The Government, in its response to this report, has basically opted out of making any recommendations about the reports on racing or competitive equestrian sports. I find it a little incongruous that the Government can say on the one hand that it has no involvement with these sports while on the other hand suggesting that a National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare will provide advice to the Government on the recommendations. One minute it is saying that it wants to opt out and the next it is saying that it wants to opt in.

para.tab: Given the enormous success of the very much underfunded equestrian team in the recent Olympics—the team of Matt Ryan from Singleton, Andrew Hoy from Culcairn, Gillian Rolton from South Australia, and David Green, who is now resident in England but previously a Queenslander—one would hope that in future the Federal Government takes a more active interest in this equestrian sport as well as others. If our team members can be successful—as they were with almost nothing from the Federal Government—imagine how much better they might have been with some assistance for coaching and other financial help that it has given to other sports such as swimming.

I welcome the Government's response to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare on the transport of livestock within Australia. I believe the report was a credible document. The report involved considerable research on behalf of the Committee and its secretariat, and a large number of honourable senators were involved during the Committee's existence. I am pleased that many of our recommendations have been supported. I say to Senator Burns that I believe it shows the worth of the Senate—the Senate that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) wants to get rid of. But I am disappointed that other recommendations use the hackneyed phrase `supported in principle'. That is too often akin to doing nothing or duckshoving to yet another committee, subcommittee or department.

Recommendations 1 and 2 highlight the need for a national approach to transport. In a country such as Australia, I believe it is absurd that we have different rules for different States, given that a truck can drive through three or four States in 24 hours.
