It is obvious that only a national approach to transport will be effective and efficient and in the best interests of the animals involved. I am concerned that at the Federal level we have various committees dealing with animal welfare. We have SCAW, the Subcommittee on Animal Welfare, the National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare and now subcommittees of these to review various legislation.

The report back process under this regime has a tendency to get bogged down. I hope this will not be the case with the recommendations from our report that have been referred to these committees. Our recommendations, such as codes of practice, may well get lost in the toing and froing, and it might be another decade or so before the drivers who transport livestock become aware of such codes. We found in the inquiry that, too often, drivers and transport companies were unaware that such codes existed. I hope that the new revised codes are better circulated and publicised in the future.

I note that distribution of the new codes, which was recommendation 4, is only supported in principle; in other words, it is not our job. If everyone says that, there is no point in writing them. Recommendations 5 and 6 on the uniformity of animal welfare legislation have once again been referred through the Agricultural Council to the various States and Territories. Although it is a matter for the State Governments—rodeos have been banned in the ACT, even though they are not held here—this ad hoc approach to animal welfare laws should obviously stop as soon as possible. Constant reminders through the Agricultural Council might be the only way, but it definitely needs to be repeated.

The response to recommendation 7 is probably the most disappointing of all. Our Committee called for all State and Territory governments to prohibit the transport of horses in double-decker vehicles, which the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Burns, made reference to a little while ago. The response is, in my view, a total cop-out by the Government. There was an abundance of evidence to prove that transport of horses in this manner is inhumane. Offhand, about the only submission to favour such a move was the Queensland Department of Agriculture, which obviously had considerable pressure from long-haul transport drivers and maybe horse meat processors. Of course it is cheaper to use one truck rather than two to transport 60 head of horses, but to take animals from Queensland through to Peterborough in South Australia by this method is barbaric in this latter half of the twentieth century.

I hope the new Consultative Committee on Land Transport of Livestock acts quickly to ensure a uniform ruling on this issue. I believe that anyone who is interested in horses—especially horses that have been friends of the people who have been riding them—would believe that the practice of horses being sent away to spend the end of their days in such an inhumane way should stop.

I hope also that this committee looks favourably and acts quickly on national design rules for vehicles. We need minimum standards before we can start to achieve uniformity of legislation. The Government response to recommendation 12 on further examination on optimum density loading comparative to volumetric loading is neither a yes nor a no. It merely states, `The issue is contentious'. That is precisely why the Committee suggested that further research on this was needed.

Other recommendations involving training programs for drivers are also supported. I hope that the major driving and other relevant industry organisations have already started to work towards this. They said during our inquiry that they were. Personal experience has shown me that there is a wide divergence in the skills and the expertise of drivers employed by transport companies. In the inquiry on which we have embarked into the feedlot industry, it was quite interesting to hear that the industry is making sure that the drivers who bring their stock in and take their stock away are their accredited drivers. It is so important that the animals are handled in the correct manner due to problems of bruising and stress, and other bad handling methods which make for bad-eating meat.

I believe that, for their own part, transport companies have little to go on when hiring drivers other than the experience the driver says he has. If there were accredited driver training schools, at least prospective employees could demonstrate some expertise in this area. I think that would be a step in the right direction. I am pleased that the Government has finally responded to these reports, even if it has taken some 13 months to do so.

speech.speaker: Bell Sen R.J.

talk.start.para:
—I, too, am pleased to finally see a response to these three reports of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, which cover the transportation of livestock within Australia, aspects of animal welfare in the racing industry and equine welfare in competitive events other than racing. I will direct my remarks in this debate to the
Transport of Livestock Within Australia
report and the Government's response to that. As a member of the Committee, I share with the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Committee their disappointment to some extent that the Government has chosen to express its response with words such as `supported in principle' and has not given sufficient detail to how this principle will be either enacted or enforced in sufficient circumstances.

para.tab: On the first page of the Government's response, at the end of the paragraph under point 2, mention is made that consideration is being given to the establishment of an Australian horse industry council in order to facilitate research and development in the horse industry. It sounds quite a good sentiment to express but gives us no indication of either a timetable or a method by which such a council can be established. As I have said, it does not indicate when it will be established.

Similar sorts of wordage are contained throughout this response and I think that is the reason for the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman expressing some degree of frustration with it. Although it seems to be a response which takes into account the concerns that the Committee found through examining numerous witnesses and travelling extensively on the inquiry, the response lacks a definite approach.

We are told that legislative control of animal welfare and transport within Australia is primarily the responsibility of the State and Territory governments, and I can certainly forgive the Commonwealth Government for making that observation. We are told that the Commonwealth's involvement is limited to a coordinating role. What the four parties that were represented on the Committee unanimously found—and this was strongly supported by all witnesses who came before it—was the need for somebody to take the lead and to do a little bit more than coordinating by showing that leadership. Suggestions were made about the areas in which leadership was required urgently. The coordination was going along fine, but without leadership the coordination was not producing the results that were necessary in this particular area of animal welfare.

It is all very well for the Government response to include a list of what legislation and codes of practices are administered by the governments of the States and Territories and to illustrate lack of agreement by those States so that a transporter could traverse several areas of jurisdiction in carting animals from one part of the country to the other. That is hardly a revelation; Australians have been observing that for almost 200 years. This is a big country involving many different sets of circumstances. What we need is some leadership in pulling these documents together and making them logical and relevant.
Parts of the response do not merit cynicism. I congratulate the Government on them. In response to recommendation 2 the Government proposes:

speech.para: that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Transport and Communications establish a livestock transport consultative committee.

In short, the Government's response is to say that the establishment of this consultative committee will be implemented by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Transport and Communications. That is certainly welcome, but again I observe in passing that there is no indication of a timetable, so perhaps it is a hollow promise; I have no reason to think it is anything else.

para.tab: I can agree with the Government's response to recommendation 4, which is:

speech.para: that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in conjunction with other members of the Australian Agricultural Council ensure that these Codes—
I will just refer to them as that because it is understood what they are—
are distributed to all relevant parties.
The Government does say `supported in principle' and, on this occasion, I can agree with that because part of the explanation given by the Government is that it, the Government:
considers that industry organisations must share the responsibility for making their members aware of, and encouraging them to comply with, the Codes.

That is something that I agree with. It is all very well to require the Government to print these in a cheap and available format and recommend that they be adopted, but there is a dual responsibility, and I must agree with that.

para.tab: I will not take too much of the Senate's time by reading each of the recommendations and drawing a conclusion which is shared by most of the members on the Committee. I agree with the sentiments that have already been expressed by the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman. I have faith in the content of the response which, I believe is forthcoming from my colleague Senator Calvert. I share with him the sorts of sentiments that I understand he will express.

This Committee was unanimous in its recommendations; there is not a minority report. The Committee was exhaustive in its discussions and I must say that the inspections and the hearings that were conducted by the Committee were well attended by the Committee members. I am confident in knowing that the sorts of reactions that I am expressing here are shared by the other Committee members. Recommendation 7 states:

speech.para: that all State and Territory Governments prohibit the transport of horses in double decked vehicles.

I note the Government response that it `supported in principle'. This recommendation can be criticised by all Committee members who would ask what does it mean when the Government response in part says:

The Government concurs with the view of the Bureau of Rural Resources Report entitled "The Welfare of Horses Being Transported" which concludes that further research is needed into the welfare implications of horses travelling long distances with their heads close to wither height before a conclusive statement can be made on the humaneness of double-deck transport for horses.

I know that I can speak on behalf of other members of the Committee when I say that our Committee heard sufficient evidence to know what effect that would have and also to make the recommendation, as we did in recommendation 7, without any qualification. That recommendation was made after the exhaustive hearing of evidence that indicated that it was not a matter needing further research.

para.tab: The research was presented to our Committee and our Committee unanimously accepted it. The response of the Government in this instance I would describe as being unacceptable because it is ill-informed.
The Government's response to recommendation 14 is quite lengthy. In part, recommendation 14 states:

speech.para: (i) seek uniform road transport regulations which would permit vehicles carrying livestock to be loaded to optimum density and exempt such vehicles from regular and random weight checks.
There is further amplification of that recommendation as well. In part, the Government's response is to tell us that:
Volume loading has not been adopted outside Queensland because of a lack of general agreement between the State and Territory Governments due to concerns about greater road damage and safety.

That observation is not contested. The recommendation that we are making to the Commonwealth Government is for it to remove that lack of agreement, to take the lead, show the States how agreement can be reached and use the evidence that has been presented to the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare as a basis for implementing a recommendation which is founded that evidence.

para.tab: We are told at the end of the Government's response to recommendation 14 that:

speech.para: The Government considers that the establishment of a common national livestock and transport advisory committee will facilitate resolution of this longstanding issue.

Although that sounds as if we might be getting somewhere, we are caught up in wordage. It `will facilitate resolution'; it will not require resolution. I am afraid that what the industry requires is the resolution of this longstanding issue. It may be facilitated, but I am afraid that is about as weak as most of the responses that we have before us.

para.tab: Recommendation 16 recommends that all drivers of vehicles carrying livestock as part of a commercial transport enterprise should be properly trained and possess a suitably endorsed vehicle driving licence, et cetera. We are told that that is supported in principle. Then we are given the revelation that the issue of driving licences is a State and Territory function but qualifications are a National Road Transport Commission function, and any proposals to include additional information on the licence would require the agreement of all States and Territories. We know this; it is not news. We are asking for leadership, and perhaps heading towards the implementation of relevant and necessary accreditation of people who have been trained in the transportation of livestock. I am disappointed that what we are told in response is a bunch of truisms rather than some enlightenment that we can follow or leadership which is worth while.

As the Deputy Chairman of this Committee, Senator Brownhill, mentioned, a couple of years after hearing evidence on this particular subject, the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs is hearing evidence from those who are involved with the feedlot industry. We are hearing evidence from the operators of cattle feedlots that training in and proper execution of their duties by those involved in transporting cattle is crucial to the profitability of the industry. It is a matter which is treated so seriously by the operators that we were told in evidence that operators employ their own regular drivers and are very reluctant to consider employing somebody who is not known to them or recommended strongly by somebody who knows what requirements there are in the moving of livestock.

That is so important. We were told this at this particular inquiry a couple of years after we first asked about, and then had confirmed, the need to train drivers and to ensure that they were capable of understanding the special needs of transporting livestock. Having been told this again at a different committee of inquiry only serves to confirm that which the Government does not recognise sufficiently strongly in this response.
Recommendation 18 states:

speech.para: that Australian National Railways review the operation of Train No. 7166 in order to ascertain whether transit times can be reduced.
We are told that this is supported and that Australian National Railways has been contacted and has actually explained how this may be—

talk.start.para: —Provided that train No. 7166 arrives at Dry Creek at 10 a.m. on Sunday.

—I agree with Senator Calvert; provided that train No. 7166 arrives at Dry Creek at 10 a.m. on Sunday, everything will be hunky-dory. This all sounds very well. Several witnesses addressed themselves to the problems of rail transport. Page 59 of the report, which honourable senators may care to refer to, states:

speech.para: Dr Peter Barnard, Director of Transport of the National Farmers' Federation, referred to the results of a study on bruising and other indicators of animal welfare incurred during various modes of transport. The study concluded that "rail came out worst".

para.tab: It was suggested to the Committee that rail's poor record in running to schedule, owing to both delayed departures and unplanned stops, exacerbates animal welfare problems. For example, Dr Plant, a member of the Australian Veterinary Association, commented on "sheep leaving Broken Hill, where they had to be loaded at a certain time in the morning but probably did not leave until the afternoon".

speech.para: Dr Wirth and others added to that evidence. The point of my raising that now is to suggest that the good intentions of Australian National Railways, in suggesting that everything would be fine provided that train No. 7166 arrived at Dry Creek at 10 a.m. on Sunday, may be all very well, but in practice we have evidence that such schedules can go wrong. The whole matter requires a little more than the assurance that it is possible to fix it. In this response we are looking for something more than what amounts to a response of words rather than action. It may read very well, but I would have preferred to see a timetable of action and assurances that were couched in legislative terms rather than promises.

talk.start.para: —I would like to follow on from where Senator Bell left off on the Government's response to the reports of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. I wholeheartedly agree with the point he made that in some ways it responds to some things and leaves a lot out. It has been very detailed in its response to the matters that the Commonwealth sees as its own, and that is mainly related to the transport of livestock. It is what it does not say that I believe is the most disappointing part of this response.

para.tab: This Government has done the usual trick of most Federal governments over the years: when they see something that is the responsibility of the States, or that they think is the responsibility of the States, they handball it off to the States and it goes back to where it started from. It is most disappointing, as a member of the now disbanded Animal Welfare Committee, to see the amount of work that was put in by not only ourselves but also those people who made submissions and all those well-intentioned people who put forward their views and tried in their own way to improve what has been rather contentious. I am referring mainly to the racing industry.

It is a disappointment, considering the amount of time we spent on the report and the publicity we received. Some of the publicity was not all that positive—when we attended the Melbourne Cup, for instance—and I can understand the criticism. When one looks at our report, one sees it is only so thick, and it is a disappointment that of even those recommendations the Government is saying, `It is really not our business; it goes back to the States'.
The racing industry is a very important industry. It has an annual turnover of more than $250 billion a year. It employs 250,000 people. The best we can come up with is a report only so thick because we did not have the time, the resources, the know-how and the willpower to finish it because it was too hard. By the same token, in response to that report, the Government is saying, `It's a matter for the States'.

If we are serious about things such as the use of the whip and all the animal welfare issues that were raised, including the racing of two-year-olds, harness racing and greyhound racing, I am sure we should have built on the evidence we received and made the report a more comprehensive document. The sporting people involved in the racing clubs were looking for something better. They did not get it. The response they got from the Government was even worse. It has gone back to the States where it will stay and nothing will happen.

Something positive did come out of this report, believe it or not. When we were taking evidence on the sulky design and harness racing, Mr Bede Ireland, one of the people who submitted evidence, put forward a very strong case for changing the sulky design because of the accidents that had been happening in harness racing in Australia. We gave a platform to those people who were concerned about the design of sulkies to put forward their views. We did not make a recommendation—another thing about which we were not positive enough in our report. We did not pursue the matter because we ran out of time, but at least we raised the issue, the issue has been debated and I believe in recent days statements have been made and action will be taken about changing the design of sulkies, which could be of some assistance to the safety of our racing industry.

Another area that we covered, which again was not examined in the Government's response, is equine welfare in competitive events other than racing—and here I refer to rodeos. As rodeos are seen as a State issue, there was virtually no response from the Commonwealth Government. But I notice there has been a response from the Labor controlled ACT Government. It is in the process of—if it has not already—banning rodeos, along with performing live animals in circuses. This is the same Government that has allowed abortion clinics to open up and, in recent days, has decriminalised drug taking in the form of marijuana. The ACT has always been the centre in Australia for obtaining pornographic movies. The ACT Government does not have enough money to support decent health care for aged people in the Australian Capital Territory, but it certainly knows how to ban rodeos and how to stop people from enjoying good, wholesome family fun at a traditional circus.

It is disappointing to see that the Government has not responded to the issue of rodeos. They are part of our culture, particularly in the northern parts of Australia where the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), who is at the table, comes from. Rodeos are held in his area and I do not think the governments there have any great problems with them. Most of the RSPCA bodies keep an eye on those things.

I turn to the issue of the transport of live animals. In Queensland there is optimum loading; in other areas it is called volume loading. As far as I am concerned, it is commonsense loading. If someone has a truck and puts as many animals on that truck as is reasonable, without causing too much discomfort to the animals, not only is the situation being avoided where those animals may be bruised and trampled on and welfare matters may arise but also the amount of money people pay for freight is minimised. It seems that optimum loading is allowed in only one State at this point in time because of the load weight limitations in other areas in Australia.

The Federal Government supports the recommendations for a national set of standards for the loading of livestock. It also supports in principle the recommendation that drivers of vehicles carrying livestock be properly licensed and have the proper qualifications to cart livestock and—a very important area—that owners provide train drivers or clearers for the stock that spend so much time on rail transport. The sooner those recommendations are put into place the better.

All in all, it is good to see that the Government is supporting some of the recommendations. I hope it supports them through to fruition. I guess support in principle is okay but, as I said at the start of my speech tonight, someone has to pick up the recommendations of the racing industry report and the equine welfare report. In the endurance riding area, a significant number of horses are being killed from overriding. That came through to us loud and clear. It is important that we have a decent report as soon as possible on the problems in the multi-billion dollar racing industry. As soon as we have that, it is to be hoped that the Commonwealth Government—whichever agency it may be—will come up with some national principles and national rules.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debate.sub1.title: Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations

speech.speaker: McKiernan Sen J.P.

talk.start.para:
—On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, I present a report of the Committee entitled
Australia's Refugee and Humanitarian System: Achieving a Balance between Refuge and Control
, together with submissions, transcripts of evidence and minutes of proceedings. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.para: The tabling statement will be somewhat different from the tabling statement put down in the other place this afternoon. The reasons for that will be obvious as I go through the tabling statement. I pay tribute to the secretariat of the Committee who assisted in the development of the report. I draw particular attention to the Committee's legal adviser, Dr Kathryn Cronin, and the current Committee Secretary, Mr Andres Lomp. Also worthy of mention is the previous Secretary of the Committee, Ms Robina Mills, and secretariat staff, Miss Dianne Fraser and Miss Cassandra Paulus.

para.tab: The report is and will in time be recognised as a very significant report in this debate on this most delicate subject. I am pleased to be associated with the majority findings and recommendations of the Committee. The report focuses on all issues concerning on-shore asylum seekers, that is, those persons who seek asylum at Australia's borders and persons who are temporary residents in or illegal entrants into Australia and who seek asylum within Australia. This report is the most comprehensive assessment of the on-shore refugee situation yet undertaken in Australia by any public body.
During the inquiry, the Committee received a large number of submissions and took a considerable amount of public evidence at

speech.para: hearings over a two-year period. It is worth mentioning as an aside that during that two-year period over 300 asylum seekers arrived on the shores of this nation in boats.

para.tab: The Committee's inquiry, and this report, has come at a critical time. Today, the world is faced with a refugee crisis of proportions not seen since the Second World War. Australia, like many other countries around the world, is faced with an increasing number of asylum seekers applying for refugee status either at the border or once they have entered the country. It is estimated by the United Nations High Commission for Refugees that there are some 17.5 million refugees world wide. Fifty-five thousand of those are recognised as being people in need of immediate resettlement in a third or other country.

The problem is even greater than that. I seek leave to incorporate a document into
Hansard
which outlines the causes for international displacement of refugees and refugee-like movements throughout the world. I have sought permission from representatives of the Opposition to have the document incorporated.
Leave granted

talk.start.para: —This document indicates that some 42 million people around the world may be in need of assistance. This is more than double the entire population of Australia. The problem is massive; there is no question about that. Incidentally, the document that I incorporated was one which came from a conference held in Sydney earlier in the year called `Welcome Stranger'. It was convened by the Australian Catholic Bishops Committee for Migrant Affairs and the Australian Council of Churches Refugee and Migrant Services. To deal with this growing problem, Australia and other major countries of resettlement such as the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom have been reviewing and amending their refugee laws and processing arrangements.

para.tab: The Joint Standing Committee's inquiry has been an important part of that review process. With countries around the world looking to each other for solutions to their own refugee difficulties, the Committee report takes on a significant international dimension. The recommendations in this report will be compared with and assessed against the proposals which other countries are bringing to the refugee debate. In the report, the Committee has sought to achieve a balance between the best humanitarian outcome for asylum seekers while ensuring that Australia maintains control over its refugee programs and systems.

During the inquiry, the Committee had to come to terms with a number of changes to Australia's on-shore refugee and humanitarian system implemented by the Government. Through these changes, the Government has sought to address the deficiencies in the existing processing arrangements. Most of the evidence to the inquiry supported the establishment of a simpler and speedier processing system for on-shore asylum seekers. There was a strong view that lengthy delays in processing not only disadvantage genuine refugees by the prolonged uncertainty in their lives, but also provide an incentive for those who do not have legitimate refugee claims to lodge an asylum application as a mechanism for prolonging their stay in Australia.

In this report, the Committee has noted the recent changes which have been implemented and announced in relation to both the primary refugee decision making process and the review procedures. At the primary stage, the changes include priority processing of border claimants and detained illegal entrants, time limits on the lodgement of applications and greater emphasis on case officers obtaining information at interview.

At the review stage, the changes include the recently announced replacement of the Refugee Status Review Committee with a new and independent Refugee Review Tribunal in 1993. The Committee anticipates that the RRT will be demonstrably fairer, should allow for more accurate assessment of the merits of a claim and should be faster and less costly. The Committee, though, was concerned to ensure that there would be consistency in decision making between the various members appointed to the Tribunal. For this reason, it has recommended the appointment of a senior member to the RRT who would be responsible for allocating work to Tribunal members, ensuring development and enhancement of country expertise and who would be empowered to establish three-member Tribunal panels to consider model case types for persuasive authority.

During the inquiry, one notable criticism of the existing decision making process was that information available to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs regarding events and circumstances in particular countries was incomplete and out of date. The Department itself admitted in evidence to the Committee that the data available to it is limited as its documentation centre is still in the formative stages. To rectify this problem, the Committee has made a series of recommendations aimed at improving the information which is available to both the Department and the review body.

In particular, the Committee has recommended that the Department establish and maintain a current and comprehensive database relating to every country in the existing refugee case load for use by departmental officers and the Refugee Review Tribunal. In addition, refugee applicants should be able to request and obtain all publicly available information which is used by the Department or the Tribunal in making its decisions.

The Committee also gave consideration to the existing procedures for granting entry on humanitarian grounds. In this report, the Committee has endorsed the principle of providing short term extensions of stay to particular ethnic or nationality groups in humanitarian need. Recent examples of this policy include the concessionary arrangements applied to the nationals of Kuwait and Iraq during the Gulf conflict and to nationals of the former Yugoslavia. The unique situation relating to students in Australia from the People's Republic of China is dealt with by way of a separate chapter in this report.

In the Committee's view, such a policy allows the Government to respond appropriately by providing protection to classes in need while ensuring that such protection is given for the term of the conflict or disaster which is the basis of the need and not beyond it. To this effect, the Committee has recommended that short term extensions of temporary stay not only should be given to individuals in a class or group affected by civil disorder, but also should be considered for individuals in groups whose homes or livelihoods have been affected by a major natural disaster. The areas affected by the civil disorder or natural disaster could be either a nation state or parts of a nation state.

To ensure that the temporary extension of stay is given to those who actually need it, the Committee has recommended that where repeated extensions of stay in excess of one year have been given, before any further permit is granted the applicants should be expected to show not only that they are citizens of the country affected by the civil strife or natural disaster, but additionally that their homes, livelihood and families are in areas affected, or that they would be required to return to the area affected if returned home. The Committee was unanimous in support of this measure but unfortunately that consistency has not remained through the further deliberations of the Committee and its recommendations.

In terms of the general on-shore humanitarian program, the Committee considered the existing procedures for humanitarian entry, under which the refugee and humanitarian streams are combined into one process. The Committee was firmly of the view that the refugee and humanitarian streams should not be separated because of previous problems relating to duplicitous applications. However, it has recommended that to assist future decision making in this regard, monitoring of the existing refugee case load is required to determine which cases are more appropriately humanitarian claims than refugee claims. The Committee has also recommended that the new Refugee Review Tribunal be empowered to recommend to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs that, in deserving cases which do not meet the requirements for grant of refugee status, the Minister grants stay on humanitarian grounds.

One of the more contentious issues during the inquiry related to Australia's procedures for processing people who claim asylum at Australia's borders. This includes boat arrivals who, under existing requirements, are held in detention until their applications for asylum are processed. In particular, the Committee heard some criticism about the lengthy detention to which recent boat arrivals have been subjected. In a number of cases, persons have been held in detention for over two years. Various explanations were given to the Committee for this lengthy detention, particularly of the Cambodian boat arrivals. While some have criticised the processing procedures of the Department, others have been critical of the time taken by lawyers to lodge refugee applications.

I have been particularly concerned about some of the public comment on this issue. It has been argued that undocumented arrivals should be released into the Australian community because they have been detained for so long.
It is conveniently overlooked that some of the delays in the processing of applications were in part caused by the withdrawal of applications lodged on an individual basis. The withdrawal was requested by refugee support groups who delayed the re-lodgment of the applications and now conveniently blame the authorities for the delays.

The Committee is firmly of the view that, regardless of where the blame should be apportioned, the detention of those boat arrivals has lasted far too long. It is imperative that the procedures which are in place do not allow a repetition of such lengthy detention. In this regard, the Committee has noted the recent initiatives of the Government which are aimed at achieving a more efficient and expeditious determination system for border claimants, including the adoption of processing target dates. The Committee has also noted the amendments to the Migration Act in May this year, which set out the intentions of the Parliament that undocumented boat arrivals should be held in detention until their status is determined, but that such detention should not extend beyond a designated time frame.

As for existing detention arrangements, the Committee has recommended that, given the new expeditious processing procedure for border claimants, the Government retain the policy of holding border claimants in detention until such time as their applications can be processed. Priority, though, must continue to be directed to the expeditious processing of border claimants, with adequate resources to be directed to the Department to ensure that processing targets are met.

The Committee has also recommended that the detention facility at Port Hedland be maintained. While the Committee heard various criticisms about the Port Hedland facility, particularly about its remote location, the Committee found that the facility had proved useful in ensuring improved access to detainees and improved opportunities for obtaining information relevant to their claims. In particular, the Committee took note of evidence from one group of lawyers working at Port Hedland that the location of the facility enables those lawyers who are assisting border claimants to focus on the task of preparing applicants' claims without the usual daily distractions.

The fact that the Committee did not, as a committee, visit the Port Hedland facility probably detracts from the report. Had we done so, we would have been in a better position to refute some of the more outrageous claims that have been made about the facility. The Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Dundas, and I found during some in camera hearings that we were advantaged by the fact that we had some understanding of conditions at Port Hedland because we had seen them first hand. I hasten to add that Mr Ruddock was in Port Hedland at a different time to myself. Our first-hand information enabled each of us to ask incisive questions of witnesses.

At the next meeting of the Committee, I shall be moving that the transcripts of in camera proceedings of the Committee be published with the appropriate deletion of names. I give notice of this action, because I feel inhibited by the in camera proceedings to refer to that evidence in public at this time. However, I do feel that the Government and, indeed, the taxpayers of Australia, should have the opportunity to see how some publicly funded bodies argue their case before parliamentary committees. The Government and the taxpayers should be able to judge whether they are getting value for money. Indeed, the refugee applicants, the asylum seekers, should be able to judge this as well. I suggest that some asylum seekers would be more than a little disappointed in their advocates, based on the evidence presented to the Committee.

With regard to the role of lawyers in the refugee processing system, the Committee has recommended that public funding be available for the provision of legal assistance to border claimants in relation to the preparation of primary applications for refugee status. However, the Committee felt that public funding should not be available for pursuing unmeritorious claims through every avenue of appeal. Accordingly, it has recommended that publicly funded legal assistance to refugee claimants seeking review of a refusal decision be provided via the Legal Aid Commission, based on the merits of the particular case.

At this time I will move away from my prepared notes to say that, on reading the final document, I now have some concerns about the words that we have used in our final recommendation. If we had put in something about making application to legal aid commissions in the various States, it might have better and more appropriately reflected the views of the Committee and certainly my own personal views. I am aware that many legal aid commissions throughout the nation are strapped for cash because some of the State Governments are not fulfilling the obligations that they have in the past agreed to. I will draw that point to the attention of the Minister in due course.

The Committee also considered the issue of permanent residence for refugee applicants. In the past, Australia granted successful refugee applicants immediate resident status. However, this policy was modified in June 1990, when new regulations were introduced which gave refugees a four-year temporary stay with the option of obtaining permanent residence at the end of the four years, subject to availability of places in the migration program.

While endorsing the general principle of granting a four-year temporary stay to refugees, the Committee was concerned about the inflexibility of this arrangement. In the Committee's view, there are a few refugees, notably torture and trauma victims, who ought not to be required to wait out their full four-year temporary permit time if places in the refugee program are immediately available or become available at some earlier time within the four years. Recommendations to this effect are contained in the report.

The final chapter of the report discusses the contentious issue of asylum seekers from the People's Republic of China. This issue was the subject of much debate during the inquiry and within the Committee itself. In particular, considerable attention was focused on the position of PRC nationals who had arrived in Australia prior to the incident in Tiananmen Square in June 1989, and the Government's decision to grant such persons four-year temporary entry permits.

Debate within the Committee was directed especially to the undertaking given by the then Prime Minister that no PRC national in Australia before 20 June 1989 would be forced to return to China against his or her will. This undertaking was reaffirmed in April 1992 by the current Prime Minister. The Committee concluded that while recent policy in relation to PRC students—
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m, under sessional order I put the question:

para.tab: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question put:
Question so resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

speech.speaker: McKiernan Sen J.P.

talk.start.para: —The Committee considered that there were difficulties in granting permanent residence to pre-Tiananmen Chinese as a class. It also considered that there are problems if all such PRC citizens are rejected for permanent residence when their temporary entry permits expire in June 1994. Such a move would raise the alarming possibility of the refugee determination system being clogged with some 10,000 PRC citizens when their temporary entry permits expire in June 1994.

para.tab: In searching for a solution to this problem, the Committee came to a consensus agreement that Australia, as a nation, must stand by the word of its Prime Minister and should honour the spirit of the commitment which was made to those PRC nationals. However, there was disagreement in the Committee as to what constitutes a solution to the PRC dilemma within the spirit of the Prime Minister's commitment.

On this question, the Chairman of the Committee chose to follow his own point of view which differed from that of the majority of the Committee. The Committee recommended that the Government should end the uncertainty concerning the long term future of PRC permit holders in Australia by announcing the arrangements which will be used to differentiate between those who, from June 1994, will be granted permanent residence; those who may be granted a further four-year temporary entry permit; and those who will be returned to the People's Republic of China.

The Committee has recommended that, from June 1994, PRC permit holders should be able to apply either for permanent residence on the basis of already existing criteria for change of status—like everybody else—or for continued protection on a case-by-case basis against internationally accepted refugee criteria. The Committee has recommended that those who do not meet the selection criteria should be granted on expiry of their permits a short extension of stay—say, three months—to put their affairs in order and make appropriate arrangements for departing Australia.

The key words in the Committee's recommendation No. 28 are `non-discriminatory criteria' and `principle'. Little emphasis was placed upon those words when the report was tabled in the other place. In fact, the Chairman very carefully omitted reference to the words in his tabling speech. This is surprising when considering the importance of the meaning of these words and particularly the meaning and effect of the words in the context of the recommendation and the report as a whole.

The Committee, in saying that the Government should not treat PRC nationals any differently than any other national group, is saying that there should be no distinction, no favour for or against, no prejudice against or for, PRC permit holders. The Committee is quite properly reflecting in this recommendation the evidence that was given to the Committee during the inquiry. `Principle', according to the Macquarie dictionary, means, among other things, `a fundamental, primary, or general truth, on which other truths depend'. In addressing the dilemma of the PRC temporary permit holders in Australia, the Government should be non-discriminatory, principled and consistent.

Finally, commenting on the cost of processing onshore applications as opposed to the cost of processing refugees from overseas, I quote from the speech given by the Secretary of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs Mr Chris Conybeare, to the conference I mentioned earlier, the Welcome Stranger conference, which was convened by the Australian Catholic Bishops Committee for Migrant Affairs and the Australian Council of Churches Refugee and Migrant Services. Mr Conybeare said:

speech.para: The difference in cost between on-shore and off-shore processing of refugee cases is staggering. The Government has allocated $42 million for 1992/93 for processing of on-shore asylum claimants. On current processing and approval rates up to 1500 people will be approved for refugee status on-shore next year. This represents a cost to the Australian tax-payer of $28,000 just to process each successful on-shore refugee. This is over 100 times the cost of processing a successful refugee applicant overseas—processing of Australia's planned off-shore component for 1992/93 is expected to cost just over $2 million.

I suggest that that figure is outrageous. I suggest also, as I did some three weeks ago at the close of business on the Thursday night, that it is offensive to Australian taxpayers and the Australian Government, when some PRC nationals have gone through the process of making claims, lodging appeals and then being granted refugee status, that those people should then come out publicly and bag the Government which is granting them refuge. I suggest that these words be taken into account by all future successful refugee applicants and that they, in their public announcements following the success of their claims, be very guarded in their comments because the words of those last six who visited this chamber did not help the situation of refugee claimants in this country.

talk.start.para:
—The political news from this important parliamentary report entitled
Australia's Refugee and Humanitarian System: Achieving a Balance Between Refuge and Control
of the Joint Committee on Migration Regulations is that a majority of Government members and all Opposition members call for an end to the discriminatory refugee policy which was announced by the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, with regard to China. This majority have called for a non-discriminatory refugee and humanitarian policy whereby persons applying for refugee status in Australia, from whatever part of the world they come, will be treated alike. I welcome that emphasis in the important, indeed major, parliamentary report that is before us today.

para.tab: I note that the three honourable senators who serve on the Migration Regulations Joint Committee are Senator Cooney, Senator Lewis and Senator McKiernan. I note that two of those honourable senators are absent from the chamber today on parliamentary business, so it is following Senator McKiernan that I make these few remarks as a coalition senator.

I very much welcome the particular remarks of Senator McKiernan that have differentiated his tabling speech from that of the Chairman of the Committee, Dr Theophanous, in his reported remarks in the House of Representatives today. I do not agree with the minority report of Dr Theophanous. For that matter, whilst I recognise the conscientiousness of the minority report of my other colleague and good friend Senator Cooney, I do not favour that either. I would want to look with some scrutiny at the majority report, and certainly I prefer it to the two minority reports.

The fact that there are two Government members of Parliament on this important Committee who have conscientiously disagreed with three of their colleagues and have joined with the four coalition members of the Committee is something of political note. I regard the conclusions set out in the minority reports, somewhat similar between Senator Cooney and Dr Theophanous, as a softer option, as an overemphasis on compassion and as not getting the balance right between Australia's ability and justice in making available refuge and the issue of control.

I wish to differentiate three periods in Australia's immigration experience with regard to refugees: firstly, prior to 1975; secondly, a transition period between 1975 and 1989; and, thirdly, the more difficult years since 1989. Most of us are familiar with the great contributions made to Australia by refugees from Europe following the Second World War, particularly east Europeans dislodged from their countries by the communist menace and those of the Jewish community in Europe who had been persecuted by the nazi war machine in Germany.

There are in all of our cities Australians from all of the Eastern European countries—indeed most countries of Europe—who we know have made positive contributions to this country. I am proud that Australia was a refuge for these people trying to find a stable and peaceful home, a place where they could constructively develop their own families. I do not wish to single out the Baltic communities, but I am very close to the Lithuanian, Estonian and Latvian communities and I recognise the enormously positive contribution they have made to this country through three generations now.

That is the pattern of refugee immigration to this country that we were all brought up with. But then we have the Indo-China refugee situation, the so-called boat people, from 1975 until 1989. We are aware that over these years Australia gave as many as 22,000 refugee places a year, a higher number per capita than any country in the world—even exceeding that of the United States and Canada. In this period the intake was still somewhat limited to the people escaping, if you like, from Vietnam and Cambodia. The number was rather limited. At the same time, there were refugees in Australia from Central America, Chile and other parts of the world where there was totalitarian persecution and a denial of the freedoms and rights of people.

After that experience we came to this much more difficult era that has been with us since 1989. Why do I pick 1989, and why does the Parliamentary Committee refer to this matter as a worldwide problem requiring a new sensitivity, as Senator McKiernan said in his speech just now, involving scores of millions of people in every part of the world right now? What are the concerns in respect of this new era of refugees in what we will call the new world order post-Cold War, post-Gulf war and following the collapse of communism in the Soviet Union? I think we are in a new era when we will not easily see the end of distressed refugees fleeing countries and even parts of countries. We see the problems in Africa—Somalia, Mozambique and many other parts of Africa—in Yugoslavia, still in Indo-China and also in many other parts of the world.

Along with that we have seen particularly students but also others coming away from China following the massacre in Beijing and the breakdown of order in that city in June of 1989. Of course, the largest group concerning Australia in these last three years in terms of making applications for immigration on a humanitarian basis has been people from China. We were aware that at the time of the events in Tiananmen Square in Beijing there were 21,000 Chinese in this country, the majority of them students. They were, by a wave of the hand, given the ability to stay in this country by the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. But it is not widely known that some 44,000—more than double the number here at the time—came from China to Australia under not very vigilant visa requirements, again mostly students. The great majority of those arrivals are still in Australia and still have undetermined status.

Many of them are illegal residents in this country. Many of them think they have been promised some continuation of temporary residence. Some of them think that they will never be forced to leave this country and return to their own country. Many of them believe that they will be successful in making applications based on humanitarian considerations. It is therefore highly appropriate that this important joint Committee of the Parliament consider all of those elements, including the international situation, the precise law and regulations in this country and our processes of making determinations. Therefore, in chapters 1, 2 and 3 we see the development of this report. In chapters 4 and 5 there is direct discussion in detail of law and practice concerning refugee status and humanitarian status, and in chapter 6 the determination process is examined.

I really salute the members of the Committee. I note that Senator McKiernan is in the chamber. I mention also my colleague the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, Mr Philip Ruddock, whom I represent often in this chamber in handling immigration matters for the Opposition. I really respect the body of knowledge that they have developed and the conscientiousness and care with which they have gone about producing those chapters of the report.

I was happy to serve on this Committee during its inaugural year and to sit with those colleagues, and also the Chairman, Dr Theophanous. I also note the expertise of the legal adviser, Dr Kathryn Cronin, and the staff of the Committee.

Even though I have had only the day to read the report, and I have indicated that I much prefer the majority report to the minority reports, I believe that all of us should still read the report very carefully. I would not be surprised if the Government, when it responds to the report, was still not as inclined to move away from the control aspect as is suggested by even the majority report. I am very aware that Australia must look to its own national interest and must assure the Australian people that the immigration program is under control. The present Labor Government has been beset by confusion, indecision and delay in these matters, and, whilst this report goes a long way towards helping the Government out of those huge difficulties, I do not believe that it is necessarily getting the balance exactly right.

I very much respect my four Opposition colleagues who have been right through this inquiry for two years, and I do not wish to express a disagreement with them and the majority of the Committee. But I want to say that I, and I believe other senators, feel that we should look away from the soft option side of some of the expressions in this report and ensure that the government of the day gives confidence to the Australian people that it is in control of our immigration program, including refugee and humanitarian determinations.

I conclude by referring to chapter 8 and the recommendations therein concerning citizens of the People's Republic of China. I have not yet seen in the report any direct admission of the mixed motives of those who have applied on the basis of humanitarian and refugee considerations for permanent residence in this country. Amongst these mixed motives is widely acknowledged to be a straightforward love of Australia—an aspiration to find in this country a better lifestyle, greater affluence and a better life for the applicant's children by establishing families in this country.

These are all good aspirations and no doubt the great majority expressing those aspirations will be excellent citizens of this country. But I wish to see in the report—and I do not see it—an explicit recognition of these mixed motives in the persons who are applying. I talk of up to 40,000 applications with regard to these matters. I wish to come down in the same way as Senator McKiernan and my colleagues in the Opposition in this report by stressing that we should make sure we have an immigration program which is non-discriminatory and which is fair to all applicants.

I believe that there are millions of people around the world who would love to have a lifestyle such as is possible within Australia. They would love to see their children grow up in Australia and they would love to see the opportunities that Australia affords for them and their families. We must be fair in our immigration program choosing between applicants from all countries and not least applicants who would set out applications on the basis of refugee or humanitarian concerns.

I have not time now to expand upon recommendations 27, 28, 29 and 30, which are certainly fair, stable and preferable to the minority reports, and certainly do come from the considerations set out in the body of the report, especially chapter 8. If I have differed, even with the majority, it is to ask questions only; to ask questions about whether the balance really has been right and how we can ensure that we restore confidence to all the Australian people—or at least the great majority of Australian people—by having a refugee and humanitarian determination process which inspires their confidence. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.title:
SALES TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1992
SALES TAX IMPOSITION (EXCISE) BILL 1992
SALES TAX IMPOSITION (CUSTOMS) BILL 1992
SALES TAX IMPOSITION (GENERAL) BILL 1992
SALES TAX AMENDMENT (TRANSITIONAL) BILL 1992
SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) BILL 1992

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 9 September, on motion by
Senator McMullan
:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Vanstone Sen A.E.

talk.start.para: —This evening we are continuing the second reading debate of the Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992 and a package of related Bills. There is no better example available to the Senate or interested parties of the ineptitude of this Government than this particular package of Bills. It is not just that it is a package of Bills that displays some ineptitude; it is a package of Bills that goes to the very heart of what the next election in many respects is going to be about, that is, taxation reform.

para.tab: It is well-known that some time ago my Party said the wholesales sales tax system had to go. It was unreformable, unwieldy, unworkable, too complicated and nobody understood it, and that system and some other indirect taxes had to go and be replaced by a simple one-rate goods and services tax.

To that claim the Government said, `Do not be ridiculous; you are a hopeless lot of idiots and you do not know what you are doing. The wholesales sales tax system can, in fact, be reformed'. What we see in this package of Bills is the Government's attempt at reform. We all know that the issue of tax reform is really going to be one of the key issues at the next election; it is central to the outcome of the next election and which party will form government after that election.

Therefore, we have a situation where my Party says, `This hopeless wholesale sales tax system cannot be reformed,' and where those opposite say, `Yes, it can'. The Government announced in the 1990-91 Budget that it would undertake a review aimed at simplifying the wholesale sales tax system. In short, the Government has messed it up and messed it up badly. Those opposite have had a long time from the 1990-91 Budget—the first Budget introduced by this Government after the last election—to do it and they have messed it up.

The Government said, `One does not have to get rid of wholesale sales tax; one can so simplify it as to get rid of its problems'. This simplification process has proceeded in two steps. The first was the extension of wholesale sales tax exemptions available for business inputs which were announced in the 1991 economic statement. This package of legislation we are talking about tonight is the second and final step, as far as the Government is concerned, in fixing that wholesale sales tax system.

This package was introduced into the House of Representatives on 26 May and agreed to by the House on 28 May. I am not sure, but I think it was debated under a guillotine. The package of six Bills certainly went very quickly through the House of Representatives without obvious adequate scrutiny.

The package of six Bills replaces the current total of 27 wholesale sales tax Acts. One can turn to the Senate program of business to get the names of the Bills concerned. The primary substance of the changes to the sales tax system are included in the first two Bills; the other changes in the remaining Bills are much more mechanical. Prior to the legislation being debated here, Senator Short, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, supported by the Democrats quite wisely, successfully moved a motion to refer the legislation to a Senate select committee for examination. We had already heard concerns in the community about the way the Bills were drafted. These are the Bills that are the result of an extensive inquiry into how to simplify the sales tax system.

The Committee was established on 25 June and had as a reporting date 19 August. That was not a very long time. The Committee advertised for submissions and in spite of the very short time involved, 150 submissions were received from a very broad spectrum of business and community organisations. There were 150 groups or individuals that put in a view in that short space of time. I will not say pretty well all of them but by far the great majority said, `You have messed it up. You have not simplified this in the way you said you would'. There were some people saying that, from the taxpayers' point of view, it would be worse.

Public hearing dates were set for this select committee. The Committee met on 12 August and 13 August. What did we find on the night of 11 August? We found the Treasurer issuing a short press release announcing that due to the continuing consultations that he had had—which is the nice way of saying, due to the fact that someone had tipped him to the fact that he had messed this up—he would now have to make amendments, drastic amendments, to fix up the mess he had made. Because the Government did not want to be as overtly honest as that, it said that due to the continuing consultations it now had to make some improvements. That is a euphemism for fixing up a botch.

This press release was issued the night before the Senate select committee was to meet. I have a deep suspicion that had Senator Walsh not been on that Committee and not looked through the submissions, toddled around to the Treasurer and said, `Listen buddy, I do not know whether you can read or not but you have messed this up badly', not much would have happened. We can at least be sure that if the Government had its way and the Bills passed in the original form they would have been very badly flawed Bills.

Why did that not happen? The reason it did not happen is that the Bills had to come here. In the Senate there was a capacity to force the Government to wait for its Bills, to submit those Bills to further proper scrutiny and to allow the members of the community who were going to be affected by the Bills a better chance to have their say as to how the Bills in reality would affect them. It is because of that action that the Government had to announce its drastic backdown.

To look at what the substance of the legislation is meant to be about, one goes to the ministerial second reading speech in the House of Representatives. One sees that in that speech the main features of the package are painted as being a significant reduction in the number of persons required to pay tax, a complete restructuring and redrafting of the wholesale sales tax system into plain English, a streamlining of the system for acquiring business inputs and other conditionally exempt goods free of tax, and a significant strengthening of the anti-avoidance provisions. That is what one would think it is all about.

If one reads those highlighted features, they would suggest that the simplification process was primarily concerned with the mechanics of the sales tax system rather than changes to the tax base or to the tax treatment of various goods and business operations. It is now apparent that this was not the case. The proposed legislation included clear policy changes, particularly related to the following areas: external costs, leases, goods donated to or used in repair or construction of buildings and so on owned by exempt bodies, coverage of tax rulings, businesses operating as deemed manufacturers and the treatment of untaxed goods.

The legislation also had the effect of overturning a number of court decisions which had gone against the Taxation Office in recent years. That is more evidence again of a clear change of policy being painted as being mere simplification; it is getting through under the guise of being simplification. These proposed changes to the sales tax system understandably raised the ire of the business community and that resulted in this last minute backdown. It was a pretty pathetic effort; a press release issued the night before a Senate select committee was set to have public hearings.

The backdown was on six key elements of this so-called simplification package. The elements are: the treatment of external costs, the application of the general anti-avoidance provision, exempt use leases, the untaxed goods provision and the deemed manufacturers provisions. It might be worth spending a bit of time to go through some of those to give an idea of just how badly the Government messed this up.

Let us deal first with the external costs. As I understand it, the original legislation sought to bring into the sales tax base product design and development costs incurred by persons beyond the wholesale taxing point, that is, design costs incurred by a retailer who contracts out the manufacture of goods. It was particularly intended to catch large retailers who were involved in designing and developing their own brand products. What the select committee was told was what the public response was—that this provision would affect a much larger group than was its intention, bringing into the tax net things such as shop floor designs, promotional material and letterhead paper, the difficulties of isolating the design or development component of a good, and calculating a notional wholesale value to it. These elements were highlighted.

The design industry was also vocal in arguing that the provision would strongly impede products innovation. The Government backdown in this respect is that it has said that it will not proceed with the external cost provisions at this time. Therefore, the design and development industry is not totally happy. `At this time' seems to imply that at another time if the Government can it will. Nonetheless, at least at this time that is not being proceeded with and the Government is going to be happy with toddling off to do some further examination of the issues raised by business—some further examination one could argue it should have done before it brought the Bills into this place.

Secondly, I refer to the general anti-avoidance provision. The original proposal gave very wide scope to the Tax Commissioner to decide whether or not a taxpayer was involved in tax avoidance—it was a frighteningly wide power—and to cancel the identified tax benefit according to the Commissioner's own view of what otherwise might have occurred. Business argued very strongly that these powers were too wide, and that the provision was draconian and would threaten many legitimate commercial transactions and create considerable uncertainty in business dealings.

The Government saw the writing on the wall and we had a back-down there too. The Government will now include a list of criteria in the general anti-avoidance provision which the Commissioner will have to consider in deciding whether or not to cancel a tax benefit. I understand that the Commissioner will need to determine that the overall dominant purpose of an arrangement is to gain a tax benefit before commencing proceedings.

As to exempt use, the original legislation stated that for a good to be conditionally exempt, the immediate user had to qualify to receive the tax exemption regardless of the status of the final user. The public response to that was that community and business organisations expressed concern that this would result in tax on things such as construction and repairs carried out by contractors for exempt bodies such as charities and public instrumentalities, and goods donated to charities. It would be a disaster. The Government realised the stupidity of its course of action and backed down. The Bill will be amended to retain exemptions that would have been removed by the original proposals.

Similarly, with leases, the original legislation would have removed tax exemptions for equipment leased by businesses for short periods. Business argued that this proposal would hamper efficient commercial practice and give a competitive advantage to firms that could afford to take on long term leases or buy equipment. I understand that the amendments will show that the Government now has to retain the current tax treatment of leases.

I could go on and deal with the untaxed goods provision and the deemed manufacturers provision, but the story is the same pretty well all along. We have a package of Bills that is meant to reflect a competent review of the wholesale sales tax system by a government that says it is competent, and in six major respects it mucked it up.

It might be worth while, Mr Deputy President, to raise with the chamber through you some of the things the Select Committee was told. Mr Firmstone, from the Institute of Chartered Accountants, who presumably knows something about these matters, said:

speech.para: We doubt that—
that is, the new system—

will, in the ultimate, be easier for taxpayers to work with. It will be easier for tax consultants to work with, but the language of it and the sheer size of it is such that I do not think taxpayers are going to be any less daunted in their task of trying to deal with it, despite its re-expression and streamlining.
He went on to say:
We think that on balance certainty has not been added to, it has been detracted from.

One of the key elements of any taxation reform is certainty. Mr Firmstone, representing the Institute of Chartered Accountants, said that on balance its view is that certainty has been detracted from, not added to.

talk.start.para: —What about simplification?

—If there is a problem with certainty, there is a problem with simplification. Many would say that simplification simply has not been achieved. Mr Gartland, the Group Taxation Director of Qantas, said:

speech.para: A lot of the Bills before us. . . tend to confuse rather than simplify, and they appear to be adding restrictions to certain areas that were not there before.

That is certainly the view of the aviation industry. People have written to me in the last couple of days about extraordinary difficulties with the Tax Office in relation to some of those matters. I will not mention another quote that I was thinking of mentioning.

para.tab:
I think it is worth repeating the mess-up that this is, and exaggerating the degree to which it is a mess-up. I do not have the
Hansard
in front of me, but I see some of the officers who were at the hearing are assisting the Minister in the chamber. They will no doubt remember that there were occasions when questions were put by senators. None of us on the Select Committee, as I understand it, are accountants. I do not know about Senator Short; perhaps he has worked as an accountant. I think his degree is in economics. None us being accountants, we put pretty simple questions and were told by the Tax Office that they would have to be taken on notice.

That is the answer to Senator Archer's question: what about simplification? There were numerous—and by `numerous' I do not mean to imply that there were 20; it was perhaps even less than a dozen—occasions when the Taxation officers assigned to assist the Senate Select Committee were asked questions about the so-called simplified package and they had to take them on notice. They did not know what the effect of this or that particular provision quite specifically would be.

The question is: if the Tax Office does not know at a Select Committee hearing, how can we possibly expect taxpayers to know? How can this Government continue to deny that the operation of this wholesale sales tax system, simplified or otherwise, is costing people in the business community a fortune because they have to pay to get advice as to how this matter works. They get themselves into quite serious trouble if they take a guess and get it wrong.
What that leads to is that this purported simplification should probably not be proceeded with. The Government should accept that the best thing to do with the wholesale sales tax system is simply to get rid of it. Lest the arguments as to why that should happen have fallen on deaf ears in the past, as I imagine they have, I will repeat them.

If we get rid of the wholesale sales tax system and shift to a goods and services tax, as proposed by the coalition, we will take the wholesale sales tax element in the cost of products out. We will stop that wholesale sales tax element, indirect or otherwise, cascading through the system, so that consumers pay when they buy, whether they are people who want to buy the goods to reuse them or people like you and I, Mr Acting Deputy President, who want to consume the product. This is often lost on people because when we buy something at the supermarket it does not have a big tag on it saying `wholesale sales tax'. That is one of Labor's biggest lies. Those in the Labor Party march around the country saying, `Members of the coalition hate low income earners, they have no compassion for them and they are going to put a tax on food and clothing. Isn't that shocking? We would never tax food and clothing'.

Let us look at food. Let us take the example of Weetbix. The wheat has to come from somewhere and it has to go in something to get to the Weetbix factory. By and large, it goes in trucks that are pretty big—trucks that have a wholesale sales tax component on them of upwards of $25,000 on each truck. All these trucks are out there carting around all this stuff, whether it is wheat to the Weetbix factory or flour to some bakery. They go to all the factories that produce food that low income earners and high income earners buy and eat. All that stuff that gets from the producer to the factory goes in these trucks that have this wholesale sales tax component on them and their parts, and a fuel excise on the fuel that they use.

It should be no surprise to anyone that the freight companies that carry the wheat, the flour and everything else to these food companies do not pay that out of the goodness of their hearts. They are not the Salvation Army and we do not expect them to pay them out of the goodness of their hearts. So what do they do? They pass it on. The freight man says, `I've had to pay this wholesale sales tax. This is my cost and I'm going to mark up my cost'. So he not only pays the tax, but he also puts a mark-up on it and passes it on to the poor old Weetbix factory.

Then we toddle along to the Weetbix factory and we have a gander at what is happening in there. We find a whole lot of people who do not think they are paying payroll tax, because they are not; but someone is paying it on their salaries. It is being loaded onto the price of the Weetbix because the Weetbix manufacturer does not pay the payroll tax out of the goodness of his heart either.

It is not only a case of payroll tax on the salaries of the people in the Weetbix factory plus these taxes involved in bringing all the gear there; wholesale sales tax is also on a whole range of things in the factory that are non-production related items—and that is not paid for out of the goodness of anyone's heart. What do the Weetbix people do when they have put all this stuff together, when they have paid all their taxes and the profit on it is charged by the freight forwarder? They add up their costs and they add a bit more on to that. So the tax component not only has been put up by the freight man but also has now been put up by the Weetbix man. Surprise, surprise, it all goes into another set of trucks on which there is another lot of sales tax, with another lot of sales tax on the parts, and another lot of fuel excise. All this stuff is rolling around the country, cascading through the price of food.

We get to the wholesaler and what do we find again: more people with payroll tax on their salaries, more trucks going out, more bits and pieces in the wholesale warehouse that do not have an exemption from sales tax. What does the wholesaler do? He does not run this service for nothing. He is not the Salvation Army. He calls in another set of trucks with wholesale sales tax on them and another load of people with payroll tax on their salaries and off it all goes to the supermarket.

talk.start.para: —And Weetbix.

—If Senator Faulkner is sick of hearing this, he should just shut his ears and listen again. Finally, we get to the store and what do we find: a whole lot more people with payroll tax on their salaries, more bits and pieces around the supermarket—probably shelving and stuff like that—which has wholesale sales tax on it, and more trucks to get there with wholesale sales tax on them. All of this is loaded into the price of Weetbix. Because the supermarket does not have a big sign on it saying, `Sucker, Food Tax Here', Labor pretends that it does not tax food. That is the biggest load of rubbish I have heard in my life.

para.tab: From the moment the ingredients leave the farm, at every step along the way, taxes are added to the price of food. They are passed on and they are marked up.
