That is why we say they cascade through the system. Mr and Mrs Average and Mr and Mrs Low Income are paying tax now on food and clothing.

The big Labor lie `They are going to tax food' tells the truth—yes, we are going to put a goods and services tax on just about everything—but not the whole truth. Those opposite are trying to pretend that they are the Salvation Army and that there are no taxes on food and clothing and that they are going to keep it that way. By pretending that, to the extent that they do say that individually, they will be liars because they will be telling the truth but not the whole truth. They will be deceiving the public because of that.

What do we want to do? We want to get rid of this stupid system so that the sorts of business input taxes I have been referring to will be abolished. There will be a simple 15 per cent tax on the value added at the end. That will, of course, mean that a lot of prices of goods and some services will be reduced because we will be made more competitive.

These arguments fall on the deaf ears of those on the other side of the chamber because they have locked themselves into rejecting Option C, which was the preference of the then Treasurer. It has been dumped now because we have opted for it and those opposite cannot afford to come too close to our position. They want to keep this existing wholesale sales tax system. They want to keep a system that has, as one of its smartest moves, things like taxing carbonated mineral water but not taxing flat mineral water. That is a really bright spark initiative. They want to tax goods but not services. Why should we continue to do that? Why should people who make things suffer some sort of an administrative burden when people who provide services do not? It is clearly ridiculous.

We say this whole stupid system should go. We say not only that this system should go but also that a number of other taxes should go, some of which I have referred to, including fuel excise, payroll tax and a number of other taxes. We say it should go not just because it is stupid to have taxes cascading through the system from some academic point of view. It is stupid to have them doing that because it is costing us jobs. It is making the prices that we pay for goods and that we charge for goods uncompetitive, and that is costing us jobs. This Government does not seem too interested in that, since it has cost this country over one million jobs. Over one million people are looking for work because those sitting opposite do not have the brains to run the country properly. I only hope they have the brains to call an election sooner rather than later so that they can be tipped out and we can be put in; so that this wholesale sales tax system can be tipped out; and so that a simple goods and services tax can be put in. That will make us a much more competitive nation and it will generate real jobs.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: —Before all the people who have come to hear my speech leave I would like to take the opportunity to tell them about cornflakes—or rice bubbles or any other breakfast cereal—and tell them exactly the same story that Senator Vanstone has told them. Let us make no mistake: Australia has a consumption tax at this moment. It is a hidden consumption tax—a tax which, as Senator Vanstone has said, cascades down through all products, including food.

para.tab: We have the absolute nonsense of Labor candidates in the Victorian election running around handing out little brochures saying that 15 per cent will be added to the cost of every item of food. One of the brochures I have seen does have the good grace to show an example of a list of items from the supermarket. The wholesale sales tax is taken off, although there is no indication of what it is so that people know what is on their confectionary, what is on their pet food and what is on all the other items, such as carbonated drinks, they buy in the supermarket, and can then add on 15 per cent. All the other taxes that we are taking off under the Fightback package are not taken off. These candidates are putting around propaganda that is just wrong.

Unlike the coalition's goods and services tax, the Labor Government's consumption tax is not visible. It is not an up-front consumption tax; it is quite the opposite. It is a hidden tax that is levied at the wholesale level without the vast majority of Australians even knowing about it. The older Australian who goes down to the supermarket to buy the pet food does not know it, but he or she is paying wholesale sales tax on that pet food. People are paying wholesale sales tax on their tonic water so that they can have a gin and tonic at night. They are paying a hidden tax. It is not fair; it is not broadly based; and it is not a single rate like the coalition's goods and services tax.

Any Government member who can explain why lemon barley crystals attract a different rate from lemon barley water, or why a 60 millilitre plastic container for measuring medicines attracts a wholesale sales tax while no other measuring glass does, is a better person than I am. I do not think Government members will be able to explain the difference. There are many items on which there are anomalies that one cannot explain.

talk.start.para: —What about flavoured milk and plain milk?

—Flavoured milk and plain milk is a perfect example. The Government's consumption tax is not levied at a single rate, it is ramshackle and it is levied arbitrarily on different products at different rates ranging from 10 per cent to a massive 30 per cent.

para.tab: Quite unlike the coalition's GST, the Government's hidden consumption tax is a tax on business. Whereas a GST is fully rebatable on all business inputs throughout the production cycle, the Government's consumption tax is in-built into the cost of many goods—including Weetbix—used by business and not one cent of this in-built cost is rebatable. This means that the Government's consumption tax unnecessarily distorts the choice of production processes and the choice of products produced.

Unlike our GST, the Government's consumption tax, as Senator Vanstone has so graphically pointed out, is also a tax on tax, because it is not rebated at each level of production. It has a cascading or a pyramidal effect whereby each seller throughout the production process includes the effect of the tax in his or her mark-up price.

The Government's consumption tax is particularly destructive because it increases the costs of our exports and reduces the competitiveness of our struggling primary producers and manufacturers. The fact that the vast majority of our overseas trading partners are not burdened by this sort of debilitating consumption tax on the goods they export to Australia makes it even more difficult for our exporters. Unlike the Government's consumption tax, the coalition's GST will not apply to exports. They will be zero rated, meaning that the GST will not be charged to exports, while exporters will get the GST on their business inputs rebated to them.

Another major difference between the coalition's proposed GST and the Government's consumption tax is the fact that the coalition has given an undertaking, which will be written into the legislation, that the rate of the GST will not rise above 15 per cent and that it will have to be debated here in Parliament. In stark contrast, the Government is constantly both increasing the rates of its consumption tax on individual items and applying its consumption tax to new items.

I will give just a few examples of the widening of the coverage of the consumption tax since 1983. In the 1983-84 Budget, new items to which Labor's consumption tax was applied included oil and lubricant for business or industrial purposes—another tax on the trucks that get the food to the supermarket in the long run—matches, non-agricultural tractors, ride-on mowers, skin care creams, disinfectant, swimming pool parts and filters, soda bicarbonate and non-irrigation guttering, piping and tubing.

By the end of 1985, Labor's consumption tax had been applied to alcoholic wine and cider, low-alcohol beer and imported horses. In the 1986-87 Budget, Labor's consumption tax was extended to non-alcoholic wines and cider, packaged flavoured milk, Australian fruit juices, bathroom fittings, sinks, tubs—a real luxury—toilets, and the development of photographic film.

In 1988-89 Labor's consumption tax was applied to wrapping material for marketing use, pre-packaged coffee, chocolate and malt drinks, muesli bars, ice-creams and containers for marketing alcoholic beverages. In the 1990-91 Budget, at the same time as the Government announced its simplification and amalgamation of the wholesale sales tax system, the Government extended sales tax to newspaper supplements and inserts.

Probably the most despicable thing about the Government's consumption tax, and a major difference between it and the coalition's GST, is the fact that the Government has not seen fit to pay one cent of compensation to taxpayers for the $10 billion it takes from them annually in wholesale sales tax. Since it came to power in 1983, the Hawke-Keating Labor Government has increased the amount of money it stealthily takes in wholesale sales tax by 60 per cent in real terms. Today the Government's consumption tax amounts to 5.4 per cent on everything we buy. This is actually higher than the net effect of the coalition's GST, which is estimated to be 4.4 per cent by the coalition and less than 4 per cent by the Treasury.

Despite the fact that under Labor the annual amount of wholesale sales tax collected has risen from $3 billion to $10 billion, Australians have not received one cent of compensation to make up for the decline in the purchasing power of their earnings. In stark contrast, the coalition will ensure that all Australians are compensated for the GST through tax cuts averaging 30 per cent, through an 8 per cent increase in pensions, through a higher tax-free threshold, through a doubling in family allowance for low income families, through a 6 per cent increase in other social security benefits, through GST tax credits for people who cannot be fully compensated through tax cuts or benefit increases, and through wealth compensation for the effect of GST on the value of people's savings. There is simply no comparison between this comprehensive compensation package for the GST and the total lack of compensation by the current Labor Government for its consumption tax.

The final major difference between Labor's consumption tax and the coalition's GST is the comparative cost of their administration. Labor's consumption tax imposes a huge administrative burden on Australian business. This complex, cost-ineffective tax is characterised by many exemptions and differential rates and has long been plagued by problems relating to valuations and classifications. Because of its complexity, it is estimated that about $400m in staff costs is spent annually by businesses in complying with the Government's consumption tax. Another $100m is spent by businesses annually on the professional fees of lawyers and accountants to assist in interpreting Labor's anachronistic consumption tax. In addition, the Australian Taxation Office employs some 763 personnel nationally to administer the Government's costly and cumbersome consumption tax.

I would like to point out a couple of examples of administrative problems which are entailed in the administration of the Government's consumption tax. The first is the application of wholesale sales tax to veterinary materials. Item 6 of the first schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act provides a sales tax exemption for:

speech.para: Goods (and parts therefor) for use in the maintenance of livestock, viz.:-
(13) Veterinary instruments, appliances and materials of a kind ordinarily used by veterinary surgeons.

While it appears from item 6 that the Parliament wished to restrict the exemption `for use in the maintenance of livestock', this was not the practice of the Commissioner of Taxation, who for some years applied the compensation to all veterinary materials. However, earlier this year the Government moved to fix a date for the commencement of the stricter interpretation of this subitem which would have extended Labor's consumption tax to veterinary products used to treat household pets. That would have meant that people who were paying wholesale sales tax on their pet food would now be paying wholesale sales tax also on veterinary products used to treat their animals at home. However, due to complaints lodged by the veterinary field and the Opposition, prior to a date being fixed the Treasurer announced that no change to the current practice would occur. Item 166 of the first schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill now provides for an exemption for veterinary instruments, appliances, materials and preparation of a kind ordinarily used or prescribed by veterinary surgeons.

para.tab: Secondly, in the 1986-87 Budget, the Labor Government announced that, in situ, in-ground swimming pools would be subject to a 20 per cent consumption tax. Earlier this year, the High Court ruled that legislation which made swimming pools constructed on site taxable by deeming them to be goods for sales tax purposes had no effect. The legislation had sought to have in-ground swimming pools treated in the same way as off-site, prefabricated swimming pools.

The High Court ruled that a swimming pool constructed in situ forms part of the land and is denied the character of the goods, the majority holding that the tax imposed was not a tax on goods but a tax on land. The High Court ruled that the restriction imposed by section 55 of the Constitution requiring laws imposing duties of excise to deal with duties of excise only could not be avoided by deeming them to be, as they are not. We do not have to go on and on with what happened and how the Government had to twist and turn to try to rectify that situation with legislation.

I want to give another example tonight in this chamber of a situation that I find absolutely appalling. A manufacturer of a product produces it and decides, on reading the Sales Tax Act, that wholesale sales tax should not be charged on the item. So he does not charge it. He is then visited by the Australian Tax Office and told, `You should have charged wholesale sales tax on this item. You owe us all this wholesale sales tax'. `No, I don't', says the manufacturer, `I've read the Tax Act'.

After a number of visits from the Tax Office, he is told, `We are going to take you to court and we'd like to speak to your lawyer'. The manufacturer says, `I do not have a lawyer'. He is then told, `Well, you had better get one because you are going to court'. `If that is the case', says the manufacturer, `I will speak to all the other people who manufacture this product who have been charging wholesale sales tax'. What then happened? The Tax Office came back with an agreement and said, `Tell the manufacturer to sign this, but do not publish it as part of the agreement. If he does not tell the other manufacturers, he will not be liable to pay this. Although he is still liable for it, he will not be liable at this moment to pay that wholesale sales tax'.

That is blackmail. That is what we are getting with this corrupt and ramshackle wholesale sales tax system. Decisions are being made which are corrupt and which involve people in blackmail. It is appalling. That is what is happening in this country. Our tax system is in such disarray that we are seeing an agreement struck between a manufacturer and the Tax Office so that the other people who are charging wholesales sales tax do not know about it. That is what is happening.

If that manufacturer publishes that information, he will be liable to pay that debt. It is disgraceful. It is not acceptable, and that is what is being perpetrated by this archaic and out of date wholesale sales tax system. That is what we are trying to get rid of.

The swimming pool example was but one that reached the High Court. I do not know how many other agreements have been made between the Tax Office and manufacturers—maybe one day I will find out—but I do know that there has been an agreement made on one occasion and it is totally unacceptable.

In stark contrast to the Government's consumption tax, the coalition's GST is a straightforward tax for business to administer. Business knows where it stands; it knows whether it should be charging it. There is not some discussion or debate between the Tax Office and the manufacturer about whether the tax should be charged on an item and, if the manufacturer has not charged tax, whether it owes money, as in the ridiculous situation I have just mentioned. It will be levied at a single rate on all sales.

Submitting a GST return will entail a one-page statement of business inputs and sales. Any business which maintains records of its costs and sales will face little or no administrative costs in complying with the GST. We will not have the business of agreements and the situation of businesses not knowing whether they should charge a GST. It will be charged. If it is not at the end of the production line, the input cost of the GST that is paid by the next line of production will be rebatable.

Business will also receive a substantial cash flow benefit through being able to hold on to the GST received from sales being made between collection periods. It will also get a cash flow benefit now. If I am a jeweller or I have items in a shop which attract wholesale sales tax, and I have a large number of items, all that wholesale sales tax sits on the shelf until I sell those items. There might be 30 per cent in tax on some items. I have borrowed the money from the bank. With the interest rates the way that they were last year, I am paying interest on all that.

But under the GST that tax will be rebatable, so I will get another benefit. A coalition government will also provide income tax deductibility for any additional capital equipment needed to accommodate the GST. As we are debating these Bills, which will supposedly simplify a ramshackle and archaic wholesales sales tax system that is beyond repair and really should be abolished, it is imperative that the people of Australia realise that the Labor Government continues to levy a consumption tax of its own.

Comparing the Government's consumption tax with the coalition's GST is like comparing chalk and cheese. The coalition's GST is a broadly based, up-front and highly visible tax. As I said before, it will be levied at a single rate which will not be raised beyond 15 per cent. It will be fully rebatable on all business inputs and will not apply to exports. The coalition will provide a comprehensive compensation package to offset the inflation effects of its GST, which will replace seven current taxes. I have said this before and I will keep saying it: finally, the GST will be simple and inexpensive to administer and will result in substantial cash flow benefits for business.

On the other side of the coin, Labor's consumption tax, which it calls a wholesales sales tax, is levied arbitrarily at rates ranging from 10 per cent to 30 per cent on a wide range of goods which are used every day by Australians. Labor's consumption tax is a cascading tax which also impacts indirectly on the price of many everyday items, including Weetbix, as Senator Vanstone pointed out. Unlike the GST, it is not fully rebatable on all business inputs. Labor's consumption tax applies to exports, making it more difficult for Australian exporters to compete with overseas traders which do not levy such an incentive sapping tax.

Over the last 10 years, Labor has increased more than threefold the amount of money it collects from Australians through its consumption tax. But, as I have said before, it has not seen fit to provide one cent of compensation to taxpayers to offset its effect on their purchasing power.

Finally, due to its many exemptions, classifications and variable rates, Labor's consumption tax is cumbersome, very expensive for business to administer and, as I said before, leads to anomalies which mean that some manufacturers may be charging GST and some may not, or that some people enter into agreements with the Tax Office, which I find totally unacceptable. I am sure that when the Australian public is made aware of all the facts and it is given the opportunity to make an informed comparison between Labor's consumption tax and the coalition's GST, the vast majority will agree with me that the GST is infinitely superior.

A couple of weeks ago, I was in New Zealand with Mr Reith in a factory that manufactures electrical goods. We went to the factory floor and chatted with some of the young people soldering in the component parts area. We asked them, `What do you think about the GST?' Their immediate reaction was, `Terrible'. It was as if someone asked me, `What do you think of income tax?'. I would say, `Terrible'.

We said to these young people at the factory, `GST came in when you were 12; is that right?'. `Yes', they said, `12 or 13'; these young people were now 18 or 19. We then said, `If you accept that the Government has to get money for defence, health and care for old people and it gets it from taxes, you are now paying income tax and a GST'. Let us assume that they were getting about the right amount of money—and we could argue about that. We asked, `Would you like the Government to increase your income tax and get rid of the GST, or do you want to keep the GST and have the tax as it is?'. One young fellow said, `Keep the GST'. He was not in favour of the GST at the beginning, but when he had the option of having either higher income tax or a GST, that is what he opted for. Do you know what he said? He said, `If I go out and choose to spend my money on sausages, I pay less GST. If I choose to buy steak, I pay more GST. It is fairer'. This came straight from the factory floor. That 19-year-old said to me, `It is fairer'.

Faced with the choice of higher income tax or a GST, he said, `I would rather it the way it is now'. His mates said, `That is right; it is fairer'. One of the others said, `You have the money in your pocket and you choose'. Those words were not scripted; they were not from a pamphlet. That was what those young people who had experienced life under a system of GST and lower income tax rates were saying.

Now members of the Labor Party can go around for all they are worth telling people that, under the GST, they will pay 15 per cent more on all their goods. But we will go around telling people that there is another side to the story—they already pay huge amounts of wholesale sales tax, a tax that is unfair, ramshackle and archaic, and it needs to be reformed. Mr Keating himself wanted to do that. How he can backtrack now is beyond my belief. I assure the Senate and my colleagues that I will do everything in my power in the run-up to the next election to convince Australians of the importance of the need to reform the tax system, but not in the ridiculous way the Government has tried to do it by patching up the wholesale sales tax.

One Nation became Done Nation; finished. The Budget fell in a heap; the attempt has failed, so what does Mr Keating turn to: vitriol and attack on the personality of Dr Hewson. That is all he can resort to now. Everything he has tried to do has fallen apart, the wheels have come off. So what does he do now? He turns on the person because that is the only way he knows how to operate: he cannot actually run this country so now he turns to personal abuse. But let me tell him it will not work because the Australian public is much brighter than that, Mr Keating.

speech.speaker: Archer Sen B.R.

talk.start.para: —I come into this debate because of the way that this package has been handled by the Government. I would just like to try to bring the debate into some reasonable perspective. I start by repeating some of the comments from a speech made by Steven Kates, the Chief Economist of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. I would certainly commend the speech to all Government members. I will just quote a few pieces as follows:

speech.para: I do not of course argue that the only voice a government should listen to is the business community. But I do say that when weighing up the various views about structure and levels of taxation, a government should pay closest attention to the views of business. Not only will this be in the best interests of the business community, but it will also end up being in the best interests of the community in general.
A little later on he says:

But what would be best of all is that the introduction of the GST . . . as odd as it may at first appear, the aim of the GST is to lower taxes . . . If Australia is to emerge from recession, it will first be essential that taxes and excessive Government spending are wound back.
The importance of the GST is that it will allow other forms of taxation to be reduced.
Again:
The GST is also useful in improving the trade balance since exports are not subject to the tax while imports are.

The absence of a properly constituted consumption tax needlessly penalizes the Australian economy since the virtues of this change in the tax mix are well understood and the practical results can be observed in virtually all other industrialized economies.
That is only the ACCI and I suppose those opposite would say, `What would it know?' It represents the entire productive sector of Australian industry, that is all.

para.tab: The Bill that went into the House of Representatives on 26 May passed through that chamber with no proper debate of any sort and it was brought in on the guise of being a so-called tax simplification process—anything else but not that; nothing could be further from the truth. It was obviously brought in with very limited discussion from people with any knowledge on the subject, as was borne out by the submissions that were made when it went to the Senate committee. Almost 150 submissions were made.

If those people had been adequately consulted at the time the legislation was being prepared, the legislation would not have come forward in that condition in the first place and it would not have been necessary for these people to have made submissions. Then we had the farce of trying to cram that into two days of hearings. I think it is important to consider what Coopers and Lybrand said in its submission because it is an expert in the tax field. It said in part:

speech.para: As sales tax is a self-assessing tax, it is imperative that this `new law', which replaces existing sales tax legislation, meets all the tests of a good statute, ie simplicity, equity, efficiency and certainty. In generality, in our opinion, the legislation as it presently exists, fails all four tests.

So far, not one Government member has been able to produce a case that would in any way defend the present wholesale sales tax. It is a ramshackle mess that has grown and grown and is now virtually falling to pieces under the weight of its own production. As we know, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) made various changes, but not the sorts of changes that were going to improve it. As various witnesses have confirmed, the Government has done everything other than reduce the confusion, uncertainty and concern of the Bills. The Treasurer's about-turn emasculates much of the two-year simplification exercise to rehash the old system and has left it without the certainty that the previous legislation had.

para.tab: As a number of witnesses said, it will not make the sales tax one bit easier or simpler for taxpayers. That was one of the things that we understood from their very titles—the tax simplification Bills. The Government has done anything but make it simpler. It goes to show that the Government has a total lack of understanding of the tax process and the effects of it. It is the real double whammy, and by increasing sales tax we have become even less competitive in other countries than we already are. The legislation would make

speech.para: many more people unemployed—it has already made hundreds of thousands of workers unemployed—and it will continue to do so. It has discouraged investment, but still the Government presses on. I quote from Steven Kates's speech:

So the question that business can answer is how best to structure the tax system so that business can pay taxes in ways which least harm production. What it does indicate is that business prefers a tax system which will least interfere with its ability to generate the greatest amount of production. You would think that would be the kind of tax system every government would want to encourage.

Of course one would think that. But that is not the way it is turning out. It makes me wonder how many members opposite have owned and operated businesses where sales tax was a feature of everyday life. The stupidity and the hassles that go with the sales tax regime are a nuisance, a nightmare and a terrible disincentive to many people in business. Honourable senators know that there is only one way to handle the wholesale sales tax, and that is to abolish it. If we bring our taxes up-front and let the people know what the tax is, they will be much better off. As I understand the figures, since this Government came into power, sales tax has increased by 223 per cent.

para.tab:
Sales tax is a relic of a bygone era. As it has been added to, so it has become more cumbersome. It is real tax by stealth. Every item of electrical goods, furniture, clothing and food is affected by sales tax; in every case, each item suffers and reflects sales tax to some degree. Those goods also reflect, of course, some of the equally constraining taxes that have already been alluded to tonight and previously—and the list keeps growing. I seek leave to have incorporated in
Hansard
a table of sales tax figures which was approved by a previous Minister in the chamber.
Leave granted.

The table read as follows
—

speech.para: [TABLE OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 811]

talk.start.para: —Clearly the Government is getting wrong advice. I would like to know the sources of its advice. It seems to me quite simple that we should get our advice from the correct people—those who are investing their own money and who are living and dying by the way that they invest. We should be dealing more with the researchers, engineers and marketers—the people who are in the marketplace. We should be listening to ordinary people, such as members of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, a representative of which I have already quoted.

para.tab: Instead, here we have a Bill that would add wider powers of departmental discretion and things like that which are so terribly dangerous; they are really dangerous powers to give at a time like this. I heard it explained not long ago when we were looking at powers to tax on what someone in the department thinks a taxpayer may have thought or intended. That is no way to run a tax operation.

Tax on production is one more item destroying Australia's ability to compete with other countries. It matters not whether we are talking of competing in Australia against exports or in overseas markets. It goes on just the same. For instance, I display here two volumes that come from Singapore. They just happen to be books describing what that country will do to assist industry to overcome the problems of dealing with other countries. If we were serious about our trade issues, we would be doing something like that too. Instead, we are hitting everyone who is competing with imports or trying to build up an export market with taxes all the way through that they cannot avoid under these circumstances. Tax on production is a real killer, a stupid killer. What other countries would ever try to do the same thing?

I was recently in Victoria at a car parts plant which has been transferred largely to New Zealand. I was told there that the cost in Australia they must use is the net labour cost plus 51 per cent. Having built the factory in New Zealand and transferred the main part of the enterprise there, the cost is the New Zealand net wage figure plus 17 per cent. So much of that cost in Australia is taxes, including sales tax, and rates and so on, but it makes us uncompetitive in the real world.

Sales tax is a tax on production, a tax on investment, a tax on employment and a tax on international competitiveness. It determines very much who gets the sale. Twenty-one out of 24 OECD countries are against our present system and, as a result, they will beat us on the world markets nearly every time. Please, cannot Government members see that we are on the wrong track in the world arena?

It would not matter whether they were right, which they are not. The dictates of the world demand that Australia does not penalise itself if we are trying to survive. As we all know, in 1975-76 Prime Minister Keating knew this, and all that has happened is that even more countries have followed the path and not one has gone the other way. The Bill and the theory behind it are flawed, and we all know it.

If we follow this route, we have a guaranteed direct route to further economic decline. The present taxes are business based. Primary and secondary industry is taxed on every bend. We are still competing with the old ALP view that businesses are the employers and, as such, are against the workers, are anti-union and should be taxed more mercilessly than ever.

Look at the effects of the wrong tax policy. We have lost tens of thousands of businesses. We are buying what we used to make. We are discouraging those who could help and we owe the people we buy from $150,000m on our purchases. At the same time, remember that a place such as Taiwan, which is half the size of Tasmania, does it differently. It has $A100,000m in overseas credits. I point that out to the Government, because if it really studied the matter it might work out that there could be some connection.

I look to the other side to see how many Government members have ever employed people in the productive sector. I then have to ask: what would they know about employing people? Would they, if they did know, whip in yet another round of sales taxes, super taxes, training levies or taxes under any of the other names that they give them? How would they know what the effect is on the ordinary, little struggling business that is trying to make Australia survive, export and compete with imports? How many of them over there have laid awake at night worrying about whether there would be orders tomorrow; whether they would survive without some new equipment that they cannot afford; how they were going to fund the Christmas pay; and how they would compete with imports or big industry or whatever?

How many of them over there can speak with any experience in this area? What would they know about fronting the bank manager in times of recession or having to pay off long serving, tried and true employees because of new government taxes and charges or the recession that we had to have? The varying rates, exclusions and interpretations, as I have said, make it a rabble and produces what, at best, are referred to as unintended consequences.

I will throw in another case scenario. If we get a builder to build a wardrobe, we pay tax on it; but if we push it up against the wall and put a screw in it, it becomes part of the building and is not taxable. How stupid can one get? This is the sort of system that we are reduced to.

We know that we cannot get the support of the Australian Democrats on a matter such as this because they have their own fabulous tax dream. They believe that we should tax business and the wealth producers to extinction. If we do, I suppose we then come back to having everything manually operated and to bringing back the horse and buggy, candles and so on. But that is the way they see it.

Let us look for a moment at the presentation of the legislation. Look at the mess that it was in when it arrived in the Senate. Look at the changes that have been made and the mess that it is still in. Whatever happened to consultation? What a mess the legislation is in! At present, there are still outstanding unsatisfactory issues: the general anti-avoidance provision and the fact that there is no protection for taxpayers who are acting genuinely in the course of commerce or trade; the situation in respect of rulings and the continuing uncertainty that revolves around the issue; the continued speculation about external costs; the administrative compliance arrangements; the many and varied exemption anomalies and inconsistencies; the tax treatment of deemed manufacturers; and the discrimination against two Australian oil companies. However, the Government still expects us to pass this legislation.

The hearings revealed that the Government's proposed new wholesale sales tax would include a tax on food, a tax on services, a tax on exports, a tax on tourism, a tax on farmers, a tax on many manufacturers, double taxation, a tax on infrastructure and a tax on plant and buildings. All these things are ahead of us the way we are heading now. This ramshackle wholesale sales tax legislation is an absolute mess. It is a disgrace that it has got to the state that it is in. I, too, want to know why it is that, if a spoonful of chocolate is placed in a glass and a cap is put on it, it is taxable whereas it is not taxable if one puts it in oneself. I am talking about things like this. The inconsistencies of it are crazy. The administration of it is a nightmare for the people who are supposed to administer it and for the people who are having it administered. We have to do something that is better, fairer and not so ridiculously, stupidly opposed to the people who are competing on the world market, whether as exporters or as people competing with importers.
That is the condition we are in. I would like to make it clear at this stage that I will certainly be opposing the legislation and supporting Senator Short's amendment.

speech.speaker: Crowley Sen R.A.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support this group of Bills—the Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992, the Sales Tax Imposition (Excise) Bill 1992, the Sales Tax Imposition (Customs) Bill 1992, the Sales Tax Imposition (General) Bill 1992, the Sales Tax Amendment (Transitional) Bill 1992, and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill 1992. In particular, I chose to come into this debate mainly to correct the appalling errors put into it by the Opposition. For openers, I want to say that it is pretty wicked of Senator Patterson to suggest that the Opposition would introduce a GST but would compensate people whereas this Government has done nothing by way of compensation.

para.tab: One of the ways Senator Patterson says the Opposition proposes to compensate people is by reducing personal income tax. I decided not to interject on her at the time, but I do suggest that Senator Patterson checks out the number of times personal income tax has been cut since this Government has been in office. If she claims that could be a compensation for the Opposition, then clearly she should acknowledge that there has been considerable compensation to people under the Labor Government. I do not know whether one would say it was compensation; it is just that the Government has, on a number of occasions, very significantly reduced personal income tax. The Government has also done a number of other things by way of addressing the needs of people through family payments, setting benchmarks for the cost of rearing children and so on. But I do not want to trawl over those items, at least at this stage. I want to have a look at the appalling errors from those opposite.
In particular, I had the pleasant duty of being Madam Acting Deputy President and, therefore, listening to Senators Bishop and Knowles last week. Senator Bishop said:

speech.para: It is very interesting that products that women buy are taxed the hardest and highest.

I do not know what Senator Bishop means by `products that women buy', but I suspect that she is referring to those which Senator Knowles listed more explicitly. At page 590 of
Hansard
, Senator Knowles said:
..the cost of products used by women was going to increase.
She goes on to say:
Ms McHugh failed to say that the cost of products used by women—whether they be cosmetics, sanitary items or whatever—are taxed at 30 per cent.

In the course of that speech Senator Knowles accused Government members of being `liars', and she was reminded that that kind of language was unparliamentary. I do not know what to say in this place about Senator Knowles. If one goes around insisting that cosmetics and sanitary items are taxed at 30 per cent, then one suffers from the inability to get it right; one is very, very ignorant; wickedly ignorant; or one is fibbing—to quote Senator Knowles, `telling whoppers'.

para.tab: But for the record, there is no wholesale sales tax on sanitary products. That was removed in 1948. My view is that probably around 1948 we did not need cotton wadding for the war effort. I cannot imagine why else, but there were probably other reasons. But sanitary products have not had a wholesale sales tax on them since 1948. They are not taxed at 10, 20 or 30 per cent. They have no tax. They are certainly not taxed as luxury items, as Senator Knowles would have us believe. Neither are Tampax although, if one listened to Senator Knowles, one would think that they were. Wrong, Senator Knowles; wickedly wrong. Tampax may come with strings attached but they have no tax.

The Opposition policy is going to put a 15 per cent goods and services tax on these products. Those opposite are going to force women to pay 15 per cent more for all those sanitary products, which are already a significant cost to any household that has one or more women in it. Madam Acting Deputy President, you would know as I do the considerable burden that places on many families with one or two teenage daughters or more; I refer to the cost each month from their household budgets. Under the Opposition, those products will cost 15 per cent more. Those opposite, of course, will dodge and twist on this. They have got it wrong. There is no tax on Tampax or sanitary products; there will be a 15 per cent goods and services tax if the Opposition comes into government. They are, I think, forcing women to consider going back into rags, and that is because the goods and services tax policy in this area is in tatters.

I will certainly pursue Senators Patterson and Vanstone, as well as Senators Knowles and Bishop, and I should say that particularly women senators opposite should know better. They should know better than to go around misrepresenting the facts like this. But the Opposition is going to go to the polls on a pad and Tampax tax. I am quite sure that when we tell women that—it is already a considerable cost—they will not be fooled by the Opposition's curious arguments about tax.

talk.start.para: —A P and T tax!

—Senator Kernot is quite right. The sanitary products, of course, are not only used by menstruating women; they are of considerable importance to older women or to people who suffer from early incontinence. We know that many women have to deal with this kind of problem every day, so, as I was quite rightly reminded, it is not only restricted to women facing problems of menstruation. It is quite outrageous that some people, in particular, women senators opposite, who should know better, are going around the country telling that great whopper to the people of Australia. There is no wholesale sales tax on sanitary products. The Opposition is completely wrong in saying there is. I think we have to remind people how wrong it is. If the Opposition gets it as wrong as that on that product, it has got it wrong on lots of others.

para.tab: Senator Knowles also said that women who buy cosmetics—we will not talk about the men who buy them—are hit with a 30 per cent wholesale sales tax. Wrong, Senator Knowles. They are charged a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax and, indeed, it will be more or less the same price with a 15 per cent goods and services tax; not much to argue about there. As Ms McHugh has said in the other place, and in various speeches, there is not much nutritional value in cosmetics. If the Opposition wants to argue about the 15 per cent wholesales tax on these things, it must know that the prices will not be different, in one way or another, from what they are now. But if it wants to talk about these items, it should talk facts. Talk facts, Senator Knowles; talk facts, Opposition. The Opposition should not tell the whoppers that it has been telling.

Senator Knowles went on to say that she was shocked to discover that the `Slip, slop, slap' commercials encouraging people to use sunscreens were to be set back because sunscreens were now enjoying wholesale sales tax. Well, once again, Senator Knowles is wrong. If a sunscreen is above a factor 4—that is, has a content that prevents the sunburn effects of ultraviolet rays—up to factor 15, and more, it does not attract a sales tax. I have to say to Senator Knowles that under the Opposition's goods and services tax the hats that people will wear on their heads—do wear now and will wear in the future—will attract a 15 per cent goods and services tax. So will the shirts on people's backs; so will the trousers on their legs; and so will the shoes on their feet. Sunscreen is not enjoying a sales tax, if it is a sunscreen. Senator Knowles is wrong on that, but under the goods and services tax the whole campaign will be dramatically different. All the clothing that people will wear to avoid sunburn will be taxed 15 per cent.

talk.start.para: —Is she misleading the Senate?

—If Senator Knowles is not misleading the Senate—the Minister is quite right in raising this point—she suffers from monumental ignorance. Senator Brownhill—usually a reasonable person—got it wrong, too. He is quoted as saying that unsuspecting taxpayers are ripped off to an enormous amount. I think he quoted a figure of about $9.4 billion of sales tax from baby nappies and funeral caskets. It is a double bill of some imagination. But he is wrong in both cases. There is no wholesale sales tax on any sort of nappy. I have made it my business to check that out. Wrong, Senator Brownhill. There is no wholesale sales tax on funeral caskets. Wrong, Senator Brownhill.

para.tab: This is the problem we have to deal with. The Opposition, in trying to defend its goods and services tax, is popping up with any kind of random idea. The Opposition tells us that things in our supermarkets actually attract taxes all the way to 30 per cent. As far as I can tell, almost nothing—indeed, I would say nothing, but, being a cautious person, I will say almost nothing—attracts a 30 per cent tax in supermarkets. Ten per cent and 20 per cent, yes; 30 per cent, no. Wrong again, Opposition.

Senator Knowles added, in the course of another speech on the same day which, again, I was listening to, that there will be no goods and services taxes applied to health. First of all, one would not need to apply a 15 per cent goods and services tax if one were increasing the price of every visit to the doctor by 30 per cent. That is a subtle little addition to the costs for people.

Moving to the AMA schedule of fees, the cost of health will go up by 30 per cent. Each doctor visit will be—as a minimum—$5; but invariably people will have to find $31 before they can start claiming that money back. The cost of health will be dramatically more expensive for people and so will the cruel hoax of Dr Hewson's private health insurance policy. He is going to either seduce or force people into buying private insurance; but he is not going to tell people that if they have private insurance they cannot have any guarantee that they will not be hit with very large bills. That is why people are leaving private insurance at the moment. It is no assurance at all. But it is certainly a right to large bills. Any number of us here know of those many stories of people who say, `I have had private insurance all my life to protect me against the costs of going to the doctor or having an operation. I finally used it and now I have got a $3,000 or $5,000 bill. What on earth am I going to do? I will not be able to pay it'.

That is the problem of private insurance at the moment. That is the problem of private insurance under the Opposition's proposals. It is a cruel hoax. One would not need a GST on top of a 30 per cent increase in costs; that would be, even for the Opposition, too bald to go with.

The Opposition says that there is not a goods and services tax applied to health; but consider the kiosk in any hospital. The Opposition wants to say that its goods and services tax is easy, because there are no exemptions and everything is clear: there will be no tax in the area of health. But what about the kiosk in any public hospital, or in any private hospital?
(Quorum formed)

The Opposition says that there is no goods and services tax in hospitals or on health care. But we are at the kiosk in a hospital and, as far as we can tell, all the products in the kiosk will have a goods and services tax. If we want to buy a bunch of flowers and take it up to sick grandma, it will have a 15 per cent whack on it. If we want to take some apples and oranges to comfort people, to feed them fresh fruit and vegies, the Opposition will whack 15 per cent on them. Gosh, the Opposition is mean. How mean can one get?—taxing the fruit and flowers one might want to take to people in hospital.

talk.start.para: —Health care costs do not include chocolate and flowers.

—That is the pits, really the pits. The Opposition is actually saying that it is not going to have a goods and services tax on health. But the Opposition is there, in hospitals, creating terrible problems. Senator Watson had better come clean. Is he planning to say that, in fact, kiosks in hospitals will be exempt? If he wants to say that, then he should come out and say it. If he is not going to exempt the product in a kiosk in a hospital, then he should come out and say that. I do not think he will, but I assure honourable senators that I will. I am going to say that when people want to take a bunch of flowers to grandma or grandpa or to little children they will have to pay 15 per cent GST on top of the cost of their flowers. Fresh fruit—
—Senator Crowley is not going to tell people about the fact that the tax system is going to be better, or that they are going to have a lot more money in their pockets.

—I am coming to that. This is my speech, not Senator Brownhill's. I want to tell it my way. He wants to say that the Opposition's system is going to be so simple. I think that even that has to be examined very closely. The Opposition also says that people looking to the matter of education will not have to pay goods and services tax, but it should tell us about the status of food for boarding school meals. It is not clear that these will be exempt, as part of education. Indeed, it seems very likely that they will have a goods and services tax, so that when people take their children off to boarding school, not only will they be paying fees, but they will be paying a goods and services tax on all the food their children eat. That situation is what the Government knows is so invidious about the goods and services tax.

para.tab: The Opposition may carp and complain about the current system, but the people out there know that an extra 15 per cent tax on food and clothing, on fresh fruit and vegetables, is a very unpalatable tax. I heard Senator Archer lamenting the challenges to business. I am surprised that Senator Archer wants to trawl through the litany the way he did, but he does not tell us about the successful businesses that are coping very well under the present system. There are many people who can cope, because they know the rules and they get on with it. To suggest that the imposition of this tax is going to make it easier for business does not address the full truth at all, and it certainly avoids the problem of what the goods and services tax will do to the service industry.

The service industry is currently not being taxed, but the Opposition's policy plans to tax every service going. Think of how much fun it will be for the people running a cinema. Not only will they have to charge people a fee to go in, but they will have to collect a goods and services tax. Why did Senator Archer not tell us about that kind of problem?

talk.start.para: —Tone it down.

—No; I will not lower my voice for Senator Vanstone. I would like everybody to know what I am saying. I would hate to think that the honourable senator missed it. The Opposition did not tell me about the complications of the service part of this. It did not tell me about the electrician who is going to have to collect the 15 per cent goods and services tax on the services he or she performs when fixing a power switch, or light switches or anything that he or she comes and does in the house. The Opposition is going to have to tax the electrician, and tax the plumber. How are all those people who currently do not have to collect those taxes going to collect the tax on all those services? Have honourable senators opposite thought about the impact of their goods and services tax on tourism, and the service industry of tourism? They duck and shove when it comes to the hard bits, but they do not want to talk about those: they want to tell us about the cascading effect which they admit might be up to—
—There is no cascading effect.

—No, no. Senator Watson is leaping in: he wants to accuse the Government of a cascading effect, but he wants to avoid the fact that, like it or not, the Opposition says the goods and services tax has to be compensated for. What does that mean? It means that people will be out of pocket because of it. That is all, and, very simply, that is what it means. The Opposition is going to have to compensate people for the tax it is whacking on them: whacking tax on for their food, for their clothing and for all services. Next time they go to the footy it will be 15 per cent dearer, under the goods and services tax—if and when anybody makes a decision to be so dumb as to elect the Opposition to government. Food and services, with people going to the flicks, the drive-in, the footy—going to any of the simple things that people do—will be hit with a 15 per cent goods and services tax. The service industry and Senator Archer are pretty silent about all that.

para.tab: Not long ago I had the pleasure of being in Toronto for a brief time. Let me tell honourable senators what the people in Toronto think about the goods and services tax—over 70 per cent of them loathe and detest it. I had to ride in a taxi or two, and in the taxis they have printed in sort of gritty letters along the edge of their windows the words, `The goods and services tax is already included in this price'. They hate it.

At restaurants in Toronto not only do patrons have to work out what to pay for the 15 per cent tip but they also have to add on the 15 per cent goods and services tax. The menu might say $20 for a main course, but it is 30 per cent more than that when the goods and services tax and tip have been paid. Canadian people absolutely hate their goods and services tax! It is very clear what they think about it. I think Australians should be told what it means for them.

It means increasing costs by 15 per cent with a goods and services tax on all the products so critical to everyday living such as food and clothing. It also means that people will have to be taxed when they buy things. That means that people whose disposable income is limited and fixed and largely goes on expenditure will be hit very hard by this goods and services tax, and on any evidence they cannot be adequately compensated for that.

This Opposition proposes to absolutely wreck equity in the name of a goods and services tax. The members of the Opposition do not like equity at all. They also, by the way, have skidded over the fact that many people in the Tax Office will have to be devoted to collecting this goods and services tax. Senator Bishop talked about how many people are currently involved in collecting the wholesale sales tax. I think I am correct in saying that she was told that there were 763—and it was to be reduced to 740—officers in that category.

New Zealand, which has a much smaller population and a smaller demand on its tax officers, started off with 1,000 dedicated tax officers for its goods and services tax. Of course, it would have to be much higher in Australia. By way of comparison, the number of dedicated officers for the goods and services tax in Canada was 5,000. So it is quite clear that in Australia the figure would have to be, at a very moderate and conservative estimate, at least 2,500. It would probably need to be more than that, and that is a significant increase on the 763 or 740—whichever it is currently—that Senator Bishop was complaining about.

Senator Bishop did not tell us in detail about how many more officers will have to be involved in Treasury in the collating and collecting, parsing and analysing of the goods and services tax. In the end, it is very simple. The goods and services tax is a 15 per cent charge on the essentials of life—on food and clothing, rent and services. It is going to be most inequitable because for those people who have low and fixed incomes it is going to affect almost all of their income.

It is going to be very nice for those on a very high income with the top marginal rate reduced and more choice. Those people will have more opportunity to save. This tax is classically regressive. It is going to be terrible and damning for people on low and fixed incomes and, as part of the package, it is going to give a much easier ride for people on high incomes. It is for those reasons, as well as the fact that it is levied on food and clothing, that I so strongly oppose it. It is regressive and it is unfair.

I would like to close on the point that was raised by some members of the Opposition that this tax is 15 per cent and that there it will stay. Honourable senators should wonder about that. In the United Kingdom, the original rate was 10 per cent; now it is 17.5 per cent. In New Zealand, the original rate was 10 per cent; now it is 12.5 per cent. In Austria, the original rate was 8 per cent; now it is 20 per cent. In Sweden, the original rate was 11 per cent; now it is 25 per cent.

I would not hold my breath about the Opposition keeping its GST at 15 per cent. Of course, it will not do so because, as well as its packet of GST, it is proposing to massively cut government expenditure, so somewhere or other it will have to find the dollars to maintain the services that this Government thinks are so critical to maintaining quality of life and services to people, particularly those on low and middle incomes. Those services are what the Opposition is going to do away with. Quite clearly, not only would the GST be 15 per cent on food and clothing: in no time at all it would be more. The goods and services tax is an appalling tax: it is regressive and it is unfair. As I have said, it comes from the Opposition's mouth time and time again incorrectly, based on gross error to the point where one could say only that the Opposition must intend to get it wrong or else it is so sloppy that it never checks.

The points I particularly want to correct tonight relate to the sanitary provisions for women. Pads and Tampax have not had tax on them since 1948, but the Opposition is going to bang a 15 per cent tax on them. Its policy is in tatters. It intends to go to the election on the pad and Tampax tax: not a winner with women.

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Under standing order 191 I wish to make some remarks in response to Senator Crowley's speech. As I heard it, she said she wanted to refute some points made by me and a number of other speakers. She has clearly misunderstood some of the points she wants to refute that she alleges I made.
—Do you want to make a personal explanation?
—I want to make an explanation of my speech under standing order 191. I do not want to do it for very long.
—In other words, you are claiming misrepresentation.
—Please use the right form.

—I will come to Senator Cook on another date. It is not worth having an argument with him at this stage. If he does not understand the Standing Orders, he can get them out. The heading of standing order 191 is `Explanations of speeches', and that is what I am seeking to do. I am not making a personal explanation.
—That is what the Chair asked you.
—What I want to do is make an explanation of a speech under standing order 191. If the Chair does not understand that, I will wait until it does.
—You are claiming to be misrepresented. Proceed.

—It is not a personal explanation. There are actually two misrepresentations. Senator Crowley said there is a clear skating over of the coalition proposal to put 15 per cent on everything. There has been no attempt, and certainly not in my speech, to skate over that. I am sure the record will show in the
Hansard
later today that I made it abundantly clear that we are going to put a 15 per cent tax on just about everything. If Senator Crowley thinks that I have attempted to misrepresent that case, I think she has misunderstood what I have said. I think I said perfectly clearly that we will put a 15 per cent flat, simple tax on just about everything. There is no walking away from that. It is one of the key elements of the policy that it is so simple and people will not have to work out what the taxes are on this or that category of good.

para.tab: The second aspect of my dispute of Senator Crowley's interpretation of what I have said relates to the question of whether there is a tax on food or clothing. I suspect that Senator Crowley has allowed me to speak tonight by simply at large saying, `Senator Vanstone said blah, blah, blah', because it is clear to me that she probably was not listening to what I was saying. Had she been listening she could not have misunderstood me so drastically.

What I said was simply that one of the big Labor lies—one of the biggest—is to go around saying that the coalition wants to tax food and clothing. The implication contained in that allegation is that there is no tax on food and clothing at the moment. That is exactly what Senator Crowley has tried to imply in here tonight. She has clearly misunderstood that part of my speech that explained the cascading effect of indirect taxes that are not directly placed on individuals but cascade through the system. If you were in the chamber, Madam Acting Deputy President, you will realise that they are measures such as payroll tax and the wholesale sales tax charged on trucks. I will not go through the list again but I did use, at length, the example of wheat coming from the farm, going to the factory, going to the wholesaler, going to the retailer—there are other goods that do that—and how at each stage the trucks that carry them have wholesale sales tax on them and the fuel used in those trucks has an excise on it. Those people do not pay that out of the goodness of their hearts, nor do the manufacturers of Weetbix pay the payroll tax out of the goodness of their hearts.

What I tried to show in my speech, and what I think I clearly did show, was that there is an element of indirect wholesale sales tax on food and clothing, and for anyone in the Labor Party to be saying that there is not a tax on food and clothing at the moment is grossly misrepresenting the truth of the matter. I regard that as one of Labor's big lies.

Therefore, for Senator Crowley to say that I am, in the first instance, trying to skate over the question of a 15 per cent tax is to misunderstand what I have said. I have said quite clearly that there will be a 15 per cent tax on just about everything. It is one of the key elements of the package.

The second point I wanted to make was that for her to suggest that I have tried to put in the debate tonight something in relation to the tax on food and clothing that does not amount to a tax is to misrepresent what I have said. I have admitted that we want to put a tax on food and clothing. What I have said is that those who pretend there is not one there now are lying.

talk.start.para: —I have been misrepresented and I seek leave to make a statement.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Senator Vanstone, I would have to say, has always impressed me with her equableness from the chair, but I think that one of the problems that Senator Vanstone suffers from—and I had not detected it until this point—is that like most other Opposition senators she thinks she knows what I think. I would have to say that that has to be the most classic example of misrepresentation ever. You need to read what I said, Senator Vanstone. It is quite clear, no matter how you say it, that it is skating over the fact of putting a goods and services tax on if you also have to offer to compensate people.

para.tab: There is no doubt that there is some sales tax effect in there. No-one denies that, but you are actually putting a 15 per cent tax on food and clothing for which you are going to have to compensate people. If that is not a clear admission that that is a tax on food and clothing that was not there before then I do not know what is. I suggest that Opposition senators would all do much better if they stopped telling us what we meant to say or what was in our minds, which has to be the most clear misrepresentation there can be. Leave us to account for ourselves. Leave us to account for the goods and services tax. It is a pernicious and invidious tax. I will be delighted to tell the Australian people about it.

speech.speaker: Kernot Sen C.

talk.start.para:
—You might not recognise it but we are actually debating a package of sales tax Bills here this morning.
(Quorum formed)

para.tab: I would like to get on the record that that was the second retaliatory vexatious quorum calling by Senator Brownhill and I regard it as a further abuse of this chamber. It has been going on all night.

talk.start.para: —On a point of order: I believe that the remarks just made by the honourable senator actually reflect on something that was not done in a vexatious way whatsoever. It was just done because there was not a quorum in the chamber.

—Senator Brownhill, are you asking for the remarks to be withdrawn because you regard them as offensive, or are you just trying, under the guise of a point of order, to respond to what Senator Kernot said?
—I regard them as being offensive.
—Senator Kernot, I think if the senator regards—
—No; I am sorry—

—Senator Kernot, if I can tell you what I think, you might then make an assessment of it. As I understand it, if a senator takes offence, unless it is an extraordinary case where offence is clearly not to be taken, the senator who has made the remarks should withdraw them. You have suggested that Senator Brownhill had a vexatious motive in doing that; he has said he is offended by your words. It is going to be a long night. I think it would help the course of the proceedings if you would withdraw those remarks.

—On a point of order: with respect, I do not think this is called for. It is clearly a vexatious calling of a quorum. Senator Brownhill has engaged in it several times. We know this is going to be a long night. We know that Parliament is riveted by this debate and that senators who wish to participate in it are here or are tuned in to it in their offices. Simply to use the standing orders to call for a quorum is a well-known device to interrupt and prolong proceedings. Given the night, it would be reasonable to allow the comments made by Senator Kernot to stand and to get on with hearing her contribution to this debate, which I am sure will be enlightening to all in the chamber.
—I raise a point of order.

—Senator Faulkner, I will just respond. What I am trying to do is to keep things as calm as they can be. This could easily get out of hand and we do not need it to do that, because we are going to be here for some time. What I have said to Senator Kernot is that my understanding is that if a senator takes offence at remarks and asks for them to be withdrawn, by and large they should be withdrawn. What Senator Brownhill has told the chamber—through me—is that he does take offence at the suggestion that he has some improper motive, that is, a vexatious one, in using the particular standing order that he has used. In response to that I have said to Senator Kernot that I think it would help proceedings if she would care to withdraw her remarks. It is entirely up to her whether she chooses to do that. Do you want to add to that? I am happy for you to have your say.

—On the point of order raised by Senator Brownhill: it seems to me that the Chair has to make a judgment as to whether the words used by Senator Kernot in describing the call for a quorum by Senator Brownhill as `vexatious and retaliatory' are in fact unparliamentary. I do not believe that either is; hence, I do not believe it is a point of order; hence, I do not believe that Senator Kernot needs to withdraw.

—On a point of order: it seems to me that if senators are called into the chamber to hear Senator Kernot speak, how can that possibly be described by Senator Kernot as vexatious? I would have thought that since Senator Kernot and her colleagues wanted us to sit these long hours this evening, presumably she wanted to have people hear her contribution to the debate. So it is beyond me how this could possibly be described as vexatious.

—As far as I am concerned, it is not a question of whether it is properly described as vexatious; it is a question of whether the senator has taken offence. All I have done is say to Senator Kernot that I think it would be helpful if she withdrew. If she does not want to do that, I am going to let it go. But it will be on the record that she has chosen not to be helpful and that that is her decision.

—I would ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, how you reconcile the offence that I take at the way in which the quorum was called after I had begun my speech, in a way in which it has not been perpetrated—
—It happens all the time.
—No. You have to reconcile that principle, Madam Acting Deputy President. I would not wish to withdraw. I do not believe—
—Senator Walters, perhaps if we could let Senator Kernot say what she wants to say—she has the call.
—I would not wish to withdraw because I really do not believe what I said was unparliamentary. I would like to continue with my remarks because this time is coming out of my time.
—All right, continue.
—Thank you. I was saying—
—Madam Acting Deputy President—
—I am sorry, Senator Kernot. Senator Brownhill has a point of order.

—On the point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President, the point is that I did not call the quorum in a vexatious way. I called the quorum because there was not a quorum present in the chamber at the time, which I am entitled to—
—There is no point of order.

—This is the first complete revision of the 1930 sales tax legislation and the measures we are debating tonight stem from the decision announced in the 1990 Budget to review and simplify the sales tax system in its entirety. Some would argue that the Government has done this in response to the Opposition's release of Fightback. Others would say the Government has been working on this for a couple of years. Whatever is correct, I think it could be argued that the package, the simplification, is also a worthwhile initiative in its own right as most of the members of the business and professional community have stated. Inevitably, however, this debate has become the `My GST is better than your WST' debate that we had to have.

para.tab: I guess it raises the question: what is the purpose of taxation in a developed society? Is it simply to raise revenue for public services? Is it to facilitate business growth which then stimulates employment? Is it a redistributive tool to be used to achieve desirable economic and social results, such as a fair distribution of wealth and income? It is my belief, and the Democrats' belief, that it is a combination of these principles.

Currently, sales tax is imposed at differential rates to reflect social priorities. Exemptions—those nasty exemptions—can be used to support charities, hospitals, schools, universities, people with disabilities, and to favour certain products such as recycled products, solar collectors, safety equipment and so on. Further, the multi-tax sales tax system can be used as a disincentive against harmful products to shape consumer preferences in environmentally beneficial ways—for example, away from inefficient motor vehicles towards fuel efficient ones.

A selective tax can also be used to pursue socially just objectives such as exempting the necessities of life from taxation. It is interesting to note in this regard that not even Mrs Thatcher proposed to tax food, children's clothing and so on, although she is the one who actually implemented the draconian poll tax. So perhaps she thinks taxing the necessities of life is more draconian than that. But giving up such an important economic policy tool of discriminating in favour of a flat rate, non-discriminatory tax will please only those who advocate that our values and priorities should be shaped solely by the market—the total hands-off approach of the Opposition. I am not an advocate of the market at any cost, and in any event we all know the theory is completely flawed because it assumes that there is perfect information and perfect competition as a natural state. Everybody knows this is absolutely ridiculous.

Unlike the coalition, for whom it is survival of the fittest, or `Stand there and wait, and if you are lucky it will trickle down to you', I believe that government has a role. It has a responsibility for the well-being of the community, and it must have the capacity to intervene when the need arises. So when I am asked to make a choice between a GST and a WST regime I will continue to choose the wholesale sales tax, not because I denigrate the role of business but mainly because I reject the trade-off that business must be treated most advantageously, and that other social policy must fall into line behind this priority.

I do not put business ahead of battling families who struggle to feed their kids properly or disabled veterans who can currently buy their motor vehicles free from tax. They are equally important. I do not want to allow more luxury cars to be imported whilst unemployed Australian workers do not have the dignity of a decent job with fair industrial rights. In other words, I think it is fair to discriminate and I think that is much more important than the claims made for the merits of the GST.

The Opposition is arguing that the wholesale sales tax system is in need of repeal, not reform. The Democrats reject that position. We all know there are some problems with sales tax; this legislation addresses many of them, and there will be further changes after this. However, this is not a weakness in the system. It is simply reflecting the fact that, like all other bodies of law, indirect taxation needs to be constantly finetuned to achieve optimal outcomes. This finetuning will involve altering classifications to either stimulate or contract the demand for the particular product concerned. In particular, I think we could go to a system which increases the taxation on luxury items, especially those which are imported, and reduces the taxes on those items which contribute to sustainable development.

The wholesale sales tax was introduced in 1930, during the Depression, to address the collapse in customs duties which was being experienced by the Scullin Government. It is perhaps appropriate that this time of the worst economic downturn since the Depression is the time chosen to reform and modernise the system. The Opposition is calling this the `so-called simplification'. I think that is totally disingenuous because without question this is the largest scale taxation legislation simplification project—or what I would call a streamlining project—ever undertaken. The volume of legislation is being more than halved. The drafting style is plain English and the extremely cumbersome system of multiple assessment and imposition Acts is to be reduced by over 20 pieces of legislation. Is that not enough? According to the Opposition, the system is bad because it discriminates.

Without committing the Democrats to supporting every detail of the Bills, I would like to acknowledge the work done by the officials of the Tax Office on this project. The supporting material to the Bills—the explanatory memoranda and the cross-referencing document—are of a very high standard and deal with the most complex of matters in an understandable way. In addition, the work done for the Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation by the Tax Office was of a high quality and done under great pressure of time imposed by us.

I will now turn to the specific proposals in the legislation and I may well be the first speaker to do so. Sales tax will be imposed on assessable dealings with assessable goods unless an exemption applies. If the dealing is taxable, tax will be imposed at the rate of tax applicable to the goods. If the goods, or some input to the goods, have already been taxed then a credit for that earlier tax will reduce the tax payable on the later dealing. An assessable dealing may be exempted from tax because one of the parties to the dealing had made a quote. There will be two types of quoting: quoting a registration number by a registered person and quoting an exemption declaration by an unregistered person. There will be general grounds for quoting for both registered and unregistered persons. In addition, there will be special quotation grounds available to registered persons. Registration will be purely voluntary and will be solely to gain access to the special quotation grounds. No special obligations will be imposed on persons who choose to be registered.

The main assessable dealing will be a wholesale sale. This is similar to the current system and means that the current small number of taxpayers will be maintained. Contrast this with the absolutely massive compliance costs which a GST will impose on all levels of business in Australia and the massively increased administrative task which the Taxation Office would have to undertake.

In this legislation the multiple rate structure has been maintained. The rates are 0, 10, 15 and 30 per cent. All other goods are taxed at the standard rate of 20 per cent. It is this multiple rate structure which, we say, is so important in any fair indirect tax system. The system is designed so that certain types of consumption are favoured by the tax system and certain types are discouraged. This is a very basic concept, a very fair concept, and a very important tool to encourage, amongst other things, sustainable development.

The Opposition believes that all consumption should be treated in exactly the same manner. There is no room for preference as an instrument of public policy.
