Those in the Opposition want to tax the purchase of a hand gun at the same rate as the purchase of an orange. There is no room in their economic model for equity or compassion or price discrimination, to achieve environmental and social goals. My goodness, no, that is not the role of government! In its rigid inflexibility, I believe, they are out of step with public opinion on this issue, and they may well lose the upcoming election because of this rigidity, irrespective of all almost one million people being unemployed.

Some of the proposals in this legislation have attracted well-publicised criticism and this has tended to overshadow the other non-contentious changes. I will spend just a few moments dealing with these changes before I deal with the controversial ones. Firstly, the small business exemption is being significantly broadened. Currently, there is an exemption from sales tax for Australian manufacturers whose turnover of goods over a five-year period does not exceed an average of $50,000 per annum or whose sales tax liability does not exceed $1,000 per annum. The legislation proposes to change the existing concession to provide an option sales tax exemption for all taxpayers, not just manufacturers, whose total sales tax liability over a 12-month period does not exceed $10,000; that is, there will be a common exemption for all small businesses which will be considerably simpler than the current system. This will be 10 times as generous as the current system. This will reduce the administrative costs for the Taxation Office and will eliminate the sales tax compliance costs of many small businesses altogether.

What do those in the Opposition say in respect of this excellent proposal for small business? They are opposed to it. They will be voting against these Bills—not because of the intrinsic merit or otherwise of the proposals but because, I think, they are worried that these legislative changes basically make their GST position much less marketable with respect to small business.

The cost of this liberalisation is estimated to be $20m to $30m in a full year, and the reason that the cost to revenue is so low is that sales tax is predominantly paid, that is, remitted to the Taxation Office, by very large businesses. The Tax Office's 1991 annual report contained some remittance statistics on page 136. These show that over 90 per cent of the sales tax revenue is remitted by businesses with a liability of over $100,000 and that almost 75 per cent of the revenue is collected from businesses with a liability of over $1m. This just reinforces the huge efficiency—not the inefficiency, but the huge efficiency—in terms of administrative and compliance costs which a wholesale based tax system has compared to a multi-stage system. Indeed, the
Australian Financial Review
reported on this matter on 10 June in an article by Christopher Jay entitled `GST Compliance Costs Hit Small Firms'. The article referred to a survey conducted in Britain and it stated:

speech.para: Should the Federal Opposition gain office and introduce a Goods and Services Tax, small business can expect to have a compliance cost of almost 2 per cent of turnover.
Where business has a $100,000 turnover, it will incur $2,000 costs; and where it has a $500,000 turnover, it will incur $10,000 costs.

para.tab:
Honourable senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Those in the Opposition hate all this stuff about compliance and administrative costs, do they not? They hate having to acknowledge it. How can these costs sit comfortably with all the rhetoric that they have about protecting jobs and small business?

para.tab: So the Democrats will be supporting the increased small business exemption. The original Bill has been improved by the additional measure outlined in the Treasurer's press release. We support this further improvement and commend the Government for accepting the representations made by the public on this matter. But at this stage I would wish to publicly question the wisdom of a particular decision which I think Senator Vanstone mentioned tonight, to exempt unprocessed bottled mineral water. I hope the Government has some figures to justify this decision because it really seems to me that if we are being discriminatory, and in our case we would like to look at categories of luxury goods, it is ludicrous to exclude what is accepted as a luxury product, much of it imported, at a time of massive current account deficit and huge hardship for the unemployed and families in this country. Other items have had their exemptions removed or their rate of tax increased, for example, containers for takeaway food, ornamental crockery or glassware, and pet food except for that used for guide dogs or in animal shelters.

I will be moving an amendment during the Committee stage to introduce a dual rate system of taxing takeaway food packaging because I think the tax system should recognise that some packaging material is more benign than other materials and it should be taxed at a lower rate. We have seen the effect of taxation preference in the area of recycled paper. There is now a major industry of paper recycling in this country and some significant proposals, including the Albury mill proposal, for further expanding the industry. So discriminatory taxes can also create real, sustainable jobs.

There are a number of other areas where we should be following this type of model with other recycled products such as recycled plastic products, and with all commercial reuses of goods. An example of this latter category is the excellent printer cartridge recycling program which is run by Gestetner and which is used by the Department of the Senate. Taxing harmful products, non-recyclable products, can only discourage their use. I am not saying that taxation is the only instrument that should be used to influence industry development but I think it is a very important one. Often the Government acknowledges this point—Senator McMullan has done so repeatedly in this chamber—but usually the Government says, `We oppose this reasonable initiative at this stage but we will take it away and look at it and maybe come back later'.

One could go on all night about this legislation. Indeed, I expect that the Opposition probably will. Senator Archer said that we have to do something better and fairer than the WST. I do not believe the GST is either better or fairer and the fact of the matter is that many commentators, especially the professionals who are going to have to work with the legislation, acknowledge that it has intrinsic merit and deserves passage, and the Democrats agree.

speech.speaker: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

talk.start.para: —In this debate on the Sales Tax Assessment Bill, I shall be mercifully short. I shall come to other matters in a moment but, essentially, we were told that this legislation was intended to simplify the wholesale sales tax legislation and that it would be revenue neutral. Of course, we know now that the truth is to be found elsewhere and that it was not ultimately revenue neutral; that it does not simplify the process; that it does make some changes with respect to taxation rulings and it does make some significant changes to the administration of the taxation Act.

para.tab: I cannot help but reflect just briefly on the last one or two Labor senators who have been in this chamber. I have to say that I find their audacity breathtaking in coming into this chamber and pleading some mortgage over, or at the very least, some concern, some compassion for ordinary Australians after what they have done to them for a decade of unmitigated torture.

We have heard Senator Crowley and others talking about the Goods and Services Tax, while clearly not understanding—or deceiving both themselves and the public about the fact—that, since this Government came to office, they have hijacked the wholesale sales tax legislation and rammed it up from $2.8 billion to $9.5 billion, a milch cow of revenue. As I recall, it was during Senator Walsh's time that, so that they did not have to come back each Budget and announce that cigarettes were going up, and petrol was going up, and alcohol was going up, and the cost of bread was going up, and the cost of milk was going up, and the cost of toiletries was going up, they decided that they would automatically put them up in this insidious, surreptitious way without legislation. The costs were increased quarterly by the CPI. In other words, it happened without one knowing about it.

This is a government that agitates for honesty in labelling. Would it not be nice if we had on the label the price that the item has been caused to have as a result of the wholesale sales tax? This Government has done more to tear out of the pockets of ordinary Australians the additions to the cost of goods than any other government in the life of the Commonwealth.

What I find obscene about this debate is the fact that the Labor Party does not pretend or purport to put forward an intellectually compelling argument. Labor senators do not stand and argue on the logic. They will not compete in the debate on the merits. They will simply get up and repeat their obscene lie that the goods and services tax is a 15 per cent increase on the cost of living and the cost of ordinary goods. They know it is a lie; the Australian public is understanding it is a lie. But it is the very best argument that they have in this campaign—the best argument they can come up with. They are not prepared to argue; they are not prepared to campaign; they are not prepared to go into the next election arguing on truth and honesty. They have resorted, as they always have at the last minute, to a fear campaign which is enshrined in lies.

The truth of the matter is that, on average, costs will go up for an ordinary basket of goods by about 4.2 per cent. But what I find interesting, and I am sure that Senator Kemp will find equally interesting, is that the Government refuses to debate—yet the Democrats will—the virtue of reducing the cost of gasoline by 19c a litre. We do not hear any complaints about reducing the average personal income tax by 30 per cent across the board. We hear no belly-aching or complaints about raising the tax threshold from $5,400 to $7,000.

We do not hear any complaints about the fact that, from now on, personal income tax for 95 per cent of Australian taxpayers will be a maximum of 30 per cent. We do not hear any complaints about the fact that pensions will go up by 8 per cent; that all other government benefits will go up by 6 per cent; that single mother supporting benefits will go up by $300; that there is going to be $90m extra pumped into child-care; that the family allowance will be doubled for those on $30,000 and increased by 50 per cent for those on between $30,000 and $40,000; that the pharmaceutical benefits concession card will be increased for all aged people.

Not once have I heard a Labor Party person argue about the merits of that proposal. If we reflect upon this Government, we recognise that the group of people that it is defending are the cheats and the crooks in the community who do not pay their share. Those opposite are defending and perpetuating the black market. They are guaranteeing that those who manage to avoid this system of paying tax by being in the cash economy will continue to do so. They are not the ordinary PAYE Australians; they are the people who are into rorts and deals, who deal in large dollops of black cash. We find that this Government is defending them, of course.

I am astounded that this Government is able to stand up and argue, on the basis of the goods and services tax, that it has got some care for ordinary Australians at a time when we have got record unemployment, record bankruptcy, record foreign debt, record misery, and even record suicides, a breakdown in law and order and a decayed economy. Government members come in here and argue with us and talk to us about a GST. Perhaps I should quote one eminent Australian, who was asked:

speech.para: Aren't you taking a heck of a risk—
in advocating the adoption of a consumption tax—
and is it worth it?
That was a good question. The interviewee responded:
Yes, we are taking a risk. . . What this country has needed desperately for years now is a government which is prepared to face up to what has to be done to get this economy in proper shape.
The interviewer said:
But if you do this and then lose the election they—
the Opposition—
are the ones that will benefit.
The interviewee replied:

I'm not in politics and never have been in public life just to be there to ride a popularity wave and do what you think is going to be popular. What needs to be done is to have a government in this country which is prepared to face up to the greater challenges facing this country.

We are coming to the end of this twentieth century. We cannot any longer afford to go on, take soft options and say, `She'll be right'. The world is not going to say to Australia, `She'll be right'. . .

It will be a tragedy for Australia if we baulk at tax reform because it might hurt me here, it might hurt you there. Now for God's sake, let's, as Australians, say what does Australia as a whole, what do our children need in the next generation. Do they want a tax system which has just been slipshod, mishmashed together over 30 years, with no point or purpose, and which is inefficient?
. . . you can't have a continuation of a tax system which is haemorrhaging, imposing burdens on those least able to bear them, economically inefficient.

. . . if Australia refuses to face up to this issue, we'll slop through. . . we'll slop through. Our children will pay an enormous price if through our self-indulgence and self-interest we refuse to remedy this system.

That was the Labor Prime Minister at the time, Mr Bob Hawke, arguing persuasively and in a very articulate and passionate way for a goods and services tax, saying to Australians that they had to have the guts to get up and do it; that they could not be concerned about whether it might cost them a few votes; that there was a greater good in question. We have heard the comments of other notable people. One said:
If we don't, as a nation, adopt this proposal, then you won't see significant reform in this country in taxation for the balance of this century.
That, of course, was Paul Keating—
The virtue of having a single rate, exemption free tax, particularly in the supermarket context, is one of the fundamental criteria for pursuing a consumption tax. It has to be simple.

talk.start.para: —Is that Paul Keating?
—That is Paul Keating arguing with every single member of the Labor Party who has been taking part in this debate for the last fortnight.
—Nobody is listening, Senator Kemp.
—You will be up defending him.
—Yes, that is right.
—It is not being broadcast and I doubt whether anybody is going to read this—even his mother.

—She certainly will not. The truth of the matter is that the Government understands and knows what has to be done, but it does not have the guts to do it. It is more concerned about surviving for another wretched term than it is about embracing a goods and services tax, which we all know to be absolutely necessary.

para.tab: What is true is that an enormous number of goods now are subject to 20 per cent, 10 per cent and 30 per cent wholesale sales tax. We have radio and television receivers attracting a 30 per cent wholesale sales tax. We have toothpaste and tooth powders, safety razors, toilet dressing cases, hair brushes and combs attracting 20 per cent. We have flavoured milks, vegetable juices, biscuits and snack foods, ice-cream and confectionary—as has been said a thousand times—all presently attracting a 10 per cent sales tax. They will be abolished, at a cost of $10 billion to the revenue, for the benefit of all Australians.

In addition to that we will see the abolition of $5.8 billion in payroll tax, the abolition of $6.6 billion in excise on petroleum products, the abolition of $3.3 billion of customs duties, and the reduction in tax on exports by $1.7 billion. That is a dramatic amount of cuts. That is not to mention the training guarantee levy, the superannuation guarantee levy which will be frozen, and the depreciation allowances that will be changed. Capital gains tax will be changed. A whole range of other matters will be put in place to make it more efficient for business.

I was astounded today in Question Time to hear Senator Cook telling us how during the last decade of Labor, women's wages have gone up. That is if they can get a job. What Senator Cook should have done—and I am reminded of Senator Walters's claim and assertion after Question Time—was to divide the number of women looking for a job by the total wage available—the gross wage. He should divide one into the other and see what the real wage is. Of course, wages have gone down in real terms.

talk.start.para: —Oh!
—Senator Collins, Senator Collins. I was going to repeat myself but I will not.
—Well, you said `Senator Collins' twice.
—That gave me time to contemplate whether I was casting my pearls in the wrong direction.

para.tab: At a time that we have all these women unemployed, when there is 30 per cent youth unemployment and over one million Australians unemployed, the goods and services tax is intended to be a tax on consumption and not on income. Therefore it will be of great benefit to the manufacturing sector and to industry in Australia generally.

At the present time the wholesale sales tax advantages importers and disadvantages exporters. It is calculated and designed to cost the jobs of Australians. The goods and services tax is designed to do the opposite. It is designed to create jobs—to use that terrible expression—real and meaningful jobs, long term jobs. But that is something which this Government is prepared to jettison. That is something this Government is prepared to reject on the basis that it believes it can make a dash to the polls while lying about the truth of its implication and its application. I have always said that there is no price that this Government will not extract from the Australian people to stay in office. That is an enormous burden that it is imposing on people at the present time.
I think there are some articulate and persuasive members of the Opposition to speak after me so I will not go through the various details of the legislation.

talk.start.para: —I can't see any.
—Senator Collins, they are probably riveted to their television screens at this very moment.

para.tab: This legislation is typical of the Labor Party. There is scant regard for the truth, scant regard for knowledge and understanding, and scant regard for informing the Australian people. This is a Government that legislates by fiat. It issues press statements on the most complex and complicated and convoluted pieces of legislation and says that that is going to be it. It then passes it on to the Commissioner of Taxation. He makes his own interpretations and starts writing the laws and taxing people.

I see that the majority report signed by the Labor members of the Committee observed that given the process that the ATO and Treasury embarked on to simplify the wholesale sales tax was announced in the 1991 Budget, then it was of much concern to Committee members that so many issues of fundamental importance to the working of the wholesale sales tax remained unresolved at the time of the establishment of the select committee.

The select committee received 150 submissions from the public and, without going through all the details, it highlighted some major defects in the legislation. As a result of that, and contrary to my philosophic view about how we should deal with this wretched legislation of this wretched Government, this Government became informed of the problems. Therefore it made amendments to its own legislation, and to the extent that you can make bad legislation good, it made bad legislation slightly better.

While this process is going on we have the Prime Minister—struggling for a new issue to get himself on the front page and the economy off it—telling school children that we do not need a Senate, that we should not have a Senate. I seem to remember complaints about the unicameral system in Queensland and what that was alleged to have done to the Australian people. You would know better than most, Mr Acting Deputy President.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)
—Absolutely.

talk.start.para: —Can we tone down this mutual admiration society a bit?
—I acknowledge, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you are nodding very wisely at all the right moments. While you are in that nodding mood, I might just move on to a couple of other matters.

para.tab: A number of outstanding matters have been raised by the Committee members on this side, Senators Vanstone and Short. They refer particularly to the concern about the general anti-avoidance provisions. I have to say that, when one reads the original proposals in respect of those anti-avoidance provisions, they send a cold shiver down one's back. In particular, the Commissioner wants to determine the following matters in the following way.

The first is that particular things are to be treated as not having happened. This is Alice in Wonderland stuff. Was it the rabbit, or Alice? Secondly, particular things are to be treated as having been done by a different person or to have happened at a different time. Thirdly, particular things that did not actually happen are to be treated as having happened and taken to have happened at a particular time or to have been done by a particular person. That is a particularly complicated interpretation.

As a result of the highlighting of the abhorrence of that proposal, the anti-avoidance provisions were changed, except to say that there is no safe harbour to the extent that that is necessary. There is no encompassing provision that an act performed in the normal commercial form and way is to be assumed to be done for the right purposes and therefore will hold at law. The Commissioner has the power right now to say that something that is perfectly normal, perfectly commercial, perfectly legitimate, in his view was not even done. But to the extent that there has been modification, there has been some relief.

There are a number of other matters in respect of untaxed goods and small business exemptions. Tax rulings are another problem. We are now told that the thousands of rulings that the Commissioner has been giving over all these years are private rulings and have no general application. Because of the simplicity proposals, those rulings thus far were to be made null and void and new rulings were to apply in each individual and personal case. One can imagine the complications that that would put in train for people seeking to make judgments as to how to organise themselves in an orderly and proper way. We are told that there has been some modification to that provision, save that each ruling is still a private reading.

I shall not proceed past that point, other than to refer the problems that Caltex and, I think, Ampol have and the terrible mess the Government got itself into in seeking to deal with that. There are still problems. For instance, in this enlightened age when even the Government understands privatisation, if a government contracts out to private enterprise to build a road and a toll bridge, that will now attract a wholesale sales tax. But if they are built by a contractor for a government agency, that tax will not apply. I assume that in future years we will see more and more private constructions, both constructed and operated.

The problem with the tax treatment I have deemed to be the manufacturers as well. If my memory serves me correctly, at the present time under this proposal if a person buys a hamburger from Hungry Jack's he will be paying wholesale sales tax on the container. But if I am right again, if a person goes into Woolworths and buys its home brand already wrapped and contained, there is no wholesale sales tax on the container.

That is just a modest example of the nonsense that the Government, of which honourable senators opposite are members, is seeking to inflict upon the Australian community. There is no logic to it. There is no simple way of solving it because it is a ramshackle process. There is no justification for something being 20 per cent, something being 30 per cent and something else being 10 per cent. Why should toothpaste attract a sales tax of 20 per cent, but Australian fruit and vegetable juice attract a tax of 10 per cent? Why should garbage bins attract a sales tax of 10 per cent, but razors attract 20 per cent? Why should razors attract a sales tax of 20 per cent, but a watch and a clock attract 30 per cent?

I am sure that when the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) gets up, he will be able to explain the logic of that. He will go through the items and say, `Look, this is a sensible way of approaching it'. We will all be nodding furiously and saying, `Why didn't we realise that?'. Of course, it is so simple. Everybody understands that.

The truth of the matter is that it is a process that has been built on again and again. The rates have been struck for revenue, the items have been struck for revenue. If there is a sexy item that is going to attract plenty of revenue and generate high consumer demand, it will be put in the 30 per cent bracket. If it is an item that the affluent people are likely to buy, it will be stuck in there because it will probably raise more revenue—although I do not think toothpaste is restricted to the affluent in Australia!

There is no logic in the process. There is no logic in the system. The Government knows it. Paul Keating knew it in 1984 and 1985 when he introduced option C. Bob Hawke knew it in 1984 and 1985 when he proposed it himself. Despite Hawke's protestations about not wanting to be popular, and about wanting to do the right thing for Australia and for our kids, in the face of the ACTU saying that it would be unpopular, he capitulated. As he walked out the door capitulating, Paul Keating was still behind the door waving it on, saying that it was a good idea. I do not think he ever quite forgave him for his first little doublecross.

I do not support any of these proposals. I passionately support the goods and services tax and the whole Fightback package which the Australian community will be experiencing immediately after the next election.
(Quorum formed)

talk.start.para: —It is indeed a privilege to speak in this debate following Senator Crichton-Browne and that very precise and almost exquisitely intelligent speech that he made. It was a speech that shows how important it is to stay and listen.

para.tab: I start by noting for the record that the time is 1.56 a.m. and that we are here debating very important legislation at this hour in the morning because of yet another grubby deal between the Australian Democrats and this Government, a grubby deal that has us sitting here at all hours, with people getting very excited and almost emotional. I want to refer to comments made by Senator Kernot, who spoke just a couple of speakers back. She became very excited and very agitated at the beginning of her speech, and one cannot blame her, as she was trying to debate intelligently legislation at this hour of the morning.

We have been through this a number of times over many years. The last time we did this was when we were debating, as I recall, the broadcasting legislation, when the Democrats and the Government got together in an absolute perversity of democracy. We spoke all morning to try to prevent a Bill being passed. We told the Democrats time and time again that they should not join with the Government in putting this sort of perverse legislation through. They ignored us then. We spoke all night and, in the fullness of time, the High Court has done in relation to the broadcasting legislation what we predicted it would do. It has thrown the legislation out.

The Democrats never seem to learn. Again they come up with some deal: `Do something for us and we'll let the Senate go all night. We'll make the Parliament sit all night, as long as we get something'. This is the way this country is run—by deals, by little huddles outside, by grubby little arrangements and agreements simply to get this Government through the legislative program it has set itself; to get it through legislation which, as my colleagues have said in the many good and precise speeches before me, is flawed legislation. It is legislation that should not be allowed and, of course, should not be debated at this hour.

I can only say that it is no wonder that the Democrats are in such disarray and in such a turmoil over the attitudes they take. I can well understand why the Victorian membership of the Democrats is split asunder, why the New South Wales membership has all sorts of problems—fights against each other and police being called in to look at different things—and why in Queensland there are not even enough members to have official party starters.

I can only wonder as to what Senator Kernot's quite strange speech was all about. One of the reasons for the split, as quoted in the
Canberra Times
, was Senator Kernot's attempt to water down the Democrats' opposition to the GST. That was said by Darren Koch, who is the national economic policy convener of the Democrats. One wonders, after listening to Senator Kernot's speech, whether she or Mr Koch have any idea whatsoever about the GST or how it is likely to impact on Australia.

The other silly thing about the legislation that the Government is bringing forward for debate tonight is that the Government seems to be getting ready for what might happen, or what would happen, should the Australian public be ridiculous enough to return it to office. In the very unfortunate, and almost unbelievable, event that the Government is returned, one can be assured that this Government will bring in its own goods and services tax. However, in typical fashion, the Government will not tell anyone about it before the election; it will just bring it in afterwards. The Government will run to the election on one policy, and, come the first session after the election, it will bring in its own form of consumption tax. We know the Government will do that because it is Mr Keating's preferred way. It is the way that the advisers in Treasury want him to go.

With a $50 billion hole in the finances, there really is no other way that the Government can go to find the money it needs. There is a $50 billion hole in the finances that this Government will have available to it over the next two or three years. It is almost $14 billion this year—although those figures were fudged; it is much more than that. I think it is $11 billion next year, $9 billion the year after and $8 billion the year after that. But within four or five years, there will be a total of $50 billion unfunded. And where is the Government going to get it from? It will get it from its own GST—its secret tax, a tax that will be brought in without anyone being told about it.

We know that Mr Keating had this as his preferred option in 1985. It was the option he wanted; it is the one he knew had to be done, but he was frightened off by the ACTU and by those people in the Labor Party who thought that winning was the right thing to do, that it was far better to win than to do the right thing by Australia. Of course, one simply cannot trust anything Mr Keating says. He will go to this poll saying that there will be no GST and no consumption tax by his Government, in the unlikely event that it is returned. However, people should not believe anything he says. It was Mr Keating who said, `I think loyalty is the stuff of politics; political parties are built on loyalty'. They are the words of Mr Keating. If people believe that, they will believe that there is not going to be a consumption tax if this Government happens to be returned. Of course we do not believe him, and, certainly, Mr Hawke does not believe him, after that particular statement.

Mr Keating also said that it is not true to say that this is the worst recession in 60 years. How can we believe a man who says those sorts of things and then imposes upon us a planned recession which is the worst in 60 years? He said on 22 March 1990, `We will not let there be a recession'. It was just a few days before the last election, of course, but it was a firm and solemn promise: `We will not let there be a recession'. How can the one million officially unemployed or the two million real unemployed Australians possibly believe anything Mr Keating might say when he says that sort of thing? He also said on 19 August 1991, `I am not sitting here desperate to be Prime Minister'. How could anyone possibly believe him? Again, one should ask Mr Hawke about that.

He said on 21 March 1991, `The worst is now behind us; the Government has established its strategy'. He further said, `We won't destroy business activity; we won't destroy employment'. There are now officially almost one million people unemployed. As I said, it is more like two million, in real terms. He said in the 1988 Budget speech—Mr Acting Deputy President may well remember this—`We are well on the way to prosperity'. That was just four short years ago. But what have we had since then? We have had increasing unemployment, increasing bankruptcies and a foreign debt that has now become almost uncountable.

talk.start.para: —`Bringing home the bacon'.

—`Bringing home the bacon' is another of his statements. It has turned out to be true. A look at Brown and Hatton and the Danpork people shows what he means by `bringing home the bacon'. All it was about was saving his bacon rather than bringing home the bacon. When I think about Mr Keating, I can only agree with my colleague Senator Jim McKiernan, who said, `There are 900,000 reasons why Paul Keating should not be elected Prime Minister of Australia. The man who gave us the recession we had to have should not now be rewarded for his accomplishment'. I do not often agree with Senator McKiernan but in that instance I certainly have to.

para.tab: In spite of the protestations of my friends opposite, it is pretty obvious that, in the very unlikely event of this Government being returned, there will be a GST. Mr Keating has no answers. After 10 years he is still struggling in the wilderness trying to find answers. We have had 17 major economic statements in that time, each one supposedly to set Australia on the way—17 major economic statements and not one of them has worked. Between now and the next election there will be a continuing series of bribes, of promises—unfunded promises of the type that I have been quoting, quite crass promises—although Mr Keating knows full well that he does not believe those promises and he has no intention of abiding by them. He has no answers, no policy at all. His only resort, when he is challenged on any policy, on his failures, is to lapse into a tirade of abuse such as he has become famous for. This is the man who brought us `scumbag', `sleazebag' and `spew'; that is his level, that is all he can do when he is really challenged on economic matters.

The Bill before us is a package of six Bills which were forced through the lower house, the House of Representatives, in about 45 minutes. We knew even before then and since then even the Government has realised that the Bills are totally flawed. They are an absolute mess. They are a travesty of economic management. I think it is curious today that it is only because the Senate referred those matters to a committee and had the evidence coming in that the Government was able to see its own mistakes and to understand what an absolute mess and botch-up it was making of this legislation. It is curious that, in a day when we have to debate to save this Senate, have to save it from the attacks of this Prime Minister we have, it is the Senate that has saved this legislation for the Government. If this legislation had not been changed, we would have had in it the ridiculous proposal about sales tax on leases.

The original legislation as proposed would have removed tax exemptions for equipment leased by businesses for short periods. There was an enormous business response. Business argued that this proposal would hamper efficient commercial practice and give a competitive advantage to firms that could afford to take long term leases or buy equipment.

The Government backed down. But, had that legislation gone through, had it not been for the diligence of the Senate and that very efficient Senate committee, for the very first time local authorities would have been subject to a sales tax—local authorities which for many years prided themselves on the fact that they do not pay sales tax and they do not have taxes on taxes. For the first time, under this legislation, local authorities—city councils, shire councils—would have been subject to a sales tax through that leasing aspect.

talk.start.para: —They will be paying the GST.

—They will not be paying a GST, Senator Bolkus. That the honourable senator should make an interjection like that shows his absolute and intolerable ignorance of the Fightback package and the GST. For the first time this Labor Government was about to impose a sales tax on local authorities. As I say, it was only through the diligence of the Senate and its Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation, and particularly the coalition members of the Committee, that that was stopped.

para.tab: Inequities abound in the current sales tax regime. There are, as my colleagues have said, five separate rates: 0, 10, 15, 20 and 30 per cent. Why some should be at one level and some at another I do not really know. I know why the sales tax on some motor vehicles is 15 per cent: it was a desperate attempt by this Government to make ad hoc policy to try to stop the impetus of the Fightback package. When people realised what a tremendous relief our proposals would be, particularly in relation to motor vehicles, the Government succumbed, as it has done with the zone rebate allowance and the coal tax. It keeps pinching bits of our policy, not with any long term economic strategy in mind, but it is simply grabbing bits to try to stave off the tremendous ground swell of voter support that is coming our way.

As I said, there are these five quite ridiculous sales tax rates. As my colleagues have said before me, there are different indirect taxes that increase automatically so that no-one even knows what they are. These sales tax rates absolutely abound in anomalies, and I thank Senator Patterson and Senator Vanstone for listing earlier today quite a number of those and talking about the absolute stupidity of the current regime and how it works.

My colleagues earlier spoke about packets of cornflakes. I want to refer, very briefly, to the milk that is on the table. One hears Labor politicians going around saying that milk is free of sales tax. They are sort of half right when they talk about ordinary milk, but flavoured milk, for some unknown reason, is not free of sales tax: it has a tax of 10 per cent on it. There is that sort of stupidity in this regime that the Government continues to support.

In the Atherton Tableland area where I come from, the Malanda milk factory is a very efficient producer of milk. The milk is transported quite long distances from Malanda to Cairns and Innisfail, right down to Townsville and even out to Mount Isa. The distances involved are very long—500, 600 or 700 kilometres at a time—and the milk is taken by huge semitrailer tankers that get the milk from Malanda and take it to Townsville and Mount Isa. Those trucks would cost in the vicinity of $250,000. Under our policy—

talk.start.para: —How many horsepower?

—Five hundred horsepower, as it turns out. Under the coalition's policy, the retail price of $250,000, which includes a $38,000 sales tax component, would be only $212,000. If that figure is converted to a lease payment, the monthly payment comes down from $6,220—what it is under the present system of Mr Keating's Government—to $5,275, a saving of $945 per month or a saving per year of $11,340. Those same trucks then will have tyres free of sales tax that is now paid, they will have repairs and upkeep free of sales tax that is now paid, and the truck owners will be able to buy their fuel 26c a litre cheaper than they now do. The fuel alone will save them some $24,925 in a year.

para.tab: They will make savings from the abolition of sales tax on tyres in the vicinity of $1,675. The savings they will make from the abolition of sales tax on repairs and upkeep will be some $2,280 per annum—a total saving just on fuel, tyres and repairs of something like $20,880. If you add to that the saving in the lease payments, which I referred to before, of $11,340, one will have a saving of some $40,220 for that truck in just one year.

Those taxes currently impost on the ordinary milk that one currently pays for. Sure, there is no direct sales tax but that truck that carts the milk from Malanda to Townsville pays taxes in the year of something in the order of $40,000. That, of course, is added to the cost of the milk. So, whilst there is no direct cost on the milk, a very indirect sales tax is certainly imposed on that milk.

So it is quite ridiculous to say that there is no sales tax on flavoured milk. There is, of course, the direct sales tax on milk. There is a sales tax on milk through many indirect ways, one of which I have just given an example of as shown in the cost of that truck which carts the milk.

One other way that farmers are particularly burdened by the sales tax is an example that comes to mind in my area in the sugar country. One can buy a four-wheel drive vehicle sales tax free. In the Burdekin most farmers buy four-wheel drive vehicles because they are sales tax free. The job they want them to do does not really require a large four-wheel drive or any sort of four-wheel drive.

Most farmers just need a little utility so they can throw the shovel in the back and go down to open up the drains somewhere to look after the irrigation water. That does not need an expensive four-wheel drive but farmers buy them because they are sales tax free. All they need is a little two-wheel drive utility that will get them down and back quite easily and would be much cheaper.

But they do not buy such a vehicle because of false economy. If they buy those little two-wheel drive trucks they have to pay sales tax on them. So they do not buy that cheaper vehicle which is all they need. They go for the more expensive vehicle through false economy because they do not have to pay sales tax. That is the sort of distortion that this ridiculous regime—the Government is trying to amend the legislation by fiddling around the edges of it at the moment—supports.

We do not need to try to amend, fiddle with, improve or deal with this current legislation. We need to abolish it completely. Of course, that is what the coalition will do after the next election. As I said, we will abolish sales tax and replace it with a fair across-the-board GST.

It will not be as the Labor members quite improperly and dishonestly go around the countryside saying. And that dishonesty was repeated by Senator Crowley tonight when she talked about women's products. She said it will be 15 per cent on top of what it is now. Every Labor member dishonestly goes around Australia saying the same thing—that everything will be 15 per cent dearer than it is now. We know that is not true. Labor members know that is not true but they persist in telling those untruths for pure and sheer political purposes—

talk.start.para: —You would call it a tiddy hopper, wouldn't you?

—Exactly. So it will not be 15 per cent. Even in the example Senator Crowley was talking about, just to name one thing, the company that makes those articles would for certain pay payroll tax. With the abolition of payroll tax and nothing else—forget about anything else—the cost of producing those articles would be so much cheaper. So it will not be, as Senator Crowley tried to tell us tonight, 15 per cent on top of the existing cost. It will certainly be 15 per cent but it will be on base costs which are less than they are at the present time.

para.tab: As I say, we will be introducing this fair across-the-board GST. It will increase the cost of living by an amount, but that is no big surprise. When we say, `Yes, we acknowledge it will increase costs by something', there are some Labor members who say, `We have got you. Here it is. What a surprise!'. But it is not a surprise. Right from the first day of Fightback, we said fairly and openly—because that is how we are doing it these days; we are telling it fairly and openly as it is—that there will an increase in the cost of living. But it will not be 15 per cent. On our figures—and we calculated them very conservatively—it will lead to a cost increase of about 4.4 per cent.

Quite naturally, the Government did not believe us. It thought we were fudging the figures, so it got its own Treasury to go and check our figures. What did Treasury come back with? It said we were wrong all right, but we were too high. It said the figure was not 4.4 per cent but 3.6 per cent; that is all it would be. Whether it is 3.6 per cent or 4.4 per cent, I do not suppose it really matters. It is about 4 per cent and we acknowledge that.

What we have then done is to set out to compensate the public, and more than compensate them, for that increase in the cost of living. In the case of pensioners, whose costs of living will go up by about 4 per cent in the year, we have increased their pensions by 8 per cent to cover a 4 per cent cost of living increase. So they are going to be compensated for the 4 per cent and they are going to get a bonus of 4 per cent on top of that. In the case of someone on $20,000 with three children and driving a family motor vehicle, we have said, `Your tax will fall by $15.60 per week'. That is a 4.8 per cent after-tax increase to cover the 4 per cent increase in the cost of living. So there is a 4.8 per cent compensation to cover the 4 per cent cost of living increase.

But that is not all. For the family with three children, in addition to that $15.60 per week—which means, I repeat, a 4.8 per cent compensation to cover the 4 per cent cost of living increase—we will give $30 a week extra for family allowance. So that is $15.60 a week tax saving plus $30 a week family allowance. And every time the family fills the car with fuel, it will save something like $10, $11, $12 or $13.
For someone on $30,000 per annum, we have given a tax cut of $30.40 per week, which is 6.8 per cent after tax—

Senator McMullan interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Again, to cover the 4 per cent cost of living increase. So that is not too bad, Senator McMullan, is it? It costs you 4 per cent more to live and you would get a tax reduction of 6.8 per cent. And, if a taxpayer has three children, because he or she is in that higher tax bracket, instead of getting $30 a week it will be only $15 a week. That is how we look after those people. It is not the case that the richer people are, the more they get, because we have cut back the family allowance. They will, of course, make the same savings on the tank of fuel. A person on $50,000 gets a saving of $82.60 a week but family allowance is cut almost to nothing, and he still saves on the petrol. Those are just some examples of the sorts of compensations that will be made under our policies.

para.tab: I do not need to say anything more. I am sure those fair-minded and impartial people who will read or have listened to this quite exciting debate will very easily be convinced of the worthiness of our policies and of the complete ridiculousness of the legislation that the Government is trying to fiddle with in these amendment Bills.

I, with my colleagues, oppose the amendments proposed and urge the Australian Democrats to join us in getting rid of this WST legislation and bringing in the economic package that Australia needs.
(Quorum formed)

speech.speaker: Walters Sen M.S.

talk.start.para: —The Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992 and associated Bills before the Senate tonight just represent a continuation of the Prime Minister's decision to increase the total sales tax revenue for the Government. By the time the Prime Minister finishes he will have a very good consumption tax. Indeed, it is already his GST, well on the way. We are all aware of the hidden tax and sales tax throughout the term of this Government. When the coalition left government the revenue from sales tax was $3.5 billion. The estimate for this financial year is $9.5 billion, an increase of 170.5 per cent. All this, an increase of 170 per cent, and there is not one cent compensation for pensioners, the unemployed, the disadvantaged groups and the self-funded retirees. Because it is a tax by stealth, no-one knows they are paying it, so the Prime Minister has not been forced to compensate those disadvantaged groups as a result of the increase.

para.tab: We have 33 per cent of supermarket commodities with wholesale sales tax on them directly: things like washing powder—which everyone uses whether they are the unemployed, pensioners or other people—washing-up liquid, soap, toothpaste, toilet rolls, pet food and so on. A considerable number of the items bought at supermarkets have a 20 per cent sales tax. Some have 10 per cent. Flavoured milk has sales tax, as opposed to ordinary milk which does not. Because nobody knows they are paying it, the Government has been able, over the years, to increase this revenue take from sales tax and has not seen it necessary to compensate the low income groups.

We have been told by Mr Duncan Kerr in the other place and by Mr Gear that this has been the increase by the supermarkets. We all remember that particular Labor price watch committee. It used to go around, or it still does go around the States, abusing manufacturers and supermarket owners for the increases, but it never once mentioned that those increases were indeed increases by the Government in the form of sales tax.

We have got to realise with this wholesale sales tax that it is not a tax on the end commodity; it is an earlier tax on the wholesale value. Of course, when the retail supermarket owner buys the commodity from the wholesaler he puts his mark-up on top of the wholesale sales tax. The increase to the buyer is considerably increased.

As I said, when Mr George Gear, as chairman of that national price watch network, and Mr Duncan Kerr came to Tasmania they had a meeting in the town hall. Mr Gear and Mr Duncan Kerr started abusing the supermarkets. They berated them for the large increases. Mr Kerr was quoted as saying that the escalating cost of basic grocery items was an increased burden on families and it was important that the ordinary members of the public and interested groups had a say in developing ways of curbing the trend of the increases. There was concern about the rising prices and increases and not a day passed without people ringing him and Mr Gear on the matter. But on not one occasion did either Duncan Kerr or Mr Gear point out that the wholesale sales tax put on by their Government was the main cause of the problem of this increase.

As has already been stated by many of my colleagues in this place, the wholesale sales tax is in three different ratings: 10 per cent, 20 per cent and 30 per cent. How many families are aware that they are paying a 20 per cent sales tax on washing powder; a 20 per cent sales tax on articles such as watches, clocks, cameras, films and slide projectors? There is a 20 per cent sales tax on beer and wine and, of course, there is excise duty on top of that.

Every time a woman puts on lipstick she pays an additional 20 per cent to the Government. Every time a wheelbarrow or a garden fork is bought people pay 20 per cent tax. When people buy blankets they pay 10 per cent to the Government. If they buy a tea-towel they pay 10 per cent to the Government. Every time they buy a packet of chips the Government grabs back 10 per cent. Every time they buy a cup or a saucer or a glass, again it is 10 per cent. Every time people strike matches it is 10 per cent. They pay 10 per cent on all soft goods such as curtaining, brooms, buckets, rubbish bins, fridges, heaters, stoves, kettles, vacuum cleaners, washing machines, sewing machines and knitting machines. Buy a new house and try to furnish it and the amount of wholesale sales tax one will pay is unbelievable.

In 1987 Mr Keating took on a new direction; in line with his very firm belief in a consumption tax he decided for the first time he would impose sales tax on services. We now have sales tax on Australia Post and Telecom to name just two—an additional $320m given to government revenue. We have heard so often from the Government that the wholesale sales tax is just a small percentage of the tax paid. That is not so. Indeed, it is becoming the Government's consumption tax.

We can all remember that Mr Keating supported a consumption tax. I would like to read from the Government's own document,
A Guide to Tax Reform
. Let me read a few of the things he said:

speech.para: A broadly based consumption tax set at a higher rate of, say, 12 1/2 per cent—
that was the percentage that Mr Keating chose in 1985 when he was pushing a consumption tax. Honourable senators will remember that consumption tax. It was his Option C; it was the favoured option—
would—
. provide much larger income tax cuts.

. reduce marginal tax rates substantially at
all
income levels. (The marginal rate of tax is how much tax you pay on each EXTRA dollar you earn.)
. increase the tax take from people who continue to avoid or evade income tax.
. provide enough revenue to enable a more generous net benefit for wage and salary earners and a more substantial increase in social security payments.
. enable the existing wholesale tax to be abolished altogether.
We all remember that. We all remember how very keen he was on his preferred option. He said:

The Government's preferred option would mean a switch in the tax system, with more tax paid at the time income is spent, but less tax paid at the time income is earned. But because this will reduce the level of tax avoidance and evasion, and because many of the ways income tax is avoided will be directly removed by new laws, there will be bigger cuts in income tax than increases in consumption tax.
He said:
Social Security, Veterans Affairs and Education pensions and benefits will be increased to at least compensate, and often more than compensate, for the increase in the cost of living.
He went on to say that the end result would be:
. a fairer tax system with fewer tax avoiders and evaders
. lower income taxes, so that the reward for extra effort is greater—for example for people who work overtime
. an effective cut in total taxes for most wage and salary earners, and a larger increase in pensions and benefits than is needed to compensate for the consumption tax
He went on:
. a more efficient tax system which doesn't discriminate so heavily against different products and
different types of investment. That will help promote economic growth
. simpler tax returns for most wage earners.
We agree wholeheartedly with him in what he was trying to put forward. We did not go for the 12 1/2 per cent, but we agree with his GST.

para.tab: Let me explain just what we are doing. We are going to abolish seven taxes. Perhaps one of the most important is the wholesale sales tax. As Mr Keating said, abolish it and it will be a fairer tax. There will not be those distortions that he was referring to. So we will abolish seven taxes and replace them with a GST. Those seven taxes are: the wholesale sales tax; petrol tax; payroll tax; lump sum superannuation tax; the training guarantee levy; the customs duty levy; and the coal export duty.

We have also said that we will freeze the superannuation levy at whatever it is when we get in, because that is just an additional tax that this Government has recently decided to put on business. We said that we would abolish those taxes and replace them with a GST. This will increase the cost of living, we said, by 4.4 per cent.

Treasury—and do not let us forget that the Government, attempting to find a loophole in our figures, went over our goods and services tax and the whole of the Fightback package very thoroughly—came up with, not a 4.4 per cent one-off cost of living increase, as we said there would be, but 3.6 per cent. But whatever it is, we are happy to stick by the 4.4 per cent, because we have been very conservative in our estimates of the cost. What we are doing in return to compensate for that 4.4 per cent is of considerable benefit to Australians generally. They will be more than compensated for that 4.4 per cent. There will be lower taxes. Indeed, someone on $25,000 will be saving $1,185—a 25.2 per cent decrease in tax.

There will be a doubling of the family allowance for those families under $30,000, and an increase in the dependent spouse rebate of $300. For the first time, there will be no tax on new savings. Young people will be able to save and it will be worth their while. There will be an incentive to save, so we will be able to afford some of our own expenditure in Australia and not have to borrow outside to finance it.

We will retain and improve Medicare, with subsidies for pensioners and low-income earners who want to insure privately but who will not be forced to insure privately. Pensions will be increased by 8 per cent—not 4.4 per cent, which will be the increase in the cost of living. All beneficiaries will receive their benefits with a 6 per cent increase. There will be a pharmaceutical benefits concession card for all those over 65 years who have an income under $50,000.

All business costs will be free of the goods and services tax. Businesses will not have to pay the goods and services tax that they do at the moment with the wholesale sales tax. All our exports will be free of the goods and services tax. There will be no GST on our exports. The wholesale sales tax is a great burden for our present exports; it makes it very difficult for them to compete with overseas prices. There will be no GST on education, health or local government rates.

As I said, the individuals to whom we have been expounding our goods and services tax and the whole of the Fightback package love it. We heard from some of the Government members, and indeed from the Australian Democrats earlier this evening, that small business will have a lot of paperwork to do. All I can tell them is that small business owners have welcomed it with open arms. They have been particularly keen on the goods and services tax because they recognise that, once those other taxes are taken off their backs, they will at least be able to compete and be able to export.

We have been told by Government members that there is no wholesale sales tax, no payroll tax on food. We have been told that there is a little bit on, say, flavoured milk and biscuits, but that food generally, things like butter, has no wholesale sales tax on it and no payroll tax because supermarkets do not pay payroll tax. Mr Keating and every Labor member who says that are totally wrong. Every product on every shelf in every shop in Australia has its price increased at every stage of its production because of Labor's hidden indirect consumption taxes.

I would like to give an example of what occurs with butter, because back in Hobart I had Mr Duncan Kerr tell me during one of our debates that there was no wholesale sales tax on butter and no payroll tax in a supermarket selling that butter. Let us go back to the dairy farmer who sells his butterfat to the manufacturer. The amount of payroll tax, training levy, fuel excise and wholesale sales tax that the farmer pays is unbelievable. For instance, the freight involved in getting the fertiliser from the source to the farm gate is enormous, and under the coalition government the cost of the fuel alone will be 26c a litre cheaper. The wholesale sales tax will not be on the vehicles, on the tyres, on the spare parts, on the oil, et cetera. From the freight paid in getting the various items that the dairy farmer requires onto his property, the payroll tax, training levy, fuel excise and wholesale sales tax will be removed. None of the items that the farmer uses in production will bear those costs. I will stick to fertiliser for just a moment longer. The EZ Company in Hobart already pays $3.4m payroll tax. When that goes, when the freight goes and when the wholesale tax goes on that particular company, then it will be able to sell its fertiliser cheaper and so the farmer will get his fertiliser at a cheaper rate.

Then the dairy farmer sells his butterfat to the milk processor. The carrier takes the butterfat to the milk processor or to the butter factory. That carrier now pays 26c a litre less for the fuel. The motor vehicle will not have wholesale sales tax on it, nor will the vehicle parts. The fuel and oil and lubricants, the cleaning materials and the solvents, the office equipment and supplies, the accountant and all the professional costs, the postage and the telephone, the local council rates—all of those will be free of goods and services tax. Under the present system they carry payroll tax, the training levy, fuel excise and wholesale sales tax. So the transport of the butterfat to the butter factory will be so much cheaper. The butter factory will not be paying the payroll tax under our system, it will not be paying wholesale sales tax, and it will not be paying the training levy or the fuel excise, so the butter will be produced so much more cheaply at the butter factory.

It is then carried once again to the wholesaler, and again we have the reduction in freight costs. We then have the food wholesaler, who again will not be paying payroll tax, and who again will not be paying wholesale sales tax or fuel excise or the training levy. So we come once again to the carrier to bring it to the supermarket, and so the chain goes on. To say there is no wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, training levy or fuel excise on butter is untrue. It is on every single stage in the production of that butter.

Madam Acting President, the legislation before the Senate tonight has been a complete disaster. The Bills were forced through the House of Representatives and were sent off to a Senate committee. There, after many hours, the Government brought in about 45 amendments of their own. They realised what a dreadful mess they had made of it, and they initiated all these amendments of their own. We have amendments, and no doubt the Democrats have amendments. I believe the present legislation is in such a mess that we need more time to debate this Bill. We have not seen all the amendments that the Government has brought in. The committee stage of this Bill is going to be very long and extensive.

At the end of last week the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said that the Senate should be abolished. Yet if honourable senators follow the pushing through of this sales tax legislation through the House of Representatives, they will realise that if it had not come to a Senate committee, if we had not been able to point out the anomalies in it and the disastrous mess the Government has made of it, then the legislation would eventually have gone back to the House of Representatives for a complete redrafting.

As it is, we have sent it off to a committee and all these anomalies have been pointed out. We are now about to enter the committee stage and it is going to be a long and extensive debate. I believe that in this democracy we need to make sure that people have a firm understanding of what sort of legislation this Government is bringing through for them. We need the detail of every one of those amendments that the Government now wishes to put before the Senate.
(Quorum formed)

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —I think everyone accepts the fact that the whole system of sales tax legislation is an incredible mess. I have not heard anyone on the Government side defend the present sales tax system. In fact, the legislation we have before us tonight is an incompetent and disastrous attempt to correct the chaotic mess that is sales tax.

para.tab: The attempts to fix this mess started back in the August Budget of 1990. That is when it was announced that they would try to fix this mess, a mess which has resulted in many honest business people in Australia being stood over and blackmailed by various elements—acting without authority I hope—in the Tax Office. This involves deals which are essentially disgraceful and which are forcing small businesses in many instances to come to settlements with the Tax Office because the cost of contesting Tax Office determinations about areas of sales tax which are open to dispute is intolerably high.

If the submissions made on many occasions to my office by small business people are correct, the behaviour of some tax officers in this respect has been appalling. Within the framework of the sales tax legislation, there is apparently the capacity for inspectors to come and say to a small printer, `The wrong sales tax rate has been charged on these individual jobs'. This is because the sales tax system is so confusing and ludicrous. It is such a bad tax that there is enormous scope for disagreement about what sales tax should be applied in specific instances.

One printer might face the problem of deciding which of three sales tax rates he or she should apply. If the tax inspector disagrees with the interpretation taken by the printer at the time, there is a scenario that develops which I will outline, from examples of things that have actually happened in my area of Wollongong to people who come to tell me about them. The inspector comes and, after looking at the books, says, `You have wrongly charged these particular items, you owe us $20,000'. The little printer says, `I don't think I have. I think I have charged the right one and, in any event, if you hit me with a $20,000 bill I cannot pay I will go out of business. I will go broke'. The situation then is that the little printer says, `I will just have to fight you. I will appeal. I will do whatever I can'. It is pointed out to him that his prospects of winning may well not be great and that an appeal will cost him a lot of money. In fact, if he spends all that money in fighting these sorts of matters, that cost could ultimately end up being added to his losses if he does not win the case.

The man from the Tax Office leaves him to think about it. A little while later the tax people come back to him and say, `What are you going to do?'. He says, `I cannot pay. I will have to fight to try to stay alive, even though I cannot afford it'. Then the tax people offer him an opportunity and say, `If you pay the Tax Office $10,000, we will say that is it and everything is all right'. In other words, the little printer has the opportunity of settling, even though he claims he has not made a mistake, that he has not undercharged, and that he has not defrauded the Tax Office. He then has the opportunity of paying 10 grand and being saved from the prospect of being sent broke. Maybe that is commercial reality, maybe that is the way things should go. There are others who see it as an uncomplicated sort of standover device, whereby the people who are right, in their view, are simply terrorised out of defending their rights because of the enormous costs of doing so.

A tax system that allows or even encourages that kind of thing is simply not acceptable. There appears to be some recognition in lots of other areas that this tax system is unacceptable. We have had—and we are supposed to be debating it—a simplification review that was first announced in August 1990 and on which so much work apparently was done that it was only on 2 April this year that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) announced, in a press release, the results of that review. By 26 May 1992, almost two years after the initial announcement, the results of this enormous gestation were produced. It was a very sickly child: it was so sick that it had to have almost all its limbs amputated and replaced.

The legislation having been guillotined through the House of Representatives with minimal debate, minimal examination and minimal understanding by the Government of what it really meant, we then had a Senate committee appointed. In August this year, the day before that Committee was to meet, as I recall, to have public hearings, major changes to this enormous review were made. Obviously, that Committee did not have a proper opportunity to examine those changes—changes which were made to what was supposed to be a massive review, an enormous correction, of some lousy legislation.

It intrigues me that, after almost two years, the geniuses working on this major review were unaware of the consequences of their actions. This Government obviously had not been sufficiently concerned to find out what the real world was like in the area of sales tax. I am very disappointed to note that in the Tax Office itself there was so little understanding in so many areas of the consequences of the legislation—presumably unintended consequences, because they have all been changed—that last minute, major surgery was done.

I have here a letter from the Australian Ballet to the secretary of the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation, pointing out something that surely the creators of the legislation must have known, if they were competent—or that the Minister should have gone out of his way to find out, if he was competent. I read from this submission:

speech.para: The Australian Ballet is very concerned at the Government's proposals to introduce amendments to sales tax legislation which would have the effect of imposing sales tax on stage properties manufactured for our own use.
That was an attempt by the Tax Office to reverse decisions made in court cases relating to sales tax. It goes on:

The Government currently provides The Australian Ballet with an annual grant of $2,805,000 but this represents only 19% of our total income against our total expenditure commitments of $15,326,000 for 1992.
Our costs of manufacturing stage properties this year for our own use are estimated to be $854,000.
If sales tax legislation were amended to force The Australian Ballet to pay sales tax on stage properties we manufacture for our own use
—that is what the Government was planning to do—
it will add $170,800 to our costs when we have no way of recovering it from our government grant or box office.

The Prime Minister has indicated his support for the performing arts in proclaiming to the world our cultural excellence. There is no better example than The Australian Ballet which is internationally acclaimed and recognised as a world-class company.

The Government should be increasing its financial support for the arts not introducing legislation which adds to the taxation burden already being borne by The Australian Ballet and other arts organisations throughout the nation.

This legislation was to be the Government's special gift to the arts until someone—long after it had come into the Parliament, and on the night before public hearings were to be held—discovered, `Oh dear, maybe that is not a good idea'. Frankly, I find it difficult to accept that two years of hard work can result in this sort of rubbish, which has been wiped out. It had no merit and should not even have got to first base, let alone into this Parliament.

para.tab: I mention in passing that the Australian Ballet is one of those organisations benefiting from the fact that this Opposition objected strongly to this legislation. The Australian Ballet is also one of those organisations which will benefit dramatically from the removal of sales tax and other taxes under the Fightback package. We will remove payroll tax which costs the Australian Ballet just under $500,000 a year. Under the Fightback package not only is the Australian Ballet saved from the legislation that did not come good—

talk.start.para: —Does it worry you that all those facts you have just quoted are wrong?
—If the Australian Ballet people are totally wrong, then I am very surprised. I would be grateful to hear the facts from the Minister and he can correct—
—It would make a change in this debate.

—It is normally reasonable for senators when they have a submission of this nature to the Select Committee itself to regard it as being of some substance. I think it is quite proper of me to regard it as having some substance. I was certainly under the impression that the proposed legislation reversed the court decisions. I remind the Minister that the Tax Office at one stage tried with some enthusiasm to charge sales tax on stage properties and the Minister may like to deny that. After all, it only went to court.

para.tab: As I was saying, under Fightback the Australian Ballet will be saved just under $500,000 in payroll tax, which is one of the seven taxes to be wiped out when the Fightback package is introduced. The Minister is saying that the Tax Office was not going to try once again to tax the Australian Ballet as it had endeavoured to tax the Nimrod Theatre. That was the case that the Tax Office lost in this matter. Having failed then, I do not know in view of what the Minister said whether among the myriad of amendments made there were further changes to the situation relating to the arts. But what I do know is that an enormous volume of basic changes were made to the sales tax legislation.
It is because those major changes did not provide the Committee with an adequate opportunity to examine the consequences of those major changes that I move:

speech.para: Omit all words after `That', substitute:
(a), the bills, together with the circulated amendments, be referred to the Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation, for examination and report by 6 October 1992; and

(b) that Committee be established with the composition and powers provided by paragraphs (2) to (9) inclusive, of the order of the Senate of 25 June 1992 and with the membership appointed on that day.

para.tab: Having dealt with the problems relating to the arts, I now want to deal with the dishonest campaign of disinformation about tax on sport which is being spread by this Government. Improperly using sport as a political weapon is bad enough, but really, when it is done like this, one really has to wonder about the level of people's real commitment to sport when they misuse it for political purposes.

The Keating Government's campaign against the coalition's Fightback package has certainly hit new lows, with false claims in an official ministerial document being circulated, I might say, by members of this chamber on the Government side who have no excuse for not knowing the facts and no excuse for not knowing that what they are sending out is false, untrue and disgraceful and uses sport blatantly for political purposes.

The facts, of course, are not very comfortable for many people in the Labor Party. We have pamphlets going out—prepared, I might say, from the office of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly)—claiming that it will be compulsory for all organisations turning over more than $30,000 per annum to register. Of course, we know that that is not true; it is $50,000, and was increased some months ago. It also says that returns must be submitted regularly—usually six per year for sporting clubs. For heaven's sake, the great bulk of sporting clubs would not have turnovers of over $250,000. Most of them would not have turnovers of over $50,000. If their turnovers, under the proposed GST, are above $50,000 and below $250,000, they have to put in only two a year.

That sort of straight dishonesty is what one, I suppose, would expect from a government in such disarray. In any event, the key point is that the GST removes this whole structure—a disgraceful and incompetent structure—of sales tax which is volumes in length. It is a huge set. I think there are something like 27 Acts relating to sales tax which are reviewed in these six Bills. The GST gets rid of that whole structure, that whole mess, which this Government has just demonstrated that it is too incompetent to fix up properly, anyway.

It has been interesting to see the nature of the attack on Fightback as it affects sport. Of course, apart from the fact that the GST gets rid of sales tax, which seriously hits sport at the moment, I will just mention in passing some of those things that the Government's document sent to sporting clubs carefully avoids. The facts are that the Government charges heavy taxes on sport. For example, it imposes 20 per cent sales tax on sports programs, on soaps, on detergents, on antiseptics, on Dencorub, on sponges, on buckets, on toilet paper, on writing and wrapping paper, on mowers and on tractors. Of course, there is a 10 per cent sales tax on soft drinks, fruit juices, ice-creams, snack foods, medallions—and even trophies awarded for sport.

What will happen is that, contrary to the Government's totally dishonest claim that very few sporting organisations will benefit from the taxes to be removed by the Opposition in the Fightback package, wiping out these seven taxes will considerably reduce the cost of running sporting organisations. Apart from the fact that under Fightback the present 20 per cent sales tax on sporting goods—which costs sports people $240m a year but is not mentioned in the Government's statement about how terrible GST is going to be for sport; we could not expect a bit of honesty from the Government—

talk.start.para: —Are there any of those things that you won't tax? Not one.

—That is a very interesting comment. I am talking about honesty, which must be a new concept to the honourable senator. We are saying exactly what we will do. There will be 15 per cent on everything. That does not mean on top of present prices, because 15 per cent on many items will be less than the 20 per cent that is charged now. The Minister, in his role and with his special responsibilities, should know that. There is $240m paid by sporting people in sales tax but the Government, in its little document about GST, does not have the basic honesty to mention that such taxes will go. Honourable senators who, with a straight face, send out that document should be ashamed of themselves.

para.tab: There is further dishonesty in the Government's statement because sporting clubs, which are in clearly in the `business' of providing a service, can have their GST inputs—the GST taxes they do pay—refunded. Senator McMullan says that it must be stated that they pay them. Of course they do, but sporting clubs get them refunded. There is no net cost to a sporting club as there is under this Government's sales tax of 20 per cent. The honourable senator lacks, I believe, a basic preparedness—I do not know whether he has sent it out but I hope for his integrity's sake that he has not, because, if he has failed to tell the facts that he knows about this when he has sent that out, he stands condemned for doing something that is less than honest.
