We hear from the Government, on this score, that sporting clubs will be seriously affected by taxes on sponsorships and so on. Yet every honourable senator would know that the GST on the sponsorship is totally refundable. Under the GST there is no net cost on sponsorship.

talk.start.para: —Is that all sporting clubs or are there certain limits?

—A sporting club is in the business of providing a service. It gets a sponsorship from a corporation or a business. The corporation which sponsors it, clearly, is paying for a `service'. That GST paid by the sponsoring organisation is a taxed input, for which it receives full refund. Business inputs are totally refundable. Everyone in this chamber would know that. The Government is recklessly indifferent to the facts and sends out dishonest propaganda. I suppose it can live with that; it has been living with that kind of thing for some time. But this is the nature of the basic dishonesty of the Government's approach.

para.tab: For example, sporting clubs buying advertising space will have whatever GST they pay fully refunded. If they sell advertising or media or catering rights, or accept sponsorships, there will be no net cost difference. All the GST they are charged will be totally refunded to the buyer or sponsor, so sponsorships will not be adversely affected by the GST. Donations are free of GST and government grants are free of GST. On top of all this sort of thing, the cut of 26c per litre in fuel prices to sporting clubs and transport companies will mean a major reduction in the costs of attending competition for clubs, members and spectators. Any GST on accommodation or transport paid for by clubs will be totally refundable to the club. Yet we keep on hearing this dishonest rubbish from the Government about the disastrous effect on sport.

There is no doubt that, as a result of Fightback, sporting clubs will be much cheaper to run, because all these sales taxes will be removed, while all GST paid by clubs will be totally refunded and grants and donations to the clubs will be free of GST. While some things will clearly be cheaper, such as running a sporting club and transport to games, some things will be dearer, such as memberships and spectators' fees. We have got to accept that. But overall, if there is any increase in the cost of participation in or watching sport, it will be more than compensated for by the 30 per cent cut in Australians' income taxes and the accompanying 8 per cent rise in pensions, which is one of the main purposes for introducing the GST. Sport will clearly prosper under a Hewson government, particularly as the generation of two million or so extra jobs under Fightback will provide significantly increased opportunities for those Australians who are presently too hobbled by unemployment and the recession to participate in the sport of their choice.

Getting rid of sales tax would do Australia the world of good. Getting rid of this messy legislation, amended at the last minute, would do Australia the world of good.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I wish to support very strongly the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Baume. It is an amendment to the second reading motion, namely:

speech.para: Omit all words after `That', substitute:
(a) the bills, together with the circulated amendments, be referred to the Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation, for examination and report by 6 October 1992;

(b) that Committee be established with the composition and powers provided by paragraphs (2) to (9), inclusive, of the order of the Senate of 25 June 1992 and with the membership appointed on that day.

The Senate Select Committee was established by the Senate on 25 June to examine the Bills. The coalition is moving that because of their significant nature, the amendments that have been circulated, as well as the Bills, be considered in the Committee; because that has not been able to be done up to date.

para.tab: The Senate may recall the history of this matter over the last few months. The Government, after an almost two-year review of the sales tax legislation, produced in April a so-called simplification of the existing sales tax regime. It was said that this simplification exercise and the results of it represented the most significant change in sales tax legislation since sales tax was first introduced in 1930.

Because of the alleged significance of those changes, given that the Bills had in the dying days of the autumn sittings been guillotined in the most brutal fashion through the House of Representatives without any consideration, without any substantive debate, this Senate in its wisdom decided to create a Senate select committee to examine the Bills.

That Select Committee was given an impossibly tight timetable in which to do its work. It was established at the end of June with a requirement that it report back to the Senate on the second day of the Budget sittings, 19 August. Senators Vanstone and I represented the coalition on that Committee, there were three Government senators and there was Senator Kernot.

We received no less than 150 submissions expressing concern about all or parts of that legislation. We were scheduled to meet in public hearings on 12 and 13 August to hear at least some of those 150 submissions—a minuscule proportion of them, I must say. Because of that impossibly tight timetable, many of those submissions were incapable of being given any hearing at all by the Select Committee. Nevertheless, we were prepared to go ahead.

At 6.00 p.m. on the night of 11 August, the night before the Committee was due to have its public hearings on the submissions we had received, which, of course, were based on the Bills as presented in the Senate, the Treasurer put out a very skinny three-page press release in which he announced that the Government had decided to make several changes to the proposed sales tax Bills.

Those several changes amounted, in fact, to a whole raft of proposals to amend six key areas of the Government's sales tax proposals. These were key areas that the Government said were essential to effect a proper simplification. But so hasty were these amendments and these proposals that the Government did not have any amendments available to the Committee to consider when it was taking its hearings on the following two days and preparing its report in the three or four days after that.

So what the Government in fact did was take two years to do a so-called simplification exercise, bring it into the Parliament in May and jackboot it, with the use of the guillotine, through the House of Representatives. It attempted to do the same here in the Senate. Fortunately, the Democrats supported the coalition on the establishment of the Select Committee to which I have referred. Then, with all that work having been done ostensibly by the Tax Office, two years' solid consideration, so we were told, the Government, out of the blue, on the night before the Select Committee was due to take its hearings, announced major changes to no less than six key areas of its own proposals, but without one word of drafted amendment to show the Committee.

During the Committee hearings on the ensuing two days officers of the Australian Taxation Office were mightily embarrassed by the situation that they were placed in. It was a deliberate and blatant political ploy by the Government, and I dissociate the Tax Office officers from involvement in this ploy; they were the pawns in the game. It was a deliberate political ploy by the Government to completely undermine the work of the Senate Select Committee and, in effect, undermine the work that the Tax Office had done in the preceding two years.

The effect of the Treasurer's announcement was to throw the work of the Select Committee into total confusion. We did the best that we could and, in the circumstance, I would have to say, we did a pretty good job. But it was a job that was impossible to be done properly because the Government did not have available for the Committee the necessary drafting of the amendments that had been foreshadowed in the Treasurer's belated, last minute press release. As a result of all of that, the Committee produced a report which is less than fully adequate. It was always going to be inadequate because of the impossible time pressure that was put on it by the Government—with, I must say, regrettably, the conniving agreement of the Democrats.

It was always going to be a less than fully adequate job. This absolutely guaranteed that it would be an inadequate job. As a result, the Senate is now being asked by the Government to debate and pass a package of legislation which is totally different from the legislation that it introduced into this place. It has totally emasculated the work that, it said, was essential to achieve the simplification of the sales tax system that it claimed was so essential.

We all know that the wholesale sales tax regime in this country is archaic, anomaly ridden, inefficient and unfair. We on this side say that there is no way, with a wholesale sales tax system, that we can ever correct those problems. The only way that we can get a fair, equitable and efficient indirect tax regime is to introduce a tax of the nature of the goods and services tax that the coalition is proposing. That is why it is so vitally important that this legislation be properly debated and properly scrutinised.

What the Government has got in this legislation is, in fact, its version of a Clayton's GST. It sees this legislation, this package, as being the answer to the need for a GST. We totally reject that. But what we will not abide is the passage through this chamber and through this Parliament of legislation which is obviously a botched job. This legislation, whilst in some areas it will improve the existing sales tax regime, in other areas will simply add to the complexity and the confusion of the sales tax system.

The fact that this legislation produces a set of six sales tax Acts to replace the existing 27 or so Acts does not in itself constitute simplification of the system. The wholesale sales tax system is complex because of its inherent nature. It is complex, confusing and inequitable because it has multi-rates. This legislation does not at all attempt to address that. There are five rates in the existing wholesale sales tax regime. After the simplification process, there will still be five rates. The other complexity with the wholesale sales tax is that there is a whole series of exemptions. Because there are exemptions in the system, there are problems of classifying items as to what rate they are going to be subjected to.

This legislation does not tackle, and it does not even try to tackle, that fundamental problem of exemptions and classifications. So, far from having a simplified system, we have nothing of the sort. We now have a half-baked, emasculated system. In many ways, it is more complex and more confusing than the system that it is designed to replace. Amendments have been circulating since the Senate resumed in Budget week. I am not sure whether they have been formally circulated in this chamber, but there are some copies floating around; I did not get a copy of them from this chamber. Perhaps Senator McMullan might enlighten us to whether they have been formally circulated in this chamber.

talk.start.para: —As far as I know, they have.
—Where are they?
—They have certainly been circulated to senators. I will check whether they have been circulated in here.

—Let us wait and see what happens. If these amendments have not been circulated formally in the chamber, it compounds the felony of which I have been speaking. The idea that this Government can jackboot the proper parliamentary processes is absolutely incredible. It did it in the House of Representatives, and it tried to do it in the Senate. We at least stopped the Government part way and forced it to have a select committee, over its dead body. Now the Government is trying to outsit the Senate by getting it to sit ridiculous hours, absolutely killer hours of the night and early morning, to pass this legislation, and Senator McMullan, as the person responsible for the Bill, does not even know whether amendments to it have been circulated. Talk about gross incompetence!

para.tab: Senator McMullan gets up and rails at the coalition, in terms of trying to get order and decency in the Senate, yet his ability, and the Government's ability, to manage business in the Parliament is just lamentable. That is the reason why the coalition is moving this amendment to refer the Bills and the amendments, if they are available, back to the Senate Select Committee, which was given the job, by the Senate, to do a proper scrutiny and examination of the legislation that this Senate is supposed to pass.

That Select Committee was not able to do its work, because the amendments were not available. I believe, and the coalition is of the strongest view, that it is absolutely incumbent upon the Government, in the interests of proper parliamentary process, that the Senate be given the proper opportunity to properly scrutinise this raft of major amendments that have been circulated, or of which circulation has been foreshadowed. I do not know whether they are formal amendments, but certainly some of the ones I have seen bear no resemblance to what the Select Committee was told they would look like. For example, the Select Committee was told that the general anti-avoidance provisions were to be significantly redrafted. I do not think that that was one of the six areas where the Government, including the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), said there would be amendments.

But in the debate in the Select Committee, there was a considerable amount of discussion about the notorious clause 92(2) of the Bill, which relates to avoidance schemes. For the benefit of the Senate I might just remind them of what clause 92(2) said. It states:
For the purpose of cancelling a tax benefit, the Commissioner may, in the assessment, determine all or any of the following:
(a)that particular things are to be treated as not having happened;
(b)that particular things are to be treated as having been done by a different person or to have happened at a different time;
(c)that particular things that did not actually happen are to be treated as having happened and, where appropriate:
(i)to have been done by a particular person; or

tab.tab: (ii) to have happened at a particular time.

speech.para: That is absolutely Orwellian language. If my memory serves me correctly, we were told by the Tax Office during the Senate Select Committee hearings—because it was raised so strongly by the coalition members and by numerous witnesses—that that would be changed. That was my understanding. Now in the amendments that I have before me all this has been changed, so we are told. What do I find when I come and read the new section? What has happened is that clause 92(2) has become clause 93A. Clause 93A(2) says:

para.tab: "(2) The Commissioner may, in the assessment, do all or any of the following:
(a)determine, for the purpose of cancelling the tax benefit, that particular things are to be treated as not having happened;
(b)determine, for the purpose of cancelling the tax benefit, that particular things are to be treated as having been done by a different person or to have happened at a different time;
(c)determine, for the purpose of cancelling the tax benefit, that particular things that did not actually happen are to be treated as having happened and, where appropriate:

tab.tab: (i)to have been done by a particular person; or
(ii)to have happened at a particular time.

speech.para: With the exception of the insertion of the words `for the purpose of cancelling the tax benefit', which was always obvious in the first draft, that section is no different from the previous section 92(2). Yet we were told in the Select Committee, if my recall is accurate, that that would be changed.

para.tab: The whole problem with the Select Committee was that we had to take the Tax Office and the Government on trust because we did not have the words in front of us. Now we have the words in front of us and they do not always coincide with what the Government and the Tax Office said was going to be the content of the amendments. That is just one example—it is one of the more drastic ones. But in the absence of putting all this back to a committee for proper examination, we are never going to verify the undertakings and the changes announced by the Treasurer in his press statement on 11 August—and that skinny three-page paper was the only bit of paper on which the Select Committee was able to base its discussion in the two days of very detailed hearings.

So we do not, on this side, move this amendment lightly. We move this amendment because it is of the greatest importance to the taxpayers of Australia, who have been battered by this Government in the area of taxation at all levels in the—heaven forbid—10 years that this Government has been in office, in which time there have been 104 new taxes or increased variations to existing taxes. That is, in effect, 104 new taxes in the past 9 1/2 years.

The wholesale sales tax is a very important part of the tax system. We demand that this Parliament not be overridden by executive fiat, which is what the Government is proposing to do. We demand that this Parliament be allowed to do what the parliaments in any free, democratic society are supposed to do—to do its job in looking at the proposals of the Executive in a thorough way so that the interests of the people of Australia can be fully protected. Unless this amendment is agreed to, that simply will not be able to happen.

The coalition has very deliberately put a tight reporting time in the amendment. We are asking that the Committee do its work and report back to the Parliament on 6 October, which is the first day of the next sitting week. So any suggestion that the coalition is trying to stretch this matter out is totally unfounded, as evidenced by that very tight timetable we are imposing. It is essential that this matter be given full consideration. As I said at an earlier stage, what we are talking about now is the Government's proposal to amend its unworkable, archaic, inefficient indirect tax system in a futile and blatant political attempt to have a satisfactory alternative to the goods and services tax.

I think that the people of Australia, particularly those who have suffered at such cost through the inequities of the existing wholesale sales tax regime, will see through that. There is no doubt at all that, in the interests of the people of Australia, all of this ought to be done on an eyes open basis. That can only be done if the amendment which Senator Baume moved on behalf of the Opposition and which I am now supporting is carried.

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I do not want to interrupt but I do want to provide a bit of information. The amendment to which Senator Short referred was circulated in the chamber four weeks ago, on 19 and 20 August.

—Given the lateness of the hour, I will indeed be brief. I rise to support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Michael Baume to refer the sales tax legislation back to the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation which examined the legislation in the first place. The changes announced by the Government have been so far-reaching as to fundamentally change the character of the legislation. Furthermore, undertakings given at that Senate Select Committee have not been fully honoured in the amendments we have before us. Indeed, Senator Short was quite right in expecting further amendments in order that those commitments be fully honoured. So he was quite right in raising the question: where are all the amendments?

para.tab: It is true that certain areas are addressed by this legislation. We thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) for that. In terms of the issues that have been put to the Parliamentary Secretary and the Australian Taxation Office and subsequently by people who have been disadvantaged, these amendments do not go nearly far enough to satisfy the problems outlined at the Senate Select Committee. We believe that, if the Government gave an undertaking, by virtue of the tax simplification legislation, to bring about a certain outcome and then changed its mind, that undertaking should be honoured in some way.

I refer to the situation whereby the two Australian oil companies—the small ones, Ampol and Caltex—have a greater exposure to sales tax as a result of the backtracking by the Government than they would have under the original simplification proposals. We were expecting a government amendment and, given that that is not forthcoming, I think we are entitled to a full and appropriate explanation. There are other areas—there are concerns about X(3) arrangements and perhaps 20 others—which I will not enumerate at the present time, but I will ask for further evaluation and reasons if we proceed to the committee stage. The preferable route would be to have the tax officers, together with witnesses who could be disadvantaged as a result of this legislation, before us in the forum of a select committee to ensure the passage of appropriate and correct legislation. A lot of time has been spent on this. I believe a few more weeks are needed to get it into a better form. I therefore support the mechanism that has been proposed and I will vote accordingly.

talk.start.para: —In case anybody was listening to some parts of the debate and did not pick it up, the Senate is actually debating a package of measures to do with wholesale sales tax. So far as Senator Short's and Senator Watson's last comments were concerned, they at least referred to the Bill, which is more than can be said for some.

para.tab: I want to say in opening—and particularly because of some entirely unjustified criticism that has been directed, but it is something I would have said anyway—that I would like to thank the officers who have been involved with the development of this package of legislation. I think it is a very important package, a very well-developed and coherent package, that will do a very important job for the people of Australia. Everybody knows and senators know that the industry is trying to persuade senators opposite to stop these political stunts and pass it, because the industry knows that it is a substantial improvement in the operation of the wholesale sales tax.

talk.start.para: —Tell me one person who does.

—There are a whole lot of people who have been saying that and senators know it and the media knows it. They have been reporting it about senators opposite for some time. First of all, I will deal with some formal matters that I need to put on the record in the conclusion of this second reading debate. Included with those amendments that were circulated some weeks ago was a speech by me which outlined them. That was distributed for the information of senators. It related to the amendments distributed on 19 August.

para.tab: Two further amendments were distributed on 20 August. The first was to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill. The replacement amendments to this Bill will make one change to the original proposed amendment. The proposed business inputs exemption for a person who supplies material to be made up into goods will be extended. The exemption will now be allowed if the made-up goods are for wholesale sale and/or indirect marketing sale by the supplier. The original amendments did not allow the exemption if the goods were for indirect marketing sale.

The second amendment is to the Sales Tax Amendment (Transitional) Bill. This amendment will insert a new credit ground—CR5A—to allow people a credit if they apply tax paid goods to their own use in circumstances that satisfy one of the three proposed new exemption items dealing with exempt end users. These exemption items will allow for exemption for goods that are donated to always-exempt bodies, incorporated into other goods that are for use by a person in exempt circumstances, or incorporated into property owned by or leased to an always-exempt body.

The other thing that I wish formally to refer to in the summing up, before I deal with some of the things that were said in the second reading, relates to the general anti-avoidance provisions. The Government has been asked to clarify whether the general anti-avoidance provision will apply to ordinary commercial arrangements. The answer is that it will not. However, as these words are inexact in legal terms, and their scope is uncertain, the new provision—like its counterpart in the income tax law—is designed to apply where, on an objective view of the particular arrangement and its surrounding circumstances, it would be concluded that the arrangement was entered into for the sole or dominant purpose of obtaining a tax benefit.

There have been a number of statements made in the course of this debate that are just clearly wrong. Senator Crowley dealt with a large number of them and, given the hour, I will not repeat them. Several honourable senators have described the new legislation as a revenue grab, and someone even said that the new legislation will result in a revenue gain of $91m. That seems, to me, a case of `think of a figure and double it', because this is quite clearly incorrect.

Although the new legislation is estimated to raise an additional $28m in a full year, that amount is mainly attributable to one measure, designed to stamp out tax evasion. This anti-evasion measure, originally announced by the Fraser Government but not implemented by it, will impose a liability on taxpayers who falsely claim exemption. As this measure is to raise an additional $52m in a full year, the real impact of the remainder of the new measures is a cost to the Government of $24m. We have also had the old furphy about half a million more taxpayers, when everybody knows that that is not the case.

We have had concern expressed about the number of amendments required to be made to these Bills. It is always the case that every tax Bill needs constant review. For example, the New Zealand GST legislation has been amended: there have been 22 separate Bills in the New Zealand Parliament to amend the New Zealand GST since it was introduced. If honourable senators would like a list of them, I am happy to make that available. There has never been a tax Bill that has not required amendment: that certainly has never been the case with a GST anywhere, including the Opposition's favourite model, New Zealand.

We have had people asserting that all sorts of wonderful things are taxable under the wholesale sales tax. Senator Knowles, under the things which she asserted apart from those which Senator Crowley dealt with, wanted to say that stethoscopes, for example, were taxable—when quite clearly they are exempt now, and that exemption will continue in the new law. Senator Knowles wanted to claim that hot water tanks would become taxable under the new law—when, in fact, there is no change to their taxable situation. Senator Brownhill was a bit concerned that Senator Crowley alleged that he had said that wholesale sales tax applied to baby nappies and funeral caskets—

talk.start.para: —He reckons he did not say it.

—Senator Brownhill actually said it on page 657 of the
Hansard
of 9 September 1992, so his memory is failing him. Maybe someone else wrote the speech and he just read it and forgot that he had said it. So there are a large number of assertions. I do not want to go through all of them. I just used those as a few examples to show that people throw around assertions with a little more enthusiasm than the analysis would justify. Those things are very clear.

para.tab: We do get, however, all this passion about the fact—and it is reflected, for example, in the minority report signed by Senators Short and Vanstone, and that came out in the speeches of a number of people—that there are problems in the wholesale sales tax, because it requires classification; because there are different rates and some things are exempt. Of course, that is true. Every tax that has any differentiation has, within it, problems of boundaries, definitions and classifications.

That fact is true about the wholesale sales tax, as it is true about the goods and services tax. The Opposition does not seem to realise that it actually has three classifications: zero, exempt and taxable. As Price Waterhouse said in its Fightback analysis document, `The quagmire is dead; long live the quagmire!'. It is talking about the fact that these distortions will not go away with the passing of the wholesale sales tax.

The coalition's GST proposal is far from a distortion free tax, nor will it be without its quota of administrative complications and definitional issues. These issues are just as much a source of complexity, dispute and litigation as any other form of taxation. Since the introduction of the GST in New Zealand five years ago, there have been more than 100 GST cases before the courts. This is as many as there have been Australian wholesale sales tax cases in its 60-year history. This is this wonderful, clear, simple, straightforward, uncomplicated piece of legislation that is a lawyer's and an accountant's bonanza. No wonder lawyers and accountants support it—just as honourable senators opposite all support it because the biggest compensation in the income tax flows to people on just about a back bench salary. That is where the highest percentage increase in after tax earnings falls; it falls on people on $75,000 a year. No wonder the proposal got applause in the Opposition party room. All sorts of complications result from it.

I will not at this time start to go through what Price Waterhouse links to this wonderful proposal—all the complications, all the problems with the definitions and grey areas and all the complexities, boundaries and classification issues that are going to arise. They arise under every tax proposal because every tax has to have definitions, boundaries and classifications; they become the subject of dispute, litigation, and accountants' and lawyers' fees proliferate.

Price Waterhouse went on to say—it is on page 8 of the document—that there are great problems of definition, that there will be a measure of complexity and that dispute will be unavoidable. Of course, it pursues the question of health that honourable senators opposite have been ducking and diving to avoid recently. Those prescription based drugs and medicines that are on the PBS are going to be zero rated. But what about the other three schedules? Where are they all going to fit? They are in what Price Waterhouse calls the `grey zone'. When does a service provided by a hospital cease to be a health care service? At what stage does a service or other facility supplied by a school cease to be an educational service? If goods supplied by State governments, authorities and enterprises are sheltered from the GST under the Constitution—which it is arguable they might be—will this lead to significant distortions of competition? What, for example, will be the treatment of financial services that are supplied incidental to another business? If they are to be exempt, then how will the import tax portion be calculated? If they are to be taxed, how will competitive distortion be avoided? At what point does an exempt financial service become a secondary financial service? There will also be problems with timing rules and the issues of definition that arise particularly for the construction industry, which has been making its concerns very explicit, as has the tourist industry.

These are some of the reasons why the Opposition has had those 300 submissions to the Cole committee that it will not release. There have been three reports from the Cole committee which express how the Opposition should go about doing this in a different way and which the Opposition will not release because it does not want anybody to know what its own hired experts think is wrong with the proposal. The Opposition is just trying to hang on in the hope that these concerns and problems will not come out before the election. I have to say that I think that is a wish that will not be fulfilled. Ernst and Young and Price Waterhouse have expressed concerns about the impact of the Opposition proposals on the tourist industry. As I have said, they are concerns expressed by the construction industry.

But for all those economic and administrative problems with the goods and services tax, the fundamental problem is that it is just unfair. People just have to look at what is cheaper, compared with what gets more expensive. It becomes readily apparent what the priorities are and who wins and who loses. People should have a look at what is cheaper. Luxury cars, jewellery and fur coats are cheaper. Food, clothing and electricity are more expensive.

Look at what the coalition has chosen to zero rate, compared with what it has chosen to make taxable. Overseas holidays are zero rated, private school fees are zero rated, private health fund contributions are zero rated, but what about food, clothing and electricity? They are taxable. This is a wonderful statement of its priorities for which we are duly grateful. And then, to compensate for this unfair tax, we have an unfair tax compensation package where those on $75,000 get an increase in after tax income of 14.7 per cent and those on average weekly earnings get only 7 per cent. So we get double—

talk.start.para: —Did you criticise Opposition senators for not addressing the Bill?
—I am just enjoying the opportunity to discuss the GST. I thank the Opposition for raising it; it is very kind of it. Even at this late hour it is great fun to have the opportunity to debate that.

para.tab: There have been a whole lot of misleading things said about the wholesale sales tax. I want to respond to something that Senator Michael Baume said. I interjected on him to indicate that his facts were wrong, so I should back that up. That was not a source of contention between him and me at that point but I want to put the facts on the record. I am advised that theatrical props made for own use by theatre companies—he was referring to the Australian Ballet—are not now taxable and it has never been proposed that they would be. There was a misunderstanding by some advisers who thought that was the case. There was a decision, the Nimrod decision, back in the early 1980s. Senator Baume referred to the attempt by the Government to tax those things. I am almost certain that the proposal to impose wholesale sales tax on the theatre props produced by Nimrod commenced before the election of this Government. I am almost certain that was a Fraser Government initiative before 1983. But I do want to clarify the fact that those arts matters about which he raised concern are in fact not a legitimate ground of concern; the problem does not arise.

There will be plenty of opportunities to have exciting debates about the relative merits of the wholesale sales tax and the goods and services tax. People have been going on at length about how prices will only go up by 4 per cent, before we look at the road user charges, which is another issue. They keep pretending that food will not go up by 8.8 per cent or fresh fruit and vegetables by 10 or clothing by 11. These are the things that people have to buy every day and they are going to get more expensive every time. That is why it is so unfair, that is why people are so concerned about it. That is why we are proposing to simplify the wholesale sales tax system, as this proposal quite self-evidently does. We aim to streamline its administration, to improve its operation to make it more certain, and to reduce the administrative cost to government and the compliance cost to business. These things will be achieved by the amendments.

We clearly are not going to agree to the second reading amendment moved by Senator Baume. That is quite clearly just another delaying tactic. This has already been to the Committee, and the Senate has a capacity to deal with amendments which were circulated four weeks ago. It is called the committee stage and that is what we should be doing as soon as possible. I will indicate the amendments with which we will be agreeing during the committee stage; it is a waste of time to do so now.

I want to conclude by reiterating three things. Firstly, I thank the officers of the Tax Office and the Treasury who have over the last two years put an enormous amount of work into this package of legislation, which is a very important package and a very significant improvement in our tax system. Even if one would prefer a GST, an honest assessment must lead to the conclusion that this is a substantial improvement, even if not that which one would prefer.

Secondly, I want to say that this package of legislation needs to be passed by this Senate and needs to be passed quickly, which is why we are sitting at this obnoxious hour. Many people have chosen to make long and repetitive speeches. I think it was called tedious repetition slightly earlier in the day and we have certainly had our quota of that this evening. But it is an important package of legislation which the Parliament should get on and pass as soon as possible.

Thirdly, it is very important that this Parliament takes the opportunity from time to time to say that the wholesale sales tax has superiority over the goods and services tax, that it has the capacity to distinguish between necessities and luxuries, that it has the capacity to distinguish between environmentally beneficial and environmentally damaging products, and that it has the capacity to, and does, distinguish between necessities and luxuries, and it is therefore inherently fairer and more in the long term interests of this nation. That is why we are seeking to improve it rather than to throw it out and introduce a new and unfair tax. Therefore, I urge—

talk.start.para: —Did you thank the Office of Parliamentary Counsel for its work on this legislation?

—I am reminded by the Minister for Justice that, although I thanked the Australian Taxation Office and the Treasury, I did not thank the Office of Parliamentary Counsel for the diligent work performed by its officers. I certainly do that. Let me say that I do that at Senator Tate's prompting, just in case the officers are not aware of how diligently he pursues their interest here in the Senate. I thank the Minister for that and I thank those honourable senators who contributed to this debate. That may not include everybody who spoke in it, but I thank them anyway. After this second reading debate, I cannot urge `the speedy passage of the Bill' but I urge the passage of it, anyway.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Administrative Services upon notice, on 1 July 1992: With reference to a proposal for a Commonwealth office block in Newcastle, as discussed by Senator Tierney in his speech on the adjournment of 25 June 1992 and correspondence from the Minister to Senator Tierney of 13 April 1992 on this issue:

para.tab: (1) Can the Minister explain the contradictions between his correspondence with Senator Tierney, and a letter sent to Senator Tierney from the Minister for Social Security dated 10 April 1992, a copy of which was sent to him by the Minister for Social Security.
(2) At what stage in the Department's approval process is the proposal for a Commonwealth office block.
(3) If the Department has rejected the proposal, will it explain specifically why.

(4) Given that individual Commonwealth departments have enough autonomy to decide where they are going to be located, how were the tenancy commitments obtained from the relevant departments before construction was commenced on the Commonwealth office block in Parramatta.

talk.start.para: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1) The comments made by the Minister for Social Security in his letter to Senator Tierney of 10 April 1992, related to the fact that at that time, there was insufficient pre-commitment from prospective Commonwealth tenants to occupy a new Commonwealth Government Centre development.
(2) Australian Estate Management is currently considering the feasibility of constructing an office in Newcastle.
(3) The proposal has not been rejected.

(4) The Jessie Street Centre in Parramatta was commenced prior to the introduction of commercialisation in July 1989. Commitment from prospective tenants was therefore sought in a different environment. At that time my Department's role of regulator limited the freedom of departments to seek alternatives to our office developments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Territories, upon notice, on 4 August 1992:

para.tab: With reference to information provided to the Minister during the Senate 1992 Autumn sittings regarding an auction in London of the Campbell collection, which included the handwritten diaries of the pioneer Australian Antarctic explorer, Stuart Alexander Caird Campbell who was a member of Sir Douglas Mawson's 1930-31 expedition:
(1) Was the Australian Government, or its agents, represented at the auction.

(2) Does the Government provide funds to actively encourage library and museum organisations to bid for Australian memorabilia at overseas and local auctions to ensure the preservation in Australia of items of historical significance.
(3) What steps are being taken to ensure items of important historical association do not receive export permits.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Arts and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (2) The Government provides funding to Commonwealth collecting institutions and it is the prerogative of each institution to acquire items for its collection as it deems appropriate.
(3) The Government administers a cultural heritage import and export control scheme under the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986 and Regulations.

In the case of the auction of the Campbell collection, officers of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories contacted major Commonwealth and State collecting institutions in the field of books and documents to ensure they were aware of the impending sale. One institution had instructed its agent in London to bid for the material.
I have been advised that the Campbell collection was withdrawn from sale at the last minute and it is not known at this stage whether it will be placed on the market again.

answer.to.qon.title: Department of Social Security: Tuggeranong Offices

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 August 1992:

para.tab: (1) On what date did the department move from Civic to Tuggeranong.
(2) Did the department acquire new furniture for the Tuggeranong offices and at what cost was the new furniture purchased.
(3) What furniture from the Civic offices was transferred to Tuggeranong.
(4) Was any furniture from the Civic offices deemed to be unsuitable for Tuggeranong; if so, on what basis.
(5) Has any surplus furniture from the old Civic offices been sold; if so, what has been the amount obtained by the department for the sale.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) The Department of Social Security did not move from Civic to Tuggeranong. It relocated its National Administration (formerly Central Office) from thirteen separate locations in the Woden and Phillip areas to Tuggeranong. Units moved to Tuggeranong as buildings became available. The first of the relocations was on 26 April 1991. The last was completed on 14 October 1991.

(2) To enable the evaluation of work stations for the open plan areas of the new office accommodation, furniture to the value of $680,000 was purchased directly by the Department. This furniture will remain in use in the complex. Some new furniture was provided as part of the fitout under the contractual arrangements with Tuggeranong Office Park Pty Ltd and the contractors Civil and Civic.
(3) Approximately 1100 sets of office furniture consisting of desks, chairs, bookcases and storage cupboards were transferred from the thirteen previous locations.
(4) During the relocation process some furniture was deemed to be unsuitable and surplus to requirements. Most of it was due for replacement having outlived its useful life.

(5) The Department did sell some of its surplus furniture on relocation to its new offices. This furniture included mainly desks, clerical chairs, screens, bookcases, filing cabinets, some electrical appliances and carpet. A total of $56,000 was realised from the sale of these items.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 19 August 1992:

para.tab: (1) Has the Government considered establishing a Ministerial Memorandum of Understanding between the Commonwealth and the States as a means of ensuring a greater commitment to the implementation of the National Program of Action in accordance with meeting the goals of the World Declaration of the Survival, Protection and Development of Children.

(2) Has the Government considered expanding the membership of the Interdepartmental Committee currently working on the National Program of Action to include representatives of the Department of Defence.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) The Government is currently considering a range of options to implement the World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children. This may include some form of commitment by the Commonwealth and the States to work together towards meeting the goals and implementing the strategies in Australia's National Program of Action.

(2) One of the areas to be addressed in the National Program of Action is that of children in especially difficult circumstances including the protection of children during armed conflicts and where countries are in situations of internal turmoil. These have not been issues for Australia, and hopefully this will remain the case. I did not consider the inclusion of the Department of Defence to be warranted as the principal focus of the National Program of Action is on domestic issues affecting children.
The Interdepartmental Committee is widely representative and its composition not designed to exclude any interest.
The Department of Defence would be a welcome addition if it felt the issues to be addressed to be of sufficient relevance.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 20 August 1992:

para.tab: (1) In which years were the Japan-Australia Migratory Birds Agreement and the China-Australia Migratory Birds Agreement signed by the Australian Government.
(2) Which areas of land or sea are covered by these agreements.
(3) Will the proposed expansion of the Port of Brisbane affect any areas covered by these agreements.
(4) Which Government or authority has jurisdiction over the seabed areas that will be affected [on] by the expansion of the Port of Brisbane.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) The Agreement Between the Government of Australia and the Government of Japan for the Protection of Migratory Birds and Birds in Danger of Extinction and their Environment was signed on 6 February 1974. The Agreement Between the Government of Australia and the Government of the People's Republic of China for the Protection of Migratory Birds and their Environment was signed on 20 October 1986.

(2) Although not explicit in their texts, both Agreements apply throughout the Commonwealth of Australia, its Territories and territorial waters and are implemented through a variety of Commonwealth, State and Territory legislation. Both Migratory Birds Agreements call upon each Contracting Party to take appropriate measures to preserve and enhance the environment of migratory birds. The areas of land or sea covered by the Agreements could therefore be considered to be all those areas of land and sea which provide important breeding, feeding and roosting habitat for those species which are included in the annexes to the Agreements.

(3) The Port of Brisbane and the proposed area for its expansion lie within Moreton Bay. The draft Moreton Bay Strategic Plan, which shows the proposed expansion of the Port of Brisbane, was developed by the Queensland Government in consultation with the public. Some sites within Moreton Bay provide valuable habitat for species included in the annexes of the two Migratory Birds Agreements, and hence could be considered to be "areas covered by these agreements".

(4) The waters of Moreton Bay are State waters and therefore the Government of the State of Queensland has jurisdiction over the seabed areas that will be affected by the proposed expansion of the Port of Brisbane.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In addition, the Department was awaiting the release of the ABS publication "Child Care, Australia (November 1990)" for information on child care usage in the formal and informal sectors.
The publication was expected to be released in late 1991, and was finally released in August 1992.
(2) January 1992. The Department may recommence work on the brief now the "Child Care, Australia" publication has been released, if other Departmental priorities allow.
(3) No. To date only preliminary internal working papers have been prepared.
The Department is therefore unable to provide any completed documents.
